column5: On Selecting Physical Science Texts at the State Level
column15: John L Hubisz, North Carolina State Univ.
column18: Certain states pretty well determine what textbooks will be used across the country. Other states use those selections as a starting point for their own adoptions. What advice can you give to folks on the selection committee? After many years of considering the problem of bad selections, I offer some suggestions that you might pass on to your local school boards.

column5: Extreme Teaching: The Universal Lessons from Physics Education in Africa
column15: Maria Niland, National Science Foundation
column18: Consider the major issues confronting physics education in the United States. There is a warranted discussion on how the failure to meet these challenges will affect both economic growth and national security. Intensify the very same problems and ramifications by at least one order of magnitude. The results depict the current state of physics education in African countries. Though by no means preferable, the urgency of conditions in Africa has offered a unique opportunity. By partnering with their African colleagues, Americans teachers are forced to do more than merely discuss the common problems but to focus on finding solutions. From the experience new insights are emerging on shared concerns such as the shortage of qualified teachers, professional development, insufficient resources, the role of technology, gender disparities, language barriers, high-stakes testing, and ill-prepared students.

column5: Exploring Alternative Medicine with Introductory Physics
column15: Nancy Beverly, Mercy College
column18: The scientific literature of alternative medicine therapies often proposes mechanisms which have an electromagnetic or other accessible physics basis, suitable as interesting examples for introductory physics students, especially life/health science majors. Several examples will be presented.

column5: Using Atmospheric Muons To Test Relativity in the Introductory Lab
column15: Thomas Moore, Pomona College
column18: At Pomona College, we spend three weeks of our fall-semester introductory course exploring special relativity in the classroom. For many years we have wanted a laboratory exercise to complement this portion of our course. Last summer, we developed a three-week introductory laboratory that uses the readily-available TeachSpin muon decay apparatus to perform a test of special relativity, and we ran the laboratory with introductory students this fall. In this talk, I will describe how I and my collaborators adapted this upper-level experiment for the introductory lab, the challenges and pitfalls we encountered in getting the experiment to work, and the interesting physics behind our version of the experiment. I will also assess the success of this laboratory exercise for our students.

column5: Birefringence of the Cornea and the Individual Perception of Haidinger's Brushes*
column15: Mark D Rothmayer, Xavier Univ.
column18: Haidinger's brushes are an entoptic phenomenon of the human visual system, which enables us to detect polarized light. The mineralogist Wilhelm Haidinger (1844) discovered the effect, and Helmoltz (1866) related the perception of the brushes to the concentric alignment of the dichroic pigment around the fovea. However, the individual perception of Haidinger's brushes can vary significantly, and many subjects report they can not perceive them at all. So far no explanation for these differences exists. We suggest that the birefringence of the cornea influences the formation of Haidinger's brushes and may offer an explanation for individual differences. We devised an experimental setup to simulate the various phase shifts and orientations of the cornea and recorded the forming brush pattern. We also modeled the transmission of light through this system on the Poincare sphere, and were able to quantify the influence of the cornea on the pattern of Haidinger's brushes.

column5: The Physics of Athletic Movement: An Analysis of Vaulting Events
column15: Kim Murley, Denison Univ.
column18: The application of physics to athletic events can be useful in identifying flaws in technique, revealing sources of injuries, and discovering beneficial modifications to equipment. The aim of this study is to understand the physics involved in two vaulting events, specifically the pole vault in track and field and the vault in gymnastics. In both events, the takeoff is a critical aspect of the full vault; therefore, it is extremely difficult during the later phases of the vault to compensate for errors made during takeoff. For this study, the VideoPoint software package was used to track the center of mass positions as a function of time. The effects of initial speed, takeoff angle, takeoff speed, and percentage of speed (at takeoff) converted from horizontal to vertical on the "push height index" of each vaulter were investigated. We also investigated the energies of the vaulters; these quantities follow expected patterns.

column5: Constructing Your Own Formative Assessments
column15: Pamela Duncan, Barrington H.S.
column18: In this session, we will be looking at three formative assessments: the background knowledge probe, defining features matrix, and the minute paper. Attributes of these three assessments will be discussed and examples of how these assessments can be implemented in the classroom. We will also be examining the importance of these various strategies and how they guide assessment. We will discuss how classroom assessment tools such as CPS can be used in conjunction with these formative assessments. But this technology is not necessary to use these formative assessments. Upon completion of this workshop, you will have all the tools to begin using these formative assessments in your classroom.

column5: Venus and How Research Evolves After the Big Mission
column15: Robert R Herrick
column18: Magellan concluded operations in 1994, and was the last spacecraft mission to study the geology of Venus. Magellan's radar imagery revealed about 900 impact craters distributed randomly about the globe, and most of those craters appeared to have been unaltered since formation. Scientists use the distribution and post-impact geologic modification of craters to reconstruct a planet's global history. The initial interpretation of the craters suggested to most researchers that the planet was geologically active and then rapidly shut down. Wild hypotheses were developed to explain this highly unusual planetary behavior. Later, more detailed investigations have shown that most of the craters have been modified by later geologic processes, and much of the world view that was collectively held during the mission is proving to be in error. Such post-mission research occurs out of the spotlight and can take a long time to be known by the general population.

column5: University of Washington's GK-12 Project: Developing Elementary School Mathematical Understanding
column15: Kim Gunnerson, Univ. of Washington
column18: The NSF GK-12 project at the University of Washington works with schools in the Seattle School District to place graduate fellows in elementary classrooms to aid the teaching of inquiry based mathematics. The curriculum supported by the fellows is Terc "Investigations in Number, Data, and Space." The objective of the project has two main focuses: first, to help promote stronger mathematical understanding of elementary school teachers to help them be more effective in teaching mathematics, and, second, the graduate fellows develop their own understanding of how mathematics are taught and understood in elementary schools. We have seen some exciting growth in the teachers and schools we have worked with and will share the challenges and successes we have experienced.

column5: Physics Education in Asia: The New Delhi and Hangzhou Conferences
column15: E. L. Jossem, OhIo State Univ.
column18: The International Conferences on Phyisics Education held in New Delhi, India, and Hangzhou, China, last August and September provided a window on physics education in the world's two most populous countries. An account of the conferences and of the contexts in which they were held will be provided along with some comparisons of physics education in the two countries and that in the U.S.

column5: Squiggle Ball Capture: A Novel Visual Thermodynamics Experiment
column15: Tim Gfroerer, Davidson College
column17: Ken Rathbun, Kiril Simov, Blair Reynolds
column18: The capture of particles by low-energy traps is an important physical phenomenon that can be understood in the framework of statistical mechanics. For example, when electrons or holes are trapped by localized deep states in semiconductors, device performance can be significantly impaired. The capture mechanism depends on the average thermal velocity of the particles and the cross-section and distribution of the participating traps. We have designed a macroscopic system for exploring this process. Squiggle Balls, which use a battery-powered motor and asymmetric rotor to roll and tumble "randomly," move on a bounded, elevated platform with several circular holes. We measure the average "capture time" as a function of hole size and density, and examine our results in the context of a simple probabilistic model. We also tilt the platform to simulate an applied field, and analyze the results using Boltzmann statistics.

column5: Five Inexpensive Ways to Involve More Women in Undergraduate Physics
column15: Hillary Smith, Bryn Mawr College
column18: Everyone knows that not enough women study physics. Low representation of women in undergraduate physics begins a trend of decreasing participation that continues through graduate school into university faculty. There are plenty of expensive ways to study the problem and there are equal numbers of expensive solutions to reverse the trend. But there is only so much money to go around at any university. This talk proposes five ways to involve more women in undergraduate physics without breaking your budget. Each tactic focuses on taking advantage of existing resources to create an environment conducive to the recruitment and retention of women.

column5: The Enjoyment and Relevance of Old Science Textbooks: Three Case Studies
column15: William (Bill) Palmer, Charles Darwin Univ.
column18: Over the past few years I have centred my science education research around the collection and study of old science textbooks. This paper will bring out some aspects of this work that I believe to be relevant to today's science education by looking at the lives and writing of three men, who worked in different centuries, who influenced science education in different ways and who are largely forgotten today.

column5: Discussion of Documentary Video
column15: Kenneth Cecire, Hampton University
column18: After the documentary video, this time will be used for questions, answers, and discussion. Attendees will be asked to comment on the video in terms of its effectiveness and message; they will also be asked to discuss how it might be used in the classroom or in professional development here in the United States. The speaker will act as a discussion facilitator along with the filmmaker and at least one other member of the COSM-Zambia team.

column5: Characteristic Misrepresentations in Physics Education: Their Danger and Origin
column15: Courtney Willis, Univ. of Northern Colorado
column17: Alexander Kazachkov, John C Moore, Alexander G Anders
column18: Origins of some characteristic misrepresentations of the basic physical phenomena in textbooks and class practice are analyzed. They range from seemingly minor mistakes in the presenters' body language to gross overstretching of the limits of the explanatory models. Most regretfully, educational misrepresentations undermine the whole picture of physical world which students are supposed to acquire in the process of learning. What is especially dangerous is the fact the majority of "subconsciously" misinstructed students will have no second chance to get their knowledge improved through more fortunate teaching or self-education since they will be taking physics only once. Ways to correct or evade the reviewed misrepresentations will be proposed.

column5: Deciphering the Sky's Icy Halos
column15: Robert Greenler, Univ. of Wisconsin-Milwaukee
column18: For centuries many beautiful sky displays were either known or strongly suspected to be the result of sunlight interacting with tiny ice crystals in the atmosphere. In the 1960s we used the new computer technology to predict the appearance of sky effects that would be caused by sunlight incident on a large group of ice crystals of a particular shape and with a particular set of orientations. This approach, with its subsequent improvements, has led to the understanding of the mechanisms responsible for the majority of well-documented ice-crystal halos. The illustration of this method will be accomplished using a comparison of computer simulations with photographs of Nature's own displays.

column5: Research-Based Strategies in Upper-Division Undergraduate Physics Classes
column15: N. Sanjay Rebello, Kansas State Univ.
column18: The use of research-based interactive engagement techniques in upper-division physics classes is relatively rare. We report here on reform and action research within the context of two upper-division undergraduate physics courses at Kansas State University. A course in electronic instrumentation and another in solid state physics were modified to incorporate and adapt strategies that facilitated active learning by students. We describe the modifications to these courses and the effectiveness of these strategies in promoting student learning. We will also present the reactions of students to the modified pedagogy of these courses, our own reflections as well as lessons learned.

column5: Alaska: A Natural Laboratory To Learn Physics and Geophysics
column15: Anupma Prakash
column18: Learning physics and geophysics is learning about ourselves and about the physical world we live in. Memorizing facts and formulas and crunching numbers does not make one a physicist. Learning physics involves refining our everyday thinking, and seeking answers to why and how about the world we live in. Alaska, the vast northern most state of U.S., is strategically located and is an ideal place to see some of the wonders of nature and learn about the underlying physical and geophysical processes shaping these wonders. The fascinating northern lights, the nations highest mountain peak, the volcanic chain, the glacial movements, the polar caps, all convey physical/geophysical concepts is a fascinating and unique way. This talk will take you through a virtual tour of the State of Alaska along with a discussion on how the state serves as a natural laboratory to learn the concepts of physics and geophysics.

column5: Probing the Ice Cap and Deeper Mysteries of Mt. Wrangell, North America's Largest Active Volcano
column15: Daniel Solie, University of Alaska Fairbanks
column18: Mt. Wrangell is a 4,300 meter ice covered, active volcano, eight times larger than Mt. Rainer in volume located in Wrangell Mountains of Alaska. This talk will describe the current multi-disciplinary research effort on Mt. Wrangell to determine the thickness of the ice cap in the Caldera, as well as give a broad overview of the over 50 years of research that have occurred on the mountain. These investigations include glacier/volcano interactions, ice coring, climate change, and cosmic rays.

column5: E-learning in the Context of Kazakhstan Society: Did We Miss the Information Train?
column15: Laura Arykbayeva, Kazakhstan Institute
column18: E-learning stands for learning through electronic applications and processes, which transfers information and knowledge through time and space. In Kazakhstan today it seems that e-learning is mostly successful among youth familiar with computer technologies, understanding advantages of the information age. The rest of the society seems to stay away from new trends, demonstrating no reaction at all. We explain this from two positions. Firstly, e-education is not applicable for those who have no knowledge of information technologies. And secondly, there is a complex combination of distrust to current education system due to decreasing quality of it, and initial ignorance of e-learning. In a flash, universities were among the first who adapted e-learning. Trying to copy international teaching practices, but with limited resources, they basically helped to create an economic gap and polarize Kazakhstan society into those who have access to information versus non-users, as in the H.G. Wells' futuristic novel about society represented by "hunters" and "victims." The questions here are: Is the effectiveness of e-learning correlated to the access to information? Would its effectiveness increase, if e-learning were introduced on a wide scale? Specific steps should be taken so e-learning will not become another political idea. Will Kazakhstan society, which started its globalization process almost twelve years ago, accept e-learning and be able to solve questions that the 21st century is putting in front of it?

column5: Information Computer Technologies in Creative Hands-On Activities and Physics Tricks*
column15: Alexander Kazachkov, Univ. of Northern Colorado
column17: Courtney Willis, John C Moore, Terry Scott, Tetyana Ignatova
column18: A series of educational activities are presented as practiced with high school through college students in the Summer Research Programs at the MAST Institute at the University of Northern Colorado. The focus was to enforce the instructive impact of engaging experimental problems by advanced measurements and virtual experiments. Technologies involved included GPS units, Vernier sensors, digital video cameras, etc. Obtained experimental results were computer-processed by the student, who also contributed into design of computer animations to explain the intriguing observed phenomena ("motional" visual illusions and other).

column5: Student-Activating Exercises in Teaching Electromagnetic Field Theory
column15: Ari Sihvola, Helsinki Univ. of Tech.
column18: The basic electromagnetic field theory forms a part of the core of engineering education in the Electrical Engineering department of the Helsinki University of Technology, Finland. Around 250 students yearly take these classes. Being in charge of the courses is obviously challenging. Abstract concepts, heavy mathematics, difficulties in visualizing electromagnetics and large classes force the teacher to revise his/her educational methods and teaching strategies. In this discourse, we will share experiences in field theory teaching, using various methods where the students have more active and independent role in the learning process. Students' learning processes are activated by homework which aims to develop problem-solving abilities, problem-based group projects and providing computer-aided learning materials, i.e., animations and simulations to support learning.

column5: Stimulations for Students To Learn through the Study Record Cards
column15: Takuyuki Uragami, Okayama Univ. of Science
column18: Students individually record every time they attend the lecture class on physics on the Study Record Cards their studies, how they got the ideas, what they associated with, which fact they found intriguing, where they wished to review, when they felt to check it more closely, and so. While they fill in the cards individually, the lecturer reads some of the encouraging contents for all of the class to find sometimes most of students nodding to and confirming the situations of physics learning and study attitudes of others described in the contents. As a result of process from individual response to public resonance, students involved were stimulated to study, and they showed good results for the final at the end of the semesters. The conditions for occurrence of the class resonance have been drawing our attention. When they learn physics, they do the laws, equations, experiments, observations, interpretations, presentations, and applications; at the same time, we tried to lead them to devise individually the strategy and tactics for how to study.

column5: All the Data in the World
column15: Michael J Raddick, Johns Hopkins Univ.
column18: We will describe how teachers can access all the world's astronomy data through the tools of the National Virtual Observatory. The NVO is providing online services to share data across the Internet<0x2014>data from many different instruments, at all wavelengths of the electromagnetic spectrum. The NVO's scientific plan has focused on making research easier and better by giving scientists easy access to more data than ever before. Similarly, the NVO's education and public outreach (EPO) plan focuses on improving existing EPO projects by providing them with free access to exactly the same high-quality data. We will describe the NVO's EPO partner projects, and demonstrate existing lesson plans that use NVO's tools and services to provide data. We will also provide suggestions and technical contacts for EPO developers who want to include NVO tools and services in their programs.

column5: Curricular Transfer of Tribocharging of Sand in Zero-g (WYP)
column15: Nathan Unterman, Glenbrook North H.S.
column18: An electrostatics experiment designed by students was flown on the NASA C-9 microgravity laboratory as part of the World Year of Physics observance. This experiment examined triboelectric partical interactions and can be applied to basic electrostatic phenomena. Classroom transfer of activities arising from this project in electrostatics will be discussed.

column5: Successes with Polynesian Conceptual Physics University Students
column15: Michael Weber, BYU-Hawaii
column18: First-year Polynesian students at BYU-Hawaii encounter many culture-based challenges, some of which lead to poor academic performance. In order to help our first-year Polynesian students succeed academically, in 2003 BYU-Hawaii instituted the Freshman Learning Community (FLC) program. In each FLC, the students take three linked classes, one of which is conceptual physics. I will discuss the FLC, and the results achieved by the Polynesian conceptual physics students.

column5: Results of Tribocharging of Sand in Microgravity (WYP)
column15: Lynne Zielinski, Glenbrook North H.S.
column18: Frictional charging of small particles has been well documented in forest fire ash plumes, volcanic eruptions, dust devils, and other small particulate phenomena. Applications of this experiment extend to interstellar dust, protostars, dust in low gravity environments such as Mars, and protoplanetary processes. The behavior of these particles in smaller than one-g environments is not well understood. An experiment was designed by students and flown on the C-9 as part of the World Year of Physics. Triboelectrically charged quartz particles were placed in a uniform electric field to study their interactions. Concept, design, fabrication, flight, and results will be discussed in this session.

column5: Teaching Science Online: Challenges and Opportunities
column15: Christina Sax, Univ. of Maryland
column18: Colleges and universities have turned to online education to meet the demands imposed on higher education by non-traditional students, technology, capacity, and workforce development. This shift to online education has resulted in changing curricula, pedagogical strategies, and teaching and learning modalities. Teaching science online presents a unique set of challenges and opportunities for both students and faculty. This paper will discuss the barriers to teaching and learning science online, as well as the co-existing opportunities for students, faculty, and institutions. This paper will also describe the University of Maryland University College's (UMUC) experiences since 1998 with 22 online science courses and over 33,000 online science enrollments. This includes an overview of UMUC's lessons learned with regard to the unique needs of online science students, and an integrated approach to online course development, student support, assessment, faculty training and mentoring, and security and quality assurance.

column5: The Windy Auroral Atmosphere
column15: John Craven, Geophysical Institute
column18: Observers of colorful auroral displays in Alaska may bask in the local ambiance of the moment, but more than the creation of light is happening within the auroral atmosphere. It is not the simple, static thermosphere of diffusive equilibrium, but a place of strong horizontal winds and impressive gradients in flow direction with increasing altitude. And there are vertical winds that mix the various constituents to alter their fractional contributions to the local density. One mechanism for pushing air upwards is buoyancy, from auroral heating by energetic particle precipitation (the primary auroral electrons) and Joule dissipation. Detection of the winds with sounding rockets will be demonstrated and how these data can be incorporated in mathematical tests via the continuity equation will be discussed.

column5: Hawaii Students' Comet Tempel 1 Research Projects
column15: Mary Ann Kadooka, Univ. of Hawaii Institute for Astronomy
column18: The NASA Deep Impact mission provided the perfect opportunity for our students to conduct authentic astronomy and astrobiology research. The students have used the professional 2.0 meter Faulkes Telescope North (FTN) located on Haleakala, Maui, to investigate the comet's properties before, during, and after the impact. Prior to the actual July 3, 2005, encounter between the impactor and the comet, the students learned about comets and telescope images. During the Maui workshop at encounter, they were taught how to develop observing plans and to hone their image processing skills. Subsequently, the follow up has been crucial to provide students with the necessary resources to continue working on their projects. The process of learning to do remote observing with FTN, to use software for image processing, to assist students with analysis of images, and continuous mentoring will be described. Exciting project results will be shared.

column5: Can Writing and Writing Instruction Aid Learning in Physics?
column15: Dedra Demaree, Ohio State Univ.
column17: Catherine Gubernatis, Gordon Aubrecht, Scott Franklin, Lisa Hermsen
column18: Members from both the Physics and English departments at the Ohio State University and Rochester Institute of Technology are involved in an ongoing study addressing issues related to writing activities in the physics classroom. These activities are unique in that they include explicit writing instruction in the physics classroom since writing is context-dependent. Some of the questions that we attempt to answer are: How do writing exercises compare to traditional activities (such as labs) in terms of helping students gain content knowledge? Is there a difference in the quality of physics content in student writing between those who have explicit writing instructions and those who do not? What can we say about the correlation between the quality of physics content and the quality of writing from an English perspective? This talk will discuss some specific studies aimed at addressing these questions and present an overview of our most recent findings.

column5: Noctilucent Clouds: Ice Clouds in the Alaskan Summer
column15: Richard Collins
column18: Noctilucent clouds are the highest clouds on Earth. Noctilucent clouds form in the summer near 80 km in the polar regions. The clouds form in a region of the atmosphere that is colder in summer than winter. These clouds have been studied since the late 1800s, and were one of the first indicators that the atmosphere extended to such heights. More recently they have attracted attention as an indicator of global change. This talk will present an overview of these clouds and discuss laser radar (or lidar) observations that have been made in Alaska by faculty and students at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. The talk will cover the physics of the clouds, the observational methods and challenges, and the environmental science questions associated with these clouds.

column5: Physical Science Professional Development Programs for K-12 Teachers*
column15: Robert Endorf, Univ. of Cincinnati
column17: Kathleen M. Koenig, Don Axe, Patricia Witson
column18: Physical Science by Inquiry programs have been conducted at the University of Cincinnati for inservice K-12 teachers during each of the past 10 summers. More than 300 teachers have successfully completed a four-week, 120-hour summer workshop for grades 5-12 teachers or a two-week, 60-hour summer workshop for grades K-5 teachers. The summer workshops consist of intensive graduate courses using modules from Physics by Inquiry.
column19: * Supported by The Improving Teacher Quality Program administered by the Ohio Board of Regents. 1. L.C. McDermott and the Physics Education Group at the University of Washington,

column5: Development of a Computer-Based Resource for Inclusion Science Classrooms
column15: Julia Olsen, Univ. of Arizona
column18: Current instructional issues necessitate educators start with curriculum and determine how educational technology can assist students in achieving positive learning goals, functionally supplementing the classroom instruction. Technology projects incorporating principles of situated learning have been shown to provide effective framework for learning, and computer technology has been shown to facilitate learning among special needs students. Students with learning disabilities may benefit from assistive technology, but these resources are not always utilized during classroom instruction: technology is only effective if teachers view it as an integral part of the learning process. The materials currently under development are in the domain of earth and space science, part of the Arizona 5-8 Science Content Standards. The concern of this study is to determine a means of assisting inclusive education that is both feasible and effective in ensuring successful science learning outcomes for all students whether regular education or special needs.

column5: Cosmic Ray Research Project
column15: Jeffery Chorny, Notre Dame Univ.
column18: The earth is constantly bombarded from tiny particles called Cosmic Rays. These tiny particles are naked to the eye but can be detected from sophisticated detectors. The search for where these little particles originate will help us study the universe. The following project gives an overview of setting the experiment up using the computer board developed at FERMI-Lab. The process in collecting and analyzing cosmic rays is very time consuming, but the ultimate goal is to discover their energies an origin. The detector's used in this experiment are briefly explained in this but can be further researched on the website. The following equipment was used in this experiment: DAQ Card from FERMI Lab, HyperTerminal on the computer, and the website Cosmic Ray e-Lab developed at FERMI. This experiment is still a work in progress and hopefully will be fully developed by the end of summer 2006.

column5: Trust Me. I am a Physics Teacher
column15: Dale Freeland, Portage Central H.S.
column18: I served as the "Teacher-in-Residence" (TIR) in the physics department on the Western Michigan University campus during the 2002-03 school year. After returning to my high school classroom during the fall of 2003, I have continued my involvement with the NSF funded PhysTEC (Physics Teacher Education Coalition) project through mentoring both beginning and crossover physics teachers. The mentor work centered on planning and sequencing instructional activities utilizing the available school and personal resources. Showing the mentee how the equipment worked, explaining how lab activities should be sequenced, discussing how students can be assessed, answering difficult mentee questions and having the mentees share in conference presentations were major components of this mentoring process. I will outline our shared challenges, solutions, successes and failures. Specific mentee comments will summarize their feelings on the value of this trusting, collegial relationship in the physics education community.

column5: A Physics Conceptual Mentoring Model
column15: Michael Wolter, Muncie Central H.S.
column18: This presentation will describe a model for mentoring novice physics teachers that was developed through the PhysTEC project using components from Indiana Certified Mentor training. This form of conceptual mentoring is carried out by Teachers in Residence while they are on leave from their school districts for a year on a university campus and continues when they return to their classrooms the following year. The impact of this mentoring addresses the issues of recruitment of new physics teachers as undergraduates and provides a supportive structure for their retention as classroom teachers after graduation.

column5: The Extinction of the Calculator in the High School Physics Classroom
column15: Michae D Wolter, Muncie Central H.S.
column18: Calculator and even graphing calculators are becoming obsolete just like the slide rules that we all loved not so long ago. The implementation of math engine software greatly enhances problem solving strategies for high school physics students. Examples from high school physics classes that have been using StudyWorks software routinely for the last six years will be provided.

column5: Are Students Understanding Science or Memorizing Pieces of Information?*
column15: Quinona Mack, City College of New York
column18: Many students are able to pass high school science classes by merely memorizing what is presented without understanding the underlying concepts. In a high school summer science enrichment program held at the City College of New York we were able to explore this issue as well as try to help the students look at learning science in a different way. We used surveys, in classroom observations, and interviews in order to look at epistemological dimensions such as approaches to learning science and the importance of concepts in solving problems. This helped us gauge how the students viewed learning science and scientific thinking. The program focused on observational astronomy. By the end of the program some of the students began to change their overall epistemological beliefs, others were better able to verbalize their beliefs, while others were able to question better what they had learned and whether they really understood it.
column19: *Sponsored by Richard N. Steinberg. Supported in part by NSF.

column5: Starting a Dialogue: The Potential of Vicarious Learning*
column15: Derek Muller, Univ. of Sydney
column18: Electronic resources are increasingly available to students in tertiary physics education, but the principles of best practice underlying the design and use of such materials are still being established. Can resources that employ modelled dialogue encourage the generative processes required for meaningful learning? This question was investigated in the area of quantum tunneling. Students' conceptions of the topic were surveyed after lecture and computational laboratory instruction. The uncovered alternative conceptions were then used to create a dialogue that was viewed by students in a lecture setting. A control group viewed the same material presented in a direct expository fashion. Students also participated in focus groups to explore their perceptions of the two treatments. The results demonstrate the potential of "vicarious learning" and suggest ways to improve both electronic and lecture teaching and learning.

column5: The Origin of Students' Difficulties in Learning Lagrange's Equation: Based on New Definition of Students' Difficulties
column15: Seunghee Lee,
column18: By now a great deal of research has been carried out on student difficulties with a variety of physics concepts, much of it related to mechanics. To teach students well, we should understand what students' difficulties are and how students perceive difficulties. However, even though my researchers have used the term "students' difficulties," there is little literature which proposes well-defined explanation about students' difficulties in learning physics. In this research, we began to define the terminology "student difficulty." After we analyzed students' difficulties in learning Lagrange's equation, we found the origin of students' difficulties and different types of difficulties.

column5: A Self-Orienting Robot for Zero Gravity Environments
column15: Eric Muhs, Roosevelt H.S.
column17: Eric Muhs, Eric Muhs, Eric Muhs, Eric Muhs
column18: One aspect of the World Year in Physics Centennial was an invitation for experiment proposals to ride aboard NASA's "vomit comet" zero gravity airplane. In the fall of 2004, I successfully submitted a proposal for an experiment: Our robotics team would construct a spherical free floating robot that would sense its spin by means of light sensors. In a textbook display of Conservation of Angular Momentum, the robot would spin flywheels to control its spin in 3 axes. Genesis, construction, testing, and results will be presented, along with a bit of microgravity fun.

column5: Using an Engineering Context To Foster Inquiry-Based Approach for Teaching Physics
column15: Molly Johnson,
column18: This talk describes a series of seven inquiry-based educational applied physics and engineering Technical Activity Modules (TAMs), which have been developed, taught, and refined over the past nine years. The TAM objectives are to expose students to substantive, challenging physics content in a fun and relevant context, and to motivate students to continue studying mathematics and science. The TAM design integrates factors that are recognized to affect motivation, such as the appropriate level of challenge and sensory feedback (such as sound, light, motion). In this talk we discuss the use of an "engineering context," or "scenario" to motivate the activities. The engineering "scenario" makes explicit the approach intended to be used, which is not only inquiry and investigation of a scientific concept, but using new knowledge of science concepts to solve an engineering problem.

column5: Changes in Undergraduate Teaching and Learning Within the MSP-SWPA*
column15: John Smetanka, Saint Vincent College
column18: The four Institutes of Higher Education (IHEs) within the Math and Science Partnership of Southwestern Pennsylvania (MSP-SWPA) are small, private, regional schools. The science, mathematics, and education faculty of the IHEs are involved in a variety of activities to enhance the content-knowledge, pedagogical practice, and leadership development within the 48 partner school districts. Symbiotically, K-12 teachers (Teacher Fellows) are granted sabbatical leave to return to IHEs and assist faculty in the revision of undergraduate courses. In this way, the MSP-SWPA works to enhance student performance in science and mathematics by improving the quality of the educator workforce and implementing research-based curricular materials and pedagogical best practices at all levels of instruction. Our report gives a brief overview and then focuses on the impact on undergraduate physics and mathematics courses at Saint Vincent College.
column19: *Supported by NSF grant #EHR-0314914 and Title II Part B MSP GRANT CFDA #84.366B (Pennsylvania Department of Education)

column5: The Dialect of Learning Physics in Hands-on Versus Mind-on Context
column15: Shewaferaw Shibeshi, Lynchburg College
column18: There is a strong belief by some current education experts that for a proper teaching-learning process at high school level, physics should be taught hands-on. Nevertheless there is supporting evidence to the contrary that the hands-on approach does not facilitate student problem solving skills as much as it does on conceptual understanding and technical skills. Physics education in Africa and in most Asian countries, unlike in the United States is mostly focused on principles and theories, problem solving, and everyday observations rather than being activity or laboratory based. The history of physics supports the mind-on approach as simple observations of natural phenomenon followed by profound abstraction, logical thinking and mathematical formulations lead scientist to better understanding and discovery of the laws of nature. The discoveries of Newton's Universal Law of Gravity, Maxwell's Electromagnetic Theory, Einstein's Theory of Relativity are some of the leading examples.

column5: An Activities-Based Curriculum To Teach Light and Color
column15: Jack Glassman, Southern Illinois Univ. Edwardsville
column18: At Southern Illinois University Edwardsville, an initiative is underway to redevelop the distribution-level course "Light & Color" as an activities-based course. Teaching optics to students without a technical background lends itself particularly well to these activities-based methods. Restricting the discussion to a lecture format, even if demonstrations are included, misses the opportunity to have students directly investigate something which is, quite literally, right before their eyes. Using hardware purchased specifically for this purpose, we have developed a set of student activities which are integrated into the syllabus. As part of this initiative, a systematic evaluation of the effectiveness of the different activities has been undertaken. This course has been taught under the new paradigm with encouraging results. In this poster, the activities developed and preliminary results of the evaluation will be described and discussed.

column5: Involving Families in Homework Using Make & Takes
column15: Diane Riendeau, Deerfield H.S.
column18: The ultimate indication of successful physics instruction is the ability of the student to apply what they learn to their everyday lives. To help accomplish this goal, I have my student construct simple pieces of "apparatus" that they can easily take home with them. Once they get them home, they are required to explain them to a family member. This method of instruction seems to increase student understanding of physics and parental interest in the Physics class. In this talk, I will discuss my methodology and share several of the "make & takes" I use throughout the school year.

column5: ASISTing New Teachers To Survive the Early Years
column15: Julia K Olsen, Univ. of Arizona
column18: The first years of teaching are a huge challenge and it is generally understood that support systems are needed for beginning teachers. Research shows that well designed induction programs are essential to develop of new teachers and to retain them in the profession. A full year program focusing on the unique needs of early-career, middle school science teachers was framed and implemented by a team of formal and informal educators under the leadership of the author. The overarching intention of this program was helping the new teachers to develop the skills and practice for effective inquiry science instruction. Monthly guided-discussion sessions where the participants could interact with each other and share ideas on relevant topics focused on student learning were an integral part of this program. I will share some of the lessons we learned along the way.

column5: Teaching Physics in Alaska
column15: Jennifer Childress, Dimond H.S.
column18: This will be a presentation based on experiences, both good and bad, during eight years of teaching physics/science in Alaska. These experiences encompass teaching in villages, small communities, and the largest city in Alaska.

column5: AIP's Science Writing Award for Children's Books
column15: Bea Uusma Schyffert, c/o Chronicle Books
column18: Title of book for which she is receiving award: "The Man Who Went to the Farside of the Moon."

column5: Combining Modern Technology and Traditional Lecturing in an Introductory College Physics Course
column15: Irina Struganova, Barry Univ.
column18: Modern technology allows the instructor to enhance visual contest of the course tremendously. It also allows for immediate feedback of the students understanding of the important concepts and thus to better judge on what would be the best course of action: to repeat the material or to go forward. However, modern technology cannot completely substitute traditional lecturing. Physics is a very logical subject which is based on very few fundamental laws. It is very important for the students to know and to understand the fundamental laws and how a particular equation could be derived from a general law. Traditional lecturing is still the best way to introduce the general laws, to illustrate the derivations of particular equations, and to emphasize important concepts. The best results can be achieved not by total declining of traditional lecturing, but by combining the best of the well established methods of the past and modern teaching methods. I would like to share my experience of combining a fast response system, PowerPoint presentations, video demonstrations and traditional lecturing in an algebra based general college physics course at Barry University.

column5: Speedskiing and Physics
column15: Martin Nikolo, St. Louis University
column18: Video of speedskiing made during a World Cup meet in British Columbia discusses physics issues faced not only by speedskiers but also by skiers in general. The aerodynamic force, ski geometry and design, body suit design, tuck position, waxing, etc. are discussed. Footage of skiers breaking speeds of 160 km/h is also shown.

column5: Assessment of Using the Clickers
column15: Pengfei Li, Ohio State Univ.
column18: At the Ohio State University, clicker, an in-class polling system, was assessed in the electromagnetism quarter of a year-long introductory class. Two lecture sections were taught, only one of which used clickers. Assessment of the effectiveness of clicker usage was conducted in various ways. Normalized gains of the Concept Survey of Electromagetism (CSEM) and common exam results were compared between the clicker section and nonclicker section. Both the clicker section and the nonclicker section lectures were observed. The number of questions by various type of students during each lecture were compared between these two sections. In this talk, we will discuss the some preliminary results of this assessment.

column5: Assessment of Using an In-Class Polling System in Lectures
column15: Pengfei Li, The Ohio State Univ.
column18: At the Ohio State University, use of an in-class polling system (clickers), was assessed in the electromagnetism quarter of a year-long introductory class. Two lecture sections were taught, but only one of them used clickers. Clicker and non-clicker lectures were observed to determine relative class interactivity. In this talk, we will discuss preliminary results that include a comparison of normalized gains from pre and post testing with the Concept Survey of Electromagetism (CSEM), common exam questions, and digesting observations to assess relative class interactivity.

column5: Teaching Laboratories Featuring Medical Physics
column15: Suzanne Amador Kane, Haverford Coll.
column18: We have developed a suite of experiments on topics in medical physics appropriate for inclusion into the physics teaching laboratory at a variety of levels. Some of the experiments have been assembled from existing sources and some have been developed de novo. Most of the equipment is readily available from commercial sources, and the new laboratory manuals are available to other interested faculty. Modules include experiments on ultrasound imaging, x-ray imaging and computed tomography, emission tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, ionizing radiation, and applications of optics in medicine. We discuss our early experiences integrating medical physics topics into our sophomore and higher laboratories, and into an introductory course for premedical students.

column5: WebCT, Physlets, and LabPros, Oh My!
column15: Patricia Allen, Appalachian State Univ.
column18: Various forms of technology are currently used in the algebra-based introductory course at Appalachian State. These technologies are used to complement the on-going curricular changes to the Modeling Instruction materials and approach developed by D. Hestenes & M. Wells (Arizona State University). WebCT serves as the main "warehouse" for course materials, including Physlets, while LabPros are used during various in-class activities. The impact of these technologies on instruction and student attitudes will be presented and discussed.

column5: Near-Surface Composition of Mars Revealed Using Gamma Rays
column15: John M Keller, Univ. of Arizona
column17: William V. Boynton, GRS Science Team
column18: The Mars Gamma Ray Spectrometer (GRS) aboard the Mars 2001 Odyssey spacecraft collects gamma rays given off from the top meter of the surface of the planet. Using this data, we have detected large amounts of buried water ice in the arctic regions of Mars (

column5: Probing Student Understanding of the Atmospheric Greenhouse Effect
column15: Edward Prather, Univ. of Arizona
column17: John M Keller, Timothy F. Slater
column18: The flow of energy through our atmosphere and the atmospheric greenhouse effect are central to our current scientific understanding of climate and climate change. However, students and members of the public commonly hold weak and inaccurate conceptual understandings of these processes. We present both survey and interview results obtained over the past two years from 3,300 undergraduate non-science majors. We discuss concepts fundamental to effectively addressing student misconceptions on this topic, including the following: differences between solar and terrestrial spectra; light processes of reflection, absorption, and emission; wavelength dependent interactions between light and greenhouse gases; radiative equilibrium between space, the atmosphere, and the surface; and distinctions between the atmospheric greenhouse effect, ozone depletion, global climate change, and environmental pollution.

column5: Physics in the Mekong Delta*
column15: Paul Stanley, Beloit College
column18: We present here preliminary results of a study of physics education in the Mekong delta region of Vietnam. Based on a series of interviews and observations, the intent of this study is to develop insight into how physics is learned in Vietnam, and then to collaboratively develop pedagogical tools that are appropriate to the region. This study has already yielded surprises ranging from resource challenges to unique approaches used in teacher training programs.
column19: *Funded in part by grants from the Freeman Foundation and the Keefer Fund

column5: Documentary Film About Science Teachers in Zambia
column15: Maria Cecire, Univ. of Chicago
column18: In spite of all the problems that Africa faces today, it is neither pitiful nor hopeless. In this film the audience meets math and science teachers that are making serious contributions to education in Zambia. Andy Chimwanga teaches his students to make lab materials out of waste products; Edith Chimoka challenges her female students to overcome the obstacles to women in science. These and other teachers talk about education and development in the context of the COSM-Zambia teacher workshops of August 2004. Zambian and American teachers worked together to design simple, effective lab exercises that can reach both Zambian and American students. This 30-minute documentary will be followed by Q and A.

column5: Making Quantum Mechanics Visual and Interactive with Physlet- and OSP-Based Curricular Material*
column15: Mario Belloni, Davidson College
column18: The teaching of quantum mechanics has remained relatively frozen in time since its inception, despite recent work assessing and improving the conceptual understanding of students and despite availability of computer simulations. Students, therefore, often see quantum mechanics in terms of misleading or incomplete visualizations, as one dimensional and time independent, and devoid of almost any connection with classical physics. To address this situation, we have produced and class-tested interactive Physlet- and Open Source Physics-based curricular material in support of introductory, intermediate, and advanced courses in quantum mechanics. These exercises address both quantitative and conceptual difficulties encountered by many students in such topics as wave function shape, momentum space, time evolution, and classical/quantum correlations. The materials are adaptable and can be used at a variety of levels with a variety of pedagogies. Examples of the curricular materials, the results of our preliminary assessment, and future directions of this project will be discussed.
column19: *Physlets and Open Source Physics are supported by the NSF grant DUE-0442581.

column5: Project IBEAM: Integrative Biology Experimental Activity Modules
column15: John Pratte, Kennesaw State Univ.
column18: Project IBEAM is an interdisciplinary effort to increase biology majors' knowledge, understanding, and application of physics to issues in biology. This is done through the use of multi-week activity modules that can be used within both introductory physics and upper-division biology courses that allow students to investigate the connections between physics and biology. The modules used in the introductory physics courses consist of a set of standard physics labs done in the traditional weekly fashion that provide the background information for the biological concept under investigation, such as metabolic energy utilization, heart defibrillation, and magnetic navigation in animals. The modules finish with a capstone activity that uses a hybrid mixture of hands-on and computer simulations to apply the information learned in the other activities directly to the biological issue. This material is reinforced in later biology courses with module activities that refer back to what is previously learned.

column5: Empirical Scaling Laws of Rocket Exhaust Cratering
column15: Carly M Donahue, Berry College
column17: Philip T Metzger, Christopher D Immer
column18: When launching or landing a space craft on the regolith of a terrestrial surface, special attention needs to be paid to the rocket exhaust cratering effects. If the effects are not controlled, the rocket cratering could damage the spacecraft or other surrounding hardware. The cratering effects of a rocket landing on a planet's surface are not understood well, especially for the lunar case with the plume expanding in vacuum. As a result, the blast effects cannot be estimated sufficiently using analytical theories. It is necessary to develop physics-based simulation tools in order to calculate mission-essential parameters. In this work we test the scaling laws of the physics in regard to growth rate of the crater depth. This will provide the physical insight necessary to begin the physics-based modeling.

column5: Photon Gun Experiments and the Measurement of Light Pressure*
column15: Daniel Jaindl, Xavier Univ.
column18: We demonstrate the effect of light pressure on microspheres suspended in a liquid. The Reynolds number of such a configuration is low, therefore the drag force of the surrounding liquid dominates and the inertia of the particle does not play a role. The velocity is therefore a direct measure of the instantaneous photon flux. We shot the microspheres with HeNe Laser light exiting a lensed fiber and recorded their motion. From these data we modeled the motion and calculated the initial acceleration which can reach up to 3800 m/s2. After the sphere has reached its terminal velocity it moves at constant velocity as long as the beam waist does not expand, i.e., as long as the light pressure on the sphere remains constant. These measurements are therefore a method to map the intensity distribution in a Gaussian beam.

column5: High School Students Can Do Scientific Research: Survey Results
column15: Beth Marchant, Univ. of Notre Dame
column18: In Summer 2005, more than 50 high school students were involved in real research in university and national laboratory physics labs across the country through QuarkNet.
column19: 1. QuarkNet is funded by NSF and DOE.

column5: Bringing University Expertise into the Classroom To Enhance STEM Education
column15: Steven J Sweeney, Lehigh Univ.
column18: The Lehigh Valley Partnership for STEM Education partners professors, graduate fellows, and undergraduate fellows from Lehigh University as well as industry members from firms such as Binney and Smith with teachers and students from two local public school districts in the neighboring cities of Allentown and Bethlehem. The program has found itself with a mission to excite students from fourth grade through high school about science, technology, engineering, and math, as well as hopefully exciting college students about future careers in teaching these fields. While still early in our partnership, progress has been made in changing the attitudes students have towards these typically unpopular classes. We look to continue this work in our home schools and broaden our impact by incorporating more school districts into our program.

column5: The Arctic's Changing Cryosphere and the International Polar Year
column15: Martin Jeffries
column18: Computer models have long predicted that the effects of global warming would be observed earlier and be greater in the polar regions than elsewhere on Earth. In the late 20th century, significant physical and biological changes became apparent in the lands, seas, and atmosphere of the Arctic. These changes continue, and some of the most profound are occurring in the cryosphere<0x2014>snow, ice, and permafrost (e.g., decreasing sea ice and glacier volume), thawing permafrost, decreasing duration of snow cover, freshwater and sea ice. This paper will describe some of these cryospheric changes and discuss their broader implications, including social and economic effects, and the importance of the impending International Polar Year (IPY) of 2007-2009. The observed Arctic changes and their potential consequences lend impetus to the need for IPY, a coordinated effort to better understand the role of the polar regions in global processes, and engage the public in the excitement of polar research by creating opportunities for education, training, and outreach for all age groups.

column5: Model Comets with Dry Ice Chunks Floating on Warm Water
column15: Paul Doherty, Exploratorium
column18: At the Exploratorium we have an exhibit called "Icy Bodies," in which dry ice is used to model comets. Dry ice is denser than water and yet small pieces of dry ice will "float" on water supported by surface tension. If a bowl of warm water is used, then the dry ice will sublime rapidly expelling cold gas jets that propel the ice chunks across the water. The cold jets condense clouds from water vapor creating "tails" that are reminiscent of comets. The bits of ice often spin due to off-axis outgassing. Other interesting behaviors can be observed; the dry ice chunks seem to attract each other and stick together, yet they bounce off the rim of the water bowl.

column5: Melting the Frozen Curriculum with Information Fluency
column15: Pat Viele, Cornell University
column18: In order to make intelligent decisions, a person must know how to find and evaluate information and then incorporate good information in their decision-making process. A person who is capable of doing this demonstrates information fluency. Educational standards require students to demonstrate information fluency skills, and the bodies that are responsible for accrediting institutions of higher learning are setting standards for ensuring that college educated people have attained information fluency. Studies indicate that the most effective way to teach information fluency skills is in conjunction with specific subject matter. Over the summer, I collaborated with a physics faculty member to incorporate some information fluency assignments into a physics class. Here I will present some ideas for incorporating information fluency skills into physics curriculum at various levels.

column5: Reform of Introductory Laboratories: Baseline Data*
column15: Joshua W Jacob, Miami Univ.
column18: At Miami University, we are planning to redo our entry-level physics lab course. To confidently make a change for the better, we must first establish what the problems are. To do so, we are conducting an extensive survey to all 500+ students taking the course, and then following up with extensive interviews of volunteers. The purpose will be to define what about the lab needs to be improved from a student perspective. Continuing research could include graduate student and professor interviews to identify, on a more academic level, what needs to be improved. This is the start of a multi-year project.

column5: Static or Dynamic: The Current Status of Women in Physics
column15: Laura McCullough, Univ. of Wisconsin-Stout
column18: Are women still underrepresented in physics? Is this a problem? This talk will explore the current status of women in physics: classes, degrees, jobs, and lives. Looking at data from a variety of sources, I will discuss the participation rates of women in our field, and what work has been done on discovering how to make physics more welcoming to women. I will also discuss the gender gap in the physics classroom and the belief that interactive teaching strategies are particularly helpful to women.

column5: Geologic Overview of the 1964 M9.2 Great Alaska Earthquake
column15: Peter Haeussler, U.S. Geological Survey
column18: The 1964 magnitude 9.2 earthquake in southern Alaska remains the largest recorded earthquake in our nation's history and it is the third largest in the world. The rupture lasted for about 4.5 minutes and caused widespread damage from ground shaking, landslides, and tsunamis. The earthquake was the first to be interpreted as a subduction zone "megathrust" earthquake, and played an important role in the acceptance of the then nascent theory of plate tectonics. Horizontal movements of up to 66 feet and subsidence of six feet reveal the elastic nature of the earth's crust. A splay off of the megathrust resulted in local uplift of up to 23 feet. Movement of the crust during fault rupture generated far-travelled tsunamis, and submarine landslides generated local tsunamis with wave run up heights of up to 170 feet.

column5: Ds9: It's Not Just for X-rays
column15: John Kolena, NC School of Science and Mathematics
column18: Ds9 is a FITS image processor that was originally designed for Chandra X-ray Observatory images. Even though ds9 has been used primarily by research astronomers, it can also be employed as a teaching/learning tool with optical images in high school or college astronomy courses. Classroom-ready image processing activities and results using optical images will be presented. Examples include measurement of the parallax of (and distance to) an asteroid, determination of the mass of Jupiter from observations of its satellites, and discovery of supernovas and analysis of their light curves. Ds9's direct connectivity to the Chandra image database and its ability to analyze x-ray spectra, light curves, and power spectra remotely via the Chandra servers also can facilitate student research projects.

column5: Exploring the Possibility of a Scenario-Based Instructor Book as an Inquiry Teaching Material in Secondary-Level Physics Classes*
column15: Gyoungho Lee, Seoul National Univ.
column17: Sungmuk Lee, Kyungwoon Nam, Jaebong Lee, Mihee Kim
column18: Inquiry has been a central concept not only in physics education but also in other education areas for decades and has been extensively researched. However, there are still many questions about inquiry methods in schools. For instance, what is inquiry teaching? How can teachers be helped in using inquiry teaching? Many secondary school science teachers have less practical experience about inquiry learning and teaching. Even though there are many teaching materials for inquiry teaching, usually they do not have detailed information how to teach physics by inquiry in a specific contextual setting. Thus, the purpose of this study was to develop a scenario-based instructor book as a inquiry teaching material for secondary school science classes. In this talk we will discuss its effects and educational implications.

column5: The Chandra X-Ray Observatory Data Analysis Software and Classroom Activities
column15: Donna L Young, The Wright Center/Chandra EPO
column18: Educators, students, amateur astronomers and the general public can download and install a set of sophisticated tools, and access the public archive of observational data to investigate and analyze supernovae, binary stars, pulsars, black holes, galaxies, and galaxy clusters. The DS9 image and data analysis software tools can be downloaded into a Mac, Windows, or Linux environment. The analysis commands are executed at a dedicated server farm at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory in Cambridge, Massachusetts -- transforming any operating system into a virtual Linux machine. Any FITS file can be dropped into the DS9 imagining software, which allows comparisons among visible, IR, UV, radio and x-ray emissions for the same object. Besides basic tools -- color, scales, contrast, bias, and pixel values, the analysis tools include radial profiles, light curves and period folding, energy and spectra distribution plots and histograms. The archived data can be used for original research projects.

column5: Students, the Virtual Physics Classroom, and the Web
column15: Gerald Meisner, UNC-Greensboro
column18: The Modeling methodology developed by Wells, Hestenes, Dukerich et al. has been ported to an online environment to facilitate distance learning in the sciences. Modeling demands intensive, highly interactive and guided laboratory investigations. Has the creation of a virtual laboratory environment to emulate Modeling in a physical classroom been successful or is it an oxymoron? Students at high school and university levels have used various parts of the Learn Anytime Anywhere Physics project
column19: 1. Supported in part by Ded FIPSE grant #P339B990329

column5: Star Properties Concept Inventory: Design, Development, and First Results
column15: Janelle Bailey, Univ of Arizona
column17: Edward E Prather, Bruce Johnson, Timothy F Slater
column18: The Star Properties Concept Inventory has been developed to investigate students' understanding of the properties of stars prior to instruction. It can then be used post-instruction to document gains in student understanding on the same topics. Distractors used with the multiple-choice questions are based on known student difficulties. Questions were tested by being presented to participants in three different formats, with responses compared; written responses were also compared to those provided by participants in interviews. Modifications were made to questions as needed, based upon student responses in earlier versions. Preliminary analysis from spring 2005 data indicates that statistically significant gains were observed over the course of instruction. Analysis on fall 2005 data to test the validity of the instrument will be reported.

column5: New Insights into Student Understanding of Basic Electric Circuits Concepts*
column15: MacKenzie Stetzer, Univ. of Washington
column17: Peter S. Shaffer, Lillian C. McDermott
column18: New insights into student understanding of basic concepts in electric circuits have emerged from an ongoing investigation by the Physics Education Group at the University of Washington. We have been examining the effectiveness of various types of pretest and post-test questions in probing student thinking about the concept of a complete circuit. The results indicate that successful performance on any single question does not necessarily reflect a robust, functional understanding of complete circuits. The use of complementary companion questions may therefore be required to probe student understanding in greater detail. Results will be presented from questions administered to a range of populations, including undergraduates in introductory calculus-based courses and pre-service and in-service K-12 teachers.

column5: Impact of Technology-Rich PET Curriculum on Future Elementary Teachers
column15: Paul Zitzewitz, Univ. of Michigan-Dearborn
column18: The PET (Physics for Elementary Teachers) curriculum makes extensive use of CPU simulators, digital-video clips, and computer-based motion detectors. Are pre-service K-8 teachers comfortable enough in such an environment to envision themselves using technology in their future classrooms? Students write and post an element of their web-based science education portfolio that is a grant proposal to purchase equipment for their future classroom. They are asked to make claims about the student learning that would result and back these claims with evidence from the literature. I will sumarize the proposals of the 70 students who have completed the assignment to determine what technology they believe is most useful in the K-8 classroom and why they believe this.

column5: Teaching Physics the Last Ten Days of High School
column15: Thomas F Haff, Issaquah H.S.
column18: One of the most difficult times to teach physics is 10 days before high school graduation. Seniors are busy with senior pictures, signing year books, senior assembly preparation and all that goes with this important time of their lives. They have been accepted to their schools and some may have mentally "checked-out." Even with all of the stresses of this busy time, Issaquah High School students are still engaged in doing and learning physics. The reason is the traditional IHS Physics "Scavenger Hunt." It is a time tested unit that allows flexibility for the teacher and students. When seniors still come into the class after their last required day to "finish up" or "check a few things over," I knew the lesson was a keeper. This low stress take home final exam project may be just what you are looking for to finish up their high school education.

column5: Exploring the Invisible Universe with NASA: Activities To Study the EM Spectrum
column15: David Beier, The Barstow School
column18: As an Educator Ambassador for NASA's Swift Mission and as a Resource Agent for the Chandra, I have several different activities that will assist middle and high school students in researching and learning more about the EM spectrum using materials developed thru NASA resources to study and understand the various wavelengths of energy in our universe. I will explain the various free materials available to teachers, including the GEMS guide

column5: Catalyzing an Interest in Science and Engineering Careers
column15: Herb Schroeder, Univ. of Alaska Anchorage
column18: In Alaska, the Alaska Native Science & Engineering Program (ANSEP) is a collaborative effort between the National Science Foundation (NSF), the US Department of Education, the oil industry, philanthropic organizations, Alaska Native communities and regional corporations, and the professional engineering and construction industry. Beginning when they are high school sophomores, structured programs lead students each step of the way through high school, into the undergraduate years, on to graduate school, and into professional life. At each level the goal is to create empowerment and excitement around engineering and science. More than 300 Alaskan, Hawaiian, and Washington state high school students in 32 schools and 260 university students at 4 institutions in the three states are currently actively engaged as developing engineers. Program life retention rates in engineering are above 70% on each campus. This compares to the national average of 27% for Indigenous engineering students as published by the National Center for Education Statistics.

column5: Projecting a Community Image
column15: Jauhar Khalid, Highland Comm. Coll.
column18: This poster will coalesce last year's SPS project, the 44-foot tall trebuchet (one of the biggest in the country), and this year?s projects: 1) a fully operational, mechanical model of the skull of the recently discovered T-Rex "Jane," and 2) a B-modified racecar that our SPS chapter is building, including elucidation of numerous procedures and materials required in order to construct these structures. A variety of pictures, captions, and articles will be utilized to highlight the positive impact the Highland Community College chapter of SPS has had on the community and the Physics/Engineering enrollment at Highland Community College.

column5: Search for E(5) Symmetry in Rare Earth Nuclei
column15: Peter Manchev, Univ. of Richmond
column18: For even-even nuclei one can obtain approximate analytic solutions for the Bohr Hamiltonian. The E(5) symmetry, at the phase transition between spherical and gamma-soft limits, is not fully explored yet and only two experimental examples have been proposed so far. A theoretical search for examples of E(5) was conducted in the rare-earth using the existing level schemes. We carried out Interacting Boson Approximation calculations to explore the transition region for a finite number of valence nucleons, and to study the perturbations to E(5) at the transition point.
column19: Mirela Fetea - faculty mentor, AAPT member

column5: Practical Relativity
column15: Neil Ashby, Univ. of Colorado
column18: Technology developments, particularly continuing improvements in clocks, have led to numerous applications in which both special and general relativity are important, even crucial. The Global Positioning System is one example in which constancy of the speed of light, breakdown of classical synchronization, time dilation, gravitational frequency shifts, the Sagnac effect, and the weak equivalence principle are significant, testable, and provide numerous real examples that can be used in teaching and testing relativity. This lecture will focus on demonstrations of fundamental relativity concepts and their practical applications in navigation, astronomy, and other fields (e.g., meteorology).

column5: Using Digital Signal Processing in the Advanced Laboratory
column15: Frank L Wolfs, Univ. of Rochester
column17: Wojtek Skulski, Megan Alexander, Daniel Miner
column18: During the last few years we have gained significant experience using Digital Signal Processors (DSPs) in the undergraduate laboratory through various independent-study projects using DSPs developed by SkuTek Instrumentation. We are now in the process of developing several applications of DSPs that are suitable for the Advanced Physics Laboratory. In this presentation we will use the muon lifetime experiment as an example of the power of DSPs. In our setup, we use a relative small plastic scintillator. The scintillator signals are digitized and the DSP triggers when the captured waveform contains both the stopping and the decay signal within about 10 microseconds. The digitized waveforms are written to disk for off-line analysis. The waveforms will not only contain information about the time between stopping and decay, but can also be used to extract information about the energy deposited by the stopping muons and the energy released when they decay.
column19: This project was partly supported by SkuTek Instrumentation and by the NSF (PHY-0242483).

column5: An Undergraduate Low-Mass Balloon-Borne Cosmic Ray Experiment
column15: Robert Walch, Univ. of Northern Colorado
column17: Richard Dietz, Patricia Mills, Julie Smith, Ryan Marshall
column18: A balloon-borne cosmic ray detection experiment built, tested and mainly designed by undergraduate students will be described. Two photomultiplier tubes were encased in sealed PVC tubes each vacuum epoxied to a piece of scintillator material sensitive to charged cosmic ray secondaries. The pressure inside the PVC tubes was kept at 1 atm. This novel approach eliminated possible coronal discharge. Output signals went to a coincidence counting circuit board then to a data logger. The data showed the expected count profile throughout the 2.5 hour flight which reached an altitude of around 100,000'. The total mass of the experiment was only 2.43 kg. The project provided not only an outstanding learning opportunity for the students involved but also experience in teamwork and problem-solving.

column5: Physics is ePort-able
column15: David Weaver
column18: Both my students and I are using Electronic Portfolios (ePorts) to communicate with each other and the rest of the world. My use is primarily as a learning management system (replacing Blackboard) while my students use it to present their major work in the class. Come hear how we also use blogs, wikis and podcasting in our ePorts to improve student learning. I will show my ePort along with selected student sites. I will also entertain questions concerning various ePort platforms as well as why and how I migrated from Blackboard after 5 years of use.

column5: QUANTUM MECHANICS: Is it really difficult to understand by the college students or??
column15: Bayram Akarsu, Indiana Univ.
column18: The objective of this research is to study the potential solutions of the common misconceptions, insufficient teaching techniques and other instructional or conceptual significant problems encountered while teaching/learning an important branch of physical science, quantum mechanics (QM), at the freshmen college year. The study reported in this paper was conducted both in the US and followed by in Turkey. The aim of the study was to elaborate and analyze the difficulties of teaching and learning Quantum Mechanics (QM) in the college level. An effective answer to the corresponding instructional problem might allow the basic ideas of QM to be comprehended by the students better. Although the foundation of QM goes to the beginning of 19th century, unfortunately, studies about its difficulties encountered by the students were limited and far away from finding solutions to them.

column5: Creating a Whorl with an Optically Driven Helical Bacterium
column15: Alice M. Kemme, Xavier Univ.
column18: A left handed helical bacterium is optically tweezed with a 633nm Helium-Neon Laser. The forces from the laser cause the bacterium to rotate clockwise and thus create a whorl surrounding it. This whorl causes the surrounding bacteria to rotate around the tweezed bacterium. The path of these rotating bacteria can be tracked and from this data the curvature of the path and the angular velocity of each of the rotating bacterium can be found.
column19: Funded by the Cottrell Research Corporation

column5: The initiation of TA-student interactions in tutorials
column15: Rachel E Scherr, Univ. of Maryland
column17: Rosemary S Russ, Tom Bing, Ray Hodges
column18: At the University of Maryland we videotaped several semesters of tutorials as part of a large research project. A particular research task required us to locate examples of students calling the TAs over for assistance with a physics question. To our surprise, examples of this kind of interaction were difficult to find. We undertook a systematic study of TA-student interactions in tutorial: in particular, how are the interactions initiated?
