Do the students call the TA over for help with a particular issue, does the TA stop by spontaneously, or does the worksheet require a discussion with the TA at that point? The initiation of the interaction is of particular interest because it provides evidence of the motivation for and purpose of the interaction. This talk will present the results of the study.
column19: Supported in part by NSF REC 0440113.

column5: Reaching Out: Physics Outreach to High School Students
column15: John D. Lorenz, Univ. of Louisville
column17: Alyssa Cramer, Blakesly Burkhart, Scott Boyd
column18: One goal of the University of Louisville Society of Physics Students (SPS) chapter is to promote public interest in physics through outreach activities. Most of this outreach is to high school physics classes. We visit local high schools to encourage students to explore careers in physics, to teach physics, and to show that physics is fun. We have developed several presentations designed to achieve these aims. This poster will detail two programs: demonstrations of wave properties and outreach at all-girls' schools. We will discuss student and teacher responses to our visits.

column5: Functional Equations in the Two-Year Curriculum
column15: Steven Hoell, Pima Comm. Coll.
column18: Over the centuries, many scientific discoveries involved the solution to a functional equation. Some of these may be introduced in calculus and calculus-based physics courses. In particular, I discuss applications to special relativity.

column5: Parallels between the Dine? Philosophy of Learning and traditional physics teaching
column15: Carlon G Ami, Univ. of New Mexico
column18: Teaching the way we were taught, typically a formal lecture with limited student interaction, has not been an uncommon practice for many of us physics teachers. In the early 90's the board of regents at Dine' College, a two-year college owned and operated by the Navajo (Dine') tribe, adopted the Dine' Philosophy of Learning (DPL) model which incorporated traditional Navajo philosophies of teaching and learning as a guide for instruction at the college. DPL is cyclonic beginning with Nitsahakees (thinking), Nahata (planning), Iina (implementation), and Sihasin (stage of reassurance). Implementing these steps in addressing situations, individuals lead themselves toward Sa'ah naaghai bik'eh hozho, the Dine' traditional living system that places life in harmony with the natural world. This typifies the traditional mode of teaching/learning of most American Indian tribes, parallels the preferred method for problem-solving techniques in physics education, and thus is important for teachers of American Indian students.

column5: Science Museum (Interpretive Center) at Principia College
column15: David A. Cornell, Principia College
column18: The Science Interpretive Center (museum) at Principia College opened in April 2004. It occupies space provided by a vacated chemistry laboratory. Thematically developed around local sky, prairie, forest, and wildlife, the museum presents live displays of the natural environment. Concept areas displayed include biology, archeology, chemistry, and astronomy. Being a retiree liberated from regular teaching duties, the presenter volunteered to devote time to developing the museum. The presentation shares the museum planning process, means of implementation, and views of the current displays.

column5: Modeling of Laser Frequency Noise Suppression in LIGO
column15: Alyssa J. Cramer, Univ. of Louisville
column18: In 1916 and 1918, Einstein postulated that, just as accelerating point charges produce electromagnetic wave, accelerating masses produce gravitational waves. The Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) employs three detectors and a process of very precise distance measurement to observe gravitational waves produced by distant massive objects. LIGO uses nested control loops to stabilize the frequency of the laser light used in this distance measurement. We consider the inner servo, the Frequency Stabilization Servo (FSS), used in the Hanford four-kilometer interferometer.

column5: Service Learning in Physics
column15: Jennifer E Bustamante, Marquette Univ.
column18: Students in the Marquette University introductory physics classes participate in service learning activities. They are challenged to find a way to represent physics concepts in a way that is fun and informative for kids. At the same time, the students must master the topics themselves so that they are able to teach them. Typical topics include Newton?s laws, rotational motion, and simple harmonic motion. The students present to the first through fifth grade students at the United Community Center and other after school programs in Milwaukee, WI. Post-introductory physics students are encouraged to continue their outreach efforts through the Society of Physics Students. The club sponsors High Interest Days, targeting underprivileged elementary school audiences. A variety of demonstrations are used, the most recent addition being a bed of nails. Students enjoy working with hands-on physics and learning new concepts in building the equipment. They also learn how to teach.

column5: A Research Plan for Enhancing and Evaluating Students' Proficiency in Electromagnetics
column15: Johanna Leppvirta, Helsinki Univ. of Technology
column18: Electromagnetics is a part of the engineering curriculum in the Electrical Engineering department of the Helsinki University of Technology. Electromagnetics is often viewed as a most abstract and conceptually difficult area of engineering education. This poster describes experiences and perceptions the researcher has made while participating in two basic electromagnetic field theory courses as a participant observer. The aim has been to understand what is difficult for the students, what are students' attitudes towards electromagnetics and what is preventing students from learning the topic more sufficiently? In this poster, the researcher will also introduce a research plan for studying how cooperational learning and teaching methods could enhance students' mathematical proficiency and understanding of the fundamental concepts in electromagnetics.

column5: CoMPASS: Integrating Digital Text in Design-Based Science Classrooms: Scaling-Up
column15: N. Sanjay Rebello, Kansas State Univ.
column17: Sadhana Puntambekar, Ann A. O'Connell, Roland Hbscher
column18: Our poster describes CoMPASS (Concept Mapped Project-based Activity Scaffolding System) a five-year project funded through the National Science Foundation and currently being implemented within two very different school systems in Connecticut. CoMPASS is an inquiry-based approach that integrates hands-on science investigations and the use of digital text to help middle school students learn science. Our collaborative research team includes the implementing teachers, educational psychologists, physicists, and measurement specialists. In our poster, we will describe the student learning goals of CoMPASS and its implementation across diverse classrooms and schools, with an eye to the future challenges inherent in its potential wide-scale implementation and use.
column19: Supported by the U.S. National Science Foundation Grant IERI # 0437660.

column5: Effect of Homework Cheating in Introductory Physics
column15: David J. Palazzo, MIT
column18: From a class of ~430 MIT freshman using the electronic homework tutor MasteringPhysics, ~9% were categorized as Quick Solvers - students who answer 50% or more of their electronic homework problems in less than 2.5 minutes. We argue that such quickness results from academic dishonesty. As a group, Quick Solvers performed lower on all exams as compared to the real-time and delayed solvers. More importantly, their relative performance as the semester progressed diverged farther from the real-time and delayed solvers. On the course final exam, Quick Solvers averaged 1.5 standard deviations below all other students. Quick Solvers had a course failure rate that was 4 times higher than all other students, ~31% to 7%. Disturbingly, this means that ~70% of the Quick Solvers managed to attain the C or higher required for advancement into Electricity and Magnetism, the follow-on subject at MIT. Quick Solvers also performed lower on the E&M; final exam the following semester. We will also discuss behavioral patterns associated with Quick Solvers which illuminate why, when, and how students are cheating. These results suggest ways to eliminate cheating in order to improve overall learning, thereby reducing course failures and better preparing students for academic and post-collegiate success. We will contrast our results from Fall '03 with the most recent results from Fall '05 and gauge the effectiveness of our preventative measures.

column5: Mentoring through Catastrophe: A New Orleans Perspective
column15: Kathleen McCloud, Xavier Univ. of Louisiana
column18: The disaster in New Orleans is well documented. In this presentation, we will describe on-going efforts in the Physics Department at Xavier University of Louisiana to provide support and mentoring to K-12 teachers displaced by hurricane Katrina. These efforts are spearheaded by the Teacher in Residence (Remonda Edmond), a position which is provided through the Physics Teacher Education Coalition (PhysTEC). One focus has been locating displaced teachers and setting up a network of teachers in similar geographic areas for mutual support. We have now located most of the members of the Xavier Teacher Advisory Group, who will be able to serve as mentors in their areas, and are gathering suggestions for further ways to aid displaced teachers. Some of the challenges we have faced have implications for all institutions. Problems such as communication when the infrastructure is destroyed and access to records and resources is unavailable will be presented.

column5: Physics Workshop Project for the Twenty-First Century*
column15: Curtis J Hieggelke, Joliet Junior Coll.
column18: We will report on the workshops offered by this project for two-year college and high school physics teachers. The goal of this project has been to help TYC and HS physics students develop a stronger understanding of science, with an emphasis on physics and its applications in industry. This program addressed these issues by providing faculty development workshops for teachers who teach core physics courses for technology programs and other programs. These workshops have been designed to acquaint the participants with the integration and implementation of emerging technology and active learning strategies. These workshops provided extensive and intensive, collaborative experiences for participants with workshop materials that made it possible for participants to implement the workshop ideas in their classrooms.

column5: Design and Construction of an Electron Diffractometer for Thin Film Studies
column15: Erick Blomberg, Bradley Univ. Dept. of Physics
column18: This talk will discuss the physics behind the study of epitaxial growth of thin films through analysis of the intensity variations of features diffracted from a growing surface, and an analysis of the diffraction spot profiles. Details of the authors' design and construction of a medium energy electron diffractometer (MEED) will be presented.

column5: Applicability of the MPEX Survey in Japanese Introductory Physics Class
column15: Michi Ishimoto, Kochi Univ. of Technology
column18: The MPEX Survey translated into Japanese has been investigated as to whether it is applicable in probing Japanese students' expectations toward learning physics. The participants in this survey were Japanese students (majoring in material science, biology, or chemical engineering) in an introductory physics course. The survey results show a large gap between the expectations of the "experts" and the students in comparison to the results obtained with U.S. students. When the results of this survey were compared with those in the U.S., three differences were apparent. First, the ratios of the neutral answers, which cannot be classified in either the favorable or unfavorable category, were considerably larger. Second, the change in answers from the beginning and from the end of the course was quite small, especially in the "reality" cluster, in which a large drop was shown in the U.S. Third, the results exhibit a low favorable ratio in the "coherence" and the "math" cluster.

column5: Force Distribution on Surface of Accelerated Block
column15: Pontus Ahlqvist, Univ. of Central Florida
column18: In most introductory physics classes, one is taught to deal with contact forces. However, a great simplification is often introduced. Rather than treating forces as distributions which they in fact are, students are taught to replace this rather complicated approach with that of single forces acting from some geometrically sound point. In this project we have tackled a relatively common problem of determining the forces involved when a truck accelerates a homogeneous box at a high enough rate in order to make it seemingly stick to the truck?s front. However, rather than taking the approach normally taken (i.e. point forces), we shall consider the forces being described as distributions.

column5: Setup for Creating White-Light Holograms in the Undergraduate Laboratory
column15: Harry E. Bates
column18: A laboratory setup for making white-light holograms will be presented along with details of a method to reliably make holograms in a single laboratory period. This setup has been used as one component of an experiment in the Light and Color course at Towson University for a number of years. Recent changes in the developing technique have greatly reduced the time required to complete the experiment.

column5: The initiation of TA-student interactions in tutorials
column15: Rachel E Scherr, Univ. of Maryland
column17: Rosemary S Russ, Tom Bing, Ray Hodges
column18: At the University of Maryland we videotaped several semesters of tutorials as part of a large research project. A particular research task required us to locate examples of students calling the TAs over for assistance with a physics question. To our surprise, examples of this kind of interaction were difficult to find. We undertook a systematic study of TA-student interactions in tutorial: in particular, how are the interactions initiated? Do the students call the TA over for help with a particular issue, does the TA stop by spontaneously, or does the worksheet require a discussion with the TA at that point? The initiation of the interaction is of particular interest because it provides evidence of the motivation for and purpose of the interaction. This talk will present the results of the study.

column5: Elliptical Orbit: 1/r^2 Force
column15: Maria L Mazzino, Univ. of Louisiana at Lafayette
column17: Jeffrey Prentis, Bryan Fulton, Carol Hesse
column18: Newton's proof of the connection between elliptical orbits and inverse-square forces ranks among the "top ten" calculations in the history of science. This time-honored calculation is a highlight in an upper-level mechanics course. It would be worthwhile if students in introductory physics could prove the relation, elliptical orbit -> 1/r^2 force, without having to rely on upper-level mathematics. We introduce a simple procedure - Newton's Recipe - that allows students to readily and accurately deduce the algebraic form of force laws from a geometric analysis of orbit shapes. Newton's Recipe is based on a hidden gem in Newton's Principia - the force formula F QR/(SPxQT)2. Given any kind of orbital curve (elliptical, spiral, ?) students deduce the force simply by measuring the orbital shape parameters (QR, SP, QT) with a ruler. In our "Orb Lab", students solve the celebrated Kepler Problem: Given an ellipse, find the force. The class draws a large elliptical orbit. The orbit is cut into small pieces - orbital arcs. Each student gets his or her own arc and measures the force responsible for the shape of their arc. Students uncover a simple pattern in the variation of the force along the ellipse. In essence, the class discovers one of the most fundamental laws of nature - the law of gravity - using string, tacks, and a ruler, along with a little help from Galileo, Newton, and Kepler.

column5: Reminiscences of Project PSSC Physics
column15: Edwin L Goldwasser, University of Illinois (retired)
column18: In 1956 F. Wheeler Loomis, Head of the University of Illinois physics department, invited members to help the recently formed PSSC Steering Committee create a new high school physics course. I volunteered and attended an orientation meeting at MIT in December 1956. There it was agreed that a totally new approach to teaching high school physics was needed. Its centerpiece would be a new textbook that would be supported by new classroom demonstrations, new laboratory experiments a lab manual, movies, and a teacher's guide. The Illinois group produced the teacher's guide to the text, clarifying its relationship to the philosophy and rationale underlying the new course. We arranged for trial teaching of PSSC physics at our University High School and sent feedback to the authors at MIT. Members of our group wrote and rewrote two major sections of the text. I will describe a few interesting adventures associated with my PSSC activities.

column5: TOPS: A Summer Program Encouraging Physics Majors Towards Pre-College Teaching
column15: Ted Ducas, Wellesley College
column18: TOPS (Teaching Opportunities in Physical Science) is a six-week summer program for physics majors. TOPS is hosted by MIT and is sponsored by the Center for Ultracold Atoms at MIT and Harvard. The goal is to provide students who are considering a teaching career with an experience that might inspire them to follow that path. Participants work in two teams of four, each team under the supervision of an experienced secondary school teacher. They design hands-on curricula based on themes connected to the CUA's research and teach them to middle school students at the Museum of Science in Boston and to high school students at MIT. The program also includes talks by the CUA investigators, lab visits, and social activities. TOPS is now in its fourth year.

column5: Physics213: Learning to Find and Evaluate Websites
column15: Pat Viele, Cornell University
column18: Studies have shown that students go first to the Internet to find information. Many educators have expressed concern about that. To learn more about the situation, Professor Wheeler and I designed some assignments for his physics213 class (summer, 2005). We had three goals: students will learn some history of the concepts being studied in the class students will learn to search the Internet effectively students will learn to evaluate the information they find on the Internet. There were 25 students in the class. The majority were sophomore or junior engineering students. We found the results to be very interesting and want to share them with you.

column5: Between Cookbook and Open-ended Research: Bridging the Gap
column15: John W Zwart, Dordt College
column18: In introductory labs it can be a challenge to help students make the transition from following a set of directions to thinking through what is needed in a genuine research project. One fruitful approach is to have students find an experiment or demonstration in TPT or AJP and perform it. Student "ownership" of something they have selected is high; they are willing to expend the effort to make things work. I will provide details and examples of how this approach is implemented.

column5: An Inexpensive Demonstration of Light Ray Focusing
column15: John W Zwart, Dordt College
column18: Students sometimes miss the link between demonstrations of image production with lenses and 2-D ray tracing techniques to locate images. An easy to implement demonstration uses a clear miniature Christmas tree light as a near "point source" and shows how a lens can produce a light cone which narrows down to the focus point. Multiple lights can be used to demonstrate image formation. Implementation details will be provided.

column5: How Technology and Dormitory Climate Can Affect Student Performance
column15: Bryndol A Sones, United States Military Academy
column18: Methods for improving the physics educational development for undergraduate students often rest with student activities in the classroom. Large strides can also be made from examining what and how students can learn outside of the classroom. At the U.S. Military Academy where introductory physics enrollment is approximately 1100, cadets are grouped into 32 organizations called "companies." A study was done by surveying cadets in order to identify levels of technological acceptance and organizational priorities that may contribute or detract from physics educational development.

column5: The Open Source Physics Library and Curricular Material
column15: Wolfgang Christian, Davidson College
column18: The Open Source Physics (OSP) project has developed a Java library and an easy to use xml vocabulary for the development of physics software and the distribution of Web-based curricular material. This technology enables us to develop new curricular materials; teach computational physics; store parameters, initial conditions, and results from a computer simulation; associate a simulation, a set of initial conditions, and a narrative into a topical unit; and combine topical units into a curriculum module that can be further adapted and customized by users. We have used the OSP framework to author and organize curricular material from computational physics, classical mechanics, E&M;, statistical physics, and quantum mechanics. Examples will be available on CD.
column19: Partially funded by NSF grant DUE-0442581.

column5: Education Software and Student Learning
column15: Wolfgang Christian, Davidson College
column18: What is needed by the physics education community is not another computer program (although programs are important), but a synthesis of curriculum development, computational physics, computer science, and physics education research that will be useful for students and adaptable for teachers wishing to write their own simulations and develop their own curricular material. The Internet, Java, and extensible markup language (xml) may enable such a synthesis. Examples of Open Source Physics curricular material will be presented and its effectiveness will be discussed.

column5: Undergraduate Physics Students and the Internet
column15: Richard M Wheeler, State Univ. of N.Y. College at Cortland
column18: Most college students use the Internet routinely as a research tool In talks with Cornell librarian Pat Viele I posed the following questions: how do students go about searching the Web, what criteria do students use to evaluate information they obtain from the Web, are students aware of plagiarism issues when they use the Web, and does it make sense to embed an Internet skills component into a physics class. In this talk I will briefly describe my experiences in an introductory, 6-week physics course I taught at Cornell last summer.

column5: They're just Gurrls!
column15: Elizabeth Chesick, Baldwin School
column18: Teaching experiences gleaned from over 40 years of teaching high school physics to girls in girls preparatory schools will be presented. Included will be some research and accounts of interactions of girls from all girls classes with sturents from coed and all boys classes. The introduction of "Physics First" will be also be discussed.

column5: Incorporating Project-based Learning into Two-Year Algebra-based Physics Program
column15: Joshua B Phiri, Florence-Darlington Technical College
column18: Industry-based projects have become a critical part of our physics instruction in our algebra-based physics course. We have been using a Project Driven Learning Process that encourages problem solving and teamwork skills. The open-ended industry based projects take on many modes of presentation to ensure the creativity of students. We problem scenarios reflect workplace/industry problems as closely as possible, while at the same time, covering the appropriate subject matter content. Problem scenarios provide a context and purpose for learning. Multiple possible solutions to the Project Scenario lead students to the correct applications of physics principles, design features and mathematical calculations. The student teams are required to turn in a written report and to make oral presentation of their solution to the entire class for each project. Allowing the students to make presentations to their peers leads deeper understanding of the physics concepts. In this talk we will share some of the ideas that we have used to motivate students to become actively involved in their own learning.

column5: Microfabrication and X-ray Scattering: New Tools for Studying RNA Folding
column15: Lois Pollack, Cornell University
column18: Large biological molecules like proteins and RNA, carry out their functions by folding to well-defined three-dimensional structures. We are interested in the physical interactions that direct this self-assembly process. By combining microfabricated flow cells with sychrotron x-ray scattering, we have gained insight into the earliest steps of protein and RNA folding. A recent series of experiments indicates that the critical, first stage of RNA folding is dominated by electrostatic interactions.

column5: Modeling the 2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami for Introductory Physics Students
column15: Gregory A DiLisi, John Carroll University
column18: We develop materials to address student interest in the Indian Ocean tsunami of December 2004. We discuss the physical characteristics of tsunamis and some of the specific data regarding the 2004 event. Finally, we create an easy-to-make "tsunami tank" to run simulations in the classroom. The simulations exhibit three dramatic signatures of tsunamis, namely, as a tsunami moves into shallow water, its amplitude increases, its wavelength and speed decrease, and its leading edge becomes increasingly steep as if to break or crash. Using our tsunami tank, these realistic features are easy to observe in the classroom and evoke an enthusiastic response from students.

column5: A Curiosity Cabinet of Gedanken Experiments
column15: Daniel Kleppner, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
column18: Gedanken experiments are intended to help reveal new physical principles but are not seriously proposed to be executed. Einstein's elevator and Schroedinger's cat are two famous examples. I will discuss some experiments in the gedanken tradition that actually have been carried out, and the new physics that followed.

column5: Bridging Coursework to the Real World
column15: Jeffrey Marx, McDaniel College
column18: One commonly held goal of general physics instructors is to have their students see that the material they are learning about in class really helps them better understand and appreciate the physical world around them. Unfortunately, instruction often fails to establish a framework in which those connections can be built. In the fall of 2005, we administered ten real-world scenarios to one group of two high school honors physics classes (N ~ 30/class) at various times throughout the term. Generally, we asked the students to relate specific ideas of class to the scenarios simply for the sake of making the connection, not to solve any problem. To gauge the impact our intervention, we administered the EBAPS as a pre-test and post-test to both groups. In this talk, we'll share our results and offer suggestions to help instructors create a learning environment that fosters real-world connections.

column5: PhysTEC: Addressing a National Need in Physics Teacher Preparation
column15: Theodore W Hodapp, American Physical Society
column18: This project, The Physics Teacher Education Coalition, is setting out to help produce more better-prepared physics and physical science teachers. With primary funding by the National Science Foundation, and joint support from APS, AAPT and AIP, the project's goals include a) establishing a network of institutions that are deeply engaged in science preparation of future teachers, b) providing compelling evidence of the importance and success of ideas and components central to preparing science teachers, c) engaging physics and education faculty in collaborating in the preparation of these teachers, and d) using joint resources of the AAPT, AIP and APS to promote and disseminate these ideas and programs. At its heart, this project is about how we engage physics departments in this critical mission. This presentation will highlight some of the results, directions, and initiatives of the project.

column5: Concept Maps: Representing How Students Link Together Chemistry
column15: Gayle Nicoll, Metropolatin Community College
column18: A novel method is described for coding concept maps for research and analysis purposes. The coding system rates the use, the stability, and the complexity of each link. This coding system was successfully applied to a sample of 56 complex concept maps that had been generated from student interviews on the topic of chemical bonding. The coding system is of particular use when analyzing complex concept maps with a large number of concept nodes and links. The system described here was also particularly useful for assessing complex, non-hierarchical concept maps.

column5: Facilitating the Transition of Undergraduate from Classical to Quantum Physics
column15: Garett W Yoder
column18: A teaching approach of developing both the classical and quantum mechanical solutions to three simple physical systems is suggested. The solutions are directly compared by using the classical equations of motion to determine a probability density function for the classical system. This function is compared to the probability density function for the quantum mechanical stationary state of the same energy. The nonclassical behavior of the quantum mechanical systems is thus made more distinct. Further, this comparison allows students to gain experience using probability functions to describe physical systems and to see how the quantum mechanical solutions reduce to classical behavior in the high-energy/short-wavelength limit. As an example, the analysis of the classical and quantum bouncer will be presented.

column5: Plasma Physics in Undergraduate E&M; Courses
column15: Ramon E Lopez, Florida Institute of Technology
column18: Plasma physics is not a subject typically found at undergraduate level, or even at the graduate level. On the other hand, the basis of plasma physics is electromagnetism and the motion of charged particles. This presentation will discuss various topics commonly found in both introductory and upper-division electricity and magnetism classes where examples from plasma physics may facilitate student understanding or provide interesting, real-life examples of electromagnetism in action.

column5: Use of Response Systems at the U.S. Military Academy
column15: Corey Gerving, United States Military Academy
column18: This paper will highlight the effectiveness of individual response systems (Responsive Innovations RF response cards) during a test semester of introductory calculus-based physics at the United States Military Academy. Throughout the duration of the semester, the traditional lectures have been replaced with Peer Instruction, and the student responses are collected using the response cards and the software package Join-In, which meshes smoothly with PowerPoint. The test class consists of 71 students, all of whom are currently in remedial math classes. I will asses effectiveness based on three methods: problem solving, Force Concept Inventory (FCI) results, and student survey results. Problem solving will be assessed by administering the same final exam as a similar population of students from the previous year. The FCI was administered prior to the beginning of the semester, and will be administered again at the end of the semester. I administer a course end survey which asks students their feelings about the effectiveness of the response cards as a method of learning. Lastly, I will outline some considerations in the implementation of the specific response cards we used, as well as future plans for my work.
column19: Sponsored by the New Faculty Workshop.

column5: Manipulating Mental Images and the Application of the Biot-Savart Law
column15: Ramon E Lopez, Florida Institute of Technology
column18: The determination of the magnetic field of a current system is a manifestly 3-D task, yet it is generally illustrated with 2-D representations. Students must form 3-D mental images from these 2-D representations, then manipulate those mental images to arrive at the answer. We present evidence that student application of the Biot-Savart law can be handicapped by the cognitive load imposed by the manipulation of mental images. We also show that providing 3-D visualization of a complex current system significantly improved student success in determining the magnetic field of that current system.

column5: Using Physics Education Technology to Replace Lectures with Active Learning Exercises
column15: Dennis M Robbins
column18: The Physics Education Technology (PhET) project (Wieman & Perkins, 2005; Perkins et al., 2006) created interactive Java-based applets which allow students to explore and visualize fundamental physics concepts. The PhET website (http://www.colorado.edu/physics/phet/web-pages/index.html) includes over three dozen computer simulations addressing the breadth of introductory physics topics. Using PhET materials, curricula were written to replace the lecture portion of a General Physics course for non-majors at a large multicultural two-year college in New York City. These curricula are active learning exercises inspired by the findings Physics Education Research. Several diagnostic surveys were administered to each student as a pre- and posttest to assess the reception of these materials. The surveys included Lawson's Classroom Test of Scientific Reasoning (CTSR) and the Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey (CLASS). The results from CTSR and CLASS are reported here and implications for using PhET materials to replace the traditional physics lecture are discussed.

column5: Summary Discussion
column15: Michael D Wolter, Muncie Central High School
column18: This wrap-up discussion will allow the audience to comment on these diverse examples teacher leadership and the short and long term impact of the K-12 teacher's actions on the specific programs that they supported.

column5: Sustainability and Use of Resources at Present Rates of Production.
column15: Albert A Bartlett, University of Colorado at Boulder
column18: A government minister of Australia wrote that Australia's coal will last 110 years at present rates of production. If we assume that coal production P(t)(tons/y) follows a Gaussian Hubbert curve, we can construct a family of curves of the future path of P(t), each of which is consistent with the 110 years. This family of curves divides the graph of(P,t) into "allowed" and "forbidden" areas. Knowledge of the present dP/dt allows one member of the family to be identified as the most probable future path P(t) which reaches a maximum, the Hubbert Peak, and then declines rapidly toward zero. Sustainability requires a curve that declines exponentially.

column5: Learning and Teaching Observational Astronomy
column15: Donna L Messina
column18: The Physics Education Group at the University of Washington conducts an intensive six-week NSF Summer Institute in Physics and Physical Science for In-service K-12 teachers. The emphasis is on providing teachers an opportunity to develop in-depth understanding of the science topics they teach, including observational astronomy. Guided by the research-based Physics by Inquiry curriculum, teachers construct a conceptual model that accounts for the apparent motion of the sun and the phases of the moon. In an associated Academic-year Continuation Course, teachers work with peers and with members of the PEG to implement inquiry teaching and learning in their classrooms. Many adapt the curriculum they teach to reflect their own experiences in learning observational astronomy through guided inquiry. Research results will be presented that demonstrate the impact on the teachers' own understanding and the impact on their students.

column5: The Role of Computation in Undergraduate Physics at the Univ. of Cincinnati
column15: Richard G Gass
column18: I will discuss how computation is changing the undergraduate physics curriculum at the University of Cincinnati. Defined broadly, computation encompasses visualization and symbolic calculation as well the more traditional numerical work. All three of these aspects of computation are used in both our laboratory and lecture courses. I will describe our current efforts and talk about future directions. I will also discuss how these fit into the broader statewide initiative in computational science.

column5: Wanted: More Women in Physics Leadership Positions
column15: Judy R Franz, American Physical Society
column18: AAPT has had five women presidents in its 75-year history, and APS has had four in its 107-year history. Although the rate has been increasing, the numbers are still very small. This is typical of scientific leadership positions in general both in the U.S. and internationally. Why are the numbers so small and what can we do about it? I will try to give some answer while discussing what leadership entails and describing my position as Executive Officer of APS.

column5: Student Competencies and Learning Outcomes for Physics and Mathematics Majors
column15: Natalia Schkolnikov, Hampton University
column18: This presentation reports development of student competencies and learning outcomes for physics and mathematics majors of Hampton University. This research is a part of a broader program aimed at development of student competencies in promoting learning, building of character, and preparation of promising students for position of leadership and service. Answering the questions what our graduates should know and what skills and abilities they should possess to be competitive on the national and international levels, is particularly important for students from minority groups underrepresented in STEM majors (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics). In this presentation, we identify essential competencies for physics and mathematics majors as learning objectives and for each learning objective determine learning outcomes that should be measured at the department level. Assessment procedures for specific courses will be discussed as well. In addition, we present examples from each step of identifying essential competencies, learning outcomes, and assessment measures.

column5: Frictionless Motion on the Surface of a Rotating Parabola
column15: Carl E Mungan, U.S. Naval Academy
column18: Suppose that a bucket of water is spun about a vertical axis through its center with constant angular speed. The surface of the water will quickly settle into an equilibrium parabolic shape. Now suppose that a ping-pong ball is placed partway up this parabolic surface, with an initial velocity that matches the tangential velocity of the water at that location. (For example, it could be dropped vertically from an arm clamped to the bucket.) The ball will then remain at rest relative to the water. What happens if the ball is now given a small radial nudge?

column5: Math Animated: Calculus Courseware for Undergraduate Physics Students
column15: Samuel Dagan, Tel-Aviv University
column18: A courseware, to be hosted at the web, based on a course called "Mathematical Introduction for Physicists," given to undergraduate students at the Tel-Aviv University, has been developed. The courseware called "Math Animated" is to be hosted by the Web, and available that way to the students, on any PC at home or in a library. Furthermore, this is not just a textbook with the learned material, examples and exercises, but takes advantage of the modern technology of interactive and animated graphics, which makes complicated concepts easy to understand. The animations can be projected by the teacher in class, and accessed afterwards at any time by the students. The interactivity helps the students, to learn more effectively the material at their leisure.

column5: Franklin's Electrical Experiments and Physics Teaching
column15: Robert A Morse, St. Albans School
column18: Benjamin Franklin's elegant conceptual explanations of electrical phenomena in terms of conservation of "electrical fluid" refocused attention from mechanisms of repulsion to the underlying transfer of charge, and began quantitative thinking about electrification. Awarded the Copley medal, granted membership in both the British and French Royal Societies, Franklin was referred to in his lifetime as the "Newton of electricity." The clarity of his writing coupled with the fame gained from the Philadelphia Experiment on lightning mark a turning point in theories of electricity. In celebration of the tercentenary of Franklin's birth, this talk will hit some historical highlights, take a look at Franklin's accounts of his experiments and consider their present pedagogical possibilities to help students develop explanatory models.

column5: Introducing Biomedical Applications and Projects to Pre-Med Students in Qatar
column15: Roger Hinrichs, Weill Cornell Medical College in Qatar
column17: Roger Hinrichs, Roger Hinrichs, Roger Hinrichs, Roger Hinrichs
column18: An integrated six year program of study allowing students in the Middle East to pursue a career in medicine was begun in 2002 by Cornell University in partnership with the Qatar Foundation for Education. The two year pre-medical program component focuses on the sciences. Interest in the applications of biology and medicine in the required university physics course is easily attained but the selection and conduction of projects for these students (18-19 years of age) can be challenging. In addition to an overview of this course, details on specific experimental projects will be provided. These include electrostimulation of muscles, neurons and simulation of the action potential, blood pressure and gravity, airflow in lungs, etc.

column5: Characterization of -Amyloid (1-42) Aggregation by Dynamic Light Scattering
column15: Kathy R Chaurasiya, Simmons College
column17: Patrick Johnson, Bruce Gray, Basia Szul
column18: Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the development of amyloid plaques in the brain. These plaques are primarily composed of BETA-amyloid, a 40- or 42-amino acid peptide, denoted A BETA(1-40) or A BETA(1-42). Synthetic A BETA (1-42) forms fibrils in vitro which are similar to the core of amyloid plaques. 4.1 kDa A BETA monomers aggregate into protofibrils, which are rod-like structures approximately 4-8 nm in diameter and 5-200 nm in length. Pallitto and Murphy determined that protofibrils are more toxic to neurons than fibrils, so it is particularly important to characterize the mechanism of A BETA aggregation from monomer to protofibril formation. We use dynamic light scattering as a technique to investigate the structure and dynamics of A BETA aggregation. As the solution of A BETA in water ages, we observe a corresponding increase in the size distribution of the A BETA aggregates present. Our results demonstrate that the rate of aggregation is highly concentration-dependent.

column5: Physics and Industry: Project-based Learning Combined with Systematic Inventive Thinking
column15: Shay Soffer, The Weizmann Institute of Science
column18: Six years ago, we have started the "Physics and Industry" program as collaboration between the science teaching department at the Weizmann Institute of Science and the electro-optics industry. In this program, high-school physics students in the 11th-12th grade carry out a project in which they solve an authentic design problem. The students are mentored by engineers from the electro-optics industry, by their teachers and by experts of Systematic Inventive Thinking. In the program they study electro-optics and "Systematic Inventive Thinking" that involves new problem solving methods; they apply these methods and their physics knowledge; they carry out experiments and build an actual artifact. The students present the project in an external oral examination, and get credit as part of the official matriculation. We have investigated different aspects of students' learning such as the ability to offer alternative solutions, decision making based on various constraints, and reflection about design and investigation processes. The results indicate high achievement in the matriculation exams and high satisfaction of the students.

column5: Pulsars and Extreme Physics
column15: Jocelyn Bell Burnell, Univ. of Oxford Astrophysics
column18: Pulsars were discovered almost 40 years ago. What do we know about them now and what have they taught us about the extremes of physics? With an average density comparable to that of the nucleus, magnetic fields around 10^8 Tesla and speeds close to c, these objects have stretched our understanding of the behaviour of matter. They serve as extremely accurate clocks with which to carry out precision experiments in relativity. Created in cataclysmic explosions, pulsars are a (stellar) form of life after death. After half a billion revolutions most pulsars finally die, but amazingly some are born again to yet another, even weirder, afterlife. Pulsar research continues lively, delivering exciting, startling and almost unbelievable results.

column5: Twenty-Seven Years with PSSC
column15: McLaurin Smith-Williams, Christian Brothers High School
column18: PSSC has been in use at Christian Brothers High School in Memphis, Tennessee since 1963 with this instructor using it since he came to the school in 1978. Some reminiscences are provided concerning those early years and the evolution of the course to the present day.

column5: Force Distribution on Surface of Accelerated Box
column15: Pontus Ahlqvist, University of Central FLorida
column18: In introductory physics courses, one of the most common problems encountered is that of a box stuck in front of an accelerating car. The students learn how to deal with the forces involved assuming that the object is a point mass. However, we have found no work that examines the problem under realistic conditions. In this talk we shall revisit the problem from exactly this perspective and we will argue that the equilibrium conditions are not sufficient to provide a unique solution. However, using additional information that can be derived from the deformation of the object and the car, a solution can be obtained.

column5: Women and Physics: How Tightly Was the Door Closed?
column15: Ruth Howes, Marquette University
column18: Although their contributions are all too frequently left out of formal histories, women have played significant roles in the progress of physics during the last century. Their numbers are not large, and they are clustered in developing subfields of physics and in astronomy. However, when they are given the opportunity to do physics, women have consistently demonstrated both the ability to do good physics and enthusiasm for doing it. AAPT has traditionally worked to foster participation by women and members of underrepresented groups. We must continue to maintain a climate within the organization that welcomes all comers as friends and offers them opportunities for leadership.

column5: Professional Development for Secondary School Physics Teachers in Developing Countries
column15: Priscilla W Laws
column18: A World Conference on Physics and Sustainable Development was held Oct. 31, 2006, to Nov. 2, 2006, in South Africa. A major conference goal was to explore ways that physics can benefit undeveloped regions in the world and discuss related action plans. As co-chair of the Conference's Physics Education Planning Committee, I will report on progress on post-conference action plans to develop professional development of activity-based physics workshops for secondary school physics teachers in Asia, Sub-saharan Africa, and Latin America. In addition, I will describe how educators from the United States can contribute to the effort to create professional development opportunities throughout the developing world that should also be beneficial to teachers in the U.S.

column5: The Schon Affair
column15: Bernard J Feldman, university of Missouri-St. Louis
column18: Less than five years ago, Hendrik Schon, a physicist at Bell Laboratories, awed the world and was under consideration for a Nobel Prize for a series of remarkable results in the field of electronic devices fabricated out of organic solids. A brief history of this most famous fraud in the history of physics will be presented. Also to be briefly discussed are questions about the gullibility of the physics community, where the responsibility lies for this fraud, the place for negative results in the physics literature, and the need to educate both scientists and nonscientists that science is very much a human activity.

column5: Texas Partnerships That Worked?
column15: Robert Clark
column18: This presentation will report on two university--K-12 Partnerships (PEP and TTOPS), which have involved Texas A&M; University over the past two decades. The impact of these programs and the lessons learned will be discussed.

column5: Teaching EM Waves via Analogies
column15: Noah S Podolefsky, University of Colorado at Boulder
column18: Previous studies have demonstrated that analogies can be used promote student learning in physics. We build on this prior work to explore the use of analogy by students in a large introductory college physics course. In the first large-scale study of its kind, we demonstrate that different analogies can lead to different forms of student reasoning when taught in this environment. When learning about EM waves, we find that students explicitly map characteristics either of waves on strings or sound waves to EM waves, depending upon which analogy students were taught. We find that both analogies are useful for teaching particular characteristics of EM waves, and our findings suggest that teaching by layering one analogy after the other is, perhaps, the optimal approach.

column5: Interactive Color Photometry of Star Clusters Using an Inexpensive CCD
column15: Donald F Collins, Warren Wilson College
column18: A highly engaging activity has been developed for students to examine color-enhanced telescope images of open stellar clusters. The images have been acquired using an inexpensive non-cooled Meade DSI Pro CCD camera. The camera comes with blue, green, and red filters as well as an IR block filter in order to obtain reasonably high quality blue, green, and red images. After alignment of the three-color images, users can "point and click" on each star in a cluster image on a computer screen. This program, written in Matlab, immediately plots each star's measured luminosity as a function of measured color index, thus providing an interactive plotting of a Hertzsprung Russell diagram. The algorithm will be briefly described and demonstrated. Students have responded well to this application in general astronomy. Some student reports have shown surprising misconceptions about the nature of H-R diagrams, which will be addressed in future applications.

column5: Learning Probability and Probability Density in a Quantum Physics Course
column15: Michael C Wittmann, University of Maine
column17: Jeffrey T Morgan, Roger E Feeley
column18: As part of a new course for nonscience majors, Intuitive Quantum Physics, members of the University of Maine Physics Education Research Laboratory have created a series of activities for teaching probability and probability density. Students have trouble learning the target concepts, such as using the ratio of time in a region to total time in all regions. Instead, they often: pattern match to previously studied situations, reason incorrectly about macroscopic elements of the system, use the gambler's fallacy, and use ensemble results rather than expectation values to predict future events. We present data from pretests and examinations to show the progression of student understanding during instruction.
column19: Sponsored in part by NSF grant #DUE-0410895.

column5: And Then A Collision Occurs
column15: Dave J Van Domelen, Kansas State University
column18: While doing research on the decomposition of more complex (i.e., multiple concepts) mechanics problems by students, it was noticed that conservation of momentum sub-problems were either ignored or treated incorrectly. An online survey followed by student interviews attempted to determine some of the reasons why this happens, and a brief statement of results will be presented, including some misapplications of energy conservation principles.

column5: Tales from the Front: Five Years of Pre-Service Inquiry
column15: John K Elwood, East Stroudsburg University of Pennsylvania
column18: In 2001, the Collaborative for Excellence in Teacher Preparation in Pennsylvania (CETP-PA) helped support the development of an inquiry based physics course for preservice teachers at East Stroudsburg University (ESU). The course was somewhat unique in that it was designed exclusively for elementary education majors, and was motivated to a large extent by conversations with students in this major. As the course matured between 2001 and 2005, a varied array of techniques and approaches were explored. Some were wildly successful. Others were less so. In this talk, we discuss student performance and attitudes, but primarily focus on some of the techniques found to be most successful throughout the enterprise.

column5: Industrial Strength Physics: Teaching Academic Rigor and Relevance in Applied Settings
column15: Bill Semrau, Van Buren Intermediate School District
column18: The Van Buren Intermediate School District Technology Center's Integrated Academics program has met the call from State and National Standards documents to increase the academic rigor for high school students. Certified Physics Teachers were hired to work collaboratively with the Career and Technology Education instructors. The curriculum they developed meets both the academic needs of their students as well as prepares them for careers in various technical fields. Several examples of custom tailored application-based physics lessons will be presented from the Engineering/Manufacturing & Industrial Technology Career Pathways.

column5: Representation, Analogy, and Solving Physics Problems
column15: Noah D Finkelstein, University of Colorado at Boulder
column18: We find that both the representational format of problems (math, verbal, pictorial, etc.) and the use of analogy play critical roles in student approaches to solving physics problems. In two lines of related research, we examine student use of analogy and representation. Both lines of work draw from a socio-cultural perspective by framing the use of representations and analogies as tools in the context of solving problems in physics. We demonstrate that student reasoning and performance can be dependent, often strongly so, on the representational format of the questions asked, and while students often have robust conceptions of which representational format they are best at using, student performance on different representations does not correlate with their representational preferences. Furthermore, we find that both micro-level (particular forms of representation) and macro (instructional approach) features can strongly affect student ability to solve physics problems represented in various formats. We further observe that representations appear to play a critical role in students' abilities to effectively use analogies, and in fact posit that creating blends of conceptual domains through the use of common representation is one mechanism by which analogies occur in physics. In the first large-scale (N>100) study of its kind in physics, we find that analogies can be taught and that these affect student reasoning.

column5: Assessing New Technologies as Effective Tools for Learning Physics
column15: Graham W Dettrick, Monash University - Australia
column18: A randomized research-control mixed methods process for the assessment of physics learning can be useful. Our process included both instructor and student assessments. Our process included pre- and post-interviews, a physics and technology attitude questionnaire, a preferred teaching methods questionnaire and a preferred model of science questionnaire as well as progressive student evaluations and a final summative achievement test. Our project compared a new technologies approach to a conventional textbook/laboratory approach in a freshman university physics course. The research outcomes led to an understanding of reasons behind an unexpected and large mismatch between instructors' and students' outlooks regarding teaching methods, learning experiences, and evaluation procedures.

column5: Modeling in Physical Science for Urban Science Teachers in Grades 6-10
column15: Michele A Korb, Marquette University
column17: Anna Zimmerman, Michael Politano, Joan L. Whipp
column18: From 2004 to 2006, 18 physical science teachers from 10 high needs middle and high schools in the city of Milwaukee participated in Modeling Workshops for Physical Science. This project teamed faculty from the Department of Physics and the School of Education at Marquette University. Unlike standard modeling workshops for high school physics teachers, these were designed for physical science teachers working in grades 6-10. The curriculum was adapted from materials developed by action research teams at Arizona State University. In addition to the workshops, throughout the two-year project teachers shared resources and experiences with modeling via an online community and benefited from on-site classroom mentoring by faculty from Marquette. In this talk, we will report on changes in teachers' content knowledge, attitudes and pedagogy as a result of this project.

column5: Why Having a Theory of Learning Changes How I Teach
column15: Edward F Redish, Unviersity of Maryland
column18: Learning how to teach is a skill typically learned by doing. For more than 30 years, I struggled, through trial and error, to improve the help I gave my students. After switching my research effort from nuclear physics to physics education more than a dozen years ago, I have studied (and developed) theories of learning and education. In many previous talks, I have discussed the cognitive and epistemological theories of learning I found most intriguing. In this talk, I focus on my own teaching and how the day-to-day activities of my teaching practice have changed as a result of my looking at teaching from a theoretical perspective.

column5: Uses and Limitations of Epistemological Surveys in Course Design
column15: Tim McCaskey, University of Maryland
column18: A specially designed introductory physics course helps students develop more sophisticated epistemologies and expectations (views about the nature of knowledge and learning in physics class). In subsequent incarnations of our course, tutorials haven't changed, but other components such as lecture slides, professor, fine-grained content coverage, and homework/exams have changed in various combinations. In each case, we used an epistemology/expectations survey, MPEX2, to measure changes in students' views over the semester. The results enable us to start to pin down which facets of the course contribute to students' epistemological development. Our analysis of these facets leads to two major results, one substantive and one methodological: (1) An epistemologically-focused professor or curriculum is insufficient; both are needed to achieve large MPEX2 gains. (2) A narrowly focused survey can detect subtle epistemological differences between courses that MPEX2 is too crude to catch.

column5: Women and Minorities in Physics: Current Data
column15: Michael Neuschatz, American Institute of Physics
column18: While physics enrollments have been rising recently at the high school, undergraduate and graduate levels, women and some minority groups remain seriously underrepresented at most levels. This talk will use data collected by the American Institute of Physics Statistical Research Center and other sources to paint of picture of the current levels of representation and recent progress, and try to identify the points at which the the sharpest drop-off in representation occurs for the various groups. A better understanding of those points may help in the effort to shape more effective intervention strategies.

column5: A Variation of the Method to Measure "g" Using a Simple Pendulum
column15: Jonathan P Arnold, University of Central Florida
column18: The simple pendulum is one of the most known and studied system of Newtonian mechanics. It also provides one of the most elegant and simple devices to measure the acceleration of gravity at any location. In this talk, we will revisit the problem of measuring the acceleration of gravity using a simple pendulum and will present a modification to the standard technique that increases the accuracy of the measurement.

column5: More Industrial Strength Physics: Teaching Academics in Applied Settings
column15: Ken Mroczek, Van Buren Intermediate School District
column18: The Van Buren Intermediate School District Technology Center's Integrated Academics program has met the call from State and National Standards documents to increase the academic rigor for high school students. Certified physics teachers were hired to work collaboratively with the Career and Technology Education instructors. The curriculum they developed meets both the academic needs of their students as well as prepares them for careers in various technical fields. Several examples of custom tailored application-based physics lessons will be presented from the Engineering/Manufacturing & Industrial Technology Career Pathways.

column5: Dynamics of Heat Flow in a Metal Rod: An Experiment
column15: Bruce Thompson, Ithaca College
column18: Although steady state heat flow measurements are common in the undergraduate laboratory, dynamical measurements are not. An advanced undergraduate experiment is described which illustrates the dynamics of the flow of a pulse of heat in a long rod. Using a simple apparatus, the temperature as a function of time is measured at two positions on a metal rod. An analytical solution to the partial differential heat diffusion equation provides a preliminary model of the temperature as a function of distance and time. Estimates of the thermal conductivity and the heat capacity are obtained. Discrepancies between the data and the model lead to corrections in the model that require the use of numerical methods for solution and a rich understanding of heat flow behavior.

column5: Illuminating Teacher Learning of Technology-Enhanced Formative Assessment
column15: Ian D Beatty, University of Massachusetts
column17: William J Leonard, Allan P Feldman, William J Gerace
column18: Instructional technology is useless or harmful without the skill to use it in the service of sound pedagogy. Classroom response systems (CRS) can be employed for many purposes, including attendence-taking, drill and practice, checking understanding, and promoting knowlegde diffusion among students. We have developed a more radical and pedagogically sound model called Technology Enhanced Formative Assessment (TEFA), in which a CRS-mediated "question cycle" serves as the engine of student engagement, discussion, exploration of ideas, agile teaching, and robust learning. We will describe the model and a new five-year NSF-funded project researching how secondary school science teachers develop mastery with classroom response technology, highly interactive classroom discourse, and TEFA. A major thrust of the project is developing surveys, interview protocols, and classroom observation protocols to illuminate and track development of the many skills, strategies, and perspectives a teacher needs for such mastery.

column2: Math requirements for Physics First (9th grade) course
column5: Physics Without Filters
column15: Fred R Myers, Farmington Public School
column18: This presentation will focus on two aspects of a physics first sequence: 1) The change processes that our district navigated. 2) How our district deals with Issues raised by the huge discrepancies of student math skills. Our public school district has just completed its twelve year of teaching the "Right-Side-Up Science Sequence." For the past eight years this has been the curriculum for ALL of our students. We are committed to educating all of our students in the sciences, and do not take the position that physics should be reserved for the "best and brightest." One hurdle with which schools must grapple is the wide array of student mathematical skills brought to physics. We believe that math skills should not keep a student from experiencing the beauty and intrigue of physics. However, the math skills can be used to direct students to developmentally appropriate course levels. This presentation will explore how we deal with trigonometry and disparate algebra skills.

column5: The Physics Teacher: A Source of Ideas for Student Projects
column15: Andrew J Graham
column18: I will describe a number of projects, related to previous TPT articles, that I currently have students working on for publication. Examples include measurement of the acceleration of the Thompson jumping ring, analysis of an elliptic pendulum, and the simulation of a system of two radioactive species.

column5: How Do Physics Courses for Teachers Impact Their Teaching?
column15: Danielle B Harlow, University of Colorado, Boulder
column18: Physics education researchers have created specialized physics courses to meet the needs of elementary teachers. While there is evidence that such courses help teachers develop physics content knowledge, little is known about what teachers transfer from such courses into their teaching practices. Current research on the transfer of learning challenges researchers to move beyond assessing whether particular ideas or practices are transferred between contexts but rather to ask, What is transferred and how is it transformed in the new context? In this study, we focus on practicing elementary teachers' development and use of science discourse when learning physics in a specialized course for elementary teachers and when teaching about magnetism and electricity to third and fourth grade students. We examine how teachers talk about physics and how they do science through talk in these two contexts to infer how specialized physics courses help teachers teach science.

column5: The History of PASCO: Forty-Two Years of Physics Apparatus
column15: Paul Stockstad, PASCO
column18: The journey from a high school science project to today's PASCO included: some good products (and not so good products); product development with 100% success in the theoretical stage and a significantly lower percentage when it came to metal and electronics; the joys, and challenges, of working with the best customers in the world (physics educators); and major changes in apparatus produced by advancing technology.

column5: Demonstrations: A Bit of History, Nostalgia, and Nuances
column15: D. Rae Carpenter, Dick and Rae, Inc.
column18: A review of some of the demonstrators over the last three-quarter century including what they published and some comments about their style. Recent developments spreading down to middle school and kindergarten. What are we really teaching and more importantly, where do we go from here.

column5: Twenty-five Years of Vernier Software & Technology
column15: David Vernier, Vernier Software and Technology
column18: Vernier Software & Technology started with Apple II simulations and data collection through the game port. Over the years the company has written software and built sensors for Commodore 64, MS-DOS, eMate, Windows, Macintosh, TI calculators and Palm OS handhelds. This session will demonstrate some of this vintage software and hardware and present some of our favorite demonstrations, old and new. We will also offer some of our favorite physics jokes from our newsletter, the Caliper.

column5: Indiana's End of Course Assessment in Physics
column15: Michael D Wolter, Muncie Central High School
column18: The trends for standards based teaching and corresponding assessments has caused many states to implement their own course examinations. In Indiana a committee of high school and university representatives developed a new "end of course assessment" (ECA) in physics. Last year representatives of the INAAPT asked high school teachers attending the spring section meeting to voluntarily submit their student answer sheets at the end of the year for an item analysis study. An overview of the results will be presented along with the evolution section's proactive role in state physics curriculum and assessment.

column5: Evaluating and Improving Students' Responses to a Molecular Gas Question
column15: Michael J Sanger, Middle Tennessee State University
column18: In 1987, Nurrenbern and Pickering reported students' responses to a molecular-level gas law question that asked how the distribution of gas particles would change when the gas sample was cooled. This multiple-choice question has been used by several chemical educators since that time; however, none have described students' explanations for their choice. This paper will summarize students' molecular explanations of the question and describe three threats to the validity of this question. As a way of solving some of these validity threats, we created an animated version of the question and tested it with another set of students. Their responses, and the effect of the animated question on minimizing these threats to validity, will also be discussed.

column5: Two Balls, a Mirror, and a Puff of Air
column15: Richard E Berg, Department of Physics
column18: This paper will examine three "experiments" that have been discussed extensively in The Physics Teacher and my interactions with them. First, the racing balls demonstration, realized experimentally at the University of Maryland in about 1980. This simple problem can become rather complicated, providing a prime example of why physics demonstrations are important in class. Second, the perverted image created by a plane mirror and some of the interesting ways that people have had to describe it. Lamentably, this common issue confuses even many physics teachers who have not carefully considered it. Third, the Bernoulli Effect, as all too often it is misapplied to a variety of fluid flow problems, such as the airfoil, and suggestions for alternative explanations, such as the Coanda Effect, the Magnus Effect, and vortex shedding.

column5: An Undergraduate Physics Capstone Project at Eastern Michigan University
column15: James J Carroll, Eastern Michigan University
column18: The PHY 420 Capstone Project course was added to the physics curricula at Eastern Michigan University (EMU) to provide an opportunity for students to synthesize knowledge and skills while completing a group project. This year, students designed and evaluated a shield from charged particle radiation for a lunar base. The problem is relevant to human exploration of the moon and is not well-described. Students were divided into "teams of experts": a lunar environment team, a design team, and a computer simulation team. Experts from each team were then placed into groups, with each group developing its own design. Progress reports were given by each group member, and each group prepared a final design recommendation report. Their designs were presented at the EMU Undergraduate Symposium. In addition to the assigned classroom tasks, the poster will also describe the group presentations and the computer simulations that were developed to evaluate possible radiation shields.

column5: The Development of Workshop Physics -- a Laboratory Centered Approach to Teaching Introductory Physics
column15: Priscilla W Laws, Dickinson College
column18: By the mid-1980s it was clear from physics education research (or PER) findings that students can learn difficult physics concepts by confronting phenomena directly. Meanwhile, Robert Tinker, Ron Thornton, and others were doing pioneering development work on microcomputer-based laboratory tools (or MBL tools) that use sensors for the collection and instant analysis of data. This led several of us at Dickinson College to apply for a grant to develop laboratory-centered curricular materials to teach introductory physics by combining with outcomes of PER with the use of MBL tools. In this talk I will describe the early development of the Workshop Physics curricular materials and our collaboration with Ronald Thornton of the Tufts University Center from the Teaching of Science and Mathematics and David Sokoloff from the University of Oregon. I will also describe the evolution of techniques for teaching concepts, theory building, mathematical modeling skills, and experimental techniques without lectures.

column5: Discovering the PSSC
column15: Anthony P French, M.I.T.
column18: The paper describes the author's introduction to the PSSC via a workshop for prospective leaders of regional training institutes in 1962, and his subsequent experience in running such an institute in Columbia, South Carolina.

column5: Situating a Common Chain of Reasoning in Damped Harmonic Motion
column15: Eleanor C Sayre, University of Maine
column18: As part of ongoing research into cognitive processes and student thought, we have investigated the interplay between mathematics and physics resources in intermediate mechanics students. We present evidence from a reformed sophomore-level mechanics class which contains both both tutorial[1] and lecture components. In the context of writing Newton's Second Law for damped harmonic motion, students discuss the signs of the spring and damping forces. Using a grounded theory approach, we identify a common chain of reasoning in which a request for reasoning is followed by elaborative sense-making and checks for consistency, finishing with an optional appeal for group consensus. Our analysis provides evidence for a description of student thinking in terms of plasticity.
column19: Sponsored in part by NSF grants DUE-0441426 and DUE-0442388. [1] Ambrose, B (2004) "Investigating student understanding in intermediate mechanics: Identifying the need for a tutorial approach to instruction". Am. J. Phys 72, pp453-459

column5: Torque and a Non-Ferromagnetic Moving Conductor
column15: Ping Gu, Applied Physics Department,Hunan University
column17: Zhong Xie, Ying Zhu Wang, Jian Zhi Jian, Lin Xiao Chen
column18: In our previous work, the magnetic field distributing of the rectangular magnet was gained from the molecular current model. The relationship between the forces on the magnet and the magnetic field intensity, the velocity and the conductivity of the conductor was computed quantificationally with MATLAB when the magnet is fixed in a static state. Therefore, a new phenomenon is discovered and validated by experiment that a magnet can be driven to rotate by a non-ferromagnetic moving conductor. This paper focuses on the computing method of the torque resulting from the interaction between the magnet and the moving conductor when the magnet is rotating. At arbitrary time t, the angular velocity of the magnet around the symmetrical axis of itself under the driving of the moving conductor with velocity v is , and the angle between the planes of the magnet and the conductor is =t. Then the magnetic field is divided into vertical and horizontal components. And the analytic expression of the rotating torque resulting from the interaction at arbitrary time is deduced from Faraday's, Ohm's and Ampere's law. Finally the torque is computed quantificationally with certain parameters by using MATLAB.

column5: Teacher-in-Residence Outreach and Community College Activities
column15: Neil Anthony
column18: Some activities organized by or that involved the Ball State University 2005-2006 Teacher-in-Residence will be described including Society of Physics Students school visitations, Teacher Advisory Group meetings, and workshops. In addition, the developing relationship between Ball State University's Department of Physics and Astronomy and the Physical Sciences Program of Ivy Tech Community College of Indiana, East Central will be considered.

column5: Progress Toward Short Timescale Measurements in Ultracold Neutral Plasmas
column15: Lucas Willis, Rowan University
column18: An apparatus has been constructed to study electron dynamics in an ultracold neutral plasma. In order to probe these short (sub-microsecond) timescales of plasma evolution, provisions had to be made to prevent electron detector saturation and allow Rydberg (high principle quantum number) atom populations to be determined with ~10ns resolution. We will review progress made towards these measurements.

column5: Efforts to Revitalize an Undergraduate Physics Program
column15: A. Mina Katramatou, Kent State University
column18: The Physics Department of Kent State University has started an effort to overhaul its undergraduate program and increase the enrollment and retention of physics majors. The revised program is based on a new curriculum, new introductory physics labs, new student advising structure, creation of an environment of community for physics majors, and increased outreach efforts/high school student visits. The new curriculum aims at preparing students not only for entry into the graduate school but also into the industrial/high-tech and high school education workforce; it will streamline and consolidate the math beyond basic calculus required for upper level courses into a two-semester sequence and enable the students to customize their curriculum towards a research or a professional track. A background pilot study on the feasibility of converting the introductory physics course to an integrated one is under way. Feedback from the students so far has been very encouraging.

column5: Modeling of Thin Films of Small Organic Semiconductor Molecules
column15: Paulette Clancy, Cornell University
column18: Thin films of semiconducting small organic molecules like pentacene are under investigation for large area, mechanically flexible electronic displays. While considerable progress has been made towards fabricating organic electronic displays, there is still much to be learned about the link between structure and molecular packing of pentacene thin films and the growth mechanisms that produce these structures. We will present multiple length-scale simulations to understand how the performance of organic thin films is affected by the choice of organic compound, substrate surface, and deposition conditions.
