We will show how a combination of tight-binding simulations and ab initio Gaussian-98 calculations can help decipher experimental STM measurements, and how knowledge of the interactions between pairs of pentacene molecules as a function of orientation and the nature of the substrate can be used in Kinetic Monte Carlo simulations to predict mesoscale morphology diagrams.

column5: How Did I Measure the Index of Refraction
column15: Thomas B Greenslade, Jr., Kenyon College
column18: Of the devising of methods to measure the index of refraction of liquids and solids there seems to be no end. Ultimately, all techniques rely on Snell's law, employed in various geometries involving circular, triangular and parallel sided regions. In some cases the measurement of the critical angle is used to find the index of refraction. The talk will cover techniques and devices from the 18th-, 19th-, and 20th centuries.

column5: I.T.S. Physics: An Individualized Teaching System to Differentiate Physics Instruction
column15: Wayne A Fisher, Myers Park High School
column18: ITS is a strategy to organize instruction and assess student learning that gives students choices as to how they learn, allows them to assume ownership of their learning, yet also holds students accountable for what they learn. At the heart of ITS are learning contracts that guide students' efforts to gain an understanding of the fundamentals of physics. ITS maximizes teacher-to-student and student-to-student interactions, minimizes lecture time, and increases the learning capacity of each student. The teacher's role switches from that of a lecturer to one of an organizer of learning opportunities. Students work individually or in small groups to be actively engaged in the learning process. The end result of an ITS classroom is a highly differentiated, student-centered learning environment where students learn to be self-directed learners, collaborative workers, producers of quality products, and contributing members of a learning community.

column5: Selecting a Textbook: Let the Students Choose
column15: Linda S Dake, Utica College
column18: Two years ago I was faced with selecting a new textbook for my calculus-based introductory physics class. Since I subscribe to just-in-time teaching methods, my most important criteria is that the textbook be readable to the students, yet I find that I am not the best judge of that. So I turned the textbook selection into a class project for the students who were taking the 2nd semester introductory course. After the preliminary round of selection, we included advanced physics students in the final selection. The students unanimously chose one textbook, which I am now successfully using for the 2nd year. The project required significant planning and preparation on my part, but it was well worthwhile. The students felt that their opinion was valued, and I gained considerable insight into what students want in a textbook.

column5: Exploring Innovation and Discoveries in Physics Demonstrations
column15: Eduardo Valadares, Depto. de Fsica - ICEx - UFMG
column18: A novel approach to physics demonstrations is presented whose main emphasis is on exploring new insights and fostering innovations starting from recycled and inexpensive items, such as plastic bottles, party balloons, elastics, twine, and soap films. A set of illustrative examples are presented related to topics as diverse as gravity, surfactants, production of partial vacuum, acoustic, and macroscopic analogies to quantum phenomena. A short report on related activities developed in Brazil will be given followed by some simple demonstrations to highlight the importance of creativity and challenges to revitalize physics teaching.

column5: Boston University Academy Science and Engineering Research Program
column15: Gary Garber, Boston University Academy
column18: High School students in 11th grade at Boston University Academy spend a year in a science seminar to prepare themselves to spend 8 weeks during the summer working in a science or engineering research laboratory at Boston University. In the 11th grade year they go on weekly laboratory tours and give weekly journal club presentations. They develop their summer work into a 30 page senior thesis.

column5: Facing the Resistance of Academic Staff to Innovative Teaching Methods
column15: David Pundak, Ort Braude Engineering College
column18: There is a growing consensus that traditional instruction in basic science courses, in institutions of higher learning, do not lead to the desired results. Most of the students who complete these courses do not gain deep knowledge about the basic concepts and develop a negative approach to the sciences. In order to deal with this problem, a variety of methods have been proposed and implemented, during the last decade, which focus on the "active learning" of the participating students. Despite research-based evidence of the success of these methods, they are often met by the resistance of the academic staff. This article describes how one institution of higher learning dealt with this resistance, through the establishment and implementation of a Center of Active Learning. The article presents the sources of staff resistance, a model of the stages that a teacher undergoes to adopt a new teaching method and how the Center dealt with this challenge, by addressing each stage of the model.

column5: The FCI and Force in the Direction of Motion
column15: Paula V Engelhardt, Tennessee Technological University
column18: The Force Concept Inventory (FCI) has become a staple diagnostic tool at all levels of physics instruction. Often the focus is on student gains in a course. This poster will present a quantitative analysis of students' use of the idea of a force in the direction of motion at Tennessee Technological University(TTU). Interviews with students taking calculus-based and algebra-based physics at TTU have been conducted to uncover the reasons behind students? choice of force in the direction of motion and the effect, if any, instruction had on their choice. Results from these interviews will be presented.

column5: Physics Information Fluency: The Value of Integrated Library Instruction
column15: Bonnie A Osif, Penn State
column18: The ability to identify, access, evaluate, analyze, and share information is an essential process for all students in science and technology. With over-crowded class schedules it is often difficult to get time to present library instruction in classes. Yet these important skills can make an important difference in the learning experience of the students. A experiment that seamlessly integrated a five part, graded library instruction segment into a semester-long freshmen engineering design class is described with analysis.

column5: Astronomy as a Liberal Art
column15: Gordon C McIntosh, University of Minnesota, Morris
column18: Throughout history, poets, authors, artists, philosophers and theologians have drawn inspiration from astronomical observations. Various historical developments have been influenced by astronomical events. I will give a few examples of these inspirations and influences and explain why I use them in my teaching of astronomy.

column5: Andes: An Intelligent Tutor for Introductory Physics Homework
column15: Brett D van de Sande, LRDC, University of Pittsburgh
column17: Robert Shelby, Don Treacy, Kurt VanLehn, Mary Wintersgill
column18: The Andes physics tutoring system helps students derive conceptually sound, principle-based solutions to quantitative physics problems. Its user interface approximates a piece of paper in that students can draw diagrams, define variables and enter equations with the same degree of freedom as they would have when using paper. Unlike a piece of paper, Andes tells students whether their entry is correct by turning it red or green. Also, unlike a piece of paper, Andes will give principle-based hints when asked. Andes includes over 500 problems that cover most topics in a standard two-semester trigonometry-based physics course. Several semester-long evaluations show that students who did their homework using Andes have significantly higher exam scores than students who did the same homework problems on paper.

column5: Andes: An Intelligent Tutor Homework System for Introductory Physics
column15: Brett D van de Sande, LRDC, University of Pittsburgh
column17: Robert Shelby, Don Treacy, Kurt VanLehn, Mary Wintersgill
column18: The Andes physics tutoring system helps students derive conceptually sound, principle-based solutions to quantitative physics problems. Its user interface approximates a piece of paper in that students can draw diagrams, define variables and enter equations with the same degree of freedom as they would have when using paper. Unlike a piece of paper, Andes tells students whether their entry is correct by turning it red or green. Also, unlike a piece of paper, Andes will give principle-based hints when asked. Andes includes over 500 problems that cover most topics in a standard two-semester trigonometry-based physics course. Several semester-long evaluations show that students who did their homework using Andes have significantly higher exam scores than students who did the same homework problems on paper.

column5: Kinematics and Dynamics for Everyone: Fly Wheel Toy Car
column15: Renee Lathrop, Dutchess Community College
column18: Letting a fly wheel toy car roll down an inclined plane is an experiment that enables students of many levels to explore the fundamental concepts of kinematics and dynamics. Since a complete run can take as long as twenty seconds for a simple apparatus, a metronome or computer aided motion detectors can be used to study this motion. A sample set-up will be displayed as a part of this poster along with typical data and sample analyses.

column5: Replicating and Maintaining Successful Teaching Innovations
column15: Steven J Pollock, University of Colorado at Boulder
column18: We discuss our efforts to locally implement and sustain one of the best-researched reforms in introductory physics, the Tutorials in Introductory Physics. We examine two critical elements, replicating the success demonstrated at U. Washington, and sustaining the successes once we can demonstrate them. We measure the effectiveness of these reforms in terms of their impact on student conceptual mastery and in students' attitudes, beliefs and affect. We demonstrate successful replication of student achievements published by the original curricular authors, with further documentation that we can support productive attitudes and beliefs, albeit with some student discontent. Sustaining these reforms is a more complex story. We document that it is possible to hand off the Tutorials intra-institutionally with some success in terms of conceptual mastery and attitudes and beliefs; however, the success appears to depend upon locally contingent features, such as instructor experience and institutional support, and is far from guaranteed.

column5: An Assessment of Lecture Exam Grades and Keypad Systems
column15: Patsy A McDonald, University of Texas at Austin
column17: C Fred Moore, Ray A Burnstein
column18: Wireless and wired keypad systems have been in use at the University of Texas for ten years in a variety of courses. In particular, we have studied recent data from several sections of a calculus-based engineering physics course. There are about 150 students in each section with keypad usage ranging from daily to occasional. In three of the sections students take four identical examinations during the semester. An assessment of this data has been made.

column5: An Assessment of Lecture Exam Grades and Keypads Systems
column15: Patsy A McDonald, University of Texas at Austin
column17: C Fred Moore, Ray A Burnstein
column18: Wireless and wired keypad systems have been in use at the University of Texas for ten years in a variety of courses. In particular, we have studied recent data from several sections of a calculus-based engineering physics course. There are about 150 students in each section with keypad usage ranging from daily to occasional. In three of the sections students take four identical examinations during the semester. An assessment of this data has been made.

column5: Implementation and Results of Active Learning Strategies in Large Enrollment Classes
column15: Maria T Oliver-Hoyo, North Carolina State University
column18: A traditional chemistry format consisting of three-hour per week lecture with accompanying three-hour lab periods has been transformed into three two-hour periods per week of hands-on activities where students work in collaborative groups and the instructor serves as the facilitator for learning. The Student-Centered Activities for Large Enrollment University Programs, better known as the SCALE-UP Project, fully integrates lecture and laboratory formats into a seamless session. Pedagogies used in this innovative format have been tested in small classes, however, the SCALE-UP Project uses them in classes of up to 99 students. The project has investigated the classroom designs, classroom management techniques, and research-based curricula needed to make activity-based instruction effective for these large classes. The presentation will emphasize chemical education research methods and the results of various studies on the effects of this integrated lab-lecture format for general chemistry.

column5: Bringing Technology into High School Physics Classrooms
column15: Nouredine Zettili, Jacksonville State University
column18: Through our outreach initiative at JSU, we have been supporting a number of school districts with ways to bring technology into high school physics classrooms. This initiative is part of Project IMPACTSEED (IMproving Physics And Chemistry Teaching in SEcondary Education), a No-Child Left Behind grant funded by the Alabama Commission on Higher Education. This project is motivated by a major local need: A large number of high school physics teachers teach out of field. The main aim of IMPACTSEED is to help high school teachers learn and master the various physics topics required by the Alabama course of study. Teachers are offered year-round support through a rich variety of programs: a two-week summer institute, a series of five technology workshops, and onsite year-round support. Through our hands-on approach and the technology workshops, we have identified a number of ways of bringing technology into physics classrooms. A number of technology projects were assigned to the teachers so as to show their students how physics connects to our daily lives and to the technological devices around us.

column5: It Takes a Village: Preparation of Physics Teachers
column15: Ingrid Novodvorsky, Univ. of Arizona
column18: To open this poster session, I will provide an overview of the critical partnerships being developed at various institutions to improve the preparation of physics teachers. My presentation will lead into overviews of the submitted posters, to be followed by discussions with the poster authors.

column5: Computation in Undergraduate Physics at Kenyon College
column15: Timothy S Sullivan, Kenyon College
column17: John D Idoine, Christopher A LaSota, Benjamin W Schumacher, Paula C Turner
column18: In this paper we will describe the use of computers in physics courses and labs at Kenyon College. Kenyon Physics has a long history of innovation in the use of computers. We will we have incorporated into the curriculum our past efforts in use of digital video in labs and the use of symbolic algebra programs in our upper division courses. In addition, we will detail a novel, interdisciplinary program in computational science at Kenyon. This program is essentially equivalent to a minor. The goal is to produce a computational science program appropriate to a liberal arts college while (from the point of view of the physics department) simultaneously enhancing opportunities for physics majors to learn more about computational techniques. Finally, we will describe three student/faculty research programs at Kenyon that are heavily dependent on computation: medical imaging, complex systems, and the dynamics of phase transitions.

column5: Mahlon Loomis and the Discovery of Aerial Telegraphy
column15: James M Hardesty, PV Scientific Instruments
column18: The history of scientific discovery offers inspiring glimpses into the visions of early experimenters, and this paper presents new findings that help explain how it was possible for Mahlon Loomis to transmit and receive wireless communications when Morse's telegraph and the Atlantic cable were still recent innovations. By 1868, Loomis had dispensed with the long-distance telegraph wire or cable by utilizing antennae and atmospheric charges. Although Loomis failed to commercialize his discoveries, in 1872 his wireless system was awarded the first U.S. wireless patent. This paper follows Loomis' path through the work of Franklin, Morse, and his own experimentation to demonstrate how careful study of the basics can produce astonishing scientific advances.

column5: A Capstone Course for Prospective Physics Teachers
column15: Ingrid Novodvorsky, Univ. of Arizona
column18: Prospective physics and chemistry teachers at the University of Arizona enroll in a capstone course, Central Ideas in the Physical Sciences, which focuses on the analysis and understanding of central ideas in the physical sciences traditionally included in the secondary school science curriculum. I will describe the evolution of the course and the impact it is having on prospective teachers' thinking about the importance of content knowledge.

column5: Experimental Replication of Loomis' RF Apparatus and Experiments
column15: James F Corum, National Electrodynamics
column18: Sufficient historical documentation is available to reconstruct the apparatus employed by Mahlon Loomis in his 19th century atmospheric electricity experiments. His oscillator and detector were assembled and the physical performance documented using modern instrumentation. Loomis' results were supported by experiment and NIST-traceable field measurements: (1) The transmitter operation is plainly identified with Trichel pulse excitation of tuned resonators (operating near 500 kHz). (2) Loomis' detector was found to obey Manley-Rowe equations for parametric mixing in time-varying media, and his receiver architecture was discovered to be reasonably sensitive (approximately 300 microvolts). (3) During actual experiments, the measured field was determined to be inverse-distance and obey conventional Sommerfeld-Norton ground-wave propagation. It is concluded that Loomis' public demonstrations (distances of two miles for the Navy and 18 miles for a congressional delegation) were certainly attainable using his apparatus. Transmitter photographs, link-budget calculations, a Loomis receiver and audio recordings will accompany the presentation.

column5: Revisions to Intermediate Optics for Greater Conceptual Understanding
column15: Mark F Masters, IPFW
column18: Our physics laboratories had not been updated in almost 20 years. As such, the equipment was in poor condition and the laboratories followed a cookbook approach without concern for student understanding. We have undertaken a complete update of the optics class and laboratory. In class, we use interactive engagement with worksheets to assist the students to work through the physics. The students are required to apply the physics through challenging questions. The hardest part of the update has been development of laboratories that can be appreciated by students who have only introductory physics background to those who are senior physics majors. The approach we adopted was one of providing some basic, detailed direction at the beginning of a laboratory session, and forcing the students to reconsider this initial material later in the lab session. We present details of our approach and results of our initial trials.

column5: Gender-based Teaching Strategies for the Freshman Physics Course
column15: Jeff T Hengesbach, The Webb Schools
column18: Over the past four years the Webb Schools of California have effected a change in the science curriculum by instituting a modeling-based freshman physics course as a foundational science experience. Our schools' concurrent work with gender different learning encouraged us to separate freshman and sophomore classes by sex. This separation has allowed us to observe differences in students achievement based on the adoption of varied gender specific classroom practices and modifications to our curriculum. We will share our preliminary data and observations concerning differences in single sex physics classes, while focusing on pragmatic classroom management methods and curriculum adaptations to promote student success.

column5: Small-World Connections in a 2-D Ising Model
column15: Joshua M Sumrall, McNeese State University
column18: Although traditional Ising models with nearest neighbor interactions have been studied for years, the study of Ising models with small-world connections is a recent endeavor. Our experiment involves the parallel simulation of both traditional Ising models and Ising models with small-world connections. The Glauber dynamic is used in the dynamic Monte Carlo simulations of the Ising models. The results of both types of models are compared to determine how the small-world connections affect the properties of the Ising models, such as the ferromagnetic properties. This project has applications beyond physics to computer networks and beyond. Further work will extend to a more general n-states Potts model.

column5: Beginnings of PSSC and My Film Experiences
column15: John King, MIT
column18: From 1950 to 1996 I was part of the MIT molecular beam group started by J. R. Zacharias after World War II. I was in on the genesis, planning and early evolution of what became the PSSC program, listening in at Saturday lunches with Zach and distinguished visitors, among them Edwin Land (inventor of polaroid and founder of the Polaroid Co.). Zach?s experiences with high school students and Land?s views on education were important in forming the program. Later I was involved in the PSSC movies and had roles in about a dozen films as principal or advisor or builder of apparatus. I will tell about this through the filter of memory aided by excerpts from memos, speeches and films.

column5: Creating a Computational Methods Course in Undergraduate Physics
column15: Jaime R Taylor, Austin Peay State University
column18: The increased importance of computational methods in physics research has made it necessary to incorporate it into the undergraduate physics curriculum. This can be accomplished either by creating a separate computational methods course or teaching it across the curriculum. Both approaches have merit and as computational methods become ever more important, both approaches will be necessary. Regardless of the approach there are specific elements that are important to prepare students for graduate studies ? specifically, the computer languages used, the computational methods covered, creating code from scratch versus modifying existing code, and group versus individual project assignments.

column5: Products of Inertia and Dissection of Triangles
column15: Darya Kazachkova
column18: In present project we study different ways to dissect a triangle into specifically squared parts with a pair of crossed straight lines. The topic was inspired by the problems solved in the class of Resistance of Materials, on calculation of products of inertia of planar figures. There, ?dissecting? lines are axes of Cartesian system of coordinates, its origin positioned onto the figure?s center of mass. The sign of inertia products is negative when the bigger part of the figure is in even quadrants, and vice versa. For right triangles this estimation is easily performed by eye. We have focused on a more general problem to compare ?even? and ?odd? parts of an arbitrary triangle dissected by two perpendicular straight lines. Results obtained by exact calculation and in virtual experiments (computer program designed in Visual Basic) were tested live by cutting and weighing triangular cardboard plates.

column5: Investigating the Cognitive, Affective, and Professional Developments of MAT Students
column15: Kastro M Hamed, University of Texas at El Paso
column18: This study investigated the evolution and improvements attained by MAT participants in their first year of the MAT program. The design of the study combined and intertwined qualitative and quantitative methods to examine both cognitive and affective domains. The documentation took place in a longitudinal approach, and was done via standardized instruments, and via qualitative items such as personal journals, lesson plans, personal interactions, and class observations and surveys. Participants? Science Teaching Efficacy (PSTE) increased by a small margin in the first semester and increased significantly towards the end of the second semester. Science Teaching Outcome Expectancy (STOE) decreased in the first semester but increased in the second semester. The qualitative data showed enough evidence for the participants? efficacy belief changes as they progressed during the first year. Also, the qualitative data revealed that time management was the biggest hurdle the participants faced in attending this program.

column5: Computational Oscillations and Waves at the Sophomore Level
column15: seamus lagan, whittier college
column18: At Whittier College we created a sophomore-year computational course required of all physics majors. This course introduces students to the physics of oscillatory systems and wave motion and, in addition, it is a vehicle for them to learn to use Maple and IDL. It is hoped that the students will be motivated and prepared to use these tools in later courses, either on their own initiative or at the request of their instructor. Students learn how to use these software packages to perform tasks such as evaluating integrals, solving differential equations, solving simultaneous equations, plotting functions and/or data, creating series expansions of functions, finding roots of equations, working with complex numbers. Non-traditional topics have included modeling resonance in systems with non-standard damping, creating animations of traveling and interfering waves, modeling the thermal expansion of a solid starting from the interatomic potential energy, creating phase plots for chaotic systems.

column5: Computations in U.S. Undergraduate Physics Courses: An Overview
column15: Robert G Fuller, University of Nebraska - Lincoln
column18: The magazine, Computing in Science and Engineering, has commissioned a study of the use of numerical computations in physics courses in the USA. I am conducting this study with the help of Dave Winch, Kalamazoo College, and Norman Chonacky, Yale University. We have responses from more than 250 physics faculty members representing more than 220 different physics departments. I will discuss the range of responses and my preliminary evaluation of the present status of computational physics in undergraduate courses in the USA. A more complete report will be published in a special issue of the magazine this fall.

column5: The Bells Are Ringing
column15: Courtney W Willis, University of Northern Colorado
column17: Zach Armstrong, Alexander Kazachkov, Nick Nikolaenko, Vitaly Almaz
column18: A traditional demonstration in physics is to suspend a coat hanger by some thread. When the thread is held against the ear and the coat hanger given a tap, the observer can hear the sound of "bells" ringing. The standing waves set up in such a situation are very interesting to investigate. Two groups of undergraduate students from V.Karazin Kharkov National University in the Ukraine and the University of Northern Colorado, nearly 10,000 miles apart, have investigated various aspects of this phenomenon on long straight rods and springs. Comparisons of the frequencies as transmitted through the air and the thread have been made as well as comparisons of the frequency produced to the theoretical fundamental calculated frequency. This paper will give the current progress of this research.

column5: Details of a Computations Study of U.S. Undergraduate Physics Courses
column15: Robert G Fuller, Univ. of Nebraska ? Lincoln
column18: The magazine, Computing in Science and Engineering { CiSE}, has commissioned a study of the use of numerical computations in physics courses in the USA. I am conducting this study with the help of Dave Winch, Kalamazoo College, and Norman Chonacky, Yale University. We have responses from more than 250 physics faculty members representing more than 220 different physics departments. This poster features the details of the study, the range of responses, some sample quotes and some analysis of the present status of computational physics in undergraduate courses in the USA. A more complete analysis will be published in a special issue of the CiSE magazine this fall.

column5: Computational Physics Education: Why, What, and How
column15: Rubin H Landau, Oregon State University
column18: Starting in 1989, the Physics Department at Oregon State University started developing and teaching courses in Computational Physics (CP). There are now five courses spanning the entire undergraduate curriculum from freshman to senior year. In 2001, the state of Oregon granted permission for a new BS degree in Computational Physics. The first students entering that program will graduate in June 2006. A description will be given of the motivation for offering a BS degree in CP, the multidisciplinary subjects studied, the organization of laboratories, lectures and curricula materials, the student learning outcomes, and the place of CP within the broader Computational Science community. Also described will be the textbooks developed in conjunction with the courses, their Web enhancements, and the recent conversion of curricula materials into online courses (using the eTeach streaming video package) and eBooks (a research project in computer-human interactions). Work supported by NSF (CCLI) & EPIC

column5: COSMOS: Guiding the Development of High School Students as Scientists
column15: Matthew R Semak
column18: A team-taught curriculum developed specifically for COSMOS (Colorado Science and Math Opportunities) is presented. Students from area high schools participate in a multiple-year integrated physics and mathematics program. The curriculum stresses the development of students as practicing scientists. This is an activity-driven class in which observational, analytical, and communication skills are fostered. As the program?s theme, astronomy is defined not only as the science of celestial bodies but as the process by which we come to understand the physical nature of these bodies. In particular, students are asked to define, complete, and present their own research projects. Projects range from determining the Sun?s diameter to measuring the local acceleration due to gravity. A particular student project is discussed to illustrate the evolution of capability and confidence as the personal scientific process develops.

column5: America?s sources of energy?what will the future be?
column15: Gordon J Aubrecht, II, Ohio State University
column18: Where will America?s future electricity supply come from? According to Vice President Cheney?s energy task force, the U.S. needs to build about one 1 GW generating facilty a week in perpetuity.(1) What sort of facilities will they be? Can the economy sustain such growth? Are there other possibilities? One possibility that strikes a chord with physicists is conservation as a source of energy. In this regard, Vice President Cheney famously said that conservation is?a sign of personal virtue, but it is not a sufficient basis?all by itself?for a sound, comprehensive energy policy,?(2) echoing the Ayn Rand Instituite?s view that ?[c]onservation is not a long- or short-term solution to the energy crisis. Conservation is the un-American idea of resigning oneself to doing with less.?(3) This talk will explore the possible energy futures, their advantages and disadvantages, with and without conservation.

column5: How Davis-Besse almost blew its top
column15: Gordon J Aubrecht, II, Ohio State University
column18: The Davis-Besse pressurized water reactor was taken off line on 16 February 2002 for routine maintenance. After a hole was discovered in the reactor vessel head it was kept shut down for repairs. It did not return to producing electricity steadily until two years later, 4 April 2004! What happened, how it might have happened, how it was fixed, whether there was cause for alarm among the general public, and what effects it had on FirstEnergy will be discussed.

column5: Integration of Technology in High School Curriculum of Physics
column15: Mary M Cunningham, Argo Community High School
column18: The integration of science and technology provides a challenge to curriculum developers and teachers. Using state and national educational standards we have developed a physics curriculum that includes video and animated presentations, interactive learning modules with self assessment quizzes, and printable classroom activities. Inquiry lab experiences are provided in both hands-on and virtual formats. In a three year program of physics, chemistry and biology we worked to identify unifying themes and have integrated earth and space science components. We have also worked to incorporate interactive remote learning opportunities with major museum facilities.

column5: Three Year High School Curriculum, Integrating Science and Technology
column15: Mary M Cunningham, Argo Community High School
column18: The integration of science and technology provides a challenge to curriculum developers and teachers. Using state and national educational standards we have developed a physics curriculum that includes video and animated presentations, interactive learning modules with self assessment quizzes, and printable classroom activities. Inquiry lab experiences are provided in both hands-on and virtual formats. In a three year program of physics, chemistry and biology we worked to identify unifying themes and have integrated earth and space science components. We have also worked to incorporate interactive remote learning opportunities with major museum facilities.

column5: Concept Acquisition and Transfer from Mechanics to Electrostatics
column15: Stephen Kanim, New Mexico State University
column18: Electricity and Magnetism is typically a second-semester physics course, and for many topics instructors rely on what has been taught in the first semester as a foundation. For this reason, it is useful to know the extent to which students have learned these foundational mechanics concepts, and the degree to which they are able to reason about them in this new context. In this talk I will describe some conceptual errors that students make in introductory electrostatics and relate these to associated difficulties in mechanics. In addition, I will describe some conceptual materials that have been developed to address some of these difficulties. Finally, I will give results of pre- and post-testing of students with preliminary versions of an assessment instrument that we are developing to measure student acquisition of mechanics concepts that underlie related electrostatics concepts, and that measures their ability to apply these concepts in the second semester course.
column19: Supported in part by NSF DUE-0125831.

column5: Review of Latest RF Wireless Keypad Systems
column15: Ray A Burnstein, Illinois Institute of Technology
column17: C. Fred Moore, Patsy A Mc Donald, Patrick L Kreuzer, Morrie Schulman
column18: The use of wireless keypad systems in the classroom continues to increase. At the same time the number of available products has also increased. In particular, there are several new wireless RF systems. These systems have improved features over past IR systems together with reductions in cost. Comparisons and summaries based on the latest available data are presented.

column5: Seeing the World in a Different Light: Little Shop of Physics
column15: Brian Jones, Colorado State University
column18: In the World Year of Physics 2005, the Little Shop of Physics took its show on the road farther than ever before in three extended road trips to work with Native American groups. We presented hands-on school programs, evening community events and teacher workshops. Being part of the World Year of Physics allowed us to extend our geographic reach, but it also allowed us to develop our programs in new and different ways that taught us some valuable lessons. We will discuss our experiences, our future plans, and share some samples of our programs.

column5: Tracking Eye-Movements in Students' Judgments of Realistic Motion
column15: Jose Mestre, University of Illinois at Urbana/Champaign
column17: Adam Feil, Walter Boot, Arthur Kramer
column18: Previous studies1-3 of students? judgments of the realism of the animated motion of two balls racing along parallel tracks of different shapes revealed dramatic differences in performance between physics-nave, and physics-knowledgeable students, with the physics-nave students much better able to judge realistic motion than were physics-knowledgeable students. One of the surprising findings from those studies was that most physics-knowledgeable students failed to detect anomalous motion (a ball speeding up while going uphill with no apparent cause) in one of the animations in which the race resulted in a tie, whereas most physics-nave students detected the anomalous motion. This study will explore the question of whether this performance difference between the groups is due to different eye-gaze patterns, or whether it is due to knowledge that the physics students bring to the task (conservation of energy) which erroneously leads them to strong expectations for a tie outcome, thereby interfering with their ability to ?see? (after observing) the anomalous motion.

column5: Facilitating Inquiry by Using Powerful Ideas in Physical Science (PIPS)
column15: Patsy Ann Johnson
column18: In the National Science Education Standards, abilities necessary to do scientific inquiry and understandings about inquiry are content standards for kindergarten through high school. Students preparing to teach grades K-8 need substantial experiences engaging in inquiry if they are to be ready to guide others in inquiry. An efficient and effective way to provide these experiences is to design a college or university course using Powerful Ideas in Physical Science (PIPS) published by the AAPT. PIPS was developed and field tested by faculty, usually in physics departments. The four original modules are Light and Color, Electricity, Nature of Matter, and Heat and the Conservation of Energy. Two additional modules are Force and Motion. Most of the PIPS activities use inexpensive and readily available materials. Students record their prior knowledge, consider what their classmates think, observe discrepant events, take measurements, record data, make inferences, and reconstruct their understandings about natural phenomena.

column5: Interactive Lecture Experiments in Large Introductory Physics Courses
column15: Marina Milner-Bolotin, University of British Columbia
column17: Andrzej Kotlicki, Georg Rieger, Robert Kehoe
column18: The paper suggests a pedagogical approach which aims at transforming lecture demonstrations in a large introductory physics class into a student-centered activity via using Logger Pro technology to collect and analyze the real time data. Interactive Lecture Experiment pedagogy builds on the Interactive Lecture Demonstrations proposed by Laws, Sokoloff, and Thornton [1] and extends it through providing the students with the opportunity to analyze the experiments discussed during the lecture outside of the classroom and report their results using clickers during the following lecture. The results of the first implementation of the Interactive Lecture Experiments in the large introductory physics course (750 students) are presented. 1. Sokoloff, D. R. and R. K. Thornton (2004). Interactive Lecture Demonstrations: Active Learning in Introductory Physics, John Wiley and Sons, INC.

column5: We Know Which Angle Maximizes Range. But Which Minimizes Speed?
column15: Lawrence H Day, Utica College
column18: In a real-life situation from a vehicle accident reconstruction case, it was necessary to calculate not the angle that maximizes the range of a projectile, but, instead, to figure out the take-off angle that minimizes the projectile?s take-off speed when the range is already known. The general formula for the range of a projectile with unequal take-off and landing heights is the starting place to calculate the angle that yields the minimum launch speed for a given range. This interesting, and somewhat surprising, case will be presented. The general problem lends itself well to an investigation of a fascinating real-world example of 2-D motion for undergraduate students above the introductory level.

column5: Oersted Medalists and the Culture of Physics
column15: Donald F Holcomb, Cornell University
column18: The first Oersted Award of AAPT, to William Suddards Franklin of Rollins College, was made at the joint AAPT-APS meeting in December of 1936. Since that time, 69 other teaching physicists have been so honored. The nature of their accomplishments, their working environments, and their value judgments provide an illuminating picture of how the physics teaching and research community, as well as physics itself, has developed over that 70 year period. Our educational institutions, our students, our teaching resources and physics itself have all changed dramatically. But many values and central goals have changed very little. I'll address the question of what messages for the future might come from reviewing the work of seventy Oersted medalists.

column5: A Graduation Stole/Sash Designed for Physics
column15: Lawrence H Day, Utica College
column18: A unique graduation stole specifically designed for the physics major is presented. The design, based on the atomic spectrum of hydrogen (the Balmer Series) seen on a black background, was first created in 2002 by the author and a graduating Utica College senior, Michael Fanto. Since then, the presentation at a small departmental ceremony of a personalized graduation stole worn for the first time by each student at his or her graduation ceremony has become an integral part of the graduation process for Utica College physics majors. It is hoped that the design for the Physics Graduation Stole might spread to other colleges and universities, and that the ceremonial presentation of such a stole to graduating physics majors will become a tradition on other campuses as well.

column5: Use of Concept Inventories to Identify Misconceptions in Thermal Sciences
column15: Ronald L Miller, Colorado School of Mines
column18: Building on the proven success of the Force Concept Inventory, we have developed a concept inventory instrument to identify engineering student misconceptions in the thermal and transport sciences (i.e. fluid mechanics, heat transfer, mass transfer, thermodynamics). In this presentation, I will describe the process of identifying important and robust misconceptions in these disciplines, developing multiple-choice questions which assess the presence of the misconceptions, and field testing the instrument, known at the Thermal and Transport Concept Inventory (TTCI). Important findings about specific misconceptions based on TTCI beta test data will also be discussed in terms of relevant cognitive theories of concept formation. If time permits, we will also interactively discuss how concept inventories can be used for formative assessment in engineering and science classes and other potential assessment applications for these types of instruments.

column5: Relationship of Mechanistic Reasoning and Empirical Results During Student Inquiry
column15: Rosemary S Russ, University of Maryland College Park
column18: Current conceptions of inquiry often focus on hypothesis testing in which students design and conduct controlled experiments. This heavily empirical characterization neglects hypothesis generation and views theoretical mechanistic reasoning as biasing students by preventing them from making scientifically valid conclusions about their data. In contrast, we consider scientific inquiry as a bootstrapping process whereby student understandings of mechanisms for phenomenon appropriately inform empirical results and vice-versa. We explore this relationship by studying students in an introductory physics course engaged in an electrostatics tutorial. We use a framework we developed for identifying mechanistic reasoning to analyze the dynamics between the students' descriptions of mechanism and their empirical investigations. We discuss several distinct patterns that emerge during the hypothesis generation phase of the scientific inquiry.

column5: Relationships of Mechanistic Reasoning and Empirical Results During Student Inquiry
column15: Rosemary S Russ, University of Maryland College Park
column18: Current conceptions of inquiry often focus on hypothesis testing in which students design and conduct controlled experiments. This heavily empirical characterization neglects hypothesis generation and views theoretical mechanistic reasoning as biasing students by preventing them from making scientifically valid conclusions about their data. In contrast, we consider scientific inquiry as a bootstrapping process whereby student understandings of mechanisms for phenomenon appropriately inform empirical results and vice-versa. We explore this relationship by studying students in an introductory physics course engaged in an electrostatics tutorial. We use a framework we developed for identifying mechanistic reasoning to analyze the dynamics between the students? descriptions of mechanism and their empirical investigations. We discuss several distinct patterns that emerge during the hypothesis generation phase of the scientific inquiry.

column5: A Look Back at the Oersted Lecturers
column15: Anthony P French, MIT
column18: The list of recipients of the Oersted Medal exhibits a wide variety of backgrounds, personalities and teaching styles. This paper is about some of those awardees whom the speaker likes to recall because of their particular contributions to the advancement of physics and/or physics education.

column5: Applying Ranking Physics to Teachers Training
column15: Guillermo Gonzalez-Cuevas
column18: Due to the variety of academic backgrounds of the physics teachers in the Colegio de Ciencias y Humanidades (Sciences and Humanities College) Naucalpan, it is necesary to standardize their conceptual knowledge. A tool, commonely applied to pupils, is used to cover some conceptual gapsin different physics areas. By means of a collective revision of some of the exercises, that includes a discussion of a posible problem and the given solution, is expected that the teachers discover themselves their lack of comprehension of some of the most common, and supossedly well-understood physics concepts. No evidence of the improvement in teh conecptual comprehension has benn obtained since this is the first year of application of the tool.

column5: Measuring Gains in Introductory Astronomy with the Astronomy Diagnostics Test
column15: Shannon D Willoughby, Montana State Univ.
column18: In order to measure student gains in introductory astronomy courses, the Astronomy Diagnostic Test (ADT) has been developed. Version 2.0 tests a wide swath of astronomy topics, normally covered in school before students reach college. This test has been administered to my large enrollment classes in the spring 2006 semester, in which collaborative learning groups and other learner-centered activities are used regularly. Normalized gains (n=165) are slightly higher compared to those at Central Michigan University and the University of New Mexico [1]. Additionally, pre and post test scores are compared to results from the ADT national project[2]. Again, scores are slightly higher, but a troubling difference between male and female gains is seen in all the data. Future testing will be done in the fall semester with no changes to the course made and again in the spring 2007 semester with a new textbook being the only change made.
column19: 1. M. Zeilik, W. Bisard, C. Lee, Astronomy Education Review Volume 1 Issue 1, pages 33-46 (2002). 2. G. Deming, Astronomy Education Review Volume 1 Issue 1, pages 52-57 (2002).

column5: A Physics Program For a Many-Faceted Student Body
column15: David H Kaplan, Sothern Illinois University Edwardsville
column17: Thomas M Foster, M. Lenore Horner
column18: Electing a physics program of study offers distinct advantages to undergraduate and pre-professional students planning to enter a variety of careers. Yet, traditional physics programs have not been particularly attuned to the needs of many of these students. One of the major issues facing physics departments today involves offering, in the face of new institutional and other pressures, meaningful and efficient physics major and minor courses and programs to diverse student groups without overburdening departmental resources and student credit hour limits. In this paper, we describe recent efforts at a suburban metropolitan university with a very diverse student body toward meeting these goals. Programs for several tracks, including physics teacher certification will be described.

column5: An Optics-Photonics Masters Program
column15: David H Kaplan, Southern Illinois University Edwardsville
column17: Arthur Braundmeier, Hernando Garcia, Jack Glassman, Abdullatif Y Hamad
column18: Nowadays, many physics students opt for a master?s degree in physics without plans for future continuation in a doctoral program. These students typically wish to apply their physics knowledge in industry after receiving the M.S. degree. The traditional physics master?s degree program, with courses mirroring those of the first year of a program leading to a P.h.D., is not addressed to the needs of many of these students. On the other hand, offering broad and extensive training for a variety of careers in industry may place burdens on the resources of smaller graduate programs. In this paper, we describe a new Optics-Photonics program and course sequences developed for a small graduate physics department at a regional metropolitan university (Southern Illinois University Edwardsville), which has successfully placed students in rewarding careers in industry that utilize the physics training.

column5: SPS Summer Intern Education & Outreach Efforts through ComPADRE
column15: Ann M Deml, American Physical Society
column18: ComPADRE is a digital library of physics and astronomy education resources and is composed of several web collections. Physics To Go in one which offers the public opportunities to engage in informal physics learning. The Physics Teacher Education Coalition (PTEC) website is a developing collection aimed at improving the education of future physical science teachers. As a 2006 SPS Summer Intern, I am working at the American Physical Society to further develop these two ComPADRE collections. My contributions to Physics To Go include searching for activities and attention-grabbing images to feature on the homepage, obtaining permission to utilize such images, and selecting quality websites to expand the site?s collection. Working with the PTEC collection involves compiling and posting member institution information, increasing scholarship and calendar entries, and providing site feedback. These educational outreach efforts help to enhance the quality of physics education and the enthusiasm for physics in our society.

column5: Interactive Engagement: Is Instructor Critical to Success in 1st-year Physics?
column15: Cathy M Ezrailson, Texas A&M; University
column17: Petra Sauer, Peter McIntyre, James White, Carl Gagliardi
column18: This study attempts to characterize effect(s) of the Explicit Model of Interactive-engagement Teaching (EMIT) on: 1) physics instructors? adherence to IE methods in problem solving during physics recitations, 2) on instructors? beliefs about the nature of physics and problem solving and 3) physics students? performance in an introductory calculus-based physics course. One post doc, three physics professors and four graduate students participated in this study. Methods included explicit modeling for the four treatment group instructors using interactive-engagement methods derived from the Reformed Teaching Observation Protocol (RTOP) and demonstrated as effective in the literature. Quantitative and qualitative assessments of treatment and control Instructors and their students were performed periodically throughout the semester. Student learning was measured using the Force Concept Inventory (FCI), success on recitation problems, through grades on final exams as well as through course grades. Results indicate a difference in student performance based on instructor style illuminating an area for further study.
column19: Participating graduate students were Chris Bertinato and Jim Ferguson.

column5: Learn to Love Elliptic Integrals
column15: Norman F Derby, Bennington College
column18: The "generalized complete elliptic integral" (cel) is a powerful but apparently little known function that can be used effectively to describe physical situations such as fields due to loops, discs and solenoids. It is more natural to use than the standard forms for elliptic integrals and it allows compact analytical expressions to be written and manipulated. Perhaps more importantly, there exists a simple, elegant and amazingly efficient algorithm that makes cel desirable in computational physics. Some familiar examples and some less familiar will be demonstrated. Handouts will be available.

column5: 3D Scanning: World Coordinates to Virtual Reality
column15: Nicholas C Nuar
column17: Dr. Daniel M Bubb, Brian Collins, Dr. Laurence Hassebrook
column18: 3D Scanning is the process of taking an object in the real world and through finding the relative phase in camera coordinates and projector coordinates, we produce a 3d model. In this project, we use software freely available from Laurence Hassebrook at the University of Kentucky along with an inexpensive Logitech webcam, a digital projector -- the kind used at many schools, and a laptop to take simple 3D images. A number of Mathematical and Physical topics can be motivated from a fun classroom demonstration.

column5: Measurement of Alpha Particle Track Lengths with a Diffusion Cloud Chamber
column15: Jeffrey P Hafner, Andrews University
column18: Measurements of alpha particle track lengths have been performed since 1911, when the first cloud chamber was made. In 1936 the creation of the Diffusion Cloud Chamber made classroom demonstrations possible. We used an A.U. Physics Enterprises Diffusion Cloud Chamber with a Lead-210 alpha source to produce alpha particle tracks so that students can determine their average lengths. Data was collected using a camcorder and then analyzed using Tracker software. We assumed that all alpha particles were the result of Polonium-210 decay and that they had energies of 5.3MeV. Since radiation is projected in all directions equally and the cloud forming region has a thickness less than the expected track length only a fraction of total tracks will end within the cloud forming region. Students can determine mean alpha particle track lengths close to the accepted value of 3.9cm.

column5: LabView Programming in an Advanced Physics Laboratory*
column15: Thomas F Colton, University of California Berkeley
column18: The physics department at U.C. Berkeley recently introduced a three-week unit on computerized data acquisition, signal processing, and control into the junior-level electronics lab course. Students learn to program virtual instruments in the National Instruments LabVIEW graphical programming application. After an on-line LabVIEW tutorial, students construct a simple amplifier circuit and write a program to measure Boltzmann?s constant from Johnson Noise in a resistor. In the second week, students build a scaled resistor digital to analog converter (DAC) and program an analog to digital converter (ADC) . In week three, students explore digital filtering techniques and write a proportional-integral-differential (PID) loop to control a magnetic levitator. Many students use LabVIEW for their final course project and subsequent research experiences. We will share lessons learned in adding 18 computer workstations and three weeks of material to an already-packed room and course.
column19: *Supported in part by NSF CCLI grant #DUE-0411367 and a National Instruments equipment grant.

column5: On the Landing of Prisms, or Rolling Unfair Dice
column15: Gary D White, Society of Physics Students
column18: When a prism is tossed what, what are the factors that determine the side upon which it lands? We investigate some experimental and theoretical results for rectangular and hexagonal prisms, using data provided by the Eastern Michigan University chapter of the Society of Physics Students, and well as American and English schoolchildren. How do these results relate to the landing of cylinders? Sir Hermann Bondi (European Journal of Physics 14, pp. 136-140) asked this question in 1993 with the intention of determining the theoretical probability of a coin landing on its edge. A simple model due to Singmaster assumes that the probability of landing on a particular side is proportional to the solid angle subtended from the center of mass, but this model predicts too few base landings for tall prisms, and too many side landings for squatty cylinders. We obtain promising results with an alternative thermodynamic theory, perhaps surprisingly.
column19: Thanks to many chapters of the Society of Physics Students who performed some of these experiments in a variety of science outreach settings.

column5: Measuring the Speed of Light using an Adjustable-Cavity Helium-Neon Laser
column15: Justin T Schultz, Juniata College
column17: Daniel E Sidor, Michael W Best, Andrew E Papale, Mark J Pearson
column18: An adjustable-cavity helium-neon laser setup provides undergraduates practical experience relating topics in optics and error analysis. For this study, a laser was constructed from a plasma tube and an adjustable mirror, thereby allowing the cavity length to be varied. The output from this cavity was passed into a nanosecond photodetector (New Focus Model 1621) the signal from which was then examined on a spectrum analyzer (Tektronix 492P). The longitudinal mode beat frequencies present in the different cavity lengths were measured on the Spectrum Analyzer and used to calculate the speed of light to an accuracy of less than 0.2%. Adjustable-cavity experiments enable students to apply statistics through propagation of error and regression techniques and can readily be varied to include statistical topics accessible to students with a wide range of mathematical backgrounds. Additional optical principles such as polarization and loss inserted into an optical cavity could also be explored.

column5: Undergraduate Student Laboratory Experience at the Synchrotron Radiation Center
column15: Steven C Sahyun, University of Wisconsin - Whitewater
column17: Jeffrey M Polak, Christopher J Moore
column18: This poster describes the structure of an intermediate physics laboratory course, a significant component of which is dedicated to having students perform hands-on experiments and real-time data collection at the Synchrotron Radiation Center national laboratory operated by the University of Wisconsin - Madison. This poster also comments on student feedback on how this experience affected their attitudes and expectations of physics.

column5: Teaching in an Interactive Physics Classroom
column15: Jeffrey A Phillips, Loyola Marymount Univ.
column18: Two years ago our University built a special classroom designed to support interactive teaching of introductory physics. We will show some important features of the room, which facilitates both lectures and group work. We will also describe our research on student learning in interactive physics classes, which shows that students with weak reasoning skills typically achieve only modest gains on standardized conceptual surveys, such as the FCI, despite the use of interactive teaching methods.

column5: Ocean Thermal Energy Conversion
column15: Paul L Gueye, Hampton University
column17: Hesham Anan, William Salice, Anthony Pezzella
column18: With Today?s rising energy costs, the development of an alternative energy source is becoming an urgent need. The ocean waters of the planet are the world?s largest solar collector and absorb 37 trillion kilowatts annually, or 4,000 times the amount of electricity used by all humans on the planet. A typical square mile of that collector contains more energy than 7,000 barrels of oil. This talk will review the status of Ocean Thermal Energy Conversion (OTEC). We will also present preliminary results on a small scale system that was built and designed by a group of seven undergraduate students to introduce such concepts within classroom settings.

column5: Representation of Diagrams in Memory After Short Exposures
column15: Adam Feil, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
column18: Prior studies reveal that physics experts categorize problems based on deep-structure, while novices categorize problems based on surface features. Given the limited capacity of short term memory it is reasonable to expect that, following short exposures, experts represent diagrams of physics situations in memory in terms of the deep structure depicted, with surface features supporting the representation rather than being central to it. In contrast, novices should largely rely on surface features in forming their representations. These hypothesized differences should, in turn, lead to differential recall performance as surface features and deep structure are manipulated in a recall task. To physics experts, a pair of diagrams that share surface features but differ in deep structure should appear more different than a pair that share both surface features and deep structure; to a novice they would appear to be equally similar. We report preliminary findings of such a recognition memory experiment.

column5: Internal Combustion: Taking an Ecological Approach
column15: Paul L Gueye, Hampton University
column17: William Salice, Hesham Anan, Anthony Pezzella
column18: There is a tremendous desire to find alternatives to the world?s dependency on oil as a fuel source for transportation, especially with the recent rising cost of this energy source. Today? automobile engines are only approximately 30% efficient, due to uncontrolled heat losses. Through the use of electrolysis, a process by which hydrogen can be separated from water, there are potential mechanical applications for four-stroke combustion engines. We will present the current status and future progress on this emerging fuel cell technology. The results from a small scale system that was built and designed by a group of six undergraduate students will also be discussed as a tool to introduce such concepts within classroom settings.

column5: Ontological Classification of Physics Concepts
column15: Renee-Michelle Goertzen, University of Maryland
column18: Chi [1] and her collaborators have proposed that student difficulties can be explained by their incorrect ontological classification of physics concepts. Specifically, they suggest that students often classify physics concepts as material substances rather than processes and that experts correctly categorize these same concepts as processes. For many in upper-level physics, this idea is questionable, because experts appear to move fluidly between process and substance ontological classifications. We explore this idea through observations of behavior of expert physicists and students.

column5: Using Cognitive Apprenticeship to Prepare Physics Teachers
column15: Eugenia Etkina, Rutgers University
column18: One of the differences between physicists and physics teachers is that the latter possess Pedagogical Content Knowledge--a unique blend of content and pedagogy that allows teachers to transform the content of physics to make it comprehensible and learnable for the students. How do teachers acquire pedagogical content knowledge? One way to acquire a cognitive skill is through cognitive apprenticeship. In 2001 Barab and Hay suggested a four-step model of cognitive apprenticeship in which learners gradually move from being participants in the desired environment to being independent practitioners. This poster will examine physics pedagogical content knowledge and the model of cognitive apprenticeship in detail and describe how this general model can be applied to the preparation of physics teachers in the sequence of undergraduate physics courses and graduate courses in the school of education.

column5: Computation in the Physics Curriculum at Rider University
column15: Gary A Pajer, Rider University
column18: Rider University is a four-year comprehensive University known for its business and education schools, but with a small active science faculty. We expose our physics students to the "new pyramid" of Theory, Experiment, and Computation, with all three having equal status. The introductory sequence uses Chabay and Sherwood's "Matter and Interactions" which adopts the position that numerical techniques are more generally applicable than analytical techniques. The text leads students through the writing of simulations in Vpython. Our intermediate mechanics course uses John R. Taylor's "Classical Mechanics", which contains problems requiring numerical solutions. We use a cross-platform, open source environment consisting of the Python language and extensions Vpython (3D graphics), numpy (numerical extensions), scipy (special functions, ode's), and matplotlib (graphing). The Python computing environment provides all the functionality of popular commercial products at none of the cost. Our Quantum Mechanics course introduces Mathematica through a series of student exercises.

column5: Motional Visual Illusions Revisited
column15: Alexander Kazachkov
column17: Tetyana Ignatova, Vitaly V. Kalinin, Courtney W. Willis
column18: Another amazing illusion of vision demonstrated at the AAPT 2005 Summer Meeting requires the cheapest facilities, just a small paper disk colored as a darts board. When moved circularly it produces an image of a round gray spot on an axially symmetric black&white; background. In view of educational applications, an origin and properties of this "illusive" image have been studied by earlier developed technique of computer virtual measurement. All the parameters of the simulated system, in particular, the shape and coloring of the moving target were broadly varied. Conclusions of computer experiments revealing more interesting regularities were proved geometrically. Live pictures of beautiful patterns observed by the viewer have been obtained by still photography at extended exposures. Corresponding computer simulators are presented.

column5: Multiple Representations and Problem Solving I: Student Performance in Different Environments
column15: Patrick B Kohl, University of Colorado at Boulder
column18: Professional physicists, scientists, and engineers are experts at handling multiple representations of problems simultaneously. Thus, physics instructors strongly value improving student competence with multiple representations. However, even reform-oriented instructors differ in their approach to promoting multiple representation problem-solving abilities. In a study of multiple representation use, we gave students a total of five free-body diagram problems in recitation and exams. We studied students in two large-lecture algebra-based physics courses at Rutgers, one at the University of Colorado (CU), and a smaller course at The College of New Jersey. The courses differ significantly in their implementation, especially with respect to their use of multiple representations: The Rutgers and TCNJ courses are reformed and explicitly teach a concrete problem-solving heuristic that emphasizes multiple representations. The CU course is also reformed, but teaches problem-solving heuristics and the use of multiple representations implicitly. In this talk, we examine student performance on these multiple-representations tasks, and describe the similarities and differences between the various instructors and course environments. We then correlate the different instructional approaches with student success.

column5: Developing Fluid Concepts and the Fluid/Electric Circuit Analogy
column15: Mizuho K Schwalm, University of Minnesota-Crookston
column18: The concept of flow rate is unfamiliar to most introductory students. They have difficulty differentiating between the amount of fluid, for instance, and the rate of flow. Often pressure difference is also a new concept. These are among the difficulties one faces in trying to use the fluid analogy for electric circuits. Some texts use a mechanical model of fluid flowing down hill to circumvent the problem of pressure, but this is not so helpful vis--vis Ohm?s law as it does not provide as good a model of resistance. A fluid model using air pressure difference is used in CASTLE[1]. However the incompressibility of water has advantages. To establish fluid flow concepts for later use in understanding circuits, we propose context rich laboratory activities on pressure difference and direct measurement of liquid flow rate.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant #DUE-0510570.

column5: Project-Based Learning in Introductory College Physics / 21st Century (ICP/21)
column15: Alexander K Dickison, Seminole Community College
column18: Project-Based Learning is introduced in ICP/21 through activities called "applications". In an application students are asked to help a technician, engineer, or medical technician solve a work-based, multiple concept problem. The group of students assigned an application are asked to design a procedure and follow it to obtain a solution. Their procedure, findings, and solution are presented to the class. Several student presentations will be shown to exemplify thistype of activity.

column5: Epistemic Games in Upper Division Physics Problem Solving
column15: Edward F Redish, University of Maryland
column17: Thomas J Bing, Rachel E Scherr
column18: Collins and Ferguson [1] introduced the idea of an epistemic game as a locally coherent cognitive activity associated with achieving a knowledge-creating goal. These games have a restricted set of activities (moves) and may produce an external representation (form). Although intended to describe expert behavior, they can be applied more generally. Since people tend to circumscribe their behavior by framing their situations (?What is it that I think is going on here??), novices often create local goals and limit the activities they use to achieve those goals. We use the idea of the epistemic game to analyze the role of students? expectations in their approach to solving problems. This method has been very effective in analyzing student problem solving in introductory physics [2]. In this poster we discuss how epistemic games might also be effective in making sense of student problem-solving behavior in upper division physics classes.

column5: Field-Testing Activities and Instructor Support Materials at the Astronomy Workshop
column15: Grace L Deming, University of Maryland
column18: The Astronomy Workshop is a collection of 22 computer assisted learning tools (http://janus.astro.umd.edu/). The site?s Solar System Collisions web tool allows students to investigate how different variables affect planetary impacts. Students select projectile size, density, velocity, and target. Results are displayed in a colorful manner; including energy released, crater diameter, earthquake magnitude, and frequency. During 2005, eighteen UMD students of diverse backgrounds and mathematical experiences were interviewed at the computer while using the Solar System Collisions tool. Based on these interviews, activities were written and revised so that introductory astronomy students interpret differences observed in terms of kinetic energy. A field-test involving ten undergraduate and two high school classes was conducted during spring 2006. We are seeking volunteers to field-test web tools, activities, and instructor support materials during fall 2006. Interested instructors are encouraged to contact the authors. This research is funded by NASA EPO 04 410.

column5: Heat Engines and the Meaning of Entropy
column15: John E Shaw, Northwest Missouri State University
column18: No heat engine cycle operating between two temperatures can be more efficient than a Carnot cycle operating between the same two temperatures. However, more information is needed than two temperature extremes to uniquely characterize a heat engine cycle. For heat engine cycles with four turning points it is shown that five physical parameters are needed to uniquely characterize the cycle. Carnot, Otto and Diesel cycles are compared for certain choices of five parameters. From these comparisons meaning is given to the thermodynamic definition of entropy as a measure of a system's ability to do useful work. It is shown that the change in entropy during heat input in these reversible engine cycles is smaller when the efficiency is greater.

column5: How Do We Trigger Student Sense-Making in a Physics Lab?
column15: Anna Karelina, Rutgers University
column18: Rutgers PAER group is developing and implementing ISLE labs in which students design their own experiments being guided by self-assessment rubrics. These lab tasks help students acquire such scientific abilities as the ability to design an experiment, to collect and analyze data, and to communicate details of the experimental procedure. Lab experiments use simple equipment and the lab write-ups do not provide a step-by-step experimental procedure. In this study we monitored students? thinking during our design ISLE laboratories and during traditional introductory physics laboratories where students use more sophisticated equipment and where lab write-ups provide more instructions. We compared the amount of time that students spent on sense-making in two kinds of labs and traced when sense-making was triggered by the lab write-up or by a TA?s questions and when it occurred spontaneously. Our study is similar to that of Lippmann [1]. [1] R. Lippmann. "Analyzing students' use of metacognition during laboratory activities" Poster presented at the AERA Meeting, New Orleans, April 2002

column5: Multicultural Mentoring: A Personal Story
column15: Julia K Olsen
column18: During the previous school year, as TIR I had opportunity to engage in an extensive mentoring relationship with a local middle school teacher who is from Mexico, but currently living in and teaching in the US. With no science background, she was assigned to teach 6th and 8th grade science to non-English speaking, immigrant students in her school. I will share insights into our mentoring process and our successful implementation of inquiry science in her classroom, as well as the benefits we both recieved from pursuing this experience.

column5: Understanding Physics with PET
column15: Marie F Plumb, Jamestown Community College
column18: "Understanding Physics" uses the PET Curriculum developed by Goldberg, Robinson, and Otero to instruct pre-service and in-service teachers, as well as other interested parties, in fundamental physics principles. The purpose of the class is to bring forth the latent scientist in each student. The plan is to include these students in the outreach program "The Science Connection," which brings science education to local third grade students.

column5: Optical Beams with a Helical Wavefront
column15: Enrique J Galvez
column18: In recent years optical beams in high order modes have received much attention. In particular, Laguerre-Gauss beams form a family of Gaussian beams that have interesting characteristics: they can have a wavefront with a helical shape. As a consequence, they bring a new fundamental concept to optics: orbital angular momentum. This type of angular momentum, different from spin angular momentum, is due to the azimuthal component of the linear momentum of the light along the profile of the beam. We describe the introduction of these concepts, and associated laboratory demonstrations, to the undergraduate course on optics.

column5: Gravity, Magnetism, and "Down": Student's Conceptions of Gravity
column15: Julie Libarkin, Ohio University
column18: Entry-level college science instruction assumes an understanding of fundamental physical science concepts including gravity. These basic concepts provide an essential foundation for building students? sophisticated understanding of advanced concepts, such as orbital mechanics. We set out to investigate how 200 entry-level geology students enrolled at a North America university thought about and applied the concept of gravity. We found that the majority of students held non-scientific notions about gravity. Nearly 90% of students held notions about gravity that related magnetism, the Earth?s atmosphere, Earth?s rotational motion, or other phenomena to gravitational attraction. Students with alternative conceptions about gravity also completed gravity tasks in non-scientific ways. These findings suggest that instruction about gravity and other physical concepts may be a necessary first step in other college-level science courses.

column5: Post-Practice Dialogues in an Intelligent Tutoring System for College-Level Physics
column15: Sandra Katz, University of Pittsburgh
column17: John Connelly, Christine Wilson, Christopher Goedde
column18: Students often have a poor understanding of the concepts associated with quantitative physics problems, even those that they are able to solve without difficulty. We investigated the effectiveness of asking college students questions that focus on physics concepts immediately after they solved problems in the Andes physics tutoring system (VanLehn et al., 2005), and of providing help with answering these questions by engaging students in natural-language dialogues with the simulated tutor. We compared a control group who did not engage in these dialogues with a treatment group who did, under three different approaches: tutor-led dialogue with canned feedback, tutor-led dialogue with tailored feedback, and mixed-initiative dialogue with tailored feedback. The study was conducted in college-level physics classes at the U.S. Naval Academy. The main result was that the more dialogues that students did, the more they learned, as measured by a post-test, independent of the specific type of dialogue approach.

column5: Reorganizing Traditional Introductory Physics Laboratory Exercises with Context
column15: Mizuho K Schwalm, University of Minnesota-Crookston
column18: Almost all introductory physics textbooks deal examples of real world problems but this is often not done in the traditional physics laboratory instruction.
