Students are reasonably satisfied by getting anticipated data and results during the laboratory exercises. However, they may not have much understanding of why they are doing the exercises or how it relates to real world problems. Problems Solving Labs with context rich problems advocated by UMPERDG[1] represent an effort to make better connection between the laboratory instruction and the real world problems. While using traditional lab equipment but reorganizing the focus of the lab exercises and developing pre laboratory quizzes we are developing new laboratory curricula for UND and UM-Crookston.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant #DUE-0510570.

column5: Model-Based Teaching of Electricity: Improving Student Reasoning and Confidence
column15: Grant Williams, University of Massachusetts - Amherst
column18: This study compared high school physics classes using a curriculum that explicitly promotes students? construction and revision of mental models in their understanding of circuit electricity, with those that followed a more traditional approach to learning about electric circuits. All students completed pre and post-unit tests designed to determine changes during instruction in their: a) problem solving and reasoning abilities, and b) problem solving and reasoning confidence levels. The study found that students in the model-based learning classes recorded significantly greater gains, both in their ability to solve circuit problems and their reported levels of confidence in solving problems and reasoning about circuits than their counterparts who learned the concepts of electricity through traditional means. New diagramming techniques were developed to aid in analysis of videotaped whole-class discussions in the model-based classes and these were used to generate hypotheses about the nature of the successful teaching strategies employed.

column5: Good and Bad Uses of Mathematica in Physics Curriculum
column15: William A Schwalm, University of North Dakota
column18: Experienced teachers aware of the amount of material to be covered in upper level physics are leery of introducing computer exercises to the already crowded course schedules. Overloading the task of learning a computer programming language where it competes with other learning objectives can prove to be unwise. As a computer language and learning tool Mathematica has exceptional properties, although the learning curve is steep. At our school students can learn Mathematica in a summer workshop or in a physics computer course, but the essential point is how it is integrated into the rest of the curriculum, e.g., in the context of mechanics or electromagnetism. This talk is about a way of using symbolic computation that deemphasizes formal programming and focuses on the physical context. We give a general principle and example applications from the core courses.

column5: School Science vs. Real Science: Breaking the Cycle
column15: Robert H Poel, Western Michigan University
column18: It is not unusual to hear educators say that interactions with both nature and other learners are essential to real and meaningful learning. Since current research supports this, how can we help change K-16 science from teaching by telling (based upon the authority of the text and teacher) to having students learnhow to pose questions, design investigations, and make evidence-based claims? PhysTEC, an NSF funded project of AAPT, APS, and AIP, believes that one key to this dilemma lies in the preparation and support of physics and physical science teachers. This paper, based on emerging work in several PhysTEC institutions, proposes that the nuture and support of teachers as they cope with challenges of classroom, curriculum, and learning management is crucial to answering this question. This mentoring should begin as soon as a candidate is identified and continue during the initial years of teaching, possibly for a 10-year period (including the pre-service years).

column5: Do Interactive Simulations Help Engineering Students Better Understand Compton Scattering?
column15: Milijana Suskavcevic, University of Texas at El Paso
column18: A set of interactive computer based module of several key modern physics phenomena has been developed, implemented, and tested at the University of Texas at El Paso. The module were constructed using the Lab View programming environment and implemented in a course on Modern Physics for engineers. Three randomly selected groups of engineering undergraduates were pre and post tested on the content understanding of the Compton Effect. The experimental group did the computer simulation, ?quasi-experimental? group took the interactive handout, and the comparison group did not undergo any intervention. In our assessments we compare concept gain differences on content tests between these groups. Furthermore, we review the results of our analysis and discuss future work on improving the simulations and our assessment procedures

column5: Incremental Integration of Computational Physics into Traditional Undergraduate Courses
column15: Kelly R Roos, Bradley University
column18: Over the last ten years to I have endeavored to provide effective computational physics instruction to my undergraduate students enrolled in my classical mechanics, and statistical mechanics and thermodynamics courses by introducing computational issues in what I consider to be a natural manner by merely extending the traditional cannon of material covered to include numerical solutions (the students are required to produce the numerical solutions!) of some of the analysis which cannot be cast into closed-form. Also, to properly introduce students to such topics as chaos and nonlinearity, and to the stochastic nature of many topics in statistical mechanics, computational techniques do not just augment the treatment, they are utterly necessary! I believe this approach has been especially effective because the computational material fits well into its ?natural habitat?; that is, within the context of the physics that generates the need for the computational treatment. I will cover the details of my approach and show some examples of what the students have been exposed to.

column5: An Implementation and Evaluation of "Tutorials in Introductory Physics"
column15: Robert J Endorf, University of Cincinnati
column17: Gregory A Braun, Kathleen M Koenig, Cyrill Slezak
column18: We describe our adaptation and implementation of the "Tutorials in Introductory Physics" by Lillian McDermott, Peter Shaffer and the Physics Education Group at the University of Washington, in the recitation sections of the large introductory calculus-based physics courses taught at the University of Cincinnati. These courses are taken by approximately 600 students each year, most of whom are first year engineering students. Results will be presented on our investigations of increased student conceptual understanding, based on pretests and posttests given to the students in the courses. Our results indicate that the tutorials are more effective than traditional recitation classes and that the manner in which the instructor interacts with the students in teaching the class is critical.

column5: Introducing Students to LabVIEW Without Tying Up the Semester
column15: Marty Johnston, University of St. Thomas
column18: Like many worthwhile endeavors, programming in LabVIEW has a significant learning curve. By integrating LabVIEW into our sophomore level modern physics and experimental methods courses as well as our junior level optics course we have successfully introduced students to programming in LabVIEW. By carefully picking specific aspects of the language tailored to specific courses we can teach the programming techniques in conjunction with physics applications instead of just focusing on programming skills. Students? first introduction to LabVIEW is in modern physics laboratory where they use prewritten applications to collect data. Following a short tutorial, students can make simple modifications to the data collection programs. Formal development of LabVIEW programming skills takes place in the experimental methods course and is further refined in optics. Student response to the spread-out approach to learning a language has been excellent. Future plans include introducing LabVIEW into the introductory classical physics sequence.

column5: Web-Based Tutorials for Enhancing Problem-Solving Skills of Introductory Physics Students
column15: Daniel Haileselassie, University of Pittsburgh
column18: We are developing interactive web-based problem-solving tutorials in order to help introductory physics students learn effective problem-solving heuristics and enhance their problem solving, reasoning, and meta-cognitive abilities. The self-paced tutorials provide scaffolding support for a variety of problem solving techniques,and opportunities for knowledge and skill acquisition. We discuss the assessment of the tutorials which involves controlled studies comparing performance of the learners using tutorials with those who learn identical content from other means.
column19: Supported by NSF-DUE 0442087. Sponsored by Chandralekha Singh.

column5: Assessment of Using the Clickers
column15: Pengfei Li, The Ohio State University
column18: At Ohio State University, clicker, an in-class polling system, was assessed in the electromagnetism quarter of a year-long introductory class. Two lecture sections were taught, only one of which used clickers. Assessment the effectiveness of clicker usage was conducted in various ways. Normalized gains of the Concept Survey of Electromagetism (CSEM) and common exam results were compared between the clicker section and nonclicker section. Results show the clicker section performs better on both the CSEM and common exam question. In this talk, we will discuss the some preliminary results of this assessment.

column5: Tutorials on Coulomb's and Gauss's Laws
column15: Zeynep Isvan, University of Pittsburgh
column18: We discuss the development and assessment of research-based tutorials on helping students learn about Coulomb's law, superposition, symmetry and Gauss's Law. We discuss the performance of students on the pre-/post-tests given before and after the tutorials in several calculus-based introductory physics courses. We also discuss the findings from individual interviews with students. We compare the performance of students using the tutorials in the regular sections of the calculus-based courses with honors students who did not use the tutorials.

column5: Assessment of In-class Polling System in Lectures
column15: Pengfei Li, The Ohio State University
column18: At Ohio State University, use of an in-class polling system (clickers), was assessed in the electromagnetism quarter of a year-long introductory class. Two lecture sections were taught, but only one of them used clickers. In this poster, we will discuss preliminary results that include a comparison of normalized gains from pre and post testing with the Concept Survey of Electromagetism (CSEM), common exam questions, and clicker surveys.

column5: Investigating Student Understanding of Quantum Mechanics
column15: Chandralekha Singh, University of Pittsburgh
column18: We are investigating the difficulties that students have in learning upper-level quantum mechanics. Our investigation includes about 100 hours of interviews with individual students and the development and administration of free-response and multiple-choice tests. We are designing and evaluating quantum interactive learning tutorials (QuILTs).

column5: Student Response to Innovation in Introductory Physics
column15: Maria Ruibal Villasenor, Rutgers University
column18: The design of some of the introductory physics courses at Rutgers University has been changed. From an underlying educational philosophy that stressed primarily subject area content, they have moved to one that in addition to content understanding promotes the development of scientific abilities, critical thinking skills, and creativity. However, this reform is not embraced by all of the students. Some of them seem unwilling to redefine their role in the classroom and/or their ideas about a structure of an introductory science course. We conducted a qualitative study to investigate ways in which students react to the changes in the learning and teaching methods implemented in our innovative physics course; the environmental conditions that affect their responses to the changes; and the consequences of student responses for learning. A good understanding of the phenomenon will provide us with an invaluable tool to help students assimilate scientific ways of thinking.

column5: Workshop on Teacher Preparation at Ohio Section's Spring 2006 Meeting
column15: Susan E Ramlo, The University of Akron
column18: The Ohio Section received financial support from the AAPT Executive Board to actively address issues concerning the preparation of K-12 teachers. The State of Ohio uses Academic Curriculum Standards to indicate the content standards, including benchmarks and indicators. These standards stress that the need for familiarity with these standards and to complete an analysis of the current science program. Our workshop session focus was to familiarize those attending with the standards related to learning physics in grades K-12. We hoped that both K-12 teachers and physics educators from higher education, who play a role in pre-service teacher education, would participate in this session. Instead, the majority of participants represented two-year college faculty. Still, our discussions concerning the current Ohio standards and preparation for teaching introductory physics courses were enlightening. This poster will highlight the findings, from discussions and a survey, and the implications for our section and AAPT.

column5: Design and Assessment of a Physics Exploration Center for Large Introductory Courses
column15: Chandralekha Singh, University of Pittsburgh
column18: We have designed a ``Physics Exploration Center" (PEC) to supplement lecture-oriented teaching in the large introductory physics courses. At PEC, physics lecture demonstrations are turned into fun activities that are integrated with the introductory physics courses. The central objective of PEC is to provide students an opportunity for hands-on, demonstration-based homework problems. These can be assigned in large classes since students can do them at their own convenience and at their own pace during the week. Students are encouraged to predict the outcomes of the activities before they perform them in PEC. The PEC experience is different from a traditional laboratory, and is meant to be more conceptual and open-ended. The primary purpose is to help students with conceptual understanding of the lecture material, to challenge their preconceptions by providing contradictory experiences, and introduce them to scientific method. Evaluation of PEC by administering standardized pre/post tests with appropriate control group shows that visualization of concepts helps students in conceptual understanding of the material discussed in the lecture and in developing physical intuition about the phenomena. A student survey of PEC shows that a majority of students enjoy the hands-on activities in PEC and find them useful in understanding and remembering concepts.

column5: Vascular Analysis: Where Geometry Is King
column15: Kenneth R Hoffmann
column18: Radiologic vascular analysis is based on relatively simple physical and geometric principles. X-ray images, acquired using a divergent projection geometry, are generated by differences in absorption of x-rays in different anatomic structures. As a first approximation, blood vessels can be modeled as tapering circular cylinders. When two or more x-ray views are obtained, the 3-D imaging geometry can be determined using simple geometric relationships. Computational fluid dynamic techniques, which are used to solve the Navier-Stokes equations, allow analysis of flow in the 3-D vasculature. In this talk we will review some basic physics and geometry pertaining to vascular analysis, and discuss applications of this to our study of blood flow in aneurysms, including factors potentially responsible for aneurysm growth.

column5: Student Understanding of Magnetostatics
column15: Chandralekha Singh, University of Pittsburgh
column18: We have been investigating the difficulties that students in the algebra- and calculus-based introductory physics courses have with concepts related to magnetostatics. We discuss the findings from written free-response and multiple-choice tests given to several thousand students and from individual interviews with a subset of students.

column5: Writing to Learn in Post-Secondary, Calculus-Based Physics Laboratories
column15: Matthew Wiesner, Marquette University
column18: This report describes a one-year study that sought to determine if the use of a framework of writing assignments that were increasingly complex but all closely related would lead to greater comprehension and retention of physics content. The project also sought to test whether the practice in science writing would improve student?s technical communication skills. This study was part of a larger project which implemented these writing assignments first in non-calculus based physics labs and then into calculus-based labs. The instruments used to measure and evaluate the success of the study included the administration of diagnostic tests at the beginning and at the end of the two semesters, a collection of writing samples from representative students and solicitation of student feedback in surveys and interviews.

column5: An Apparatus to Demonstrate the Energy Stored in a Capacitor
column15: Andrew D Tomasch
column17: Ramon S Armen, David W Gerdes
column18: We describe a simple apparatus to quantitatively demonstrate the energy U stored in a capacitor of capacitance C charged to a potential difference V, by directly extracting mechanical work. The work delivered by a small motor and gearbox can be obtained directly by measuring the distance a known mass is lifted vertically in the earth's gravitational field. Students can quantitatively measure the relationship between the energy stored in the capacitor and the extracted mechanical work and calculate the efficiency for the system. The apparatus has been developed for use in introductory E&M; laboratory courses, and is constructed from readily obtained commercial parts requiring a minimum amount of skilled labor for fabrication and assembly.

column5: Sparks from Journals
column15: Gorazd Planinsic
column18: Why do we read journals such as TPT? To broaden our knowledge, to learn about new teaching strategies and methods, to get new ideas for refreshing our teaching repertoire... but also to get ideas that trigger more ideas of our own, which eventually may result in a new article and thus close the circle. I will present how one of my ideas completed such a circle, appearing on the front cover of TPT and being later implemented in several forms by others. Then I will present one of my new experiments that has lately ignited from the sparks from TPT.

column5: The Computer Physics Bachelor's Degree Progam at Illinois State University
column15: Richard F Martin, Illinois State University
column18: After integrating computational assignments into physics major courses in the early-mid 1990's, the Illinois State University Physics Department initiated a degree sequence in computational physics in 1999. The goals were multifold: the recognition that most working physicsts and engineers use computational methods and to satisfy requests from majors, to offer an alternative to our students who were not interested in a traditional physics career, and to enhance physics major recruitment by taking advantage of perceived student demand for computer-oriented careers. A five-year assessment of the program indicated that the recruitment goal was not accomplished, but made a good case for the other two. We will describe the development and structure of the program and update those assessment results, with an eye toward building practical suggestions for other departments interested in going the computational physics route.

column5: Some Elementary, but Surprising Facts About Evaporation
column15: A. James Mallmann, Milwaukee School of Engineering
column18: Analysis of some easily obtained data for evaporation of liquids made me aware of some facts that surprised me, and that may surprise you as well. Contemplating those facts has inspired some challenging questions and problems for students of introductory physics courses and for the teachers of those courses.

column5: Math Without Math
column15: Kenneth W Ford,
column18: When we talk about using math in physics, we usually mean using some particular organized branch of mathematics such as algebra, geometry, trigonometry, or calculus, and using it to solve problems. In teaching physics to ninth graders (or to any other age group, younger or older), math can be more broadly defined as logical relationships among things?rules of increase and decrease, proportionalities (direct and inverse), causal linkages, patterns, symmetries, how symbols relate to measured concepts, the "meaning" of equations, how to estimate magnitudes and uncertainties, and more. Physics is indeed mathematical?a precept that we should embrace, not dodge or deny, while recognizing that there's a lot more to math in physics than the relentless problem solving that, for many students, gets in the way not only of interest but also of learning.

column5: The MIT Teal Simulations and Visualizations in Electromagnetism
column15: John W Belcher, MIT
column18: We have developed a broad range of 3D visualizations and simulations to foster student intuition about electromagnetic fields and phenomena. We discuss the software approaches we use to create these simulations, including Macromedia Shockwave and Java 3D applets for interactive visualization, passive animations created with 3ds max, and the Dynamic Line Integral Convolution (DLIC) method for constructing time dependent representations of the electromagnetic field. The DLIC method is far superior in depicting the structure of fields compared to other methods. Our strong opinion is that for effective student learning, such visualizations must be embedded in a software framework for their interactive delivery. This ?guided inquiry? framework is essential to influence and optimize what students take away from the visualizations. We have released our Java 3D simulation software as open source with a liberal open source license, with support from the Davis Educational Foundation.

column5: A Partnership to Join the Ranks of America's Top Modelers
column15: Kathleen A Harper, The Ohio State University
column17: Jason M. Cervenec, Andrew F. Heckler
column18: A phone call from a local teacher to an Ohio State University employee in 2003 started a partnership that to date has offered 3 state-funded multi-week summer workshops for physics and physical science teachers.1 Additionally, it has produced a revamping of the local physics alliance, several conference presentations, and a publication.2 The collaboration credits several factors for this success: 1) Each partner knows his/her strengths and weaknesses. 2) The center of these activities is the exemplary Modeling method developed at Arizona State University.3 3) The workshop has addressed the state?s science standards. 4) Modifications made to the original ASU structure have been based upon research. This talk will focus on the summer workshops, including seeking funds, planning, structuring, and evaluating.

column5: Learning Writing to Learn: Training for Undergraduate Physics Lab Teaching-Assistants
column15: Melissa A Vigil, Marquette University
column18: This report describes the teacher training aspect of a one-year study that sought to determine if the use of a framework of writing assignments that were increasingly complex but all closely related would lead to greater comprehension and retention of physics content. The project also sought to test whether the practice in science writing would improve student?s technical communication skills. Staff from the university writing center worked together with the physics department to develop training for the TA?s. Assessment of the training program included analysis of student work, associated TA feedback, student surveys, and TA interviews.

column5: Is "Force" a Property of an Object or Something Else?
column15: Brant Hinrichs, Drury University
column18: Toward the end of their study of Newton?s Laws, students in an introductory level calculus-based physics course are asked ?Is force a property of an object, or something else? Explain?. The course is taught using Modeling Instruction which was developed at Arizona State University. Relevant instructional details include an emphasis on representing interactions between objects using a diagram called a system schema, and defining force as ?the description of an interaction between two objects?. Typical student responses will be shown and discussed. Similar data from a class taught more traditionally will be compared and contrasted.

column5: Writing in Physics vs. Physics in Writing
column15: Jean-Francois S Van Huele, Brigham Young University
column17: Justin B Peatross, R. Steven Turley
column18: We report on the introduction of an undergraduate Writing in Physics class at Brigham Young University. The class which fulfills the university advanced writing requirement is developed and taught by physics faculty and uses the senior thesis as its main vehicle in order to make the acquisition of writing skills more urgent, more relevant, and more pertinent to the students. We discuss departmental motivation and commitment, and tally the resources expended for the course. With a first (winter) edition completed and second (summer) class under way, we share student and instructor impressions of the class, give our preliminary evaluation and make projections as to where the class is headed. Two fundamental questions motivate and challenge this unique enterprise: can physics truly serve writing and does writing ultimately serve physics?

column5: Multiple Representations and Problem Solving II: Do Students Do What They Say?
column15: David R Rosengrant
column17: Patrick B Kohl, Noah Finkelstein, Eugenia Etkina
column18: Physics education literature indicates that using multiple representations is beneficial for student understanding of physics ideas and for problem solving. Students may say they use representations to help them solve problems, but do they actually construct representations when they solve problems? We analyzed how students in four different classroom settings from three institutions solved five specially designed problems [1 exam, 4 in-class]. Next, we created a questionnaire to document what students say regarding how they use multiple representations, specifically pictures and free-body diagrams, in their physics classes. We compared the responses students gave to the questionnaire with how they actually solved the problems. Finally, we compared student work at the different universities to increase our understanding of the instructor?s influence over how likely a student will construct or thinks she/he will construct a representation to help solve a problem.

column5: How a Problem's Context Influences Students to Construct Free-Body Diagrams
column15: David R Rosengrant
column18: Haim Ginott said that teachers are a decisive element in the classroom. The instructor?s method in the classroom has an effect on how students solve problems. However, the problem?s design may also influence how students solve problems. The instructor in this study follows the Investigative Science Learning Environment (ISLE) curriculum. ISLE is an inquiry based learning system that promotes the use of multiple representations in both conceptual development and problem solving. We analyzed the results of a two year study on how students solved exam problems in an introductory based physics course. We correlated several features of the exam problems to the number of free-body diagrams students constructed to help them solve the problems. Our findings suggest that certain features of exam problems influence a student?s choice to construct a free-body diagram to help him/her solve an exam problem.

column5: Outreach at Different Levels
column15: Hang Deng-Luzader, Frostburg State University
column18: Dept. of Physics/Engineering at Frostburg State University has organized several outreach programs for the community. The programs were designed to reach out to the students at different levels. I will share our experience by this presentation.

column5: Teaching Scientific Process Skills to Future Teachers
column15: Frank Hicks, California State University, Sacramento
column18: Science education standards require teachers to help their students conduct scientific inquiries, but few teachers have carried out scientific inquiries themselves. A major barrier is proposing and selecting high quality investigation questions. This is now one focus of the physics course for future K-8 teachers at Sacramento State. In "Conceptual Physics and Scientific Inquiry," the scientific process is directly modeled as students go through a complete cycle of a scientific inquiry. In coursework that runs parallel to content knowledge development, students: 1) individually come up with a set of questions they are interested in; 2) select and revise one of their questions to submit as a formal proposal; 3) as a group, choose one of the proposals and carry out the investigation; 4) formally report the results of their investigation. This talk and poster will describe the relevant course materials, present sample work, and discuss preliminary results assessing the success of this approach.

column5: Teaching Scientific Process Skills to Future Teachers
column15: Frank Hicks, California State University, Sacramento
column18: Science education standards require teachers to help their students conduct scientific inquiries, but few teachers have carried out scientific inquiries themselves. A major barrier is proposing and selecting high quality investigation questions. This is now one focus of the physics course for future K-8 teachers at Sacramento State. In "Conceptual Physics and Scientific Inquiry," the scientific process is directly modeled as students go through a complete cycle of a scientific inquiry. In coursework that runs parallel to content knowledge development, students: 1) individually come up with a set of questions they are interested in; 2) select and revise one of their questions to submit as a formal proposal; 3) as a group, choose one of the proposals and carry out the investigation; 4) formally report the results of their investigation. This talk and poster will describe the relevant course materials, present sample work, and discuss preliminary results assessing the success of this approach.

column5: Investigation of Science and Math Behaviors of High School Teachers
column15: Cynthia M D'Angelo, Arizona State University
column18: One of the projects that the Center for Research on Education in Science, Mathematics, Engineering, and Technology (CRESMET) at Arizona State University is working on is Project Pathways, a Math and Science Partnership (MSP) NSF grant. CRESMET is implementing a four-course graduate level sequence for in-service science and math high school teachers, helping them to gain a deeper understanding of science and math and presenting a model for integrating the two in their own classrooms. I will talk about my research with the science and math high school teachers regarding their behaviors and beliefs about science and math. I will examine how these beliefs affect relations with their fellow teachers, their progress in the courses, and their willingness to enact reforms in their own classes.

column5: Dynamic Imagery During Model Construction in Classroom Discussions
column15: Lynn Stephens, University of Massachusetts
column18: The use of a set of imagery indicators has enabled us to code videotaped large class discussions for evidence of student use of mental imagery. This makes possible an investigation into the roles that imagery appears to be playing in student reasoning. In a case study of a high school classroom involved in exploring the nature of gravity, we found that depictive hand motions and reports of imagery?both visual and kinesthetic?are associated with the generation of new model elements by the students. In some instances, it has also been possible to track changes in the visualizable models of an individual student through verbal and gestural contributions to large class discussion. The evidence suggests that, in this classroom, the use of dynamic imagery and mental simulations was central to the learning process as students constructed and refined their mental models.

column5: WYP2005 Physics Talent Search: Engaging Young Minds Worldwide
column15: Andrew D Gavrin, Department of Physics, IUPUI
column18: The WYP2005 Physics Talent Search was an international educational project aimed at increasing participation in physics among middle and high school students and their families. Its primary goal was to create enthusiasm and interest in physics among students who might never have considered physics before. Thus, it was complementary to events that focus on strong physics students, e.g., the Physics Olympiad. The USPTS followed a "merit badge" model: students earned points for activities such as interviewing a physicist, or developing a physics lesson and delivering it to younger students. Students also completed one required experiment. Students earned various levels of distinction at different point levels. At its conclusion, the top six students (three boys, three girls) from twenty countries on five continents participated in an international symposium hosted by Tamkang University in Taipei, Taiwan. This talk presents an evaluation of the Talent Search, which will be repeated in 2006-07.

column5: Helping Undergraduates Climb the Computational Physics Learning Curve
column15: Louis F DeChiaro
column18: Today?s science graduates need considerably more computational skills than their predecessors if they wish to strategically differentiate themselves from their competitors in nearly any of the technical professions. This paper summarizes the author?s strategies to identify the optimal combination of software environments and computational physics topics and to deliver the material. The goals are first, to ensure that the students acquire a minimum level of programming competence and second, to build upon this and form a firm foundation that will prepare them either for graduate study or for immediate entry into the job market.

column5: Validity and Reliability of the Force and Motion Conceptual Evaluation
column15: Susan E Ramlo, The University of Akron
column18: The Force and Motion Conceptual Evaluation (FMCE) is a multiple-choice test that has been used to evaluate the learning of force and motion concepts. However, the validity and reliability estimates have not been determined in the way a social scientist would expect, based upon psychometric data. This study used FMCE post-test results of approximately 150 students in a first-semester college physics course. Reliability of a test is defined as the consistency of the measure (Newman & Newman, 1994). Factor analysis of students' answers (scored as 1 for correct and 0 for incorrect) was used to examine the structural validity of the FMCE. The results indicate that the FMCE has very high reliability and validity. The Cronbach alpha estimate for reliability was .907. The post-test factor structure consisted of three factors: Newton's First and Second Laws, Newton's Third Law, and Velocity.

column5: Can the Lawson Test Predict a Student Grades?
column15: Michael A Dubson, Univ. of Colorado at Boulder
column18: Recently, Coletta and Phillips[1] suggested using the Lawson test of scientific reasoning along with the FCI to measure the effectiveness of alternative interactive engagement strategies. In a 500-student algebra-based, college physics course, we administered the Lawson test as a pre-test, as well as the Force Concept Inventory and the CLASS (Colorado attitude survey), both pre- and post. This course was taught using interactive engagement techniques, including concept tests and peer instruction during lecture, Tutorial-style group work during recitation and lab, and heavy emphasis on qualitative reasoning and conceptual understanding on exams and homeworks. We find a significant correlation between course performance and Lawson pre-test score. We will report on detailed correlations among course performance, Lawson pretest, FCI pre and gain, CLASS pre and gain, as well as gender effects.
column19: Supported in part by NSF CCLI, DUE #0410744.

column5: Improving Introductory Physics at Chicago State University I: Background and Motivation
column15: Samuel P Bowen, Chicago State Univ.
column18: The physics program at Chicago State University (CSU) is currently in its second year of a project supported by a National Science Foundation ? Course, Curriculum, and Laboratory Improvement (CCLI) Grant. This funding has allowed CSU to make major changes in how the introductory physics course is taught by implementing a wide variety of research-based instructional materials. In this talk we provide a background on our project, discuss the current status, and present the successes and challenges we face in implementing these materials. In the following talk we discuss some of our efforts to measure the effectiveness of our implementation.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant #DUE-0410068. Sponsored by Mel Sabella.

column5: Computing in the Introductory Physics Course
column15: Ruth W Chabay
column18: In the Matter & Interactions version of the calculus-based introductory physics course (http://www4.ncsu.edu/~rwchabay/mi), students write programs in VPython (http://vpython.org) to model physical systems and to calculate and visualize electric and magnetic fields. VPython is unusually easy to learn, produces navigable 3D animations as a side effect of physics computations, and supports full vector calculations. The high speed of current computers makes sophisticated numerical analysis techniques unnecessary. Students can use simple first-order Euler integration, cutting the step size until the behavior of the system no longer changes. In mechanics, iterative application of the momentum principle gives students a sense of the time-evolution character of Newton's second law which is usually missing from the standard course. In E&M;, students calculate electric and magnetic fields numerically and display them in 3D. We are currently studying the impact of introducing computational physics into the introductory course.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant DUE-0237132.

column5: Put a Little Geophysics in Your Program
column15: Jim Lehman, James Madison University/Retired
column18: In 1975 a seismic sensor was designed in the Physics Department of James Madison College (now J.M.U.).This reasonably simple design was well received, and a number of seismic systems resulted. The simplicity of the sensor lends itself as a student construction project. Interfacing the electro-mechanical device enables one to record events with a traditional long period profile. Skills exercised are simple machine shop techniques, op-amp electronics, and interfacing to a chart recorder or an A/D converter to a computer display. Several typical world and continental performance records will be displayed including atomic tests of earlier days and a seismic "caustic".

column5: Improving Introductory Physics at Chicago State University II: Implementation
column15: Kim Coble, Chicago State Univ.
column17: Samuel P Bowen, Mel S Sabella
column18: Funding from the National Science Foundation has allowed Chicago State University to restructure and improve the introductory algebra and calculus-based physics classes through the use of research-based instructional materials. Because there has been little work on evaluating the effectiveness of these materials at an urban institution, we have been involved in a systematic investigation that looks at the effectiveness of these materials with our population of students. In this talk we provide a specific example of our evaluation efforts in the context of the algebra-based course. Although our preliminary results indicate that these instructional changes have led to improved attitudes toward physics, better understanding of certain concepts, and improved scores on some diagnostics, we anticipate that further revisions to our courses will lead to additional gains.

column5: How Should We Teach Special Relativity?
column15: Walter S Jaronski, Radford University
column18: This talk is inspired by a rereading of a paper by Bell with a similar, albeit more dogmatic, title [1] and by teaching (again) a standard sophomore/junior modern physics course. I am struck by a couple of things in the standard textbook treatment of special relativity: (1) the slight coverage, indeed virtual neglect, of the precursors of special relativity, and (2) the very cautious language used in discussing kinematical effects, particularly the Lorentz contraction. Einstein?s contributions are rightly emphasized, but ignoring the work of FitzGerald, Lorentz, Larmor, and Poincar presents the development of the theory in a somewhat misleading context. On the other hand, the Michelson-Morley experiment is perhaps given more attention than it deserves. If time permits, Bell?s spaceship paradox will also be discussed.

column5: Applying the Methods and Tools of PER to Reveal Isolated Sets of Knowledge in Physics Students
column15: Mel S Sabella, Chicago State University
column18: Physics education researchers have learned a great deal about students? conceptual knowledge. However, conceptual knowledge is only one part of what students need to know in order to solve complex physics problems. They also need to know how and when to use that knowledge and be able to connect different types of knowledge. In this talk we look at representations of knowledge from the cognitive science and the Physics Education Research perspective. We show how the methods employed by those in PER can be used to provide evidence that the knowledge our students form is often characterized by local coherences that may inhibit their access to additional needed information.

column5: Investigating Learning Capabilities of Artificial Neural Networks
column15: Edgardo L Ortiz, University of Massachusetts, Amherst
column17: William J Gerace, Robert J Dufresne
column18: Can artificial neural networks (ANNs) be used to model students' physics knowledge and predict how they will answer questions? In order to answer this we are developing an online test in the area of introductory mechanics for eliciting students? conceptual associations and obtaining a measurement of performance. The test consists of two parts: a Conceptual Mapping (ConMap) task known as Situation-Prompted Term Entry (SPTE), in which subjects are presented with physics situations and expected to enter physics terms triggered by the situations, and a series of questions constructed for each situation in three categories: conceptual understanding, reasoning, and problem solving. An ANN will be constructed and trained using the data obtained from students? answers to both parts of the test. Once trained the ANN can be used as a predictor of students? responses to physics questions that could help us construct better assessment and diagnostic tools, and tutoring systems.

column5: National Studies: What Are the Goals for Physics Courses?
column15: Alan Van Heuvelen, Rutgers University
column18: I will systematically analyze several recent (ten years or less) national studies and reports concerning education in science, math, and engineering. What do these studies suggest as goals for the instruction in our courses? For example, would they be happy if our students left introductory calculus-based physics courses with a good understanding of the physics concepts and an ability to work the problems at the end of book chapters? Or do they want more, and if so, what are other important goals which these reports encourage? Is there any relationship between the goals of the reports and changes in our society while moving from manufacturing in the 20th century to a knowledge age in the 21st century?

column5: Toward an Effective Use of Clickers in Lectures
column15: Neville W Reay
column18: It has been widely demonstrated that clickers (electronic polling systems) engage students in lectures, but less has been done to create and assess strategies for their use. The hypotheses that learning is context dependent, and that explicit cognitive discrepancies might play a catalytic role in helping students restructure their existing knowledge framework, were applied to create a strategy. Question sequences, each displaying a single concept in a variety of contexts, were developed to trigger cognitive discrepancies in students during lectures. Over 40 such sequences containing more than 130 individual electricity and magnetism questions were used in introductory physics courses at The Ohio State University. Studies comparing clicker lecture sections that used the question sequences with non-clicker control sections were conducted for several quarters. Results shed light on the effectiveness of the method and indicate possible directions for future development.

column5: Students' Framing While Using Mathematica
column15: Thomas J Bing, University of Maryland
column18: External tools such as paper, abacuses, and symbolic representations increase our ability to solve problems by off-loading memory onto external storage. Powerful computer programs like Mathematica carry this process a step further. They actually off-load processing power and function dynamically on their own by making representational decisions and performing elaborate symbolic manipulations, numeric calculations, and graphical renderings. We have videotaped advanced undergraduate physics majors working on homework problems in groups and see a number of dramatic effects of their use of Mathematica. How students frame their activity becomes especially critical when such a dynamic tool is in use. We have seen them frame their use of Mathematica differently in different situations, ranging from treating it as a sense-making companion to seeing it as an inscrutable but omniscient oracle. This framing has implications for how they think about the problem they are solving.

column5: Getting Everyone Onboard: Adding Computational Elements Across the Curriculum
column15: Marty Johnston, University of St. Thomas
column18: Undergraduate physics programs traditionally focus on developing solid analytical and laboratory skills. While analytical skills provide the theoretical framework for much of physics, in the real-world, computational methods also play a role in finding solutions. Over the past decade, many in the physics community are realizing that we are doing a dismal job of teaching computational techniques. Most programs endeavor to address this shortcoming, but implementation is often inconsistent. These efforts are often the result of dedicated work by one or two faculty members and don?t directly influence courses taught by others. In our department, we are working to rectify this problem by integrating computational elements across the entire curriculum. This is not an easy task to accomplish, particularity since there are widely varying levels of computational skills among the faculty. A healthy, collaborative spirit is essential for successful implementation of wide-scale curricular changes involving the entire department.

column5: The Cognitive Blending of Mathematics and Physics Knowledge
column15: Thomas J Bing, University of Maryland
column17: Edward F Redish, Rachel E Scherr
column18: An important sign of physics students? progress is their combining the symbols and structures of mathematics with their physical knowledge and intuition, enhancing both. No longer just symbols to be manipulated upon, the numbers, variables, and equations of the mathematics we use in physics come to represent physical ideas and relations. Likewise, physical intuitions become encoded in a precise way that readily lends itself to the complex manipulations often required of a physicist. The language of conceptual blending, introduced by Fauconnier and Turner [1], provides an excellent framework for discussing this combination of mathematical and physical knowledge. Several examples from university physics classes will be analyzed within this framework, highlighting how physicists tend to interpret expressions not just according to the rules of mathematics but also through the lens of physical experience.

column5: The Not-So-Simple Pendulum
column15: Clifford E Swartz, Stony Brook University
column18: The restoring force on a pendulum bob is proportional to the sine of the angle between the vertical and the string. The exact solution to the differential equation leads to an elliptic integral that is messy to solve. The approximation that the sine of the angle is equal to the angle yields a value for the period that is wrong by less than 1 percent for angles less than 27 degrees. Most pendulums are not quite that simple, however. Take the cawe of a pendulum with a string 10 cm long (to the center of the bob) with the bob having a diameter of 2 cm. For a first approximation, model the ball cut in half horizontally, glued together again, with each hemisphere having its own length of string. For this pendulum the error in the period is 0.5 per cent. Hand outs will give the details.

column5: Disequilibration-Driven Inquiry to Develop Understanding
column15: Dewey I Dykstra, Jr., Boise State University
column18: Before many of us in the physics community heard of Jean Piaget, he was developing a theory that people strive for equilibration between their experiences and the mental constructs they create to explain their experiences. When a state of disequilibration is perceived between one?s mental constructs and experiences, one makes moves to accommodate to achieve re-equilibration. When accommodation is in one?s mental constructs, as an explanatory system for experience, the re-equilibration constitutes development. The self-constructed explanatory system constitutes knowledge in this theory. This would be just a theory, if it did not usefully inform physics instruction. Data will be presented that such a theory can inform instruction with substantial positive results. The resulting instruction is subtly and profoundly different.

column5: Infrastructure Support for Doctoral Research in Optics & Photonics at Hampton University
column15: Uwe Hommerich, Hampton University
column17: JaeTae Seo, EiEi Brown, Bagher Tabibi, Doyle Temple
column18: We report results of an infrastructure support program for doctoral research in optics and photonics at Hampton University. The goals of this ongoing NSF HBCU-RISE program are to strengthen the education and research training in the growing Physics Ph.D. program at H.U. and to build a pipeline of minority students pursuing advanced degrees in engineering and science disciplines. The specific emphasis of the grant is to enhance the education and research capabilities in the area of Optics & Photonics. Research activities in this program are focused on two thrusts: i) luminescent materials development and ii) nonlinear optical spectroscopy of nano-structured materials. Educational activities during the first two years of this award included the recruitment of new graduate students, research mentoring, curriculum development, and outreach to local high schools.

column5: Mini-Projects: Bridging the Gap Between School Knowledge and Model Design
column15: Dorothy V Langley
column18: Eleventh grade physics majors participate in a 12 month, out-of-school, "Physics & Industry" program, during which they design a working model based on electro-optical principles. The gap between students' existing and required physics content knowledge, and technological and technical skills presents a major instructional challenge. We employ two initial stages for bridging the gap. The first stage involves training in Divergent Thinking strategies of Systematic Inventive Thinking and constructing solution models employing ?imaginary elves?. The second stage consists of 90 minute mini-project activities intended to initiate the students into an applicative, engineering, team work frame of mind. Each mini-project is preceded by a guided exploration, highlighting pertinent physics knowledge and is accompanied by a semi-structured worksheet consisting of two main sections: ?Presentation of the technological problem" and "Team performance report". We shall report on typical performance and reflection of over 50 students who have participated in performing three mini projects.

column5: Phenomenal Physics: A Guided Inquiry Curriculum
column15: Russ Harkay, Keene State College
column18: Inquiry has become a buzzword of late, even though texts on the topic existed as early as the 1960's. The presenter uses material from his textbook, develped under NSF grant Project Inspire and experience in the clasroom to answer such questions as "What IS inquiry and what is its place in the classroom" and "Are there limitations imposed by thsi methodology and how might one minimize those?" Statistics show that the mode of instruction presented here is not only flexible, with value in grades middle school through conceptual college courses for nonscientists, but leads to a remarkable level of retention, interest in the subject, and total lack of apprehension. At Keene State, we also apply this methodology to the preparation of pre-service elementary and middle school teachers who are majoring in General Science with much success. Handouts will be available for exercises and examples demonstrated, including Java Script, Beady Eyes, and Resonance.

column5: Scientists and Innovators in the Schools: Helping Teachers to Make a Difference
column15: Marina Milner-Bolotin, Univeristy of British Columbia
column17: Valery Milner, Aviv Milner, Arie Milner
column18: Scientists and Innovators in the Schools (SIS) is a North American Non-Profit Organization that helps link scientists with local schools. In British Columbia, SIS is supported by BC PALS funding and is administered by Science World. British Columbia with its population of about four million has more than three hundred active SIS volunteers visiting local schools and helping bring the excitement of science to all the students in the province. During the 2004-2005 year more than 97,000 students were visited. The effect of the scientists' visits is especially prominent for the elementary school children who have often very little access to "real" scientists. Feedback from the teachers and students indicates that a visit by a scientist can spark students' interest and make them interested in pursuing science careers in the future. The experiences of a family of four SIS volunteers (parents-scientists and their children) in BC schools will be presented.

column5: Physics and Industry: Project-Based Learning with Systematic Inventive Thinking
column15: Shay Soffer , The Weizmann Institute of Science
column18: The ?Physics and Industry? program is collaboration between schools, the science teaching department at the Weizmann Institute and the electro-optics industry. In this program, high-school physics students in the 11th-12th grade carry out throughout a year, a project concerned with an authentic design problem. They are mentored collaboratively by engineers, teachers and experts of systematic inventive thinking (SIT). The students study electro-optics, use SIT for divergent and convergent reasoning; run experiments; document the process in a portfolio; conclude with a working-model; and present the project in an oral matriculation examination. We have investigated aspects of students' learning such as the ability to offer alternative solutions; constraint-based decision making; coherence between task, methods and outcomes; knowledge of physics; and reflection about design and investigation processes. The results indicate that students advanced in all these aspects; had high success in the matriculation; and were very satisfied with the program's contribution.

column5: The Investigative Science Learning Environment in an Introductory Electromagnetism Course
column15: Xueli Zou, California State University, Chico
column18: In collaboration with the Physics and Astronomy Education Research Group at Rutgers University, an investigative science learning environment (ISLE) [1] has been developed, implemented, and tested in a calculus-based introductory EM course at California State University, Chico. ISLE students follow a cycle of observing physical phenomena, devising conceptual explanations, inventing physical quantities and mathematical models, testing, and applying their models for each unit of concepts. This paper will illustrate how students learn in this environment and what scientific investigation skills they develop.
column19: Supported in part by NSF DUE # 0242845 and #0088906.

column2: University and K-12 Partnerships That Work
column5: Increasing the Potential of Your Grant
column15: Karen J Matsler, Education, Assessment, and Training.Inc
column18: Math and science initiatives are at the forefront of the American public due to the American Competitiveness Initiative proposed by President Bush. There is a need for more teachers of science, particularly in the physical sciences and engineering, and AAPT members must be willing to help teachers meet those challenges. Teachers need additional training in the physical sciences, however, that training is costly. The AAPT/PTRA program has been training secondary teachers in physics and physical science for over 20 years. In order to remain effective, the AAPT/PTRA program has looked at both internal and external evaluations as well as other sources of information and alternative sources of funding. This talk will discuss the latest initiatives of the AAPT/PTRA program, how evaluations were used to increase the effectiveness of the program, and discuss how they are utilizing grants to maintain their program.

column5: A Program for Boston-Area Teachers: Two Years of Lessons
column15: Andrew G Duffy, Department of Physics, Boston University
column17: Peter Garik, Luciana Garbayo, Tiffany Sikorski, John Son
column18: Through a joint effort of the Department of Physics and the School of Education, Boston University is currently offering a 20-credit graduate program to provide in-service high-school physics teachers with comprehensive courses that cover physics content, the physics education research literature, and the conceptual history of physics. The physics content is taught in a hands-on workshop format. The program is aimed at cross-over teachers (teachers not licensed to teach physics), of which there are a significant number in the Boston area. We will report on the second year of the program, during which the first cohort of teachers completed the program, and the second cohort completed the first half of the program.

column5: What Support Do New Physics Teachers Ask For?
column15: Brian Adrian, Kansas State University
column18: Teachers of physics can often lack the type of support they desperately need. The Physics Teaching Web Advisory (Pathway) is a dynamic digital library for physics teaching that is designed to offer such support. Carnegie Mellon University?s synthetic interview technology provides the foundation for a system that allows physics teachers to ask questions of a virtual mentor and get video responses. A log of the questions asked of our system provides a rich database of information about just what types of support teachers are requesting. This talk will present a summary of the common types of questions teachers ask. Such information is valuable as we design support systems for physics teachers, both new and experienced.
column19: Supported by NSF grants DUE-0226157, DUE-0226219, ESI-0455772, and ESI-0455813.

column5: Multiple Representations and Problem Solving in Different University Environments
column15: Patrick B Kohl, University of Colorado at Boulder
column18: Professional physicists, scientists, and engineers are experts at handling multiple representations of problems simultaneously. Thus, physics instructors strongly value improving student competence with multiple representations. However, even reform-oriented instructors differ in their approach to promoting multiple representation problem-solving abilities. In a study of multiple representation use, we gave students a total of five free-body diagram problems in recitation and exams. We studied students in two large-lecture algebra-based physics courses at Rutgers, one at the University of Colorado (CU), and a smaller course at The College of New Jersey. The courses differ significantly in their implementation, especially with respect to their use of multiple representations: The Rutgers and TCNJ courses are reformed and explicitly teach a concrete problem-solving heuristic that emphasizes multiple representations. The CU course is also reformed, but teaches problem-solving heuristics and the use of multiple representations implicitly. In this poster, we examine student performance on these multiple-representations tasks, and describe the similarities and differences between the various instructors and course environments. We then correlate the different instructional approaches with student success, and begin to investigate how students are making use of representations.

column5: Students' Integration Methods for First-Order Differential Equations
column15: Katrina E Black, University of Maine
column17: Eleanor C Sayre, Michael C Wittmann
column18: While indefinite integration and solving for the value of the integration constant is a technique often stressed in math classes, physicists more often rely on choosing physically relevant limits of integration. We examine intermediate mechanics students? use of boundary conditions in mathematical and physical contexts though small-group interviews and exam results. In a purely mathematical context, students typically depend on a memorized solution or on indefinite integration to find the general result. In both situations, they then use the boundary condition to find the value of the integration constant. When presented with physics problems involving unexpected limits, students often choose inappropriate limits of integration based on what ?seems right? or use indefinite integration. Because our data follows individual students over many weeks of instruction, we can also discuss the evolution of student use of indefinite and definite integrals.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grants DUE-0441426 and DUE-0442388.

column5: Analysis of Student Understanding of Symmetry in Gauss' Law
column15: Katrina E Black, University of Maine
column17: Adrienne L Traxler, John R Thompson
column18: To study introductory physics student difficulties with electrostatics, we compared student use of Gauss' law when finding the electric field for a spherically symmetric and a non-spherically symmetric situation. We used short interviews to design a free-response and multiple-choice-multiple-response survey that was administered to students in introductory calculus-based courses. We describe the development of the survey based on interview data. We also present the survey results and discuss them in light of Singh's results for Gauss' law, Collins and Ferguson's epistemic forms and games, and Tuminaro's extension of games and frames.

column5: Clinical Medical Physics: Bridge Between Technology and People
column15: Robert J Pizzutiello, Upstate Medical Physics,Inc.
column18: Advances in medical imaging have made it possible to obtain diagnostic information about patients quickly and accurately. Clinical medical physicists support physicians, technologists, and other health care providers in making the best use of advanced imaging technology. In this talk some of the physics related to medical imaging will be discussed, and real world examples will be presented illustrating the positive impact of diagnostic medical physics on patient care using radiography, fluoroscopy, CT, and other imaging modalities.

column5: Home Energy Audits: A Service-Learning Project
column15: Beth Parks, Colgate University
column18: In a class on energy sustainability for non-scientists, I include a project in which students complete energy audits for local homeowners. The students learn to determine energy use by appliances and heat loss through convection and conduction. They also determine what improvements to the home would be cost-effective. Students learn skills that will be helpful to them in their future lives, such as focusing on the largest cost (refrigerators, not electric toothbrushes) and considering the yearly cost instead of just the purchase price of an appliance or a home. At the same time, they help a family reduce its energy bills. One difficult lesson, however, is that despite optimistic predictions that energy use in the U.S. can be decreased by as much as 70%, such large reductions are usually only possible with substantially higher investment than is cost-effective at current energy prices.

column5: Physics Teaching Web Advisory (Pathway): Technology and Progress
column15: Dean Zollman, Kansas State University
column18: The Physics Teaching Web Advisory (Pathway) is a new type of digital library for providing ongoing enhancement and preparation for physics teachers. Combining state-of-the-art digital video library technology with contemporary ideas about pedagogy and materials contributed by teachers, Pathway provides continuously improving and always available assistance and expertise for physics teachers. Pathway is building on CMU's Informedia Digital Video Library, and Synthetic Interviews. These systems provide unique ways to extract information from video and audio content. Synthetic Interview is a technology that creates an anthropomorphic interface into video of a person responding to questions. With Synthetic Interviews developed for Pathway, teachers can now "converse" with knowledgeable teachers on issues of physics pedagogy. This poster will describe the methods and content of the project.
column19: Supported by NSF grants DUE-0226157, DUE-0226219, ESI-0455772 & ESI-0455813.

column5: Effects of Changing Representations in 2-D Motion
column15: R. Padraic Springuel, Univeristy of Maine
column17: John R Thompson, Michael C Wittmann
column18: The representation of two-dimensional motion using vectors provides a rich area in which to study how student reasoning about velocity and acceleration depends on the graphical and physical interpretation of the situation. Previous research by Shaffer & McDermott and Flores, Kanim & Kautz has shown that students have a variety of difficulties in using and understanding the necessary vector representations. Thompson?s extensions to this research have shown that changing the physical situation described in the question can change student reasoning about graphical and kinematic quantities. For example, motion along identically drawn curves described as vertical rather than horizontal yields different student reasoning about the kinematics. We report on pretest results from two different years of an introductory algebra-based course. We compare student reasoning about identical physical situations (horizontal motion) with only slightly different representations.

column5: Student (Mis)application of Partial Differentiation to Material Properties
column15: Brandon R Bucy
column17: John R Thompson, Donald B Mountcastle
column18: Students in upper-level undergraduate thermodynamics courses were asked about the relationship between the complementary partial derivatives of the isothermal compressibility (k KAPPA) and the thermal expansion coefficient (b BETA) of a substance. Both these material properties can be expressed with first partial derivatives of the system volume. Several of the responses implied difficulty with the notion of variables held fixed in a partial derivative. Specifically, when asked to find the partial derivative of one of these quantities with respect to a variable that was initially held fixed (e.g., (d k /dT)P) [NOTE TO AAPT: should read as the partial derivative of kappa with respect to T at constant P]), a common response was that this (mixed second) partial derivative must be zero. We have previously reported similar difficulties in the context of the Maxwell relations, indicating persistent confusion applying partial differentiation to state functions. We present results from before and after instruction and discuss the design of curricular materials to address these issues.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant #PHY-0406764.

column5: ABC Labs: A Lab Structure Stressing Conceptual Understanding
column15: Steve Lindaas, Minnesota State University Moorhead
column18: I want labs to reinforce concepts, develop specific quantitative measurement and reasoning techniques as well as provide some inquiry-based possibilities. I also don't like reading long lab reports - especially when it is apparent that the student or group of students has missed major connections in the lab. It is very difficult to be able to traverse the lab and be there "just in time" for each lab group when they need help or correction. So I am trying ABC Labs. Lab groups have to demonstrate a passing (C) conceptual understanding of the lab idea before moving on to the (B) basic quantitative lab exercise which is worked on before the optional (A) advanced lab. Summaries are written for both the basic and advanced labs. Feedback is quicker and student learning (as measured by the FCI) has improved. I will share example labs as well as student feedback.

column5: Professors' Views on the Difference Between Learning and Doing Physics
column15: Chandra A Turpen, University of Colorado, Boulder
column18: The National Science Education Standards call for the science classroom to more closely reflect the actually process of practicing science. We present our preliminary results from a study of physics professors' views about the similarities and differences between the practice of doing physics and the process of learning physics. Our findings suggest that what physics professors value about the process of doing physics is different than those values portrayed in the National Science Education Standards. In order for the process of doing physics to become more integrated into introductory university physics classrooms, dramatic cultural shifts in physics faculty's beliefs and their views of the purpose of an education in physics may be required. We examine whether learning physics in the introductory classroom is or should be analogous to the process of conducting research in physics.

column5: Web-Based Materials for Teaching Physics Using Information Technology Contexts
column15: DJ Wagner
column18: Nearly all current students will end up in careers which, at the least, use information systems on a daily basis. Many students, even those in non-technical fields, will someday hold jobs where understanding the operation and limits of computer systems will be advantageous. Yet most students majoring in fields other than physics or engineering will never learn what distinguishes semiconductors, why optical fibers are so superior for transmitting data, or why Moore?s Law may soon fail. We have developed web-based materials teaching physics concepts, some common to most introductory courses and others less typical, which can be integrated into physics courses for diverse audiences. This poster will demonstrate some of the materials and present the successes we have had in using them.

column5: Traditional Lab Instruction and Student Understanding of Momentum and Energy
column15: Michael E Loverude, California State University Fullerton
column17: Luanna G Ortiz, Steve E Kanim
column18: As part of an NSF funded research and development project, we are developing a set of research-based lab materials for introductory algebra-based mechanics. Labs will cover topics including kinematics, forces, momentum, and energy. As part of this project, we are examining the understanding of students after completing traditional laboratories. In particular, we have investigated the extent to which students can answer questions on energy and momentum after completing traditional laboratories on collisions and the ballistic pendulum. We will present results from written questions posed in lab courses before and after standard labs.
column19: Supported in part by NSF CCLI grants 0341350, 0341333, and 0341289.

column5: Teaching Light and Color via an Activities-Based Curriculum
column15: Jack Glassman, Southern Illinois University Edwardsville
column18: A course to teach elementary Optics at a level suitable for nontechnical majors exists at many schools. At Southern Illinois University, Edwardsville, we have developed such a course using an activities-based curriculum. We have found that this method of teaching is particularly well suited to the students who enroll for this course and to the material covered in it. Restricting the discussion to a lecture format, even if demonstrations are included, misses the opportunity to have students directly investigate something which is, quite literally, right before their eyes. An internal grant enabled the purchase of hardware for this course, allowing the transition from a traditional lecture plus demonstration format to the activities-based curriculum now used. This course has been taught under the new paradigm with encouraging results. In this talk, the activities developed and preliminary results of the evaluation will be described and discussed.

column5: Activities for a Hands-on Course in Optics for Non-technical Majors
column15: Jack Glassman, Southern Illinois University Edwardsville
column18: We have developed a set of hands-on activities for students enrolled in a course entitled ?Light & Color.? This course is designed for non-technical majors with limited mathematics backgrounds. As such, the opportunity to have students directly investigate something which is, quite literally, right before their eyes is lost in a pure lecture format class, even if demonstrations are included. We have found, therefore, that this subject lends itself particularly well to activities-based pedagogy. In this talk, we will describe some of the activities we have used in the context of the concepts they are intended to clarify for the students. We will also discuss activities that are under development and which are expected to be implemented when the course is taught again in the Fall. The results of a systematic evaluation of the effectiveness of this curriculum, when compared to the same course taught by the same professor at SIUE without activities in prior semesters, are also presented. A clear improvement in the effectiveness of the course under the new curriculum is noted.

column5: Visualizing Energy Conservation
column15: M. Lenore Horner
column18: I present a visualization energy during the course of a physical process. The visualization is simple to hand-draw, spatially compact so that the time development is readily visible, makes energy conservation and flow readily visible, and encourages explicit thinking about transitions as well as particular points in the process. Finally, the visualization lends itself to linkage with quantitative problem-solving.

column5: Jerrold Zacharias and PSSC
column15: Charles H Holbrow, Colgate University/AAPT
column18: Jerrold Zacharias had a talent for eliciting bold ideas from the best physicists of his day and then inspiring them to put their ideas into action. PSSC was only one of many instances when he did this. He was a member of that cohort of physicists whose accomplishments in World War II empowered them with confidence and authority that they applied with great effect in the Cold War. More than passive agents of the government, they strove to influence the government to respond to various crises with broader vision and higher idealism than was associated with conventional views of defense. PSSC illustrates their ability to spin straw of Cold War tension and fear into the gold of major educational reform. In short remarks between the other papers of this session, I will tell some stories of his strengths and his weaknesses.

column5: Students Difficulties, Cognitive Conflict, and Mental Models in an Inquiry-Based Course
column15: Gyoungho Lee, Seoul National University
column18: There are somewhat independent studies on students' difficulties, cognitive conflict, and mental models. In this study, we tried to develop a framework, which could help us understand the three terminologies with comparing and synthesizing them. For this purpose, we conducted a study using weekly surveys & individual interviews in an inquiry based course. In my talk, I will show the temporary results of this study and discuss its educational implications.

column5: Benefits and Limitations of Vygotsky's Theory of Concept Formation
column15: Valerie K Otero, University of Colorado, Boulder
column18: I have used Vygotsky's theory of concept formation in PER because it offers a mechanism for explaining how socio-cultural processes interface with individual cognitive processes (appropriation and mediation). Although understanding this interface is only sometimes a goal of my research, Vygotsky?s theory offers possibilities for expanding a cognitive argument into its socio-cultural influences or expanding a socio-cultural argument into its cognitive features. In trying to account for variation in qualitative data, these issues should be addressed. Further, many other theoretical perspectives such as distributed cognition, participation, and activity theory were derived from Vygotsky?s work. I will demonstrate how Vygotsk?s theory was used in the analysis and explanation of my data and how (and why) it was combined with other perspectives, such as Piaget?s to frame a research project. Limitations of the theory will be discussed and the theory will be compared to other theoretical perspectives designed to meet similar goals.

column5: Instruction Evaluation of Electricity and Magnetism in a Large University
column15: Genaro Zavala, Tecnologico de Monterrey
column17: Beatriz Gonzalez, Andres Vargas-Lugo, Hugo Alarcon
column18: The Concept Survey of Electricity and Magnetism (CSEM) was administered at the beginning of the semester as a pre-test and at the end as a post-test to engineering students taking calculus-based electricity and magnetism in their third semester in our university. Students take this course divided in groups of 30-40 students and with 10 to 12 different instructors, full and part time professors. Data obtained on the tests in two semesters were analyzed using concentration analysis for the purpose of evaluation of instruction by drawing vectors in a Gamma-Score (GS) graph from the pre-test results to the post-test results for each of the concept areas of the CSEM.
