Results showed that the magnitude and direction of the GS vectors are instructor-dependent and that professors had some strong and some weak concept area GS vectors. The analysis can be used to give feedback to professors for the purpose of improving instruction.

column5: Experience-based Tips and Advice on Curriculum Development
column15: Alexander K Dickison, Seminole Community College
column18: It was 1993 when the idea to develop a new college physics curriculum was conceived. Thirteen years later, Introductory College Physics/21st century is published. This paper will not only relate some of our experiences, but will offer some general advice and tips for anyone developing a new curriculum.

column5: Lecturing on Modern Physics for Non-majors: Confessions from a Backslider
column15: Gary D White
column18: Having returned to the classroom after a four year hiatus, I found it easier than ever to slip into a comfortable lecture format, despite all my good intentions to be an interactive-engagement soldier. The course was intended to be an introduction to modern physics for non-science majors with a laboratory and a significant writing component. It felt a little like too much of a good thing. I will report on the more novel aspects of the course such as the writing exercises, the use of less-traditional texts (Gamow's Mr. Tompkins' series and a more historical book by Cassidy, Holton and Kennedy), and an idea about pedagogy that I call "Learning by Contrast".

column5: Study of Chaos with Magnetic Pendulum
column15: Roman Y Kezerashvili
column18: We study the motion of a simple pendulum with a magnet ball on the end of the string and a physical pendulum with the magnet on the end of a rigid rod, in the different periodic configurations of magnetic field. The comparison of the motions of both pendulums without magnetic field and in the present of the magnetic field shows the chaotic nature of their motion in the magnetic field. The different periodic configurations of the magnetic field were produced by system of strong magnets placed on a metal base in the certain regular order under the pendulums. In all cases we observed the chaotic motion of the pendulums. The chaotic behavior of the motion lies in the fact that systems are nonlinear. We described the motion of magnetic pendulums by a set of first order differential equations and soled these equations numerically in Mathematica. The phase-space diagrams and Poincare sections are plotted and analyzed.

column5: PhysTED: Online Library for Physics Teacher Education and Professional Development
column15: Dan L MacIsaac, SUNY Buffalo State College
column18: A poster describing the newly established Physics Teacher Education and professional Development online collection of resources spoonsored by the Physics Teacher Education Coalition (PTEC). Resources, contributions, design, intentions, and plans for the site will be described and comments from the physics teacher preparation community will be solicited.

column5: Attitude and Content Knowledge
column15: Edward A Von Iderstein, SUNY College at Buffalo
column18: This study shows the different challenges that face today's science teachers. Both primary and secondary science educators must approach the science classroom differently than their predecessors. Cultural diversity, advances in technology, and new state and federal legislation are among many new issues that science teachers must overcome. These factors can affect the attitude of pre-service teachers. A pre-post survey of post-baccalaureate students, independent of gender and cultural background variables, is evaluated to compare attitude and beliefs toward teaching math and science, obtaining content knowledge, and efficacy over an intensive summer physics and science education course.

column5: Collaborative Web-based Polling System for Notebook Universities
column15: David M DeMuth, Jr, University of Minnesota, Crookston
column18: A web-based classroom polling system has been developed over five years to facilitate and assess learning in an introductory physics course taught at the University of Minnesota Crookston campus. Features include secure access, multiple question type, confidence and reasoning input, randomized ordering, automatic polling intervals, and performance histograms. A comparative study of use in individual and collaborative modes will be presented for both the physics, and economics course.

column5: Improving Students' Understanding of Chemistry Using the Science Writing Heuristic
column15: Thomas J Greenbowe, iowa State University
column17: Thomas Greenbowe, Thomas Greenbowe, Thomas Greenbowe, Thomas Greenbowe
column18: A two-semester longitudinal study investigated the impact a laboratory instructional strategy, the Science Writing Heuristic (SWH), had on improving student academic performance in the lecture portion of the course. The SWH helps students do inquiry science laboratory work by structuring the laboratory notebook in a format that guides students to answer directed questions instead of using a traditional laboratory report. In this approach, students must make a claim (inference) about what was learned through the laboratory experiment and provide evidence to support that claim. Then, through reflection, students continue to negotiate meaning from the experiment(s) they conducted. Successfully implementing the SWH requires a student-centered learning environment. In this study, the instructors were rated on how well they implemented the SWH and inquiry. The hypothesis under investigation was that the more proficiently an instructor engages students to do inquiry and the SWH, the more effectively students respond to learning. The results of this study indicate that students, who have an instructor in laboratory who proficiently implements the SWH, earn more total points in the lecture portion of the course compared to students who have a laboratory instructor who does not fully implement the Science Writing Heuristic. Also, the SWH helps students who enter the course with low chemistry content knowledge succeed in the course compared to students who have not had the SWH.

column5: Conceptual Dynamics: Understanding Changing Student Views of Force and Motion
column15: Ronald K Thornton, Tufts University
column18: Carefully constructed short answer or multiple choice conceptual evaluations can be very valuable as a means to evaluate student learning. Such evaluations can also be used to identify student views of the physical world and to explore the dynamic process by which these views are transformed during instruction. Studying ?conceptual dynamics?, aids the determination of the multiple student views, even for large numbers of students in instructional settings, and provides a method for the ordering of student views into learning hierarchies. In this talk the methods of conceptual dynamics will then be applied to student views in a specific area of physics--force and motion, using questions from the FMCE. Common student views of force and motion for each of different cases that students distinguish will be articulated and learning hierarchies discussed that allow a statistical prediction of student progression through the various views. Newton's First and Second Laws, for example, become the Four Student Laws of Force and Motion where different force and motion relationships apply to objects standing still, slowing down, moving at a constant velocity, and speeding up. Students adopt a physicist view of the four cases of motion in the order just listed. Student descriptions of each view, in their own words, will be given. Data will be presented to support a model for the transition from one view to another that postulates that many students move through mixed transitional states when changing views.

column5: Physics and Art: A Life of Quality
column15: Dwight E Neuenschwander, Southern Nazarene University
column18: Although crucial differences exist between physics and art, they are also deeply analogous. Both endeavors require creativity, use metaphors, look beneath the surface, confront the relationship between appearance and reality, and interpret our experience. Art and physics enrich one another: the development of geometric perspective anticipated coordinate systems; challenging problems are solved, revolutions and paradigm shifts occur. Here I illustrate these analogies and differences through paintings. This presentation is an excerpt of a larger one that I present to Fine Arts classes, physics students, and the public. The term "Quality" as used here comes from Robert Pirsig's book "Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance": the link between the "Classic" (analytic) and "Romantic" (artistic) modes of understanding.

column5: Biomedical and Biometric Imaging with Polarized Light
column15: Adam S Green, University of St. Thomas
column18: We are developing laboratory experiments for our undergraduate optics course in which students investigate the effectiveness of polarization-difference imaging for the detection of faint or invisible targets that scatter polarized light asymmetrically through turbid media. In particular, students will learn about noninvasive skin cancer detection, fingerprint identification, environmental sensing, and how certain animals navigate and communicate using polarized light. Our experiments focus on contemporary imaging and image processing techniques with LabVIEW IMAQ and optical elements such as linear polarizers, liquid crystal variable retarders, spectral filters, and CCD cameras.

column5: Best Practices in Online Homework: Tenacity and Efficiency
column15: Colin M Fredericks, Univeristy of Massachusetts, Amherst
column18: An examination of detailed online homework data can show many student behaviors and strategies, from tendencies towards guessing and reverse-engineering to taking breaks while working to starting homework early. Certain combinations of behaviors, including combinations which one could call "tenacity" and "efficiency," are excellent, statistically significant predictors of later performance as measured by exams and final course grade. This may have implications for the design, use, and evaluation of online homework systems.

column5: Teaching Quantum Physics Without Paradoxes in Introductory Physics Courses
column15: Art Hobson, University of Arkansas
column18: The resolution to the wave-particle paradox has been known for 80 years, but is seldom presented.* Briefly, the resolution is that both photons and material particles are quanta of spatially continuous but energetically quantized fields. Because this quantum field theory explanation is not usually spelled out in ordinary language, it is neither generally understood nor generally taught, especially not in the context of general introductory physics for scientists and non-scientists. Why not teach from the beginning that electrons are quantized excitations of a real physical field? Four experimental results form a good framework for teaching: interference fringes in the double-slit experiments for light beams and electron beams, and the isolated photon and electron interactions that appear on the screen when these experiments are done with low-intensity beams. * American Journal of Physics, July 2005, pp. 630-634

column5: Thoughts on Physics Education for the 21st Century
column15: Art Hobson, University of Arkansas
column18: We physics teachers must broaden our focus from physics for physicists and other scientists to physics for all. The reason, as the American Association for the Advancement of Science puts it, is that "Without a scientifically literate population, the outlook for a better world is not promising." Physics for all (including the first course for scientists) should be conceptual, not technical. It should describe the universe as we understand it today, including general relativity, modern cosmology, and quantum fields; many science writers have shown that this is possible. It should emphasize the scientific process and include such societal topics as global warming, nuclear weapons, and pseudoscience, because citizens need to vote intelligently on such issues.

column5: A Physical Science Course for Rural Middle School Teachers
column15: David G Haase, North Carolina State University
column17: Sharon K Schulze, Scott Ragan, Stephanie D Rankin
column18: We report the outcomes of a one-semester Physical Science course for middle school teachers from several counties in rural central North Carolina. Supported by an NC Mathematics and Science Partnership grant, the project aims to improve student learning by enhancing teacher content knowledge. The Physical Science course mixed three Saturday laboratory sessions with web-based lesson and Webassign homeworks. The curricula reviewed the key concepts in the NC 6-8th grade Science Standard Course of Study (waves, energy, forces and motion, chemistry and the solar system). We will show how the course meshed with classroom coaching and examine outcomes from pre- and post-testing as well as teacher comments and work products.

column5: Citizens and Technical Issues: Energy and Evironment
column15: John W White, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
column18: The world is faced with a serious problem. We anticipate an increase in demands placed on energy resources due to many nations growing their economies. The traditional and dominant role has been played by petroleum; but concerns have arisen due to the greenhouse gas issue associated with petroleum use and due to the earth's limited supplies of petroleum. There are many possible alternative energy sources: coal, solar, hydroelectric, wind, geothermal, nuclear reactors, etc. All have difficulties. Other relevant issues include conservation, fuel cells, etc. This talk will focus on the education of citizens that is needed so that they can sort through these issues when faced with ballot box decisions.

column5: Community College Student Success in Algebra-based Physics One
column15: John Cise, Austin Community College
column18: Students at Community Colleges enrolled in algebra based Generanl College Physics 1 have a success rate(A,B,C grade) which I have found to be a function of various previous factors. Some of these factors are: GPA when the student enters the Physics 1 course, success and when they have taken College Algebra, completion rate(% of courses completed after the student has enrolled in any college course), etc. Many years of data will be presented from a large sample of students at 36,000 student Austin Community College. It is the largest community college physics dept in Texas offering 36 sections per semester.

column5: Computation in the Lawrence Physics Curriculum
column15: David M Cook, Lawrence University
column18: The physics curriculum at Lawrence University introduces on-line data acquisition, statistical data analysis, and curve fitting in the introductory laboratories; includes the required course ?Computational Mechanics? in which sophomores learn to use computer-based symbolic, numerical, and visualization tools to address intermediate mechanics problems that involve ordinary differential equations, integrals, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors; and offers the junior-senior elective ``Computational Physics'' that focuses on numerical solution of the wave, diffusion, and Laplace equations by finite difference and finite element methods. Because ?Computational Mechanics? is prerequisite for most upper-level courses, faculty members can as appropriate assign computer-based exercises in those courses. Further, students are encouraged to use our Computational Physics Laboratory on their own initiative whenever that use seems appropriate. Details about the Lawrence curricular approach and about the microscopically customizable text that has been written for some of its components are posted on the web site at www.lawrence.edu/dept/physics/ccli.

column5: Preparation for the Realities of Diversity in Seconday Classes
column15: Joan E Mackin, Retired
column18: This presentation will describe a program including field experience for pre-service teachers in the semester prior to student teaching. This program was possible because of a partnership between the university and local school districts. During this experience pre-service teachers learned about the real world issues including diversity in secondary classes through observations and actual teaching. The field experiences were integrated with assignments and discussions in the methods class and were a preparation for teaching experience during the last five weeks of the semester. Mentoring from in-service teachers, university instructors and supervisors added to the experience. The presentation will include the research findings from surveys and interviews with the participants.

column5: News and Views of the Proton
column15: Elizabeth Beise
column18: It has been over 60 years since the Nobel Prize was awarded to Otto Stern for the discovery that the proton has an anomalously large magnetic moment, nearly three times what one expects from a spin-1/2 point particle. This was one of the first hints of the underlying structure of the protons and neutrons that make up the bulk of the visible mass of our universe. The now well-established theory of Quantum Chromodynamics describes the strong interaction between quarks and the gluons that bind them, and accounts for many of the observed bound states that are seen in nature. But there are still many unanswered questions. I'll present a current-day snapshot of what we know today and what the upcoming research directions are, with a focus on experiments involving electron scattering.

column5: The History of High School Laboratory Work in Physics
column15: Keith Sheppard, Teachers College, Columbia University
column18: For more than a century, laboratory work has been a regular feature of physics classes in American high schools and colleges. How did the laboratory method of teaching physics become so prevalent? What brought about its general acceptance and widespread dissemination? How has the role of laboratory work changed over time and what are the implications for its future role? This paper attempts to answer these questions by tracing the historical development of individual laboratory work in physics in the USA from its introduction in the late nineteenth century to its rapid and widespread incorporation in standard physics curricula of the early twentieth century. The paper highlights the role that key individuals such as Charles Eliot, Edwin Hall and Charles R. Mann played in the process.

column5: The Return of the Anthropic Principle
column15: James K Simmons, Waynesburg College
column18: In the 1980s, the Anthropic Principle received a modest amount of attention from physicists. One version of the principle was as follows: "What we can expect to observe must be restricted by the conditions necessary for our presence as observers." Some physicists argued that this statement was trivially true; others argued that it was an obvious (and, therefore, not very interesting) methodological rule of thumb. However, recent philosophical work suggests that the Anthropic Principle makes a significant (non-trivial and not obvious) contribution to our understanding of inflationary cosmology. This talk will describe that contribution.

column5: The Relationship of Coherence of Thought and Conceptual Change to Ability
column15: Jim Minstrell, FACET Innovations
column18: Students' thinking in topics of force and motion seems to fit a perspective of "knowledge in pieces" (diSessa) rather than specific Theoretical Models of thinking in physics. In most of our research the pieces (we call them "facets") are constructions of one or more smaller pieces of experience or prior ideas. The facets of thinking applied to situations frequently vary depending on features of the situation, suggesting that students (especially younger or lower ability students) are inconsistent in their reasoning across contexts. Recently we have been mining our data to see if there might still be some coherence across contexts, (e.g. forces on objects while speeding up, moving with constant speed, and slowing down) and to see the extent of change in understanding through middle and high school. We will present our findings in this presentation.

column2: Use of the Internet for Public Physics Education: Research and New Directions
column5: The Physics Portal: A One-Stop Website for Physics
column15: David Hestenes, Arizona State University
column18: There is a growing number of Websites designed to educate the general public about physics. We believe that physics education community has a stake in providing a useful lens with which to critique the content of such Websites. We describe here the concept of a Physics Portal, which can serve as a one-stop entry into the world of physics for the general public. The Portal will provide a framework for managing the quality of physics content in a way that makes it easy to navigate the world of physics. The Portal will present an enticing as well as a faithful image of physics to the public. We will conclude our presentation with an open discussion with other invited speakers and the audience in this session who bring to bear diverse perspectives in the appropriate use of the internet for educating the general public about physics.

column5: National Standards and InterActions in Physical Sciences Curriculum
column15: Patricia M Heller, University of Minnesota
column18: The developers of the middle-school (grade 8) curriculum, InterActions in Physical Sciences, utilized the Benchmarks for Science Literacy (American Association for the Advancement of Science, 1993) and National Science Education Standards (National Research Council, 1996) to determine both the content and the pedagogy of the curriculum. This talk will describe the process and the resulting decisions for the general themes of the curriculum, the pedagogy, and the content. One unit, Interactions and the Structure of Matter, will illustrate the process of starting with a standard and ending with a sequence of activities to meet the standard.

column5: The Role of Cognitive Conflict in Student Learning
column15: Lillian C McDermott, University of Washington
column18: Certain conceptual and reasoning difficulties that students encounter in the study of physics are sufficiently serious that they may preclude development of a functional understanding. Results from research indicate that, in some instances, students do not even recognize the contradictions between what they think and what they are being taught. Under such circumstances, the creation and resolution of cognitive conflict can be an effective instructional strategy for improving student learning.

column5: Viability of Testing Conceptual Understanding with Essay Responses
column15: Diane M Bunce, The Catholic University of America
column18: Students in chemistry and other sciences traditionally experience more difficulty responding to essay questions as opposed to calculating a numerical answer for the same concept. The purpose of this study was to investigate students? understanding of what constitutes a complete and cogent essay answer in chemistry. Data from 39 non-science majors support the hypothesis that students do not reliably recognize or construct adequate responses to chemistry essay questions. In addition, students? intention to construct a complete and cogent argument was compared to their actual responses. Inability to construct complete and cogent arguments may result in lower achievement scores on essay questions on tests. Since essay questions are typically used to test achievement and the effectiveness of innovative teaching practices, this situation may mask significant research results. These data suggest the need for a more extensive investigation of student construction of quality essay answers in chemistry as well as other sciences.

column5: Observing Students' Framing of Tutorials
column15: Rachel E Scherr, University of Maryland
column18: Research-based physics curricula that engage college students in collaborative active learning have proven successful at fostering conceptual change. However, there is little research into what happens during the instructional activities, and in particular, no systematic investigations into how students understand the experience. What kind of activity do they understand themselves to be undertaking? Questions of participant understanding of the nature of an activity are interpreted in anthropology and sociolinguistics in terms of frames and framing. For example, a student may frame a physics problem as an opportunity for sense making or an occasion for rote use of formulas. Following Tannen, we seek evidence of framing mainly in behavior including speech, vocal register, affect, grammar, gestures, and body language. Studying tutorials in particular, we have found five distinct clusters of behaviors so far. We hypothesize that these behavioral clusters correspond to cognitive states.

column5: Leadership Through Service
column15: Karen L Johnston, North Carolina State University
column18: The concept of an association of physics teachers in America originated with a few and has developed over these past seventy-five years through the volunteer efforts of many. Our mission statement, refined over time, defines the core value of our association and signals to those outside of the association how we expend our efforts: ?To enhance the understanding and appreciation of physics through teaching.? Among physics societies, the AAPT is unique for many reasons. One of those reasons is our structure?we?re a loosely constructed federation of regional Sections. Another reason is our process?the work of the AAPT is accomplished primarily by volunteers who lead through their service. The special opportunities I have had to serve the AAPT have been laboratories for learning about leadership and service. I?ll discuss some of the insights I have gained in the context of the growth and development of our association.

column5: An Interactive Engagement Course for the "Other" College Physics
column15: Scott W Bonham, Western Kentucky University
column18: Over the last five years I have been developing a technology-rich interactive engagement course for a non-life science algebra-based physics course. The students in the course form a diverse, challenging population that has not received a lot of attention. The course begun as an effort to implement a SCALE-UP type curriculum, but has evolved in a different direction, drawing from a variety of interactive engagement curricula such as cooperative group problem solving, RealTime Physics, Just-in-Time-Teaching, Peer Instruction and interactive lecture demonstrations. I will discuss this population and the challenges, the history of the evolution and reasons for curricula choices, and present results on the impact of different curricula on student conceptual learning and problem solving skills.

column5: Development of Instructional Materials for Introductory Electrical Engineering
column15: Christian H Kautz, Hamburg University of Technology (TUHH)
column18: At Hamburg University of Technology (Germany) we have begun a research program on student learning in introductory engineering courses. As part of this study, we are investigating student understanding of fundamental electrical engineering concepts that at other institutions are often covered in physics courses. The results of our investigation are being used to develop instructional materials that are modeled after the "Tutorials in Introductory Physics*," but attempt to address student difficulties with these concepts in the context of electrical engineering applications.

column5: Development of a Wave Concept Survey
column15: Alvin Rosenthal, Western Michigan University
column17: Charles Henderson, Drew Isola, David Schuster
column18: To accommodate the greater amount of time required for PER-motivated instruction, the curriculum of the first two semesters of our introductory calculus-based physics sequence has been pared down and the topics of waves and optics have been placed into a third semester course. We are currently in the process of developing an instrument suitable for monitoring conceptual development in this course. The pilot version of the wave concept survey contains twenty multiple-choice items covering the following topics: basic wave kinematics; superposition; interference; standing waves; transmission and reflection. We will describe the design of this instrument, compare it with others already in circulation(1), and show the first results of its use. Not surprisingly, performance on the Wave Concept Survey suggests that students have considerable conceptual difficulty even after one semester of instruction with an emphasis on fundamental physics. Implications for instruction will be discussed.

column5: Abstract or Concrete: Which Is Better for Learning and Transfer
column15: Andrew F Heckler, Ohio State University
column18: A common educational assumption is that learning is facilitated when knowledge is expressed in a concrete form, such as with rich examples or manipulatives. In addition, many educational curricula use multiple representations, some with varying degrees of concreteness, to aid in learning and transfer. However, there are reasons to call into question the effectiveness of concrete representations. In a series of experiments, we study the effects of concreteness on both learning and transfer. Both undergraduates and sixth graders learned the rules of a simple algebraic group, which has many isomorphic and ?real life? instantiations. The instantiations learned and tested differed only in the amount and/or kind of concreteness. Results indicate that there are important tradeoffs in both learning and transfer between abstract and concrete representations, and that at least in some cases the learning of multiple representations does not change this conclusion.

column5: Case Studies of Student Understanding and Beliefs in Modern Physics
column15: Sarah B McKagan, University of Colorado
column17: Katherine K Perkins, Carl E Wieman
column18: This talk will present an overview of results from case studies of seven students in a transformed modern physics course for engineering majors. The course included peer instruction and concept tests in class, collaborative homework sessions, interactive simulations, and homework emphasizing reasoning development, model building, and connections to real world applications. By interviewing the same students regularly throughout the semester, as well as observing them in lecture and problem-solving sessions and analyzing written work, we have been able to track the evolution of these students? understanding of and beliefs about modern physics as they progress through the course.

column5: Case Studies of Student Understanding and Beliefs in Modern Physics
column15: Sarah B McKagan, University of Colorado
column17: Katherine K Perkins, Carl E Wieman
column18: This poster will present an analysis of the interaction between beliefs and understanding in case studies of seven students in a transformed modern physics course for engineering majors. The course included peer instruction and concept tests in class, collaborative homework sessions, interactive simulations, and homework emphasizing reasoning development, model building, and connections to real world applications. By interviewing the same students regularly throughout the semester, as well as observing them in lecture and problem-solving sessions and analyzing written work, we have been able to track the evolution of these students? understanding of and beliefs about modern physics as they progress through the course.

column5: Has Computing Changed Physics Courses: Need for a National Study
column15: Norman Chonacky, AIP/IEEE-Computer Society
column18: In the fall of 2005 I undertook to act on a recommendation made at the Salt Lake City AAPT meeting. This suggestion came from a Cracker Barrel convened to discuss the state of computing in undergraduate physics curricula. My action was to commission a modest national survey to establish baseline data and evaluate individual and departmental efforts. Robert Fuller, who conducted it, will present the results of this survey next at this session. My task is to relate briefly the context for this survey and our rational for the choice of speakers we invited to this session. I will also outline a broader strategy aimed at facilitating a national discussion of approaches to, and issues surrounding, a rethinking of physics curricula in the age of cheap and powerful computing.

column5: Minimal Matlab in Mechanics Courses
column15: Charles Leming, Henderson State University
column18: Matlab is recognized as one of the best tools for computing applications in physics research. It is less well known that Matlab can be very easy for students to use. The ease of use allows Matlab to simplify the integration of numerical methods into existing physics courses without altering the intrinsic character of such courses. This poster displays examples of elementary Matlab applications in intermediate-level undergraduate mechanics. The small subset of Matlab capabilities used in the course can be acquired by students in only one or two class periods. As a result, numerical methods are introduced with minimal alterations to the traditional mechanics course and with no prior computing knowledge required.

column5: My Experiences with Combining Popular Texts with Traditional Textbooks
column15: Matthew B Koss, College of the Holy Cross
column18: Over the past five years, I have attempted to combine and use popular science books with conventional textbooks in the traditional undergraduate curriculum. I have met with mixed success, yet, I persist. In this talk, I will share my motivations and experiences from this approach in courses on Electronics, Modern Physics, Thermal Physics, and in a science course for non-science concentrators.

column5: The STAR Curriculum Evaluated
column15: Alice D Churukian, Concordia College
column18: The Science Teaching using Astronomy References Curriculum (STAR Curriculum) is an innovative curriculum that incorporates an astronomy theme into an inquiry-based physical science curriculum for pre-service, elementary school teachers. Many physical science courses are a non-cohesive collection of topics required for state teaching licensure. Through the use of astronomy and earth science examples, the STAR Curriculum?s coherent theme ties the wide variety of physical science topics together and provides many real world applications. Three goals of the STAR Curriculum are to provide positive experiences for pre-service teachers, improve their comfort level with physical science and astronomy topics, and increase their interest in teaching these topics in the future. The effectiveness of the new curriculum in comparison to the old has been assessed through pre- and post-instruction surveys of students? attitudinal beliefs and conceptual understanding as well as focus group interviews. The results of our evaluation will be reported. *Supported by the IDEAS grant program of the Space Telescope Science Institute.

column5: How Can Computing Change Physics Courses: Need for a National Discussion
column15: Norman Chonacky, AIP/IEEE-Computer Society
column18: Here are the elements of a tentative strategy that Computing in Science and Engineering magazine, in collaboration with the AAPT/AAS ComPADRE project, plans to use to facilitate a national discussion of how computing might change undergraduate physics curricula.

column5: Inking Up the Curriculum: Incorporating Digital Ink and Wireless technologies
column15: John T Fons, Univ. Wisconsin - Rock County
column18: At University of Wisconsin ? Rock County, tablet PCs have been issued to the students enrolled in the introductory physics courses for their use throughout the semester. They have been used for note-taking and note-sharing with students and with classroom communication software to facilitate and monitor in-class student work and engagement. The digital ink capabilities of the software have been used by the students and instructors as a simple and natural way to imbed sketches and equations into more formal electronic lectures such as PowerPoint presentations. The tablets are very useful for real-time assessment of student progress. Information is easily shared through the two-way wireless communication between students and instructors. I have found that classroom communication software allows instructors to sample student work for enhanced problem solving in the classroom. I can also gather student feedback through on-the-fly polling. The tablets were obtained through grants from Hewlett Packard.

column5: A Post-Positivist Perspective on Physics Education
column15: Melissa H Dancy, Unversitiy of NC at Charlotte
column18: Positivism dominates discourse in both science and science education. This domination is largely unexamined and unrecognized. Acknowledging the rarely questioned role positivism has in our thinking and actions, and considering the nature of the role is valuable. Post-positivism offers an alternate view of knowledge, rejecting the possibility of objective knowledge. When science and science education are examined through the lens of post-positivism a new view emerges, promising new understandings. In this talk we consider the effect of positivism on the practice of science and science teaching. We will also consider insights and possibilities offered by post-positivism.

column5: Breaking the Paradigm: Working from a Sociopolitical-Critical Perspective
column15: Melissa H Dancy, Univeristy of NC at Charlotte
column18: Our research goals follow from our personal goal of working toward a more socially just society. We believe physics education can be, but is not currently, an effective tool for meaningful and positive social change. Therefore our research focuses on both understanding and articulating the ways in which the educational system functions to maintain and serve the status quo as well as identifying teaching and research methods that encourage a more just society. In this interactive poster we will describe some of our research and show how it provides understandings not possible from other research perspectives.

column5: Teaching Quantum Mechanics with PhET Simulations
column15: Sarah McKagan, University of Colorado
column17: Katherine Perkins, Wendy Adams, Danielle Harlow, Michael Dubson, Chris Malley, Sam Reid, Ron LeMaster, Carl Wieman
column18: The Physics Education Technology (PhET) Project, known for its interactive computer simulations for teaching and learning introductory physics, has expanded to include ten simulations on Quantum Mechanics. We have developed a growing collection of simulations where students can explore and construct an understanding of the fundamental principles of Quantum Mechanics, key ideas in historical experiments, and the quantum principles underlying everyday life applications. By providing visual representations of abstract concepts and microscopic processes that cannot be directly observed, these simulations help students to build mental models of phenomena that are often difficult to understand. Like all PhET simulations, these are developed using the results of education research and feedback from educators, and are tested in student interviews. They can be used in lecture demonstrations, recitation activities, or homework assignments to improve student learning and appreciation of modern physics. All PhET simulations are free and available at http://phet.colorado.edu

column5: Physics by Inquiry: Combining Teacher and General Education
column15: Karen Cummings, Southern Connecticut State University
column18: We report on a collaborative effort to make the Physics by Inquiry (PbI) curriculum (McDermott) adaptable to a wide variety of environments by investigating how one can implement the class without the graduate student teaching assistants typically used and/or accommodate larger numbers of students than in the environment in which the curriculum was originally designed. In this talk, I focus on my efforts at Southern Connecticut State University where subsets of PbI materials are used as part of a curriculum designed to meet student needs in a course populated by both pre-service teachers and general education students. I will describe how I incorporate PbI material into the class to meet state standards for pre-service teachers and the role of my undergraduate teaching assistant. In addition, results from pre-post testing using the Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey and conceptual learning assessments will be presented.

column5: Creating Lasting Reform: Diffusion of Educational Innovations via Co-Teaching
column15: Charles Henderson, Western Michigan University
column18: Most instructional reforms at the college level eventually fade when the original investigators move on to other things. A substantial reason for this is because other faculty do not understand the reform well enough to continue it and may also not believe that the reform would be appropriate for their teaching style or their teaching situation. We describe an attempt to address these issues through the use of co-teaching. A new instructor (MF) was teamed with an instructor experienced in Physics Education Research (PER) reforms (CH). The pair co-taught within the scaffolding of the PER-based course structure typically used by the experienced instructor and met regularly to discuss instructional decisions. An outsider (AB) conducted separate interviews with each instructor at the beginning, middle, and end of the semester. Classroom observations were also made. Interviews show a significant shift in the new instructor's attitude towards and understanding of the PER-based instructional approaches.

column5: Minnesota's Energy Needs Expressed in Natural Units of Renewable Energy
column15: Louis Schwartzkopf, Minnesota State U., Mankato
column18: There is a general belief that replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy is a good idea. Most people, however, lack a clear understanding of how huge the amount of energy is that we currently use in the U.S. I use a familiar physics stratagem and express yearly Minnesota-wide energy consumption in natural units of renewable energy: wind turbines for electricity, biodigesters for natural gas, and gallons of ethanol for gallons of gasoline. The results show clearly the magnitude of the challenge we have of converting to renewable energy. This stratagem can easily be generalized to other states and/or regions.

column5: A Regional Collaborative for Promoting Excellence in K-5 Science Teaching I
column15: Paul Williams, Austin Community College
column18: Austin Community College (ACC) has partnered with two school districts in the Austin, Texas, area to form a collaborative for excellence in K-5 science teaching. The collaborative consists of ACC faculty and 25 K-5 teachers from Pflugerville and Round Rock ISDs. The K-5 teachers serve as trainers for additional faculty in their respective ISDs. The format consists of a series of training events on science curriculum covering matter and light and optics tied to the Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills presented to the teachers by fellow K-5 teachers. Kits supporting the curriculum are purchased for participating schools. The training sessions are followed up by content seminars presented by ACC faculty over the science presented in the sessions.

column5: Adapting the Physics by Inquiry Curriculum: The Community College Environment
column15: Jack W Taylor, Baltimore City Community College
column18: We report on a collaborative effort to make the Physics by Inquiry (PbI) curriculum (McDermott) adaptable to a wide variety of environments by investigating how one can implement the class without the graduate student teaching assistants typically used and/or accommodate larger numbers of students than in the environment in which the curriculum was originally designed. In this talk, I focus on my efforts at Baltimore City Community College in a small class for education majors, teachers seeking certification and as a general education course. Students serve as undergraduate peer instructors who have completed the course. I describe efforts to meet state standards for teachers, results from three semester of pre-post testing using the Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey, a required student project, how a workshop format is used, and pre-post testing results on math and graphing skills. I will present my preliminary conclusions about this community college effort.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant #DUE-0433736.

column5: Implementing Interactive Lecture Demonstrations with a Classroom Response System
column15: Paul Williams, Austin Community College
column18: Classroom response systems (CRS) provide an excellent tool for promoting active engagement in the Physics classroom. CRS?s many uses include eliciting common non-Newtonian physics conceptions by asking students to predict outcomes of experiments.(1) This poster will describe the author?s use of CRS to implement Interactive Lecture Demonstrations (ILD?s). ILD?s present a sequence of related demonstrations and have been shown to be an effective way to promote active learning of physics.(2) An ILD on Newton?s 3rd Law was adapted from Sokoloff and Thornton (3) and a second ILD on Conservation of Angular Momentum was developed by the author. Results of various assessments will be presented.

column5: Seeing Is Believing: Escaping Energy Dollars Caught by Students
column15: Carol N Burch, Hannibal Central School
column18: As recipients of a 2005 Toyota Tapestry Grant, the Hannibal School District developed a interdisciplinary multi-age educational energy conservation initiative involving the use of an infrared camera to investigate heat loss in residential and public structures. Hannibal students have been using and integrating cutting-edge infrared technology into their curriculum and their community thanks to collaborative partnerships with the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority (NYSERDA), Entergy Corporation, Infrared Solutions Inc., and the Rochester Institute of Technology?s (RIT) Center for Imaging Science. Infrared technology measures the temperature of objects and displays thermal images, allowing the viewer to ?see? heat and analyze where heat escapes a structure. Students used the infrared camera to investigate heat loss, taking infrared pictures of their own homes (7th grade) and local community buildings (high school). Students analyzed the photographs, collected data, and presented their findings as formal reports including possible remedies to save energy.

column5: UTeach: An Innovative Teacher Preparation Program Comes of Age
column15: Jill A Marshall, University of Texas, Austin
column18: The UTeach secondary math and science teacher training program at the University of Texas, Austin, enrolled its first students in the Fall of 1997 and since that time has grown to a steady-state enrollment of over 400 teacher certification candidates with over 70 graduates annually. Local versions of UTeach are being planned at several sister institutions. Many innovations in education disappear as soon as the heroic innovators move on or seed funding disappears. UTeach, in contrast, has become fully institutionalized with dedicated faculty and staff lines and a substantial endowment. I will present lessons learned as the program has come of age and grown to scale, including results from a recent large-scale survey of our graduates.

column5: Summer Science Program for Fourth Graders from Title I Schools
column15: Paul Williams, Austin Community College
column18: In an effort to recruit future scientists from traditionally under represented groups, Austin Community College has for two summers offered a summer math and science program for exiting fourth graders targeted to students from Title I schools in Austin, TX. In a two week, half day format, 24 students participate in hands on activities in physics, geology, environmental science, biotechnology, chemistry, and math. This paper will present aspects of our outreach program, efforts to assess the program, and future plans for improvement.

column5: Gotta Problem with That?
column15: David Weaver
column18: I used to include a project in each of my physics course as a capstone activity. As it always came late in the semester (and students were focused on finals), I was never able to exploit it as a major learning activity. It was fun though? Then I attended a Problem Based Learning workshop presented by faculty from a medical school, and it got me thinking that making projects the core of the course rather than an add-on could work splendidly. I?ve turned my courses from a topic-driven mode to a contextual learning model by having student teams engage in 3 major projects each semester wherein they teach themselves the physics involved. Come see how splendidly it has turned out.

column5: Lessons Learned from AutoTutor Physics: ITS for Conceptual Physics
column15: Donald R Franceschetti
column17: Arthur C. Graesser, George T Jackson
column18: AutoTutor is an intelligent tutoring system (ITS) in which students can learn a variety of subjects through conversation in natural language with a software agent. The agent appears as a face on the screen, with a synthesized voice, and responds to typed input from the student. Student understanding is modeled from student responses, which are matched to high quality essay responses and known misconceptions and bad answers using latent semantic analysis. With ONR and NSF support a version of AutoTutor covering Newtonian dynamics at the level of Hewitt's Conceptual Physics has been developed and extensively tested. As a byproduct of this work, several thousand student responses to a small number of conceptual physics questions have been collated and mined for misconceptions. Some results from this process will be presented along with a demonstration of Autotutor-Physics at work.

column5: Using Computer-Interfaced Lab Sensors to Enhance Introductory Physics Laboratory
column15: Pedro A Derosa, Louisiana Tech University
column18: Louisiana Tech University has an NSF-funded integrated science curriculum for its physics, math, chemistry, computer science and secondary science education majors. The curriculum focuses on calculus and introductory labs in physics, chemistry and biology. In the two-course introductory physics lab sequence, the main objectives were to increase student awareness of 1) physics concepts behind the lab activities, 2) the process of expressing physics concepts in mathematical terms, and 3) relationships between physics concepts and concepts in chemistry and biology. These were achieved by revising the labs to incorporate computer-interfaced lab sensors and modifying the lab manual to accommodate the new technology, better guide students through the physics concepts, and increase the level of critical thinking required to complete the lab experiments. In this talk we outline the project and highlight the challenges and opportunities associated with using this type of modern technology to enhance learning, connect concepts and engage students.

column5: National Standards in the Era of "No Child Left Behind"
column15: Jo Ellen Roseman, AAAS Project 2061
column18: The No Child Left Behind (NCLB) Act engages the federal government in K-12 education at an unprecedented level, mandating states to develop high quality academic standards and assessments that are aligned to them. In this state-centered environment, are national standards still relevant? With NCLB testing in science scheduled for 2007 and a new science framework for the 2009 National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP) based on the national standards, this paper considers how Benchmarks for Science Literacy (American Association for the Advancement of Science, 1993) and National Science Education Standards (National Research Council, 1996) can help states address the aims of NCLB through improvements in curriculum materials, instruction, and assessment. Drawing on physical science examples to illustrate the continuing role of national standards, the paper also identifies research areas and next steps that are likely to have the most benefit in the context of NCLB and of science literacy for all.

column5: Classification of Physics/ Astronomy Concept Inventories
column15: Elizabeth Peak, Southern Illinois University Edwardsville
column18: Lindell and Foster have developed a classification scheme for concept inventories. They propose three types of concept inventories: local tests, efficacy tests, or diagnostic instruments. The author will present research, which utilized these classifications to analyze the development methodologies of various concept inventories listed on the North Carolina State University's Assessment Instrument Information Page, which include commonly used instruments such as the Astronomy Diagnostic Test, Brief Electricity and Magnetism Assessment, Force Motion Conceptual Evaluation and multiple others. Results of this analysis will be presented.

column5: A Teacher-in-Resident Year in Perspective
column15: Neil Anthony
column18: Some of the accomplishments and growth experiences of a Teacher-in-Resident's year working with the PhysTEC program will be described.

column5: From the First Course to a Feedback Control Course Routine
column15: Antti Rissanen, National Defence College
column18: The study starts with a development paradigm how a new teacher forms course plan for her first lecturing period in a new university. A semantic presentation shows how syllabus as well as resources are studied to form the first plan divided into lecturing, exercise, demonstration, and a preliminary structure of the examination. Second part of the study establishes quality based follow-up for interventions and an idea for continuous development and maintenance for the next and future courses. Based on a case study on applied physics and pure physics courses different methods of getting feedback data is presented. Ideas how to analyze data as well as how to find priority in the feedback based development work is discussed.

column5: College Students' Perceptions of Astronomical Images
column15: Jennifer Greenwood
column18: Astronomy students must be able to decipher images of astronomical phenomena. How they decipher these images is crucial to their understanding of the subject. In this study we are analyzing over 50 interviews of college students explaining their perceptions of astronomical images from textbooks. Specific snapshots discussed include phases of the moon, time-lapsed photos of lunar and solar eclipses, time-lapsed photos of the motion of the moon, as well as apparent motion of the Sun and the night sky. Those interviewed included elementary education majors and physics/astronomy majors. Preliminary results of this analysis will be reported.

column5: Instrumentation and Measurement for Biological Engineering: An Undergraduate Laboratory
column15: Maxim Shusteff, Biological Engineering Division, MIT
column17: David C Appleyard, Peter T. C. So, Matthew J Lang, Scott R Manalis
column18: We have developed an undergraduate course to teach the principles and practice of making quantitative measurements using advanced instrumentation. Students gain hands-on experience building and operating measurement systems and applying them to biological experiments. The course material centers around three "home built" measurement systems constructed mainly from off-the-shelf components, and costing about an order of magnitude less than their research-grade versions: an atomic force microscope (AFM), an optical trap, and a fluorescence microscope. The AFM is capable of sub-angstrom position resolution, and allows measurements of force, elastic modulus, and thermo-mechanical noise, as well as imaging. The optical trap can be used to directly manipulate living cells, and to perform single-molecule force spectroscopy experiments. We are making the design details of the apparatus and associated experimental protocols available online for use by the education community. We encourage the development of new experiments and modifications to our apparatus.

column5: Computerized Applications of Fourier Transform to MRI
column15: Eric Holzapfel, Ramapo College of NJ
column18: The goal of this work is to introduce the undergraduate science major to the theory of Fourier transform and its applications to nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Discrete Fourier analysis is of central importance in digital signal processing (DPS), and the introduction of a efficient fast Fourier transforms (FFT) revolutionized the field. Though the computations of DSP have been relegated to computers, it is important to understand the theory of the discrete Fourier analysis in order to recognize and minimize artifacts in digital images, and in the interpretation of MRI images. This paper describes the theory behind discrete Fourier analysis, focusing on the Cooley-Tukey algorithm of the FFT, and offers examples and discussions of transformations of artificial signals and real-world MRI images. It is structured as follows: The theory of the FFT is introduced with examples performed on artificial data. As an application of the fast Fourier transform, we will take a detailed look a the data acquisition and image reconstruction in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). MRI is is introduced, and examples of transforms on MRI data, images, and artifacts are discussed. The analysis of the MRI raw data is based on the concept of k-space, which will be presented in detail. All examples are written in the IDL programming language. The poster will showcase some of the examples from our paper and will illustrate the effects of modifying the k-space data, including incomplete sampling, artifacts in the phase encoding direction, etc.

column5: Understanding Problem-Solving by Transforming "Context-Rich" to "Context-Poor" Problems
column15: Edit Yerushalmi, Weizmann Institute for Science
column18: How to foster in students a realization of the nature of the problem-solving process, and it's distinction from an exercise-solving process? We present an activity in which students were required to compare two problems similar in regard to the physics principles required to solve them: One was "context-rich", and required vast analysis and planning; the other, labeled "context-poor", did not. Students were asked to transform a context-rich problem into a context-poor form. The students were enthusiastic about coping with the challenging task and appreciated the usefulness of the activity in developing planning and analysis skills. In the presentation we describe findings regarding how students performed the task, and in particular: (a) How they convert an informal presentation of a problem into a formal one; and (b) How they phrase a sequence of sub-problems The activity was reported in physics education (Yerushalmi, E., & Magen,E., Phys. Educ. 41 (2006) 161-167).

column5: Instrumentation and Measurement for Biological Engineering: An Undergraduate Laboratory
column15: Maxim Shusteff, Biological Engineering Division, MIT
column17: David C Appleyard, Peter T. C. So, Matthew J Lang, Scott R Manalis
column18: We have developed an undergraduate course to teach the principles and practice of making quantitative measurements using advanced instrumentation. Students gain hands-on experience building and operating measurement systems and applying them to biological experiments. The course material centers around three "home built" measurement systems constructed mainly from off-the-shelf components, and costing about an order of magnitude less than their research-grade versions: an atomic force microscope (AFM), an optical trap, and a fluorescence microscope. The AFM is capable of sub-angstrom position resolution, and allows measurements of force, elastic modulus, and thermo-mechanical noise, as well as imaging. The optical trap can be used to directly manipulate living cells, and to perform single-molecule force spectroscopy experiments. We are making the design details of the apparatus and associated experimental protocols available online for use by the education community. We encourage the development of new experiments and modifications to our apparatus.

column5: Adapting Physics by Inquiry: A Course for Non-science Majors
column15: Leon Hsu, University of Minnesota
column18: We report on a collaborative effort to make the Physics by Inquiry (PbI) curriculum (McDermott) adaptable to a wide variety of environments by investigating how one can implement the class without the graduate student teaching assistants typically used and/or accommodate larger numbers of students than in the environment in which the curriculum was originally designed. This talk focuses on the implementation of PbI in a general education class for non-science majors. Undergraduate teaching assistants and techniques from the literature on cooperative grouping have been employed to allow class sizes of up to 45 students. In addition to those two aspects, I will also discuss remarkable gains shown by students on the Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey.
column19: Supported in part by NSF DUE-0410804.

column5: Culture and Cognition in the Physics Classroom
column15: Colleen Megowan, Arizona State University
column18: One cannot divorce thinking from the thinker, nor teaching from the learner. If we study intellect and affect separately, we risk viewing students' thought processes as ?thoughts thinking themselves? (Vygotsky, 1962). It takes more than just a solid grasp of good pedagogy, developmental pathways and cognitive processes to predict and explain student achievement in physics. We must coordinate our understanding of students? interest, identity and cultural engagement with what we know of thinking and reasoning if we are to have functional model of the physics learner. This presentation will report on an ethnographic study of two modeling physics classrooms, one 9th grade Physics First class and one traditional. I focus particularly on discourse processes in which students engage one another dialogically, and I attempt to shed some light upon how culture affects cognition, and how we, as teachers, can help our students by teaching them to make their thinking visible.

column5: Cosmic Ray Research in the Classroom
column15: Susen Clark, University of Rochester
column18: PARTICLE is a collaboration of Rochester-area secondary school science teachers and particle physicists at the University of Rochester to support student-driven cosmic-ray research in the classroom. At the University of Rochester during the summer, teachers construct cosmic ray telescopes and complete prototype lab activities for students. During the school year, students, teachers, and physicists collaborate on experiments. Students then have the opportunity to present their research results at an annual "PARTICLE Day" conference in late spring. We present sample student research and discuss classroom outcomes.

column5: Recognizing What Physics Students Are Doing
column15: Paul S Hutchison, University of Maryland
column18: Many students in introductory physics courses think that what they are supposed to do is generate correct answers. Students work toward this end by memorizing correct answers or using sets of steps, often equation based manipulations, to produce correct answers. Such methods are not typically connected to questions of physical sensibility. But physical sensibility is important for students to address as they do or do not come to understand the concepts. Consequently, it is important to pay attention to what kind of activity students are engaging in. Assessing the nature of student activity can be difficult. How does one recognize it? What does it look like? When or where does one see it? Utilizing several videotaped vignettes of students in introductory college courses I begin to answer these questions.

column5: Recognizing What Physics Students Are Doing
column15: Paul S Hutchison, University of Maryland
column18: Many students in introductory physics courses think that what they are supposed to do is generate correct answers. Students work toward this end by memorizing correct answers or using sets of steps, often equation based manipulations, to produce correct answers. Such methods are not typically connected to questions of physical sensibility. But physical sensibility is important for students to address as they do or do not come to understand the concepts. Consequently, it is important to pay attention to what kind of activity students are engaging in. Assessing the nature of student activity can be difficult. How does one recognize it? What does it look like? When or where does one see it? Utilizing several videotaped vignettes of students in introductory college courses I begin to answer these questions.

column5: PARTICLE: A University--K-12 Collaboration in Classroom Research
column15: Kevin McFarland,
column18: PARTICLE is a collaboration of Rochester-area secondary school science teachers and particle physicists at the University of Rochester to support student-driven cosmic-ray research in the classroom. PARTICLE has been operating in Rochester since 2000. We discuss findings from a recent assessment of the impact of the program, and lessons that can be learned from the PARTICLE experience.

column5: Physics and Environmental Concerns II
column15: Celia C Chow, CSU
column18: This talk is a continuation of the 2005 AAPT Summer Meeting talk on the same subject. Since environmental concerns are very important, wide and complicated, we need to take a detailed study, and share information with others.

column5: Uncertainty Calculations in the First Introductory Physics Laboratory
column15: Shafiqur M Rahman, Allegheny College
column18: Uncertainty in a measured quantity is an integral part of any experimental data. Consequently, Introductory Physics laboratories at many institutions require that students report quantities being measured as well as their uncertainties. Unfortunately, given that there are several ways of calculating uncertainty, each suitable for particular situations, this is also an area that students feel highly confused about. Students at some institutions are not asked to calculate the uncertainty at all, which gives them a fall sense of the nature of experimental data. We have completely restructured our first Introductory Physics Lab to address this problem. We now systematically and sequentially introduce the various ways of calculating uncertainty including a theoretical understanding, as opposed to a cookbook approach, all within the context of six three-hour labs. Complaints about the lab in student evaluations have dropped by 80%.

column5: Comparing Three Methods for Teaching Newton's Third Law
column15: Trevor I Smith, Univeristy of Maine
column18: Though guided-inquiry methods for teaching introductory physics have been shown to be more effective at improving conceptual understanding than traditional lecture-style instruction, researchers in physics education have not studied differences between reform-based curricula in much detail. Several researchers have developed University of Washington-style tutorial materials, but little research has been done to compare the effectiveness of each. Our study examines three tutorials designed to improve student understanding of Newton?s Third Law: University of Washington Tutorials in Introductory Physics, University of Maryland (UMD) Activity-Based Tutorials, and UMD "epistemological" tutorials. Each tutorial was designed with different goals and agendas, and employs different methods to help students understand the physics. We analyzed pretest and post-test data, including course examinations and data from the Force and Motion Concept Evaluation. We find that students using the UMD "epistemological" tutorial perform better than students using the other two.

column5: PTEC: A Coalition to Improve the Preparation of Physics Teachers
column15: Mary Fehrs, AAPT/AIP/APS
column17: Ted Hodapp, Warren Hein, Jack Hehn
column18: The Physics Teacher Education Coalition (PTEC) is a diverse coalition of institutions committed to preparing highly qualified physics and physical science K-12 teachers. Through the Coalition (a joint effort led by AAPT, AIP, and APS) we are identifying, disseminating, and promoting elements of successful teacher education program for high school physics teachers and K-12 physical science teachers. This coalition is both for institutions that currently have successful programs and for institutions that wish to develop successful programs. Innovative programs and benefits, both for institutions and their faculty, will be described. Programs managed by the Coalition will be illustrated.

column5: Evaluating Integrals without Calculus in Introductory Physics
column15: Donald E Fahnline,
column18: Many introductory physics textbooks relate integrals to the area under a graph and then use students' knowledge of the formulae for the areas of simple geometric shapes to effectively evaluate a few integrals without using calculus. Within this context, this article presents a general geometric-algebraic method for evaluating additional integrals important for introductory physics. Examples include the work done by an elastic force, the work done by an inverse square force, and the moment of inertia of a thin uniform rod.

column5: Maintaining the Story Line: How to Build a Coherent Physics Course
column15: Kenneth S Krane, Oregon State University
column18: From Newtonian mechanics to the Standard Model, physicists view physics as a sequential and interconnected story, which can be told in either the chronological or the hierarchical order. For students in our introductory classes, however, the physics experience often seems more like a series of disconnected topics, whose rapid pace of presentation has been compared to ?drinking from a fire hose.? A more satisfactory approach is based on: (1) a slight reduction in content (?cover less and uncover more?); (2) a coherent grouping and ordering of topics; (3) increased attention to similarities of notation and graphical presentation. It should be the mission of the physics instructor to guide students in making these connections, which are the difference between physics being viewed as an intellectual discipline as opposed to an encyclopedic array. I will illustrate this process with examples from introductory classical and modern physics.

column5: On-Demand Publishing for Credit and Profit
column15: Robert B Teese, Rochester Institute of Technology
column18: On-demand publishing technology allows anyone, with little or no investment, to publish a short paperback book and begin making a profit on the first copy sold. These books do not need to meet the standards of a refereed journal. One of my undergraduate students published a booklet about making schlieren videos
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant DUE-0424063.

column5: Ubiquitous Presenter: Spontaneity and Interactivity in a Digital Lecturing Environment
column15: Edward P Price, California State University San Marcos
column18: We present Ubiquitous Presenter, a system that allows instructors to annotate prepared slides and students to participate electronically during in-class activities, while automatically archiving both sets of materials on the web. Using a Tablet PC, an instructor can add digital ink to a prepared slide, combining the spontaneity and natural pacing of writing on the board with the archival and rich multimedia features of computer-based presentation. Furthermore, students with internet-enabled devices (laptops, Tablets, phones, etc.) can make submissions during class, which the instructor can show to the whole class and annotate. These features enable interaction through typed text, drawn or written ?ink?, and multiple-choice selection (polling), thereby supporting and enriching many interactive engagement techniques. We describe our use of the system, present examples of instructor and student produced materials, and present data on how students use and evaluate the system.

column5: Studying the Use of Computer Simulations in Undergraduate Laboratory Environments
column15: Christopher J Keller, University of Colorado at Boulder
column17: Noah D. Finkelstein, Steven J. Pollock
column18: An interactive computer simulation known as the Circuit Construction Kit (CCK) [1] was introduced [2], [3] into a traditional laboratory environment to study the effects on students? conceptual mastery of physics and attitude towards the laboratory. Additionally, we investigated a particular feature of the simulation, the explicit visualization of current flow, by removing this feature for a subset of participants. Students using CCK with or without the explicit visualization of current performed similarly on conceptual surveys, in agreement with prior work. Furthermore, students using CCK reported more favorable attitudes toward this lab than a lab using real circuit equipment. Those students using CCK without the explicit visualization of current exhibited a more positive attitude towards the simulation, compared to students using CCK with the explicit visualization of current.

column5: High School Students and Teachers Working on the ILC
column15: LeRoy Castle, University of Notre Dame du lac
column18: The International Linear Collider work at Notre Dame headed by Dr. Mitch Wayne has started preliminary construction of prototype detectors, using known scintillator materials that are easily worked with student and teacher trainee personnel. The creation of the detector prototypes will be discussed with the usage of High School students, HS Teachers, undergrad students and technical management. Seeing what outreach personel can do in the lab to assist and create new products for research can give the physcis community ideas on how to add this to their programs.

column5: How Do Teachers Attend to Student Ideas in Science?
column15: Matty Lau, University of Maryland
column17: Andrew Elby, David Hovan, David Hammer
column18: In teaching, there are a myriad of things for a teacher to think about. How interested are the students? How are the students interacting with each other? What do students think about the concepts and the topic? The ways in which these factors influence teacher thinking are not straightforward, as evidenced by research documenting the tensions teachers feel and the differences between enacted and professed beliefs. This paper will analyze one teacher's interaction with students and their ideas, presenting evidence of shifts back and forth in his attention and strategies. In some moments, his attention seems to be on the students and their thinking, and he works to elicit their ideas; in other moments his attention seems to be on canonical ideas he is trying to impart. We will give evidence of these shifts and argue they representing different, often competing ways the teacher and students frame their interactions. Our analysis suggests that awareness of these competing frames may help teachers coordinate them more effectively.

column5: Oersted Lectures: Challenges Then, Challenges Today
column15: John S Rigden, Washington University in St. Louis
column18: In 1849, Alphonse Karr wrote, "The more things change, the more they stay the same." The title of Edwin H. Hall's 1938 Oersted Lecture is "Physics Teaching at Harvard 50 Years Ago," which reaches back to 1888. The timeline has length. Reading the early Oersted lectures is either exhilarating or depressing. It is exhilarating to learn that we stand shoulder-to-shoulder with these men of yesteryear (they were all men) as they talked about the same issues that we women and men talk about today. Much has changed since the pre-Sputnik days, but the concerns of the Oersted speakers then can be laid upon the concerns of many physicists today and there is near congruence. Have we lived with these same concerns for a century? For obvious reasons, that's depressing.

column5: How Do Teachers Attend to Student Ideas in Science?
column15: Matty Lau, University of Maryland
column17: Andrew Elby, David Hovan, David Hammer
column18: In teaching, there are a myriad of things for a teacher to think about. How interested are the students? How are the students interacting with each other? What do students think about the concepts and the topic? The ways in which these factors influence teacher thinking are not straightforward, as evidenced by research documenting the tensions teachers feel and the differences between enacted and professed beliefs. This paper will analyze one teacher?s interaction with students and their ideas, presenting evidence of shifts back and forth in his attention and strategies. In some moments, his attention seems to be on the students and their thinking, and he works to elicit their ideas; in other moments his attention seems to be on canonical ideas he is trying to impart. We will give evidence of these shifts and argue they representing different, often competing ways the teacher and students frame their interactions. Our analysis suggests that awareness of these competing frames may help teachers coordinate them more effectively.

column5: Introducing Freshman and Sophomore Undergraduates to Computational Research in Astronomy
column15: Joshua G Nollenberg, University of St. Thomas
column18: Research in physics and astrophysics can be a significant and formative experience for eager undergraduate students. However, at the University of St. Thomas we encourage many of the most experienced juniors and seniors to participate in summer REU experiences and internships at research universities so student research often entails working with freshman and sophomore students who may bring little analytical or computational experience to the lab. We explore one approach that utilizes the vast amount of publicly available observational data to give underclassmen a start in work on focused problems that simultaneously teach programming techniques, develop familiarity with commonly used data reduction software packages, foster critical thinking and provide an astrophysical context.

column5: Teaching with Technology in an Online AP Physics Course
column15: Loren M Winters
column18: After a decade of learning to use a variety of technologies in traditional classroom settings, I've had the opportunity this year to bring them all together in teaching an AP B physics course online. Technologies that I use include digital video and streaming for demonstrations, applets for investigating problem situations, guided electronic assessments, and electronic discussions. I'll show examples of how I use these technologies, and I'll describe advantages and disadvantages of using them. I'll also reflect on the effectiveness of electronic communication and feedback in teaching the course.

column5: Reviving Continuum Mechanics: How Computation Helps
column15: Dennin Michael, U. C. Irvine
column18: Computation is often described as the third leg of physics, in conjunction with experiment and theory.
