Once one recognizes that computation serves a unique purpose in the physics endeavor, it is important to determine its place in the undergraduate curriculum. Also, independent of its value as a research tool, numerical methods open up an entirely new class of problems that was previously inaccessible to students. There are multiple challenges to integrating numerical methods into a curriculum. Should it be taught as a stand alone course? Should it be integrated across the curriculum? At a large research university, how does one achieve integration across a curriculum when faced with diverse faculty interests? This poster will address two issues: a specific case of the impact of numerical methods on reviving continuum mechanics at the undergraduate level and the choices made at UC Irvine to integrate numerical methods across the curriculum.

column5: Ubiquitous Presenter: Clickers on Steroids
column15: Beth Simon, University of California San Diego
column18: We demonstrate a system that allows students to participate electronically during in-class activities through a variety of modalities, including multiple choice selection, typed text, and drawn or handwritten ?ink?. Students use any internet-enabled device through a web browser to interact with lecture or respond to prepared active learning exercises ? choosing the mode of interaction that is comfortable and appropriate for them and the activity. Student work is transmitted to the instructor machine, where she can review and select submissions to share via digital projector. Using a Tablet PC, the instructor can further annotate student-produced answers. Both student produced work and instructor annotation of prepared materials or use of an electronic whiteboard are automatically archived on a web server and can be made available for student review after class. A mock classroom with several Tablet PCs will demonstrate the system.

column5: Intuitive Quantum Physics: A Course for Nonscience Majors
column15: Michael C Wittmann, Univeristy of Maine
column18: Our course is designed to help students with little mathematics and science background gain an understanding of some of the basic ideas and results of quantum physics. Where possible, we have students build an understanding of physics from easily observable phenomena, giving students touchstone concepts to use when dealing with more complicated topics. The course contains three instructional units in which students develop skills prerequisite to understanding quantum physics, create a ?toolbox? with which to study the quantum world, and discuss applications of quantum physics. Concepts studied in the course include: superposition and interference, wave-particle duality, probability, energy, bound states, and tunneling. We use little algebra and emphasize graphical analysis and qualitative reasoning. Most material is introduced in three-hour lab-tutorial periods. The lab-tutorial includes individual, small-group, and large-group (full class) activities.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant DUE-0410895.

column5: Using Physics Jeopardy Problems to Assess Student Learning
column15: Lili Cui, Kansas State University
column17: N. Sanjay Rebello, Andrew G. Bennett
column18: In this study we conducted individual interviews to assess how students transfer their calculus knowledge to physics. Physics Jeopardy problems in electricity and magnetism were designed to probe problem solving and transfer. The purpose of this study was to determine whether students could apply calculus in the physics context. Interview results showed that students had difficulties solving physics Jeopardy problems because they could not deconstruct the equations provided in the Jeopardy problem and make sense of the different components in those equations. We will also offer suggestions for instruction to facilitate students? transfer from calculus to physics.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant DUE-0206943.

column5: New Ideas for Teaching Relativity: Space-Time Trigonometry (Doppler Effect)
column15: Roberto B Salgado, Syracuse University
column18: Space-Time Trigonometry is a unified treatment of the geometry of Euclidean space, Galilean spacetime, and Minkowskian spacetime that provides a new framework for teaching relativity. (Details are described in a related poster presentation.) Following a brief introduction to this framework, we present a new unified derivation of the longitudinal Doppler effect in the Galilean and relativistic cases.

column5: e-Labs: Wading in at the Shallow End
column15: Kenneth Cecire, Hampton University
column18: e-Labs -- online collaborations in which teachers and students can submit, combine, and analyze real data -- are a new technology using Virtual Data Grid principles that have great potential for teaching physics. In this presentation, participants will be introduced to e-Labs and will examine how an introductory physics lab can be improved using large datasets from a variety of sources. They will then see how they can use the QuarkNet Cosmic Ray e-Lab in only 1-2 class periods to expose students to real data analysis and collaboration with students from all across the US or the world.

column5: New Ideas for Teaching Relativity: Visualizing Proper Time
column15: Roberto B Salgado, Syracuse University
column18: We present a sequence of animations (created with VPython) that visualize the paths of light rays in a circular light clock. The resulting space-time diagrams suggest a pictorial model of proper time that emphasizes the relativistic view that "time is what is measured by an observer's clock." Features of the model reveal the effects of time dilation, length contraction, and the relativity of simultaneity. We apply the model to vividly demonstrate the Twin Paradox. We conclude with some ideas to visualize a uniformly-accelerated light clock.

column5: Middle School Teachers Learn About Light
column15: Hector L Lopez, Rutgers University
column18: The word "inquiry" is ubiquitous nowadays. Teachers are expected to teach science through inquiry. It is a difficult task because teachers lack content knowledge and personal experiences with inquiry. How can one help teachers learn the content, the inquiry teaching methods and the Pedagogical Content Knowledge that they need to help their students learn? A possible answer is by making teachers students in an environment that we want them to model later. One of the inquiry based curricula is ISLE (Investigative Science Learning Environment), which was developed for introductory college physics. In this talk we will share how ISLE was adopted for middle school teachers and what modifications were necessary to help them construct necessary content knowledge and PCK. We will share specific activities, teacher's metacognitive journals and the learning outcomes of the institute. We will also describe the effects of the project on the classroom environment of participating teachers.

column5: New Ideas for Teaching Relativity: Space-Time Trigonometry
column15: Roberto B Salgado, Syracuse University
column18: We present the foundations for a unified treatment of three planar geometries used in physics: Euclidean space, Galilean spacetime, and Minkowskian spacetime. Using techniques familiar from the analytic geometry and trigonometry of Euclidean space, we develop the corresponding analogues for Galilean and Minkowskian spacetimes and suggest extensions to the constant-curvature de Sitter space-times. We comment on how our unified treatment suggests a visualization of tensors (described in a related poster presentation). We feel that this provides a new geometric framework for teaching relativity.

column5: Frontier Physics: Physics Outreach Programming in Northern Illinois
column15: Patricia A Sievert, Northern Illinois University
column18: NIU?s Frontier Physics Road Shows, Haunted Physics Laboratories, Physics Olympics, Nanoscience Presentations, Family Science Nights, Physics for Scouts, and Science Camp are just some of the outreach activities of the Department of Physics at Northern Illinois University. I?ll present an overview of these activities, how we utilized one of the Physics on the Road Grants from the APS for the World Year of Physics, and what we have planned for the future. www.physics.niu.edu/frontier

column5: Physics Songs for Teaching: Much More Than a Memory Aid
column15: Walter F Smith, Haverford College
column18: Songs about physics can provide a remarkable enhancement to teaching, with benefits well beyond the obvious use as a memory aid. In fact, surveys of two introductory college physics classes in which songs were used about once every two weeks show that only about 25% of students used the songs to remember facts and equations, but 100% felt that the songs were educationally valuable. The main benefits appear to lie in the effect of the songs on the classroom atmosphere and the approachability of the instructor, and in the engagement of new parts of the students minds. In this talk, I will detail my own experiences of the best ways to use songs in the college classroom and my observations of their effectiveness. I will also perform several of the songs which have received the most positive student reactions.

column5: Electromagnetism Interactive Learning Using Labview
column15: Jos Antonio Marin Pea, Universidad de la Amazonia
column18: Electricity courses, as part of the physics class, at the Amazonia University, developed interactive work in virtual environments using virtual instruments with the LABVIEW programming language. Thanks to this learning environment students had not only learned concepts but also displayed motivation, confidence, willingness, and good use of in class and out of class time. Two classes were selected for this research: the first group included software engineering students, who knew the programming language. The second group included eight semester students of math and physics education, who did not know any computer language programming. The topic studied with both groups was Ohm's Law. The two groups learned through, first, the traditional paper and pencil based classroom techniques, and then using the virtual environment. Which initial phase was the simulated experiment, coming after the acquisition, visualization, and data collection and analysis.

column5: Transfer of Knowledge from Everyday Experience to a Complex Situation
column15: Bijaya Aryal, Kansas State University
column18: We are studying the influence of college students? prior models and how students transfer these models to a new learning situation. In two sessions of a teaching experiment, we investigated the effect of students? prior experiences on learning about aspects of positron emission tomography (PET) image construction. Some of the preliminary data show that a large fraction of the student population relates the location of light emitting sources only to the perceived brightness of those sources even when other information is available. Students can change their ideas after completing hands-on activities. We are investigating whether these changes are robust. Our results, from using analogy activities, show that these activities are useful both in encouraging transfer and changing students? models.

column5: Studying CSEM Scores for Introductory Physics Courses
column15: Julie T Nguyen, Grove City College
column18: In this study, I examined diagnostic test data from four academic years, focusing on the Conceptual Survey of Electricity and Magnetism (CSEM). The CSEM consists of 32 multiple choice conceptual questions covering basic electricity and magnetism (except circuits) and can be broken down into 11 general topic areas. I looked at matched (pre- and post-instruction) CSEM results for roughly 500 Grove City College students, 400 total in four years of a calculus-based course, and 100 in two years of a trigonometry-based course. I examined the data to identify areas of success and areas where the students still have significant difficulties. In this talk, I will summarize my findings and suggest instructional techniques to address specific deficiencies.

column5: New Ideas for Teaching Relativity: Visualizing Tensors
column15: Roberto B Salgado,
column18: Inspired by Schouten's Tensor Calculus for Physicists, the tensor algebra of vectors and differential forms is accurately represented pictorially. In particular, we visualize the operations of addition, inner-product, outer-product, index-raising and -lowering, and Hodge-dual. We provide some physical examples from electrodynamics and relativity. These visualizations can be used with the Space-Time Trigonometry framework (described in a related poster presentation).

column5: Preparing Teachers of Physics in the Boston Area
column15: Andrew G Duffy, Department of Physics, Boston University
column17: Peter Garik, Luciana Garbayo, Tiffany Sikorski, John Son
column18: The demand for highly qualified physics teachers is great, while the supply of such teachers is small. With this poster we report on a program for in-service teachers in the Boston area, which targets teachers who are teaching physics without having a solid background in the subject. Many of these teachers are teaching a Physics First curriculum. Through a two-year program consisting of 10 two-credit courses, the teachers learn physics; read and discuss articles from the Physics Education Research literature; and learn about the conceptual history of physics. Our aim is to create a set of excited, committed, and knowledgeable physics teachers who are capable both of turning their students on to the wonders of physics, as well as passing the Massachusetts Test for Educator Licensure. We will detail both the challenges and the rewards of the program.

column5: Using Clickers in Classes with Different Instructional Methodologies
column15: Neville W Reay
column18: Though clickers (electronic polling systems) appear to engage students in lectures, little has been done to create and assess strategies for their use. A strategy has been developed and is being assessed by physics education researchers at The Ohio State University. To investigate whether this strategy depends on teaching styles and educational settings, it has been applied in two classes with disparate instructional methodologies. The electricity and magnetism quarter of introductory physics at OSU is taught differently for regular students than for freshman engineering honors students. Classes for the latter are more interactive, rely more strongly on group work and more frequently use student activities in lectures. Clickers and the same sequences of clicker questions were used in both classes. Resulting learning gains and student views are contrasted.

column5: Between the Endpoints: Physics Majors' Development from Novice to Expert
column15: Elizabeth Gire, University of California, San Diego
column18: The undergraduate education of physicists is broader than learning specific physics content taught in classes. As they join the community of practicing physicists, students also develop more expert-like nature of science views, scientific epistemologies, experimental techniques, and analytical and numerical problem solving abilities. We have begun characterizing this development in students working towards a bachelor?s degree in a traditional physics program at a major research university. Survey data and interviews focusing on students' analytical problem solving skills and views about physics knowledge allow us to investigate the nature, timing, and extent of student development in these areas.

column5: Physics, Physicists, and Networks in Radiation Oncology
column15: Daniel Y Kim, SUNY Upstate Medical University
column18: Physicists in radiation oncology play a leading role in applying and developing technology to accurately and efficiently deliver maximum radiation doses to diseased tissue while sparing normal tissue. Digital patient imaging data are the crucial inputs that define and locate targeted volumes. The sophistication of radiotherapy systems has evolved to the point that networks of both computers and diversely trained personnel are required to translate technology into optimal treatments for individual patients. While this complexity enables better therapies, it also increases the risk of unwanted machine downtime and delivery errors. Recently developed innovations that improve the availability and accuracy of radiotherapy systems will be presented, and career implications of the ongoing technological evolution to prospective medical physicists will be discussed.

column5: Alternative Certification in Candidates' Understanding of Physics and Physics Teaching
column15: Kathleen A Falconer, Buffalo State College
column18: The results of a grounded theory study into alternative certification candidates in physics beliefs and values about physics content and physics teaching are presented. Their views, attitudes and beliefs about physics and physics teaching were elicited through interviews with a variety of alternative certification candidates from within the program, including new graduate students as well as recent graduates from the program. The alternative certification candidates? perceptions of the teacher?s role in teaching physics and improving students? understanding of physics content were explored with egalitarianism emerging as a major theme.

column5: What Do Physics Faculty Expect from a Calculus Class?
column15: Lili Cui, Kansas State University
column17: N. Sanjay Rebello, Andrew G. Bennett
column18: In this study we conducted individual interviews with physics and math faculty to find out their expectations of and outcomes from their respective courses. We interviewed both experienced professors and teaching assistants. The purpose of this study was to find out what physics faculty members expected their students to learn from a calculus class before they begin calculus-based physics. We were also interested in what mathematics faculty members felt their students should learn in their calculus courses. Interview results showed that there was a disconnection between the expectations of faculty members from both departments. We will offer suggestions for improving this situation.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant DUE-0206943.

column5: NIU's Haunted Physics Laboratory Hits the Road
column15: Patricia A Sievert, Northern Illinois University
column18: How do you get kids hooked on Physics? How about using the "hook" of a spooky holiday? What happens when you mix kids, hands-on physics activities and a bit of haunted decor? Come see for yourself. Check out the looks on the faces of our guests. NIU has hosted a Haunted Physics Laboratory for three years, expanding it from a few improvised, duct-taped activities to several rooms full of interactive displays. In 2005, we expanded our Haunted Physics Laboratory by bringing it out to three community colleges and an elementary school, as well as hosting it on campus. Kids and parents all got their hands on the demonstrations and our students gained valuable experience working with the public. Funds from the Bauder Fund (2004) and from the American Physical Society's Physics on the Road Grant (2005) have helped us expand. www.physics.niu.edu/frontier.

column5: Behaviors of Sucessful Introductory Physics Students
column15: Adam C Lark, Bowling Green State University
column18: The behavior of students in two introductory physics courses were tracked to determine which behaviors were most correlated with success in the course. Variables tracked include class attendance, use of textbook, use of online homework website, and office hour attendance. In addition students were surveyed about their study habits and why they chose to do what they did.

column5: CHEMX: Assessing Students' Cognitive Expectations for Learning Chemistry
column15: Stacey L Bretz, Miami University
column18: In 1998, Joe Redish?s group introduced MPEX to the PER community to measure students? attitudes and beliefs about introductory university physics. Our research group was interested to explore student expectations about the cognitive processes required to learn chemistry. Would similar expectations exist? This research describes the development of CHEMX, the survey instrument we adapted from MPEX to measure the cognitive expectations of students for learning chemistry. Evidence for both the reliability and validity of CHEMX will be presented, as will data describing the expectations of undergraduate chemistry students. Changes in expectations from freshmen to seniors, comparisons between majors and non-majors, and a profile of faculty expectations in comparison to students will also be presented.

column5: From TIPERs to TICERs
column15: David P Maloney
column18: Can the approach to developing curriculum materials that was employed in the development of TIPERs (Tasks Inspired by Physics Education Research) be applied to materials for any area of physical science? Do we share common problems and challenges with chemistry, and perhaps the other science disciplines? Do the differences between disciplines make sharing approaches unreasonable? Some preliminary answers to these questions will be presented in this talk where the TIPER task formats were applied to an issue in general chemistry to produce TICERS (Tasks Inspired by Chemistry Education Research). Similarities and contrasts to developing these materials in chemistry and physics will be described.

column5: A New Taxonomy of Physics Problems
column15: Raluca E Teodorescu, The George Washington University
column18: We present a modern taxonomy of physics problems that can be used by instructors to characterize a wide range of problems and to get an explicit understanding of the physics problem-solving process. This taxonomy can be used to establish physics education objectives and to assess students' level of proficiency in physics problem solving. Moreover, it is a tool for developers of physics problems which provides a common language when discussing the different levels of difficulty of physics problems. This taxonomy is based on the "New Taxonomy" of educational objectives by Marzano and supersedes earlier approaches based on Bloom. This new scheme is based on a model of learning that takes into account the particularities of physics knowledge and its well-defined hierarchical structure.

column5: Research-based Pedagogical Strategies in Thermal Physics: Development and Assessment
column15: David E Meltzer, University of Washington
column18: We have been investigating student learning of concepts in thermal physics in both introductory- and upper-level courses, and we are developing new pedagogical strategies and curricular materials based on this research. We will report on preliminary results from the use of our research-based materials in the context of thermal physics courses at both the junior/senior level (a course taken mostly by physics majors), and at the sophomore-level (in which enrollment is approximately 50% physics majors). Preliminary results are promising in that some gains in performance seem to have been generated, although there is still much room for further improvement.
column19: Supported in part by NSF DUE 9981140 and PHY 0406724.

column5: RF Clickers: ResponseCards (TurnngPoint) and iClickers
column15: William F Junkin, Eckerd College
column18: Radio-frequency student response systems (RF) have a big advantage over the IR response systems such as the CPS and PRS IR units; but they usually are more expensive. One main advantage: Class can flow more smoothly since there is no need to interrupt class to let students know if their response was received. What is the additional cost? Do they work smoothly? Polling from ResponseCard and iClicker units will be demonstrated and discussed.

column5: Teaching Medical Imaging with Analogies
column15: Dean A Zollman, Kansas State University
column18: Contemporary medical imaging involves a large amount of fundamental physics principles. Data are collected from signals that pass through the body or originate inside of it. Then these data are used to reconstruct an image of the interior of some part of a patient?s body. Some of the techniques used to go from the detection of signals to a detailed image of the person?s vital organs are rather complex. However, many of the basic concepts that form the basis for the reconstruction are straightforward physics. We have created hands-on activities which use analogies to help students understand these principles. The analogies use simple and inexpensive equipment such as LEDs and Legos and focus on computer tomography and positron emission tomography imaging.

column5: Preparing Minnesota Physics Teachers for the Real World of Teaching
column15: John T Truedson, Bemidji state University
column18: The physics department at Bemidji State University in Northern Minnesota has been offering an alternative physics teaching licensure program for three years. This program is designed specifically for science teachers who are currently licensed in other science areas in Minnesota. This physics teaching program consists of on-line courses during the academic year followed by an intensive lab based experience in the summer at the BSU campus. The amount of content covered in the course is significantly less than in a traditional lecture course. However, one purpose of the program is to encourage teachers to teach physics using more active lab based instruction and less lecture. Approximately 45 teachers have successfully completed the program that began in fall 2003. The focus of this presentation will be on how these teachers have modified their instructional strategies based on classroom observations and teacher surveys.

column5: Research and Instructional Strategies for Student Modeling of Microscopic Friction
column15: Edgar Corpuz, Kansas State University
column18: Owing to the increasing impact of nanoscience and technology on our everyday lives and future economy we should prepare our citizens of tomorrow to become active participants in this technology revolution. A key to understanding this field is to recognize the fundamental differences between macroscopic and microscopic physical phenomena. Our focus here is on microscopic friction, which is an important issue in nanoscience. We have conducted research on how students model microscopic friction. Based on this research we have developed and tested curricular materials and instructional strategies to facilitate introductory college students? modeling of microscopic friction. We will describe our research as well as the effect of these activities on student learning.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant REC-0133621.

column5: Constructing Models of the Microscopic World: An Example from Friction
column15: Edgar Corpuz, Kansas State University
column18: How do students model what they cannot see? As nanoscience and technology begins to have an increasing impact on our everyday lives, we need to help students understand the microscopic world so that they become active participants in this scientific revolution of the 21st Century. We focus here on student understanding of microscopic friction, which is an important issue in nanoscience. We have conducted research on how students model microscopic friction. We will describe the results of our research as well as strategies that can potentially help students learn about the microscopic world around them. We will also describe instructional materials that we have developed from our research and the impact of these instructional materials on student understanding of microscopic friction.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant REC-0133621.

column5: Sustaining Reform: Professor's Beliefs and Classroom Practices
column15: Chandra A Turpen, University of Colorado, Boulder
column17: Noah D Finkelstein, Steven J Pollock
column18: We will present data and results from an in-depth qualitative research study investigating four physics professors? perspectives on the nature of physics, as well as the nature of teaching and learning the subject at an introductory level. These topics are particularly relevant to our department as professors become more aware of research-based educational practices and attempt to adopt new teaching strategies. In hopes of sustaining the implementation of new curricula and pedagogical approaches in our department, we investigate this process and its challenges. We document a subset of the professors? stated beliefs about their role as educators and physicists through interviews, while also documenting actual classroom practices through observational fieldwork and quantitative measures such as conceptual inventories. We discuss how professors? stated beliefs and practices reflect certain conceptions of what it means to learn physics and what it means to do physics.

column5: Impact of Collaboration Among Physics Educators from Different Types of Institutions
column15: Curtis J Hieggelke, Joliet Junior College
column18: This paper will tell the story of our 12 NSF funded projects that have involved working with people from community colleges, major PER research centers, four-year colleges, businesses, AAPT, and high schools. Our collaborations have resulted in three books; a major assessment tool (the CSEM); over 60 professional development workshops plus numerous AAPT, PTRA and section workshops; and a chance to meet and encourage hundreds of outstanding physics educators to collaborate.

column5: The Effect of Assessment Variations on Sex-Based Performance Difference
column15: Mark L McKinnon, Univ. Calif. Davis
column18: Research over the last few decades has shown that, in general, females and males are cognitive equals. Yet, for the most part, males still out-perform females in physics and other science classes. We have observed more than 10,000 students over the past decade at UC Davis in the radically restructured Introductory Physics course. The sex-based difference in test scores is considerably smaller than in UC Davis? previous traditional physics course. However, some performance differences remain. We present findings that show the effect that various forms of assessment (problem solving, qualitative analysis, graphical generation and interpretation, etc.) have on sex-based performance differences.

column5: Why Do Good Students Fail Introductory Physics?
column15: Eugene T Torigoe, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign
column18: Physics 100 is an 8 week preparatory course for students who are under-prepared to enter directly into the calculus based mechanics course, Physics 211. This fall (2005) we administered a math diagnostic in Physics 100 and found a strong correlation between the results and the final exam, which is consistent with earlier findings. This spring (2006) we are following former Physics 100 students through Physics 211. We use data from logs of their online activities, their selections on 4 multiple-choice exams, and selected student interviews to track the students through the course. We recruited 10 former Physics 100 students with a variety of mathematical skill levels for interviews throughout the semester. In each interview we asked the students talk aloud as they solved problems from old exams. We chose problems which showed large differences between B and D students. We will discuss our findings and directions for future work.

column5: Challenges in Developing Effective and Useful TIPERs
column15: Curtis J Hieggelke, Joliet Junior College
column17: David P Maloney, Thomas L O'Kuma, Steve Kanim
column18: We have recently completed work and published a new book on E & M TIPERs (Tasks Inspired by Physics Education Research). These efforts were supported by a couple of small NSF CCLI grants. It was our expectation that each of these would require about two years of effort including testing and revising. It, however, was much more difficult than we expected. This paper will discuss some of the issues that we faced in this work and what others might need to know if they attempt to develop new materials for use elsewhere.
column19: Supported by NSF grants DUE #9952735 and #0125831.

column5: The Physics Factory's Education Cascade
column15: Erik A Herman, The Physics Factory
column17: Bruce J Bayly, Kip F Perkins
column18: School athletic programs rarely have difficulty getting students, parents, teachers, and the public involved in local sports. Getting physics to be as high-profile and familiar as football, baseball, or basketball is the goal of a Tucson-based non-profit, ?The Physics Factory? (www.physicsfactory.org). Putting on demo-shows out of our mobile science museum, "The Physics Bus", is one way that we capture community interest, but behind the scenes is where the real learning happens. Over the past year, the Physics Factory has facilitated a pilot program where physics and engineering undergraduates have mentored high school students in researching, designing, constructing, and finally presenting exhibits and demonstrations at local schools and events. The pilot program has been a success overall, but mostly in the motivation and dedication our teams have demonstrated and the empowerment they have enjoyed from this experience.

column5: Analysis of FCI and GFCI Data for Algebra-based Physics Classes
column15: Kimberly A Shaw
column18: In the first-semester introductory algebra-based physics course at SIUE, we have been administering the FCI1 and the GFCI2 to students in the first and last labs of the semester. For the past 5 years, students have been randomly assigned to one of the two exams at the pre-test, and are again randomly assigned at the post-test. This poster will analyze trends in the data over time, including (1) class size effects, (2) the effect of the addition of an off-sequence class, (3) performance differences on the two exams (FCI vs. GFCI), (4) correlation between performance on these instruments and course performance as measured by grade, and (5) correlation with attitudinal variables such as physics self-efficacy. Preliminary results will be presented.

column5: Major Projects from the Physics Workshop Project for the 21st Century
column15: Curtis J Hieggelke, Joliet Junior College
column18: We will report on participant's post-workshop major projects; including "Development of LabVIEW Controllers for Physics Laboratory Exercises," by Kent Reinhard; "Using Just-in-Time-Teaching Techniques in an Algebra-Based Physics Class," James E. Heath, Jr.; "Alternating Current and Voltage Circuit Project (MBL)," by Imad El-Jeaid; and many more.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant #ATE-0101589.

column5: Cars, Girls, and Science
column15: Beth Parks, Colgate University
column18: For the past three summers, I have run an NSF-funded residential camp for girls ages 14-17. This camp is designed to stimulate girls? interest in science by capitalizing on their interest in automobiles. The girls spend half the day in hands-on work with cars at Morrisville State College. The other half of the day is dedicated to laboratory exercises at Colgate University that have been designed to help girls learn the science behind the operation of cars. While it is impossible to assess the long-range impact of this program after only three years, the results seem promising. I will discuss the camp program, with particular emphasis on the laboratory experiments that have been developed, since these could easily be incorporated into standard high school or college laboratories on topics such as the gas laws and friction.

column5: An Historical Approach to Learning Physics and Science for K-8 Teachers
column15: John R Truedson, Bemidji State University
column18: At Bemidji State University most undergraduate elementary and middle school teaching majors take the introductory physical science course sequence that I have taught for the past 10 years. Each of the two courses in the sequence have an enrollment of about 350 students consisting of a large lecture presentation with a small group lab twice a week. Since this may be the only science course many of these students will take as an undergraduate it is important for the students to be able to make some sort of connection with the content covered in the class. I felt the texts I had been using for the course did not adequately address this concern. For the past three years I have been teaching the course using an historical and practical approach with material developed over the years. I am in the process of completing a text that I began using in fall 2005. The focus of this presentation will be on the content covered in the book and how this approach has helped these prospective teachers get a better understanding of the process of science and to teach science concepts more effectively to K-8 students.

column5: A Simple Evaluation of Technology-Enhanced Formative Assessment Techniques
column15: Robert A Cohen, East Stroudsburg Univ.
column18: Several techniques have been utilized with an algebra-based physics class in order to enhance formative assessment. Two of these techniques utilize technology: (a) Students email me before every class, identifying a main idea in the reading and asking a question. That day?s lesson is then organized to address their questions (as with JustInTime teaching). After class, I respond to each person individually. (b) Immediate feedback during class is provided via student hand-held remotes. Using a simple, low-cost (zero) pre/post design, the effectiveness of these techniques has been evaluated and results show that the combination of techniques leads to a significant improvement in understanding.

column5: Teaching Faraday's Law
column15: Anita B Corn, COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES
column18: MANY STUDENTS IN SECOND-SEMESTER GENERAL PHYSICS STRUGGLE WITH FARADAY?S LAW MORE THAN WITH ANY OTHER CONCEPT. WE SET UP SEVERAL DEMONSTRATIONS FOR THE STUDENTS TO WORK THROUGH, AND HAD THEM RECORD THEIR OBSERVATIONS. WE THEN PRESENTED THE EQUATION EMF = -NDM(CAPITAL PHI SUBSCRIPT M, THE SYMBOL FOR MAGNETIC FLUX)/DT AND HAD STUDENTS WRITE GROUP PAPERS DESCRIBING HOW THIS EQUATION EXPLAINED THEIR OBSERVATIONS. THE FULL LESSON WILL BE DISPLAYED AND DATA REGARDING THE SUCCESS OF THIS METHOD AS COMPARED TO OUR OLD TECHNIQUE OF PRESENTING THE EQUATION AND SHOWING STUDENTS THE DEMONSTRATIONS WILL BE PRESENTED.

column5: Investigating Students' Ideas About X-rays While Developing Innovative Teaching Materials
column15: Spartak Kalita, Kansas State University
column18: To investigate student understanding and mental models we conducted about 30 unstructured and semi-structured interviews with KSU Physics students. We concentrated our effort on X-rays, a topic for which almost all of the students should have more or less well-defined models that cannot be disregarded, and could be used in developing teaching materials. Often these models are very inconsistent and come from different sources of information including students? own experiences, mass media and their physics classes. Our last series of 10 clinical interviews focusing directly on the pre-med student population at KSU is coupled with a series of teaching interviews. Here we utilize a proposed X-ray and CAT learning module that includes simple and intuitive optical analogies. Patterns of transfer of learning from physics classes and everyday practice to medical applications are being recognized and studied in detail.

column5: Making Quark-Gluon Soup at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider
column15: Timothy J Hallman, Brookhaven National Laboratory
column18: Since the time of the ancient Greek philosophers our understanding of nature has depended on the ability to study objects at smaller and smaller scales. One of the newest, high power microscopes available is the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Laboratory. By colliding nuclei of gold atoms in opposite directions at nearly the speed of light, RHIC provides access to the smallest building blocks known thus far--quarks and gluons. The results of head-on collisions at RHIC indicate that in its infancy, the early universe was very different than today, with the quarks and gluons coexisting in a hot, primordial soup. The discovery of that soup at RHIC, and its implications for our understanding will be discussed.

column5: Detection of Nuclear Material in Cargo Containers via Neutron Interrogation
column15: Jennifer Church, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory
column18: Approximately 6 million cargo containers arrive at U.S. seaports annually, carrying up to 30 tons of non-homogenous cargo each. Highly enriched uranium and other special nuclear material concealed inside these containers is difficult to detect with existing portal monitors, due in part to the attenuation of low energy gamma-rays in the cargo. A new system is currently being developed to reduce the likelihood of false-negative and false-positive detections of fissile material in the cargo, without slowing the flow of commerce through the port. The technique utilizes a neutron beam to induce fission, and a wall of plastic scintillators to detect subsequent delayed high-energy gamma-rays after beta-decay of the fission products. Because half-lives of most of the fission products are less than 160 seconds, decay curves over 100 second intervals become an efficient diagnostic. New experimental work using a 3-7 MeV broad spectrum neutron beam will be presented.

column5: Transfer of Learning: Implications for Research, Curriculum Development and Instruction
column15: N. Sanjay Rebello, Kansas State University
column18: Transfer of Learning has often been regarded as the ultimate goal of education. But what exactly transfers is not necessarily clear, let alone how to measure it. In our research we explore this question from multiple perspectives. Based on our own qualitative research on student understanding in various contexts, we have developed a theoretical framework that allows us to explore the issue of transfer. Our framework is consistent with the views expressed by several other contemporary researchers who have examined transfer from multiple perspectives. We will describe our theoretical framework and will share our insights into how we believe our framework can help us understand students? sense-making processes in new situations. We will also present the implications of our framework for curriculum development and instructions as well as discuss the limitations of our framework.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant REC-0133621.

column5: Interaction of Theory and Practice: Evolution of ISLE Lab
column15: Eugenia Etkina, Rutgers University
column17: Sahana Murthy, Anna Karelina, Maria Ruibal-Villasenor
column18: The Investigative Science Learning Environment (ISLE)* is a system that engages students in processes mirroring the practice of science. Laboratories play a central role in ISLE. Students design and perform their own experiments to investigate new phenomena, test hypotheses, or solve practical problems. The goal of engaging students in these sophisticated activities is to help them develop scientific abilities. However, it is not sufficient to merely perform these activities. What we strive for is that students understand the purpose of these labs, see the connections between the lab activities and their future careers, and enjoy the process. To achieve these goals we combined three theoretical frameworks: contextual modules[1], transfer as preparation for future learning[2] and coordination classes[3]. In our talk we will describe how these three seemingly unrelated constructs fit together in ISLE labs. *Supported by NSF DUE 0251078. [1] C. Bereiter (1990). ?Aspects of an Educational Learning Theory.? Review of Educational Research, Vol. 60, No. 4, pp. 603-624. [2] J. Bransford and D. Schwartz (1999). ?Rethinking transfer: A simple proposal with multiple implication.? Review of Educational Research, Vol. 24, pp. 61-100. [3] A. DiSessa (2005). ?What coordination has to say about transfer,? in Transfer of Learning from a Multidisciplinary Perspective, Information Age Publishing, pp. 121-154.

column5: Physics Perspectives on Systems Biology
column15: Phillip M Duxbury, Michigan State University
column18: Traditional molecular biology and biochemistry focused upon the role of one gene, or relatively small gene pathways, on function or disease. However the majority of cellular processes involve many genes working together, so that a network or systems model is required to understand their behavior. The simplest model, introduced by Kauffman, is to ascribe two states to a gene, namely the on state and the off state. Systems biology then reduces to the study of the dynamical attractors of binary models on complex networks. This is a fascinating statistical physics problem which has generated a vast literature. I will give an overview of this literature and then describe our own efforts on gene regulatory networks of interest in cancer research.

column5: Conceptual Frameworks: Helping Students Organize Their Astronomy Knowledge
column15: Kevin M Lee, University of Nebraska
column18: Many different types of diagrams are useful in helping students organize and internalize their introductory astronomy knowledge. These include Venn Diagrams, Flowcharts, Concept Maps, and others which illustrate the relationships between astronomical objects and concepts. This presentation will demonstrate how these diagrams have been incorporated into the ClassAction project. ClassAction is a collection of materials designed to enhance the metacognitive skills of college and high school introductory astronomy students by promoting interactive engagement and providing rapid feedback. The main focus is dynamic think-pair-share questions that can be projected in the classroom. Instructors can recast these questions into alternate forms based on their own preferences and feedback from the class. The questions can be easily selected from a FLASH computer database and are accompanied by outlines, graphics, and many simulations which the instructor can use to provide feedback. ClassAction is publicly available at http://astro.unl.edu and is funded by NSF grant #0404988.

column5: Simulating the Detection of ExtraSolar Planets
column15: Kevin M Lee, University of Nebraska
column17: Christopher M. Siedell, Adam N. Davis
column18: This poster will describe a new simulation of extrasolar planet detection using radial velocity. Users have the capability to vary many parameters including the masses of the star and planet, orbital parameters, and the viewing angle and observe the resulting effect on the radial velocity curve. System parameters for many stars known to have extrasolar planets are available as presets. The Nebraska Astronomy Applet Project consists of high quality astrophysics simulations surrounded by variety of supporting materials. The resources include complete background information, student guides, instructor guides, and embedded assessment. These materials are available at http://astro.unl.edu and are funded by NSF grant #0231270.

column5: Promoting Vector Use in Introductory Mechanics Laboratories
column15: Keron Subero, New Mexico State University
column18: Recent published results suggest that an understanding of acceleration as a vector quantity is not a typical outcome of instruction in introductory mechanics. Our attempts to promote increased understanding of vector concepts through instructional modifications to the lecture portion of the course have met with only limited success. In this talk we give examples of questions about acceleration in two dimensions that students find challenging. We describe a laboratory that we are developing that is intended to give students practice at manipulating vectors and that provides opportunities for students to determine the direction of acceleration for objects moving in two dimensions. Finally, we will give initial results from our analysis of questions that we have asked to assess the effectiveness of these laboratories.

column5: Reducing DFW Rates: Good and Bad Consequences
column15: Anita B Corn, COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES
column18: IN AN ATTEMPT TO REDUCE DFW RATES IN SECOND-SEMESTER GENERAL PHYSICS AT COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES, THE TEST ON MAGNETISM (TYPICALLY THE HARDEST FOR THE STUDENTS) WAS SPLIT INTO TWO FIFTY-POINT TESTS AND STUDENTS WHOSE SCORES DIPPED BELOW A MIDDLE C WERE REQUIRED TO GET EXTRA HELP. PRELIMINARY RESULTS INDICATE THAT DFW RATES HAVE INDEED BEEN REDUCED FOR ALL STUDENTS, BUT CSEM SCORES TOOK A LITTLE DIP, AS WELL. STUDENT SATISFACTION WILL ALSO BE DISCUSSED. 1DFW(SUPERSCRIPT 1) RATE EQUALS THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS WHO RECEIVE A D, F OR W DIVIDED BY THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS WHO ENTER THE COURSE.

column5: Can Students Evaluate Their Own Understanding?
column15: Jessica Watkins, Harvard University
column18: Can students assess their own understanding in introductory physics? How does their assessment change during the learning process? Instructors often gauge how well students are assimilating the material based on the number of questions or confused looks they receive during their interactions with students. However, it is unclear how well students are able to recognize their own understanding (or lack thereof). In this talk, we present preliminary results from our study of the relationship between students' perceived understanding and their actual understanding of introductory physics concepts. We show that while students are not very good at assessing their own understanding at the beginning of the learning process they are much better at assessing it at the end.

column5: Teaching Astronomy with 200 Million Data Points
column15: Jordan Raddick, Johns Hopkins University
column18: For five years, the SkyServer web site (http://skyserver.sdss.org) has been offering data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey free of charge to teachers and the general public. The SDSS has now completed the first phase of its scientific mission, leaving a final data release of nearly 200,000,000 objects. SkyServer will keep growing, adding new tools and activities, for many years to come. Meanwhile, the SDSS has begun a second phase of operations, with the specific goals of finding supernovae and mapping the structure of the Milky Way. Data from the second phase will also be available on SkyServer, and offering opportunities for new types of activities and student research. In this poster, I will show SkyServer?s new tools and projects, and describe the new operations that the SDSS is conducting.

column5: Elementary School Rockets: Making Physics a Blast
column15: Steve Lindaas, Minnesota State University Moorhead
column18: For the last few years I have been working with area teachers on rocket activities. They have been using rockets to talk about and hold their students interest in force and motion. They now launch both water (2-liter) and solid fuel rockets. The twist is that the students design and build their rockets. In the case of the solid fuel rockets they are just given an Estes engine. The students are not allowed to "just build a kit." In fact, part of the fun is using "found objects" (junk) as part of your rocket. The result is a lot of fun, learning and a memorable experience. The same activities can successfully be used in the introductory physics laboratory.

column5: Bringing the Excitement of Physics to the Public with PhysicsCentral.com
column15: Jessica Clark, American Physical Society
column18: Launched in December 2000, PhysicsCentral.com is the flagship public outreach initiative of the American Physical Society. A website in a magazine-like format with continually updated content, it is designed to bring the excitement and importance of physics to everyone in a simplified?but not simplistic?way. It features both pedagogical elements and descriptions of recent developments in fast-moving areas of current research. PhysicsCentral is designed to be attractive and informative and to emphasize that physics is an interesting pursuit carried out by interesting people. Visitors to the site can learn a little bit of physics, can find out what is happening on the research frontier, and can find links to the rest of the best physics sites on the web. PhysicsCentral carries the imprimatur of the American Physical Society and plays a unique role that is not duplicated by any other site in the universe.

column5: Why Are You in Physics, Anyway?
column15: Brian A Pyper, BYU-Idaho Department of Physics
column18: More students leave physics for non-physics majors than visa versa. We surveyed a number of students to pin-point their initial reasons to major in physics and their reasons for then leaving physics as a major. Our survey was patterned after research addressing the issue of attrition in Science, Mathematics, and Engineering majors. (1) We found some interesting results by comparing the answers of those students who left physics as a major, those who left a different major for physics, and those who have stayed in physics.

column5: Towards a Quantitative Analysis of Writing and Revision Structure
column15: Dedra N Demaree, The Ohio State University
column17: Gordon Aubrecht, Lei Bao, Scott Franklin, Lisa Hermsen
column18: Writing activities in science have a broad basis of support, yet few quantitative studies have been done to understand the impact of writing or how best to use writing in the physics classroom. As a basis for addressing these larger questions, researchers from both the Physics and English departments at The Ohio State University and Rochester Institute of Technology are looking for ways to quantitatively analyze student writing and revising. Students write short essay questions then revise them to half the original length. This emphasizes the need to focus on what information is necessary to answer the question. The writing and revising has been tracked, allowing us to begin a quantitative analysis of student work. Questions we are addressing include: can we find relations in the types of revisions and in how students structure their writing? And does the writing and revision structure correlate with content understanding?

column5: Student Resources for Understanding Motion
column15: Brian W Frank, Arizona State University
column17: Luanna G Ortiz, Stephen E Kanim, Michael E Loverude
column18: The reasoning strategies of introductory students attempting to solve a variety of physics problems involving the motion of objects have been analyzed from the perspective of a Resource Model of thinking. We present three conceptual resources broadly used by students to reason about distance, speed, and time. Although most students appropriately apply these resources to solve simple kinematics problems, the use of these same resources in more complex situations leads many students to come to false conclusions. The activation and suppression of these resources in different contexts are discussed.

column5: A New Tool for Tracking Student Writing and Revision
column15: Dedra Demaree, The Ohio State University
column17: Lei Bao, Wenhui Zhao, Gordon Aubrecht, Scott Franklin
column18: The Physics Education Research Group at The Ohio State University has developed a tool for analyzing student writing and revision. Using this tool, students can write responses to essay questions directly into the program as if they were using any simple text editor. Upon saving the file, both a final text file is produced and a file which logs the details of the writing process. This log file can then be transferred to a modified S-notation, which tracks where and in what order students insert text, delete text, and pause during the writing process. Students can also open an existing text file for editing, allowing us to track both first and later draft revisions. This poster will show this tool, explain S-notation and explain what quantitative data we can obtain from it.

column5: Using a Tracking Tool to Analyze Student Writing and Revising
column15: Dedra Demaree, The Ohio State University
column17: Lei Bao, Scott Franklin, Gordon Aubrecht, Wenhui Zhao
column18: Researchers at The Ohio State University and at Rochester Institute of Technology have used a new tracking tool to capture details of student writing in physics. This tracking tool is explained in detail in a companion poster. Using data of student writing obtained through this program we are able to run statistical analysis on several factors including locations and lengths of pauses, types and locations of revisions, and number of revisions. This information can then be compared to traditional grading of physics content. This poster will provide examples of what we can learn from this type of analysis.

column5: Exploring the Impact of Educational Reform
column15: Thomas M Foster, Southern Illinois University Edwardsville
column18: Using educational innovations without assessment is like spelunking in the dark. In this spirit, the PACBE2R group at Southern Illinois University Edwardsville has been continually assessing our introductory physics courses over the past 5 years using a pretest/posttest format. The chief advantage of this practice is we gain a longitudinal glimpse of our courses over several different teachers, instructional innovations, and fluctuations in our student population. In this poster, we will present data from our calculus-based sequence specifically data from the TUG-K[1], TOLT[2], and BEMA[3]. The poster will also present the statistical validity and reliability of each assessment based on our student population.

column5: Interactive Lectures with Clickers: They Are a "H-ITT"
column15: R. Daryl Pedigo, University of Washington
column18: Active Learning in the lecture hall is difficult to achieve; the same small group of students tend to answer the lecturer?s questions each day. In an attempt to engage the entire class (150 to 250 students) in active learning, "clicker" technology (an infrared student response system) has been employed in dozens of freshman level physics classes at the UW since the spring quarter of 2003. The system has been used in both algebra- and calculus-based physics classes. This paper will focus on the algebra-based course, which does not include the weekly small group tutorial sessions utilized with the calculus-based classes. Desirable lecture structure for best engagement will be discussed. Sample questions from selected interactive lecture worksheets that were developed at UW will be presented. Results of an in-class question and an exam question will be presented, along with student attitude survey data on the perceived value of the clicker system.

column5: Light Me Up: An Introduction to Circuits Without Wires
column15: Steve Lindaas, Minnesota State University Moorhead
column18: Can you light a bulb without using wires? This is the basic battery and bulbs activity but with no wires attached and lots of "red herrings" thrown in. The challenge is to make light using the contents of the bag. This hands-on and minds-on activity can be used as a stand-alone outreach activity or as part of a physics lab. I have personally used this activity with electrical engineering majors as well as second-grade students. I use this the first class period for the introductory E&M; physics course. Students get an immediate engaging experience, which sets the tone for the rest of the semester. In addition, this activity provides a segue to other electricity and magnetism topics. As an outreach activity this is a great reminder to participants that physics is more than just balls bouncing.

column5: An Investigation into the Effectiveness of Physics First in Maine
column15: Michael J O'Brien
column18: Data from three high schools that teach physics in ninth grade and three that teach physics in twelfth grade were used to make comparisons between these classes. Research tools include written pre- and post-tests of kinematics and mechanics concepts, a written physics attitudes and expectations survey, and individual student interviews. Portions of these tools were excerpted from well-known and thoroughly tested instruments. We compare the normalized gains on the conceptual survey, and discuss which kinematics and mechanics concepts ninth- and twelfth-graders appear to learn differently. We also compare students? perceptions of physics from the ninth- and twelfth-grade viewpoints. Preliminary results suggest that while the populations are similar affectively, they have significant differences in conceptual understanding, and this difference is amplified by different instructional approaches.

column5: UTeach: Update on Summer Master's in Education for High School Physics Teachers
column15: John T Markert, Department of Physics, University of Texas
column18: In addition to preparing undergraduates for secondary math and science teaching, the UTeach teacher-training program, an independent, multi-college program at the University of Texas at Austin, includes a Summer Master's Program, a professional development component primarily, but not exclusively, for in-service secondary school teachers. The program includes eight courses: three in learning theory, three content courses in a particular discipline, and both lesson study and research experience courses. This talk reviews the program from the Physics Department perspective, and also focuses on the second physics content course, Physics Instructional Techniques, which emphasizes a deep pedagogical and conceptual understanding of content. In addition to hands-on laboratory learning and group inquiry thrusts, the course uses two main venues, "Concept Checkups," an overview of essential physics concepts that focuses on anticipating common pitfalls and misconceptions, and "Concepts in Context," a series of multi-question vignettes involving real-world applications of physics.

column5: Student Use of Integration in the Context of P-V Diagrams
column15: Brandon R Bucy
column17: John R Thompson, Donald B Mountcastle
column18: Previous research on the teaching and learning of thermal physics, specifically in the context of the First Law of Thermodynamics, shows that students often apply the property of state function inappropriately, e.g., to both work and internal energy (Loverude et al. AJP 2002, Meltzer AJP 2004). We developed questions that probe student understanding of the mathematical concepts underlying the physics and administered these questions in upper-level undergraduate courses. These questions are analogous to examples from the literature, but devoid of any physical context. Our results suggest that while students may indeed have difficulties associated with the physical concepts in question, mathematical difficulties compound the problem. In particular, students often lack a strong understanding of two fundamental concepts of integration: the Riemann sum and the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, both of which strongly impact whether a given variable is a state function or not.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant #PHY-0406764. Sponsored by John R. Thompson.

column5: Building a Community of Physics Teachers to Support "Learning to Teach Continuum"
column15: Drew Isola, Western Michigan University
column18: The learning to teach continuum (teacher preparation - induction - mentoring & professional development) is fraught with inconsistencies and missing pieces. Universities typically see themselves as only being responsible for the first phase, some school districts take on the second and everyone or no one takes on the third area. An experienced K-12 Teacher in Residence with an active role in a university teacher preparation program can play an integral role in developing a community of teachers of physics. This community can serve as the glue to hold this continuum together and provide some continuity for individuals as they pass through this continuum from institution to institution. Examples of what such a community can do to support this continuum will be discussed along with some positive results of these activities.

column5: Comparison of Teaching Methods for Energy Conservation
column15: M. Lenore Horner
column18: Three sections, taught by different instructors, of Conceptual Physics were taught energy conservation using three different techniques: traditional - no visualization, energy bar charts, and energy bars. Performance of the groups of students on homework problems, exam questions, and final exam questions is compared and contrasted.

column5: The Conceptual Survey of Electricity and Magnetism
column15: Thomas L O'Kuma, Lee College
column17: Curtis Hieggelke, David Maloney, Alan Van Heuvelen,
column18: The Conceptual Survey of Electricity and Magnetism (CSEM) was developed and tested over a period of eight years. This paper will describe the process, testing, and refinement of the CSEM during this time period. Results obtained from the testing and administration of the CSEM will also be discussed.

column5: Analyzing and Generating Real Sound Data Using Excel
column15: Hyun-Soo Kim, Seoul National University
column18: Excel worksheets and add-on VBE programs allow students to analyze and generate their own real time sound data. This paper present educational techniques in sampled waveform graphs, animations, FFT calculations, and data acquisitions with the use of general sound device on a computer.

column5: Sustaining Innovation in Introductory Courses: Can TEAL Survive at MIT
column15: Sahana Murthy, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
column18: The introductory mechanics and electricity & magnetism courses at MIT have been reformed. They are now taught in the TEAL (Technology-Enhanced Active Learning) format: a studio-style class where presentations, problem solving, and labs are merged to create a technologically rich and highly cooperative learning environment. The changes were first implemented in Fall 2001 (electricity & magnetism) and Spring 2003 (mechanics), and have been evolving since then. The reforms were strongly supported by the department, and have led to lower failure rates and improved scores on standardized diagnostic tests. However there have also been obstacles to the innovations arising from: student attitudes, some faculty resistance, and the contrast between traditional pedagogies in other first-year courses and the TEAL format. In this talk we examine some of the issues involved in sustaining the innovations. We also discuss some strategies that can help mitigate or overcome these obstacles.

column5: Comparing Student Attitudes About Interactive Engagement Courses
column15: Sahana Murthy, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
column18: Universities throughout the country have reformed or are in the process of reforming introductory physics courses. The design of many of these courses is based on PER findings. They often employ active-learning approaches such as collaborative problem solving, peer instruction and open-ended labs. There is evidence of improved learning in these courses, as measured by standardized tests and scientific abilities assessment rubrics. However, according to course evaluations and instructor feedback, a significant fraction of students appears to resist these changes. To probe this issue further, we conducted two independent qualitative studies involving extensive student interviews. In this poster we compare and contrast the results of students? responses to curricular innovation in two different settings: an algebra-based course for science majors in a large state university, and a calculus-based course for engineers in a prestigious private university. Insights gained into students? attitudes will help us better implement and sustain future innovations.

column5: Student Thinking About Rate of Change in Differential Equations
column15: Chris L Rasmussen, San Diego State University
column18: Analyses of student thinking from cognitive and situated perspectives in mathematics education tend to highlight different aspects of the same phenomenon. For example, while cognitive models typically detail conceptual obstacles and mental processes needed at a given level for progressing to higher levels, they seldom involve the purposes and goals of the learner and they obscure the ways in which cognition is often carried out in connection with resources in the environment. On the other hand, by relying on thick, rich narrative accounts, situated accounts often lose sight of the bigger picture of the milestones that characterize important shifts in reasoning. Drawing on a multi-year research project in differential equations, I will present an analysis of student thinking about rate of change that takes into account cognitive milestones while also describing the ways in which aspects of the situation (tasks, goals, interaction patterns) constrain and afford particular ways of thinking.

column5: Virtual Tipers-like Exercises Using Open Source Physics
column15: Karim Diff, Santa Fe Community College
column18: A series of simulation-based exercises designed to promote conceptual understanding in first-semester physics will be presented. These java-based simulations use the Open Source Physics (OSP) framework and follow the approach developed by TIPERS (Tasks Inspired by Physics Education Research). Focusing on areas of first-semester physics where interactive simulations provide a unique advantage over static descriptions, the exercises place a particular emphasis on the use of multiple representations and on troubleshooting. Instead of simply illustrating a particular phenomenon or providing controls that let students modify every aspect of a simulation, these exercises expect students to process information and limit the possibility of using a random trial-and-error approach. The activities can be used as in-class cooperative exercises or as out-of-class tutorials. Preliminary versions can viewed at http://inst.sfcc.edu/~natsci/physics/simulations/

column5: What Is the Best Way to Mentor New Physics Teachers?
column15: Dale Freeland, Portage Central High School
column18: I served as a Teacher in Residence in Western Michigan University's Physics department during 2002-2003 in Kalamazoo, Michigan. I have continued my involvement with the NSF Physics Teacher Education Coalition afternoon to my classroom through mentoring beginning and crossover teachers. In this session, an analysis of the mentoring time utilization and activities will be shared along with representative commments from mentee teachers. Representative products develooped in these collaborative efforts will also be presented.

column5: Pre-Service Elementary Teachers' Attainment of the Lunar Phases Concept
column15: Rebecca Lindell
column18: Using a qualitative grounded theory approach the researchers investigated approximately 20 pre-service elementary teachers? attainment of the concept of lunar phases. The pre-service teachers came from the integrated science content course at SIUE, which all elementary educations are required to complete. Multiple data sources were collected as part of this project. These include: 45-minute pre-instructional interviews, classroom/ activity observations, 45-minute post-instruction interviews, as well as all student work. By analyzing this data, we hope to present a preliminary theory for how these pre-service elementary teachers obtain the concept of lunar phases. Results of this project will help to determine if there indeed appears to be conceptual learning hierarchy of lunar phases.

column5: The Cornstarch Flame-Thrower
column15: Thomas G Concannon, Synopsys, Inc.
column18: Igniting cornstarch powder is a classic physics demonstration, showcasing the rapid conduction of heat for a material in which the surface area is greater than the volume of its constituent particles. Including such a demonstration in a physics ?magic show? for the general public presents certain challenges such as reproducibility and inspiring awe. A simple but effective design for widely scattering cornstarch dust over a flame breaches these challenges and always results in consistently large, crowd-pleasing fireballs; so much so that the resulting demonstration has been dubbed the ?cornstarch flame-thrower.?

column5: Investigation of Superposition Principle by Plotting Equipotential Lines
column15: Kandiah Manivannan, Missouri State University
column18: Electric field lines, electric field vectors, and equipotential lines play a central role in conceptual understanding of electrostatics. Plotting of equipotential lines, a common activity found in introductory college physics laboratory courses, provides a nice way of visualizing electric potentials. Also, equipotential lines are valuable in promoting student understanding of electric potentials and fields. We show how spreadsheets can make it easy to draw equipotential line diagrams due to various charge configurations. Spreadsheets also allow us to change parameters such as charge strengths and charge separations and instantly redraw potential profiles. We will show how to use visual representations of equipotential lines on spreadsheets to demonstrate the principle of superposition, and compare them with experimental data collected in introductory laboratory classes. Using spreadsheets can significantly improve student understanding of concepts related to equipotential lines and the principle of superposition.

column5: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Animations in Student Learning
column15: Anne J Cox, Eckerd College
column18: In order to determine the role of animations in student learning, we have developed a number of ways to try to assess the effectiveness of Physlet-based and Open Source Physics materials in enhancing student learning. This includes tutorial-type worksheets, ranking-task exercises and the use of standard pre and post-test instruments. This talk will present the results from the use of these evaluation materials.

column5: Partnership for Reform Through Inquiry in Science and Mathematics (PRISM)
column15: Stephen J Van Hook, Bowling Green State University
column17: Lena Ballone-Duran, Tracy Huziak, Julie Nurnberger-Haag
column18: The Partnership for Reform through Inquiry in Science and Mathematics (PRISM) program at Bowling Green State University, an NSF GK-12 Program, creates University / K-12 partnerships to develop reform-based teaching practices at both the K-12 and University level. Graduate students in mathematics and the sciences collaborate with grades 4-12 teachers for one to two academic years to jointly infuse content-rich inquiry-based instruction into the K-12 classroom. This poster will share research on the effect of this partnership on K-12 teacher and graduate student views on inquiry-based teaching.

column5: Inquiry Activities Using Homemade Diffraction Gratings
column15: Stephen J Van Hook, Bowling Green State University
column18: This poster will describe how one can make inexpensive diffraction gratings and how these gratings can be used in several engaging scientific inquiry activities - I have used these activities with high school physics teachers, introductory physics classes, and even kindergarten students.

column5: Do Students Know What Physicists Think About Physics?
column15: Kara E Gray, University of Colorado
column17: Katherine K Perkins, Wendy K Adams, Carl E Wieman
column18: The Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey (CLASS) (1) is a 42 statement questionnaire designed to elicit student beliefs about physics. Previous results from the survey have shown that students do not agree with the attitudes of physicists and that their opinions do not change (or more often move farther away from the altitudes of physicists) after a semester of instruction. These results have raised the question of do students even know what physicists believe about how to learn physics. In this study, students were asked to choose their opinion (from a five-point Likert scale) and their opinion of what a physicist would believe. Students from three introductory physics classes (spanning engineers, pre-meds, and non-science majors) were surveyed. Results on student opinions of physicists' beliefs will be compared to their personal beliefs, and to the beliefs of physicists.

column5: Students' Opinions of Physicists
column15: Kara E Gray, University of Colorado
column17: Katherine K Perkins, Wendy K Adams, Carl E Wieman
column18: The Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey (CLASS) (1) is a 42 statement questionnaire designed to elicit student beliefs about physics. Based on previous results most students do not agree with the expert responses. This has raised the question of whether students know how experts would respond. In this study, students were asked to choose their opinion (from a 5 point Likert scale) and their opinion of what a physicist would believe. Students from three introductory physics classes (a class for engineers and physics majors, a class of mostly pre-meds, and a class of predominantly non-science majors) were surveyed and 11 students were interviewed to provide a deeper understanding. Results from the surveys and interviews will be presented. Also considered is how students? opinions of physicists? beliefs are related to gender, current physics course, and previous physics experiences and how these opinions change throughout the semester.

column5: Introductory Laboratory Reforms at the University of Michigan
column15: David Gerdes
column17: Carl Akerlof, Andrew Tomasch, Dennis Allen
column18: At the University of Michigan, our algebra- and calculus-based introductory labs serve about 1300 students each semester. We describe a series of reforms being implemented to make the labs more up-to-date, student-friendly, and relevant to the lecture. These include pre-lab quizzes, electronic data acquisition systems, and labs designed to eliminate out-of-class analysis in favor of real-time hypothesis-testing. Preliminary results from the first year of implementation will be discussed.

column5: FUNctions in Motion: Connecting Mathematics and Motion
column15: Larry Dukerich, Dobson High School
column17: Adam Thompson, Richard McNamara, Robert J Culbertson
column18: Functions in Motion was one of seven modules in ?Connecting Physics, Chemistry and Math?, the 2nd of four courses developed by the MSP Project Pathways. This course was designed to help secondary math and physical science teachers come to a better understanding of what their colleagues down the hall were doing so they could collaborate more effectively. Building on what the teachers had learned in course 1 (Functions: Mathematical Tools for Science), the Functions in Motion module was not the standard treatment of kinematics. Instead, teachers examined motions that were exemplars of 3 classes of functions (linear, quadratic and sinusoidal). Special emphasis was placed on interpretation of position-time and velocity-time graphs. Teachers unfamiliar with physics were able to attach physical meaning to the coefficients and constants in the various functional fits to the data collected in class. This talk will provide an overview of the activities in the module

column5: Connecting Mathematics, Science, and Music Using Fretted Musical Instruments
column15: Robert J Culbertson, Arizona State University
column17: Adam Thompson, Larry Dukerich, Richard McNamara
column18: A three-hour activity for in-service math and science teachers was developed to demonstrate the exponential function y(x)=a*b^x in physics and sound.
