The first portion of the activity involves measuring the lengths of fretted strings on an instrument such as a guitar, banjo, or mandolin. After plotting the length vs. fret number (a monotonic decreasing function), the teachers are challenged to find an algebraic function to best describe the behavior. This is mirrored in the second portion where the teachers measure the frequency of the associated notes using LoggerPro as an oscilloscope or its FFT function, and plot the frequency vs. fret number (a monotonic increasing function).A different base, b, is found in each case, but after connecting the behavior of vibrating strings and the 12-tone tempered scale, a common numerical relationship is discovered. Results from the experiences of this module with 55 math and science teachers will also be discussed.

column5: Impact of Online Homework on Introductory Calculus-based Physics
column15: Nicole Herbots, Arizona State University
column18: The use of online homework assignments provides many advantages and some disadvantages to both students and instructors in university physics courses. The experiences with one implementation of online homework with feedback and online tutoring, Mastering Physics, used in both large lecture sections (100-200) students of physics for engineering majors and in small sections (24 students) for physics majors will be reported. In addition to greatly reduced grading time and immediate feedback and hints to the students, the online system can provide feedback to the instructor on which specifc content areas need more attention and which do require less instruction. The instructor can tailor each course accordingly and address these areas in the next class meeting and follow up with online assessment. Results of pre and post inventories, such as the Force Concept Inventory (FCI) and the Concept Survey of Electricity and Magnetism, will also be reported.

column5: Incorporating Mathematical Covariational Reasoning into Introductory Physics
column15: Adam Thompson, Arizona State University
column18: Studies of covariational reasoning on student proficiency in mathematics have shown that students who apply covariational reasoning become more proficient in algebra and are better prepared for calculus. As a consequence, covariational reasoning is used as the framework for Project Pathways where a coherent set of four courses in mathematics, science, and engineering for in-service math and science teachers is being developped. In this case, covariational reasoning is applied to introductory college physics to study similar effects on student understanding of physics, even in contexts where mathematics is only lightly touched. Results from Project Pathways and results from a study involving approximately 50 students in a Conceptual Physics course will be presented.

column5: Conceptual Priming in Multiple Choice Questions
column15: Jing Wang, The Ohio State University
column18: Our previous research shows that students' knowledge is highly context dependent and fails to transfer to novel situations. We hypothesize that the activation of students' deeper layer knowledge may have an effect on student applications of their basic concepts in varying contexts. We carried out a study to test the hypothesis with multiple choice instruments. wo types of questions are created: one is designed to test students applications of basic concepts and the other to trigger thinking about the deeper layer of knowledge underlying the basic concepts. By altering the order of the two types of questions in a test, we observed significant difference between student responses to questions of familiar and novel context features. We will discuss the results and the implications of applying the method in research and assessment.

column5: Enhancing Early Science Instruction with Physics Songs
column15: Stephen J Van Hook, Bowling Green State University
column18: We will share the results of research in the use of physics songs in conjunction with inquiry-based teaching for young children in a collaboration among a university physicist, a university education professor, and elementary teachers. Topics for the songs include air, energy, electricity, and magnetism. These results have implications for how university faculty teach future and in-service teachers of science how to teach science to K-12 students.

column5: Comparing Charge to Mass Ratio Equipment
column15: Stephen Luzader, Forstburg State University
column18: We have used apparatus from Welch, PASCO, and Teltron to measure e/m at FSU. The Welch and PASCO equipment give very good results, while the Teltron apparatus consistently gives a relatively large error. All three are Bainbridge type setups with the electrons moving through a magnetic field produced by a pair of Helmholtz coils. In the Welch and PASCO designs, the orbits are smaller than the radius of the coils, so the electrons move in a relatively uniform magnetic field. In the Teltron design, the electron orbit is much larger than the radius of the coils, which means the electrons pass through a region where the magnetic field is nonuniform and is smaller than the value calculated using the standard equation. We?ll use numerical calculations plus measurements to determine the off-axis field between the coils and determine the expected effect on the experimental result.

column5: Transfer or Not: Depends on the Question
column15: Jing Wang, The Ohio State University
column18: In our research with conceptual multiple choice tests, we have observed that the activation of student deeper layer knowledge can impact their applications of basic concepts. In our measurement, two types of questions are created: one is designed to test students? applications of basic concepts and the other to trigger thinking about the deeper layer of knowledge underlying the basic concepts. By altering the order of the two types of questions given in a test, we observed significant difference between student responses to questions of familiar and novel context features. We reproduced the same results with both E&M; and mechanics concepts. It is suggested that the phenomenon is highly related to cognitive priming and transfer. In this presentation, we will report the results and discuss the possible mechanisms.

column5: Preparing Peer Instructors: The Enduring Legacy of a CCLI-A&I; Grant
column15: Stamatis Vokos, Seattle Pacific University
column17: Lisa Goodenough, John Lindberg, Lane Seeley
column18: The Physics Department at Seattle Pacific University has completed work on a three-year NSF CCLI-A&I; grant to adapt Tutorials in Introductory Physics(1), Activity Based Physics(2), and Real Time Physics(3) into our year-long introductory courses. Part of the challenge inherent in the effective use of these curricula at a small, private, undergraduate university is the necessity of multiple instructors. At SPU we have addressed this need by employing undergraduate Peer Instructors. We have adapted our methods of recruitment and training of Peer Instructors as our pool of available and interested students has expanded. This talk will outline the impact of our program on both introductory students and Peer Instructors, as well as ongoing successes and challenges in the Peer Instructor system. Supported in part by NSF grant # DUE-0310583 and the SPU Science Initiative.

column5: Faculty-Practitioner Collaboration: Professional Development for Pre-and In-Service Teachers
column15: Eleanor W Close, Seattle Pacific University
column18: The Physics Department at Seattle Pacific University has recently received grant support funding a master-teacher position. Lezlie Salvatore DeWater, a veteran elementary teacher, is on leave from Seattle Public Schools and is working full-time with the SPU physics faculty. This has allowed us to impact the professional development of teachers in a systemic way, through professional development courses for local middle-school teachers, professional development content workshops for elementary teachers in school districts across the state, and changes in the science methods courses for pre-service elementary and secondary teachers in certification programs at SPU. In this talk we will outline the modifications we have made to the elementary methods course at SPU (co-taught by university faculty and the resident master-teacher) in order to integrate academic requirements with experiences using locally adopted curricula and school-district supported professional development activities. In addition, we will describe professional development outreach programs with content, pedagogical, and teacher-leadership aspects.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant #ESI-0455796.

column5: Roles for Thought Experiments in Model-based Learning
column15: John J Clement, SRRI/UMass Amherst
column18: I present think-aloud case study data documenting experts generating thought experiments (TEs) spontaneously during problem solving . Depictive gestures in video tapes and other indicators provide evidence that TEs can involve mental simulations and imagery. TEs are interesting in cognitive science because of the fundamental paradox of thought experiments: ?How can findings that carry conviction result from a new experiment conducted entirely within the head?? Unfortunately, the term thought experiment has suffered from being used in multiple ways. I believe TE?s can be defined broadly as the act of making a prediction for an untested, concrete, but absent situation (the ?experiment"), and this definition appears appropriate to expressing the fundamental paradox. Used in this broad way, imagistic TEs can be seen to play a role in many kinds of plausible reasoning, including analogies, extreme cases, and running explanatory models. Implications for the importance of thought experiments in instruction are discussed.

column5: The Evolution of Students' Beliefs and Interest in Physics
column15: Katherine K Perkins, University of Colorado at Boulder
column17: Wendy K Adams, Elias Quinn, Carl Wieman
column18: Over the past 2 years, we have administered the Colorado Learning Attitudes about Science Survey [1] - a 42 statement questionnaire designed to elicit student beliefs about physics - to thousands of students in our undergraduate courses. In this paper, we examine how students beliefs about physics and their stated interest in physics evolve as they progress through the undergraduate sequence. Previous findings have shown that students who choose to major in physics have more expert-like beliefs. With these data, we evaluate whether the process of choosing to major in physics looks more like selection or evolution. That is, we evaluate to what extent these students enter first term physics with more expert-like beliefs and higher interest, versus develop more expert-like beliefs and greater interest during their coursework.

column5: Using Formative Assessment Data to Improve Teacher Effectiveness
column15: Lezlie S DeWater, Seattle Pacific University
column17: Stamatis Vokos, Pamela Kraus, Jim Minstrell
column18: The Department of Physics and School of Education at Seattle Pacific University, together with FACET Innovations, LLC, in partnership with school districts in Washington State, recently received a five-year TPC grant. We are working to identify and categorize widespread productive and unproductive modes of reasoning employed by both pre-college students and teachers on foundational topics in physical science. The first phase of research is focused on obtaining pre- and post-instruction student data to establish benchmarks in student learning under existing instructional conditions. Future work will include development, implementation, and evaluation of web-based diagnostic tools that provide detailed, real-time, facet-based formative assessment to teachers (and teacher educators) to guide further instruction. This talk will describe the program and provide some preliminary research results. We will also describe connected efforts to better align middle school and high school curricula in properties of matter, heat and temperature, and physical and chemical changes, in order to support instructional improvement.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant #ESI-0455796.

column5: Assessing the Effectiveness of Interactive Computer Simulations in Teaching Physics
column15: Katherine K Perkins, University of Colorado at Boulder
column17: Wendy K Adams, Christopher Keller, Noah D Finkelstein, Carl E Wieman
column18: The Physics Education Technology (PhET) Project [1,2,3] develops and tests interactive simulations for teaching and learning physics. These simulations create an animated, interactive, game-like environment that is designed to engage the students in active thinking, to encourage experimentation, and to help develop visual and conceptual models of physical phenomena with an emphasis on the connection to everyday life. Here we present our work assessing the effectiveness of these simulations as learning tools, working with a broad range of students and in a variety of contexts, including lecture, labs, tutorials, and homework and pre-class assignments. We demonstrate that under the appropriate conditions students learn more than with traditional approaches and activities[4], and document that these simulations support the development of positive student attitudes, interest, and beliefs about the nature of learning physics. We discuss the development of a set of research-based guidelines on design features and characteristics of the simulations that make them productive tools.

column5: Theoretical Analysis of Models and Methods for Quantitative Assessment
column15: Lei Bao, The Ohio State University Physics Department
column18: Measurement of student knowledge and change of knowledge are the prime focus of education assessment. A quantitative measurement result is the outcome of many complicated and often entangled processes affected by a wide range of internal and external factors. Data interpretation is a challenging task. During the last century, many theories and methods have been developed to comprehend test data. Examples include the classical test theory, the Rasch model, item response theory and many operational methods such as the normalized gain. Statistical and computational features of these methods have been well studied and lead to widely accepted applications in both research and education assessment. However, fundamental mechanisms about why and how these methods work are much less understood. In this talk, a theoretical model is proposed and used to compare and interpret the features of the existing data analysis methods.

column5: Presenting Physics Education Resources to the Public Through ComPADRE
column15: Bruce A Mason, Univ. of Oklahoma
column18: The ComPADRE Digital Library for Physics and Astronomy serves the needs of different communities for educational resources. This project provides online resource collections, communication tools, and review processes that allow users to share and discuss high quality educational materials. One ComPADRE collection, Physics-to-Go, is focused on informal educational experiences and resources for the general public. This talk will explore the resources available and the editorial decisions made in the selection and presentation of the materials in this collection. Time in the talk will also be spent highlighting some of the best resources, exploring connections to other ComPADRE collections, and discussing future goals for Physics-to-Go and the rest of ComPADRE.
column19: Supported in part by the NSF grants DUE-0532798 and DUE-0226192.

column5: A Switch Effect in Concept Test Questions
column15: Lei Bao, The Ohio State University Physics Department
column18: In a multiple choice concept test, the features and orders of the questions can have significant impact on student responses. Built on the existing research, we are able to create a switch effect that by varying certain context variables of equivalent questions the order in which these questions are given can lead to significantly different response patterns. Combining the contextual variables and the underlying conceptual knowledge of the test questions, we can design specific switch-pair questions to measure the level of context dependency of students' knowledge, which can be further used to evaluate the transferability of such knowledge across contexts with varying similarity.

column5: New Developments in the PhET Interactive Simulations
column15: Katherine Perkins,
column17: Sarah McKagan, Wendy Adams, Michael Dubson, Danielle Harlow, Linda Koch, Patricia Loeblein,, Carl Wieman, and the rest of the PhET Team
column18: The Physics Education Technology project (PhET) develops and tests the effectiveness of sophisticated online interactive simulations for teaching physics.[1,2] We will report on new developments during the past year. Among these developments are the creation of more than ten new simulations on a variety of topics including: energy conservation and skateboarding; a number of topics in modern physics and introductory quantum mechanics; and equilibrium in solutions and basic chemical reactions. A number of other simulations have been updated and improved, including making most simulations now ?Mac-friendly?. We have also added a searchable database of simulation based activities to which users can contribute. A high school teacher has joined the PhET project, and has developed, tested, and saved in the database an extensive suite of PhET-based activities suitable for a variety of grade levels. All simulations are free and available at the PhET website. (http://phet.colorado.edu)

column5: Switch Effect in Concept Test: Designs and Applications
column15: Lei Bao, The Ohio State University Physics Department
column18: Built on the existing research, we are able to create a switch effect that by varying certain context variables of equivalent questions the order in which these questions are given can lead to significantly different response patterns. Combining the contextual variables and the underlying conceptual knowledge of the test questions, we can design specific switch-pair questions to measure the level of context dependency of students? knowledge, which can be further used to evaluate the transferability of such knowledge across contexts with varying similarity. In the poster, we will introduce question design for creating the switch effect and present examples and data analysis methods and results. We will also discuss the applications of this method in research and education testing.

column5: The History of the Measurement of the Muon Lifetime
column15: Frank L Wolfs, University of Rochester
column18: The study of cosmic-ray muons has played an important role in the upper-level undergraduate physics laboratory since the historic measurement 65 years ago of the muon flux on top of Mount Washington by Rossi and Hall. Of particular interest have been the measurements of the muon lifetime. During the last 65 years, the setups used in our laboratories to study muons and measure their lifetime have undergone dramatic changes; from measurements based on taking pictures of oscilloscope traces to those that capture and digitize the entire waveform of the muons as they pass and stop in the detector. In this presentation we will review the history of the muon lifetime experiment, and discuss our recent work on improving this classic experiment, using digital signal processing. This new approach provides the students not only with a measurement of the muon lifetime but also a direct measurement of the muon/decay energy spectra.
column19: Supported in part by the NSF (PHY-0242483).

column5: Data Modeling of Results from the Lunar Phase Concept Inventory
column15: Lei Bao, The Ohio State University Physics Department
column18: Understanding lunar phases involves a variety of concepts and knowledge ranging from perceptual features via observations to embedded geometrical relations and dynamics. Our analysis of student pre and post instruction performance on the Lunar Phase Concept Inventory suggests that the development towards a correct understanding may proceed through one of many possible pathways, and that students often exist in a wide range of intermediate knowledge states. It is then important to identify common (if any) trajectories of student conceptual development processes and possible hierarchical structures that underlie the knowledge development. Such information can help instructors and researchers to devise more optimal approaches to enhance learning. In this presentation, we introduce a set of data analysis tools that can search through large quantitative data to look for structures consistent with researchers' hypotheses and models. We will discuss the results and implications for using such tools in research and assessment.

column5: A Mixed-Method Approach to Discovering Conceptual Learning Hierarchies
column15: Rebecca L Lindell
column18: The main focus of this research is to empirically investigate if conceptual learning hierarchies (CLH?s) exist, such that certain portions of the schema (knowledge) must be mastered prior to the accommodation of new schema (knowledge). To determine if there does exist CLH?s, the researchers have employed a mixed-method approach to triangulate the data. In this presentation, we will present a short overview of the general qualitative and quantitative methods that have been developed, as well as an example from our investigation of the concept of lunar phases. If the results and methodologies developed in this research can be extended to other concepts, the existence of such hierarchies would have a profound effect on how we teach difficult concepts, not only for physics and astronomy, but also for other areas in math, engineering and science.

column5: Elucidation of Basic Optics: Expanding on Original Uses of the Eye Model
column15: Nancy Beverly, Mercy College
column18: The water-filled human eye model lends itself to additional basic optics learning activities beyond those for which it was originally designed. Student interest is high, because the basic optics are seen in a human context. These activities will be demonstrated on-site with the eye models.

column5: Redefining Graduate Education: A Specialized Approach
column15: Rebecca L Lindell
column18: The face of graduate education in physics is changing for Masters-only institutions. Enrollments at many of these institutions have decreased immensely over last few years. To help rectify this problem, SIUE has redesigned its MS in Physics to offer three areas of specialization: Photonics and Optics; Computational/ Condensed Matter; and Physics and Astronomy Education Research. These options were designed to be appealing to individuals not seeking to eventually obtain a PhD in Physics and are marketed as such. In this poster, we will discuss our new program, as well as the successes and failures we have experienced in the two years since its implementation. One member from each specialization will be present at the poster to answer specific questions.

column5: Interface Design Guidelines: A Study of Student Learning
column15: Wendy K Adams, University of Colorado, Boulder
column17: Sam Reid, Ron LeMaster, Kathy K Perkins, Noah Podolefsky, Carl E Wieman
column18: The Physics Education Technology (PhET) project is an ongoing project that has developed over 50 simulations for use in teaching physics, chemistry and physical science. During the development of these simulations, numerous student interviews were conducted in which students worked with simulations. These interviews have been a rich source of information about how students interact with computer simulations and in turn what makes an effective simulation. We will present a summary of findings from interviews of what students are thinking and learning when playing with these simulations and the guidelines for developing simulations based on them. Specifically we describe the layout, tool use, help, representations and the usefulness of guiding questions used to engage students in ?learning mode?.

column5: Validation Studies of the Colorado Physics Problem Solving Survey
column15: Wendy K Adams, University of Colorado, Boulder
column18: Researchers have created several tools for evaluating conceptual understanding as well as students? attitudes and beliefs about physics; however, the field of problem solving is sorely lacking a broad use evaluation tool. This missing tool is an indication of the complexity of the field. The most obvious and largest hurdle to evaluating physics problem solving skills is the physics content knowledge necessary to solve problems. We are tackling this problem by looking for the physics problem solving skills that are useful in other disciplines as well as physics. We will report on the results of a series of double-blind interviews comparing physics students? skills when solving physics problems with the results of the Colorado Physics Problem Solving Survey.

column5: Biomechanics Projects to Enable Mechanics Understanding
column15: Nancy Beverly, Mercy College
column18: A sampling of student projects in the guided investigation of the biomechanics of human motion will be presented. Each student chose a body movement of a sport or physical activity of individual interest to them. Part of each project involved analysis of measurements that students took of their own bodies, both whole body and limb dynamics, to relate their changes of motion to forces and torques.

column5: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly: A First-Year Teacher's Modeling Journey
column15: Farley V Ferrante, North Broward Preparatory School
column18: The Modeling Method of High School Physics Instruction originally developed at Arizona State University employs a structured inquiry approach with minimal lecturing. After participating in a three-week workshop last summer hosted by the Center for High Energy Physics Research and Education Outreach (CHEPREO) at Florida International University, I implemented modeling in three sections of honors physics at North Broward Preparatory Schools. I had the advantage of already having most of the computer-based laboratory equipment, mainly the Vernier Lab Pro and its associated probes and sensors, recommended for modeling. I also supplemented the modeling labs and activities with additional labs from the Physics with Computers manual[1]. The results of my assessments and experiences as a first-year modeler will be discussed including the continuing challenge of guiding students to value the constructivist approach and understand that they are in fact learning even though I am not ?teaching.?

column5: Student Thinking Regarding Entropy and the Second Law of Thermodynamics
column15: Warren M Christensen, Iowa State University
column18: In our ongoing investigation into student understanding of thermal physics in an introductory calculus-based course, we continue to probe student ideas regarding entropy and the second law of thermodynamics. Nearly 90% of students enrolled in the class have had previous exposure to thermodynamics concepts in chemistry and/or high school physics courses, so many have specific ideas about these concepts before instruction begins. We will present free-response and multiple-choice data collected both pre- and post-instruction from the previous four semesters. Evidence suggests that with some key concepts, e.g., that the entropy of the universe increases for all non-ideal processes, modified instruction with research-based materials may have yielded significant learning gains. However, many student ideas remain resistant to change despite the modified instruction.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grants DUE-#9981140 and PHY-#0406724.

column5: Impact of Concentrated In-Service Elementary Force and Motion Workshops
column15: David N Nelson
column18: Many elementary teachers are not properly prepared to handle basic concepts in force and motion, which are part of many state and national elementary science standards. Professional development options to address these deficiencies range from multi-week courses to short courses or workshops. To study the impact of a concentrated workshop on elementary teacher conceptual understanding and self-efficacy, we developed and facilitated a one-week, inquiry-based force and motion workshop with an explicit epistemological component. We used the Force and Motion Conceptual Evaluation (FMCE) to gauge conceptual understanding, and the Maryland Physics Expectations Survey (MPEX) and Science Teaching Efficacy Belief Instrument (STEBI) to evaluate teacher attitudes, beliefs, and expectations about teaching and learning physics. Data show the workshop produced fairly strong affective and self-efficacy gains across the board, but only conceptually localized content gains. We discuss the results and implications for expectations of short professional development activities.

column5: The Ballistic Pendulum: An Alternative Approach
column15: Abdelkrim Boukahil
column18: In this work we present an alternative approach in the study of the ballistic pendulum and projectile motion. The standard approach uses conservation of linear momentum to calculate the magnitude of the muzzle velocity of the spring gun. The result is then used to predict the range of the projectile. In our approach we use the law conservation of angular momentum to calculate the magnitude of the muzzle velocity. The results obtained are more accurate than those of the standard approach.

column5: City-City Correlations as an Introduction to Galaxy-Galaxy Correlations
column15: Daniel M Smith, Jr., South Carolina State University
column18: The Large Scale Structure (LSS) of the universe is commonly characterized by the two-point galaxy-galaxy correlation function. But the meaning of the correlation function is somewhat abstract for typical undergraduates. A lab has been developed that enables students to find the 2-dimensional, two-point city-city correlation function for populous regions of the United States. The favorable correspondence between this function and a student?s intuition enables the student to develop a clearer idea of the meaning of the correlation function in 3-dimensions for galaxies. By analyzing Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) data, the student will discover that the two correlation function graphs are quite similar.

column5: Modeling Causal Agency in Circuits and Electromagnetics
column15: Melvin S Steinberg, Smith College
column18: This poster will describe how CASTLE instruction exploits discrepant bulb lighting and visualizable analogies to foster four sequential model-building revisions that introduce increasingly abstract and complex causal agents. These stepwise tactics help students transfer analog imagery into electrical contexts and run mental simulations to evaluate new hypotheses or solve novel problems. (1) Bulb lighting during capacitor charging identifies "electric pressure" in compressed/depleted charge in conductors as a prototype concrete conception of electric potential. (2) A neon bulb lit by uncharged metal plates near a charged insulator identifies "potential electric pressure" (= electric potential) in empty space around the charge on the insulator. (3) Sparking in air when +/- plates are closer and equipotentials are more crowded identifies "electric field," a directed causal agent that pushes +/- parts of atoms in opposite directions. (4) Bi-vector "electromagnetic field" is identified with assistance of magnets, compass, coaxial coils, bi-color LEDs and AM radio.

column5: Seeing What Works: An Empirical Approach to PER
column15: John R Thompson
column18: My research objective is to determine those concepts within a specific topic that students find challenging, by probing both what they do and do not understand and the extent to which they can apply what they know or have been taught. This characterization of the interfaces between correct, incomplete, and flawed understanding serves to identify productive starting points for developing curricular materials that lead to more effective instruction. My goals are to improve student learning in specific contexts and to provide students with the tools to generalize and apply their ideas appropriately. While results are inherently context-specific, a sufficiently large research base eventually allows (a) inferences about what students are thinking based on patterns of responses and (b) generalization of results from several contexts to generate broader principles of learning and teaching, and even to predict what kinds of difficulties might occur in new contexts.

column5: Interpreting FCI Normlized Gain, Pre-instruction Scores, and Scientific Reasoning Ability
column15: Priscilla M Pamela, Florida International University
column17: Jeffery M Saul, Laird Kramer, George O'Brian
column18: In Coletta and Philips recent article [1], they found a significant, positive correlation between normalized FCI gains and preinstruction scores for classes using PER-based curricula. This seems to contradict Hake's finding [2] of no correlation between normalized gain and preinstruction scores. However, similar results have been previously recorded in studies of studio classes. [3]. They also found a strong correlation between normalized gain and results from Lawson's test of scientific reasoning [4]. In this paper, we plan to discuss the results of trying to reproduce these results using the CHEPREO project's database of pre-post diagnostics from classes using PER-based curricula at over 12 undergraduate institutions and recent results from traditional and ASU-style Modeling classes at FIU. Our hypothesis is that the correlation between normalized gain and preinstruction scores is due to the nature of PER-based instruction and not an artifact of the test or the measure of normalized gain. Work supported by NSF Award #0312038

column5: Reinforcing Classroom Concepts with "Science Movie Night"
column15: Kristi D Concannon, King's College
column18: ?Science Movie Night? encourages students to view the contents of their introductory physics or astronomy course in light of recent popular films like ?The Core?, ?The Abyss?, and ?Armageddon?. The event occurs every few weeks and is attended primarily by students in General Physics and Introductory Astronomy. Before the film, students are told the premise of the movie and asked to construct a short list of science principles to look out for. Afterwards, the students lead a discussion of the ?good? and ?bad? use of science in the film, and students from both courses benefit from the knowledge, comments and questions of their peers. Especially useful scenes are followed up in class with quick calculations or further instructor-led discussion.

column5: Toward a Model of Inconsistencies in Student Responses
column15: Stephen R Stonebraker
column18: Previous research has established that students will often answer similar multiple choice questions in different ways depending on the contextual cues present. We have observed similar inconsistencies in show work problems, both from problem to problem and even within single problems. We are attempting to develop a model of this phenomenon that can apply to a wide range of questions, from narrowly-targeted conceptual multiple choice questions to complex, integrative written problems. We hypothesize that because different types of knowledge (procedural, schematic, etc.) are relevant for different types of questions, inconsistencies in any particular students' answers may be observarble in some types of questions but not others. Such observations may even allow us to draw inferences about the order in which students' different types of knowledge develop.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grants REC-0087788 and REC-0126070.

column5: Case Studies of Inconsistencies in Student Problem Solving
column15: Stephen R Stonebraker
column18: Previous research has established that students will often answer similar multiple choice questions in different ways depending on the contextual cues present. [1] We have observed similar inconsistencies in show work problems, both from problem to problem and even within single problems. In this poster we show examples and discuss a possible mechanism for explaining the inconsistencies.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grants REC-0087788 and REC-0126070.

column5: Trials and Tribulations of Building the CHEPREO Physics learning Community
column15: Laird M Kramer, Florida International University
column18: The Center for High-Energy Physics Research Education and Outreach (CHEPREO) is an NSF-supported project that is building a learning, teaching, and research community which includes high school students and teachers, undergraduate and graduate students, and university faculty incorporating physics modeling instruction, QuarkNet, and Treisman-based study groups. One of our main goals is to build a community of support for teachers who have participated in our summer modeling workshops to help them implement modeling in their classrooms. This talk will discuss our recent efforts including what has worked and the changes we plan to strengthen our program in the coming year. Work supported by NSF Award #0312038

column5: Doing Things Differently: Lessons Learned from a Curriculum Adaptation
column15: Charles J De Leone, California State Univ. San Marcos
column18: The physics department at California State University San Marcos has nearly completed work on an NSF CCLI-A&I; funded project to adapt and implement UC Davis? reformed introductory physics course for students in the biological sciences. The course is very non-traditional in its content, format, and in its requirements of students and instructors. This talk reports on this implementation, including a discussion of structural barriers to reform, instructor preparation issues, and student resistance to novel active-learning based curriculum, along with a discussion of the effect on student attitudes and achievement. More specifically this talk will attempt to discuss some of the lessons learned during this implementation with an eye toward informing others who are considering adapting a non-traditional introductory physics course.
column19: Supported in part by NSF grant #DUE-0410991.

column5: Evaluation and Assessment of Education Outreach in the CHEPREO Project
column15: Jeffery M Saul, Florida International University
column18: The Center for High-Energy Physics Research Education and Outreach (CHEPREO) is an NSF-supported project that is building a learning, teaching, and research community which includes high school students and teachers, undergraduate and graduate students, and university faculty incorporating Arizona State Univeristy-style physics modeling instruction, QuarkNet, and Treisman-based study groups. The project is using an outcome-based approach to achieve its objectives including buidling the community of scholars as describe above. This talk will discuss results from our evaluation of modeling implementations at the high school and undergraduate level to date and our plans to improve both the implementation of the project and its evaluation in the coming year. Work supported by NSF Award #0312038

column5: MATLAB: A Fast Development Environment for Computational Methods
column15: Jaime R Taylor, Austin Peay State University
column18: The focus of a computational methods course in physics is computational methods not the development of programming skills. MATLAB is an ideal environment for such a focus. The MATLAB environment allows for quick implementation of computational methods that are discussed within the classroom. In this environment students are less likely to lose sight of the concepts of the computational techniques by spending too much time focusing on syntax or the many other computer programming issues that arise from working with a lower level language.

column5: A Model for University Outreach to the K-12 Community
column15: Howard Kimmel, New Jersey Institute of Technology
column18: The Center for Pre-College Programs at New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) offers initiatives and programs designed to increase educational opportunities for inner-city youngsters, and to improve the quality of education at the elementary and secondary schools in the region and the State. Students in grades 5-12 participate in a wide range of intensive pre-college courses, focusing on different specialties in engineering, science and mathematics. Engineering is used as the vehicle to involve pre-college populations in science and technology education and to motivate this population to pursue scientific and technological careers. Professional development programs provide teachers with the skills and support needed to meet and implement in their classrooms the high academic requirements demanded by the NJ Content Standards science, mathematics and technology education. In addition, we are able to assist schools to address and meet their specific needs. This presentation will describe the organization of the Center and its programs designed to meet the needs of the pre-college students, their teachers, and other stakeholders.

column5: Students' Real Beliefs About the Particle Nature of Matter
column15: Mary B Nakhleh, Purdue University
column18: Research has shown that students at all levels have a great deal of difficulty in explaining macro-level observations and data in terms of the molecular level. Our research group has begun to investigate students? understanding of the particle nature of matter from elementary school through university. This talk will present the results of several studies showing that students hold three basic concepts of matter (macro-continuous, macro-particulate, and micro-particulate). However, the proportions of students holding these ideas vary with the type of matter and the age and cultural background of the students. Teaching strategies for moving students further along this continuum will also be suggested.

column5: Effects of the Una Corda Pedal on Harmonic Structure
column15: Danielle L Castens
column18: Pianists use the una corda pedal not only to decrease the volume but also to produce a more subdued tone, which is a change in sound quality. There are two possible elements that may be affected: loudness and harmonic structure. This study seeks to determine whether sound quality is altered with the use of the una corda pedal by comparing the harmonic structures of pitches played with and without the una corda pedal. Results of this study will be presented.

column5: Accelerator Mass Spectrometry: From Tracing Oceans to Nuclear Astrophysics
column15: Ph. Collon, University of Notre Dame
column17: D. Robertson, C. Schmitt, D. Henderson, B. Shumard
column18: Accelerator Mass Spectrometry makes it possible to determine not only the mass of an ion but also to measure properties that depend on its nuclear rather than its ionic charge. This unambiguous A and Z identification enables the separation of the rare ions of interest from an isobaric background many orders of magnitude higher. This technique has lead to many applications ranging from environmental science (detection of 81Kr and 39Ar at and below the natural level in both ground- and ocean water) to nuclear astrophysics The use of the gas-filled magnet technique in conjunction with Accelerator Mass Spectrometry has made it possible to measure ever smaller isotopic ratios. Such a system is presently being set-up at the Nuclear Structure Laboratory at the University of Notre Dame. The system itself as well as a new detection system has been a project involving both graduate and undergraduate students.

column5: A Learning-Goals Model for Developing Standards-based, Middle School Science Materials
column15: Joseph Krajcik, University of Michigan
column18: The Investigating and Questioning our World through Science and Technology (IQWST) project is developing middle school science curricula using a learning goal driven design model to enable teachers with diverse knowledge and experiences to teach science effectively to students with a variety of backgrounds. IQWST aligns with national standards, is rooted in principles of project-based scientific and employs research-based practices shown to promote students? science and science literacy learning. Our learning goals driven design model includes three stages: 1) specifying learning goals, 2) materials development and 3) feedback. The learning goal stage includes two steps: 1) identifying and unpacking national standards, and 2) developing learning performances to operationalize standards. The materials development stage has four steps: 1) contextualizing the unit though a driving question, 2) identifying tasks, 3) producing an instructional sequence, and 4) creating assessments. The feedback stage includes 1) pilot testing, and 2) receiving feedback from reviewers. Pre- and post-test data demonstrate substantial achievement gains.

column5: On the Shoulders of Giants
column15: Steve D Ethen, Burnsville High School
column18: The progress and success of physics education depends upon the advances made in areas such knowledge of learning theory, use of technology, demonstrations, labs, etc. Science education and in particular physics education organizations are crucial in this development. AAPT and PTRA have been vital in the dissemination of research that brings about positive change in physics education. ?The mission of the AAPT/PTRA Program is to improve the teaching and learning of physics topics in pre-collegiate education for all teachers and students in the United States.?1 The excitement of physics and the worth of the individual learner must be made known. Students are more apt to learn when they feel they are valued and what they are learning will make a difference. 1 Handbook for AAPT/PTRA Workshop Leaders (2005 - 2006 edition)

column5: Teaching Physics Using Poetry
column15: Michael Ponnambalam
column18: These days many students see physics as a bland, boring and lifeless subject--a cold collection of inert facts, presented with unpleasant equations and scary Greek symbols. In trying to make this "physics dish" palatable (even tasty), I have employed several spices. One of them is poetry. In this presentation, several examples will be provided along this line.

column5: Force, Acceleration, Momentum and Energy During a Jump
column15: Martin Kamela, Physics Department, Elon University
column18: Students generally accept the validity of Newton's laws in static equilibrium. Dynamic examples where forces do not cancel are more challenging, and among these the case where forces are not constant present the greatest challenge. We use a motion sensor and a force plate from Vernier to test the validity of Newton's Second Law in the context of a simple jump. The motion sensor tracks approximately the center of mass position and the force plate measures the normal force supporting the jumper. The demonstration can be analyzed from the point of view of momentum and impulse. It can also be looked at from the point of view of energy where it elucidates subtleties involved with "pseudo-work" on the jumper.

column5: Warped Passages: Unraveling the Mysteries of the Universe's Hidden Dimensions
column15: Lisa Randall, Harvard University
column18: Do we inhabit a three-dimensional universe floating in a four dimensional space? What if the extra dimensions required by string theory were not curled up and unobservably small, but unfurled and vast, extending forever? Could an invisible universe only a tiny fraction of an inch apart in another dimension explain phenomena that we see today in our world? These are among the questions that we will consider in this lecture about extra dimensions of space.

column5: ?The Second Year as a Teacher-in-Residence?
column15: Nancy Stauch, California Polytechnic State University
column18: PhysTEC originally envisioned a one-year position for Teachers-in-Residence. While this was the initial model, is there an advantage to a multiple year stint as a TIR? What are the benefits for the students in a program when a familiar face returns? How does this longer term help the TIR ?hit-the-ground-running? when the learning curve is so steep? Could this lead to institutionalizing the position and even a new career path for teacher leaders? We will share some of the joys and accomplishments allowed by our second year.

column5: Beginning a National Repository of Computational Science/Physics Courses
column15: Rubin H Landau, Oregon State University
column18: Progress in establishing a national repository of university-offered, undergraduate courses and modules in computational science will be described. The repository would be a collection from various pioneering programs throughout the country, which together would cover the entire field of computational science at various levels. Once in place, other schools may adopt these courses as a way of including modern computation and multidisciplinary studies into their curricula. Converting of Computational Physics courses into the University of Wisconsin's eTeach system appropriate for distant delivery has begun. This includes 1) a video and sound frame, 2) a slide frame that automatically synchronizes with the progressing office hour, 3) a synchronized external links frame connecting to applets, course materials, and quizzes, 4) a dynamic table of contents frame that highlights the titles of the lecture topics as they change, and 5) buttons allowing the lecture to be advanced or rewound 10-30 seconds, fast forwarded, or reversed. Work supported by NSF and EPICS.

column5: Theorist in the Classroom
column15: Leaf Turner, Cornell University
column18: Despite my having studied physics at a premier science high school, I appreciated it only after taking it as a 1960 sophomore (the only time Professor Hans Bethe served as TA of an introductory physics section) to satisfy a premed requirement. I believe that savoring learning as early possible is good. Hence, I was delighted to accept an invitation to teach calculus-based physics at Los Alamos HS. I taught during my LANL lunch hours from 1985-1991. Most of my students continued on in science. Their parents were most appreciative. I shall outline my rewarding experience in this role. I shall also discuss the relationship of this role to my subsequent role as Coach and then Senior Coach of the United States Physics Team. Since coaching, I have been assisting students, first at Los Alamos HS and now at Ithaca HS, to prepare for a place on US Physics Teams.

column5: One School's Physics Results in Single Gender Classrooms
column15: Beth Marchant, University of Notre Dame
column17: Tom Loughran, Pat Mooney, Ellen Reed
column18: Students at a small Midwestern 7-12 grade private school are taught physics in gender-specific classrooms. The panelists at this session will present their experience teaching physics (as well as mathematics and chemistry) in these separate sections. Force Concept Inventory data was taken for both boys and girls sections for just two years, and this data will be presented and discussed.

column5: Looking Forward: Uncooking Student Investigations
column15: David S Abbott, Dartmouth College
column18: Over the last forty years, the findings of physics education research have been making headway into even the most conservative physics classrooms. This paradigm shift from ?teaching by telling? to ?learning through engagement? is clearly improving student learning in physics classrooms nationwide. A similar shift needs to happen with labs. Research and experience tell us that traditional labs ? ones that focus on verification of results presented in the lecture (or even in the lab handout itself!)- might help students develop facility with equipment but largely fail to help students develop higher order scientific thinking skills often associated with labwork. A variety of institutions are developing, implementing and evaluating thoughtful alternatives to these ?cookbook? exercises, both in labs and also in computer modeling environments. I will examine the shift in focus of student activity and discuss the direction of research into the effectiveness of investigative activity.

column5: Extending Learning Outside the Classroom with Podcasting
column15: Erica W Carlson, Dept. of Physics, Purdue University
column18: Podcasts allow students to listen to (or watch) lectures anywhere, at anytime. With a podcast, listeners automatically receive the most recent ?episode,? downloaded to their computer or mp3 player. We discuss the impacts of podcasting on student learning in a classroom setting, as well as the use of podcasts as an outreach tool. We also give step-by-step instructions on how to start an audio or video podcast, including recording lectures, where to host the files at no cost, how to get your podcast listed in the popular iTunes directory, and finally, how to track the subscriber level to measure the impact.

column5: Identifying and Addressing Teacher Misconceptions Regarding Solar System Scale
column15: Mary Urquhart, University of Texas Dallas
column18: Utilizing adaptations of classic scale model solar system and Earth-Moon model activities, I have repeatedly observed common misconceptions in both pre-service and in-service teacher populations. Specifically, the same errors arise repeatedly in questioning of these adult learners with respect to Earth-Moon distance and in both sizes and distances of the planets and Sun. Rather than being isolated misconceptions, this work suggests that misconceptions regarding scale in the solar system impact other common misconceptions in Astronomy. In this presentation I will discuss the nature of the observed misconceptions as well as data collection methods currently being utilized and planned for the future. Implications for instruction using scale models will be discussed.

column5: Sensitivity of the Lower Extremities to Injury
column15: Saami J Shaibani
column18: The generally non-life-threatening nature of leg injuries means that they are not studied as extensively as trauma to the head, neck and chest. However, there can still be serious disability from injury in the lower extremities even when the latter body areas are not involved. Other impediments to the complete understanding of how they leg responds to insult include its binarity and the ease with which asymmetry can occur. These challenges are addressed in this research by combining physics with trauma and engineering to identify the underlying mechanism of injury. The benefit of such an approach is illustrated here by a case in which the sole injury was fracture to the right leg. The reason for this result, and for the absence of injury everywhere else, is explained in detail. Fine variation of injury severity with impact severity is also calculated and some consequences for student learning are considered.

column5: Frontiers in Nuclear Astrophysics
column15: Hendrik Schatz, Michigan State University
column18: Nuclear Astrophysics is an active, rapidly advancing field of current research. While the question of the nuclear energy source of the sun has been essentially solved by Hans Bethe in the 30s, key questions today concern, for example, the origin of the heavy elements in nature and the nuclear reactions that trigger or power stellar explosions. Both questions are related, as one believes today that nuclear reactions occuring in the explosions of stars are responsible for the existence of heavy elements such as gold or uranium in the universe and on earth. But nothing is certain at this point, and just how and where nature creates the extreme conditions needed to forge the heavy elements, and what the actual sequence of reactions is, are open questions. Nevertheless, rapid progress is being made. Astronomical observations are making new discoveries at a rapid pace. At the same time, nuclear physics laboratories such as the NSCL at Michigan State University are now able to create some of the extremely unstable nuclei that most likely participate in the reactions creating heavy elements. While these nuclei decay within fractions of seconds, they are the progenitors of the stable nuclei found today and studying their properties in the laboratory opens the door to testing our theories of the synthesis of the elements. I will discuss some of the current open questions of the field and recent progress in astronomy and nuclear physics and relate this to the historical development of this field, in particular Hans Bethe's breakthrough contributions.

column5: Marketing Physics in High School: Reaching Out to All Students
column15: Shawn Weatherford, North Carolina State University
column18: AIP reports a trend of rising enrollment in high school senior level physics courses throughout the 90s and into this Century. Maintaining this trend through marketing physics to traditional and non-traditional students is an effective tool to increase enrollment in high school populations, regardless of student body size. Strategies and anecdotes are provided to help ensure this positive trend that are mindful of expense, student diversity, and effort. Using these strategies at Williams High School in Burlington, NC led to record-breaking enrollments in advanced physics courses and doubled the number of students taking physics.

column5: Physics Formula Recollection Through a Never Before Seen Mnemonic Technique
column15: Shannon A Schunicht, TX A&M; Univ./ M&W; inc.
column18: While in the Army, Mr. Schunicht was involved in a mid-air collision rendering him unconscious for three weeks. Everything had to be re-learned, as nursing actions were reported as having been displayed upon awakening from the extended unconsciousness (19 days). Studies in recovery brought about some pragmatic discoveries to compensate for the residual memory deficits. The most valuable discovery was having each vowel represent a mathematical sign, i.e., "a" multiplication implying "@", "o" for division implying "over," "i" for subtraction implying "minus," "u" for addition implying "plus," and "e" implying "equals." Most constants and variables are consonants, e.g., "c" = "speed of light," and "R" = "rate/time variable.

column5: Teachers-in-Residence: What does the data tell us?
column15: Paul Hickman,
column18: PhysTEC Teachers-in-Residence (TIR) are experienced classroom teachers who work at a university supporting a teacher preparation program. Who are these people, what do they do, how do they spend their time and why is the role seen as a new and powerful example of teacher leadership? We will share some insights from the data provided by our twenty-eight TIRs.

column5: Analysis of Using Multiple Active Learning Techniques over Five Years
column15: Bernard J. Brunner
column18: The author has used several active learning techniques in introductory algebra-based physics for life science students including group work, Just-in-Time Teaching and keypad response systems. The Force Concept Inventory has been administered to each class since fall 2000 to assess student gains. Normalized gains for each class and average normalized gains by grade groupings have been measured will be presented. Some grade results have been correlated with classroom attendance and participation, and will also be presented. After an initial dip in gains, an upward trend occurred as the author became better acquainted with applying the techniques. Another dip in scores followed. Possible explanations for changes will be offered.

column5: Pre- and Post Lecture Comprehension Using Multimedia
column15: George Mathew, Gateway College
column18: Our focus is on delivery of course content on the web to reflect the modern generation?s comfort and demand for technology dependent and non-dependent assistance both inside and outside of class with multimedia for both pre- and post lecture preparation. The expectation of the faculty is for students to have a better comprehension of the physics course content and allow for care of advancement to the next course level.

column5: Origins of General Relativity in Newton's Laws of Motion
column15: Munawar Karim, St, John Fisher College
column18: Key concepts of General Relativity, such as the connection between geometry and gravity are embedded in familiar equations of Newton. Since General Relativity rests on a thorough understaning of intertial frames I will discuss common phenomena where effects of inertial and non-inertial frames can be distingiushed. Classical experiments of Galileo are analyzed and re-interpreted. I cite experimental and theoretical evidence that distinguishes between gravity and acceleration. Videos of an experiments will be shown. I emphasize the connection between gravity and acceleration to the geometry of spacetime. I will demonstrate the validity of gravity as an outcome of geometry.

column5: PSSC Physics: A Personal Perspective
column15: Uri Haber-Schaim,
column18: After a brief introduction I will describe the characteristic aspects of the PSSC project in its formative years. Mentioning some of the later developments and the reasons for them, I will discuss the necessary ingredients for successful projects and compare today?s climate for innovation in science education with the climate 50 years ago.

column5: Why the Textbook Explanation of the Cat Twist Is Incomplete
column15: John R Galli, Weber State University
column18: A mechanical model of the twisting, falling cat has been designed and constructed by the author. This working model (constructed from copper tubing, springs, etc.) shows the action of the muscles on the spine of a cat. This ?mechanical cat? flips over in about one-eighth of a second, similar to a real cat, but without the need for leg or tail motion. These models will be explained and demonstrated. They will soon be commercially available. Textbook authors who are at this presentation may request a complimentary model.

column5: Preparation of Physics and Physical Science Teachers: BYU's Effort
column15: Duane B Merrell, Brigham Young University
column18: Brigham Young University is actively working to help with the recruitment and training of Physics and Physical Science Teachers to meet the needs of students and the nation. Presently at BYU there are 32 students enrolled receiving physics majors with teaching as the emphasis. In the Physics Science Composite major we have about 20 students with teaching emphasis. During the past year we have monitored 22 student teachers in the physical science. All of this work is done thru the College of Physical Science and Mathematics because of a change at BYU 2 years ago. The Physical Sciences collaborates with the College of Education but the students are trained in the College of Physical Science and Mathematic. This talk will focus on the changes BYU has made to build a strong Physical Science Teacher Training Program.

column5: Learning by Design
column15: Robert J Beichner, NC State University
column18: By starting from a set of specified goals, course reform is simplified. This talk will describe the process of creating instructional objectives at several levels, using them to redesign a curriculum and learning environment, and then taking advantage of the findings of Physics Education Research to create activities. Specific examples of selecting instructional technology and appropriate assessment methods will be highlighted.

column5: Strategies for Teaching Physics Without Extensive Use of Algebra
column15: Len Bugel, Stratton Mountain School
column18: One perceived difficulty in teaching physics first in the high school curriculum is that some freshmen will not have completed an algebra course prior to beginning physics. Strategies to deal with this problem include teaching the mathematics as needed, introducing alternatives to algebraic methods for solving problems, and tailoring problems to measure conceptual understanding rather than mathematical prowess. Examples of all three strategies in several content areas, drawn from ten years experience teaching conceptual physics to freshmen, will be presented.

column5: An Insider's Look at the PER Community
column15: Laura McCullough, University of Wisconsin-Stout
column18: A survey questionnaire was sent to members of the Physics Education Research community to gather data about why we have selected this field, our relationship with the AAPT, and other issues. The survey was also designed to elicit comments about gender issues in traditional physics and PER. In this poster I will present initial analysis results from the surveys. Findings suggest a field in transition, and distinct differences between traditional physics and PER.

column5: Guinea Pig to Author: One Woman's Journey with TPT
column15: Diane Riendeau, Deerfield High School
column18: The role TPT has played in my life has evolved over the past 24 years. This symbiotic relationship began without my knowledge in 1982. As a new teacher, I relied on TPT for new ideas for demos, labs and teaching philosophies. Now, as an author and reviewer, I have the opportunity to give back to my professional community. So what have I gained from my changing relationship with TPT? Let me show you?

column5: Coherence and beating of two atomic spectral lines: Theoretical aspects.
column15: Enrique Lopez-Moreno
column17: Marcela D. Grether, Victor M. Velazquez
column18: A tenet in classical optics is that different spectral quasi-monochromatic components add incoherently, that is, they do not interfere. This fact can be contemplated as a consequence of the time average, over a huge number of light vibrations, carried out in any process of observation by means of light detectors. We consider the superposition of light from a pair of independent laser sources, each emitting at a different wavelength from each other. We calculate the Visibility in the interference pattern for this combined wave as it enters a Michelson interferometer and experiences a continuous change in the optical-path-difference. We predict collapses and revivals in the Visibility, which we can consider as a direct consequence of a two wave frequency beating. We include a prediction for some line pairs, all from atomic neon.

column5: Coherence and beating of two atomic spectral lines: Experimental aspects.
column15: Marcela D. Grether
column18: Orange light produced by a single He-Ne laser in a simultaneous emission of the 593.9 nm and 604.6 nm, both from atomic neon, is analyzed by means of Michelson interferometry. A continuous change in the optical-path-length difference, produces collapses and revivals in the Visibility of the interference pattern. In a second arrangement, the light from a pair of independent laser sources, one emitting the red line at 632.8 nm, and the other at the green, 543.3 nm, both from atomic neon, is combined by means of a beam splitter to iluminate the same Michelson interferometer, and analized as mention above. We show some interferograms and describe the apparatus.

column5: Using Time-on-Task Measurements to Understand Introductory Physics Classes
column15: John C Stewart, Univ. of Arkansas
column18: A four year study of how students use their out-of-class time in an introductory physics class is presented. The study is used to evaluate the extent to which a student?s performance on hourly exams or on concept inventories is predictable by their study habits. The correlation of good study habits with good performance is evaluated. The study tracks student behavior through a major curricular revision to determine the extent to which student habits react to changes in a physics class.

column5: Adapting Interactive Strategies for Online Learning
column15: Tom Furtak, Colorado School of Mines
column17: Dan Lecocq, Joni Dunlap, Todd Gibson
column18: Numerous classroom strategies have been shown to maintain student interest and improve student learning in the introductory calculus-based physics course. The primary challenge for the online version is to package these teaching methods for distance delivery. We have adopted a motion picture consulting team metaphor to motivate project-based interactions for group learning. We have also developed database interaction tools that approximate peer tutoring activities during asynchronous study. These are some of the features of Physics 100 Online, a novel collection of integrated modules for distance-delivered education.
column19: Supported by the Fund for the Improvement of Post Secondary Education (FIPSE).

column5: Improving Students' Self-assessment of Numerical Analysis Projects
column15: Rebecca Lippmann Kung, Uppsala Univ.
column18: Many undergraduate physics programs teach numerical analysis to some extent, often as a laboratory or a project attached to a traditional theory course. This teaching may be motivated by a desire to have the physics curriculum mirror physics in academia and industry, to give students a marketable skill, to teach particular subjects, or a number of other goals. For the students to reach any educational goal we believe that they must be able to evaluate the quality and completeness of their project. However, it appears that students have significant trouble with self-assessment in numerical analysis ? as evidenced by the frequent 'is this right?' question. In this poster we discuss several different ways students could assess their projects, and draw on related education research and quotes from student interviews to suggest ways to increase student?s abilities in this area.

column5: The Top in My Computer
column15: James W Wheeler, Lock Haven Univ. of Pennsylvania
column18: This program makes it possible to demonstrate Euler Angles and the theoretical motion of rigid bodies so that these may be compared to observations of tops.

column5: Computational Modeling in the Upper-Division Physics Curriculum
column15: Paul R Ohmann, University of St. Thomas
column18: We have developed and implemented computational modules for several upper-division Physics classes at the University of St. Thomas. These modules address a need identified by the American Institute of Physics[1]; namely, that a majority of Physics Bachelor recipients employed in certain technical fields felt that their undergraduate preparation was lacking. Our modules address this concern by imbedding computational problems throughout the Physics curriculum, thereby providing educational experiences complementary to the analytical and laboratory techniques developed elsewhere in the curriculum. This work is supported in part by an NSF CCLI grant: #DUE-0311432.

column5: Solving Problems as in Reality or as the Teacher Thought?
column15: Goran Grimvall
column18: Students, working in pairs, are presented with five multiple-choice problems dealing with Archimedes principle. For each alternative they mark how sure they are that an alternative is correct (e.g., 70%, 20%, 10% when three alternatives). The quizzes are checked during a short break and returned with only the total number of correct answers indicated. The students are now informed that the problems should be solved as it is in reality and not as in an unrealistic idealisation. Then they are allowed to change their answers and how sure they are. It is striking that many students can still be 100% sure of an answer, which is in fact wrong when confronted with reality. This exercise is used in a class of future high-school physics teachers, to let them experience how easy it is to formulate a problem for which the teacher's assumed solution is unphysical.

column5: Constructing Learning Aids for Teaching Algebra-based Physics
column15: Valentin Voroshilov, Boston University
column18: Physics teachers sometimes demonstrate just technical approach to problem-solving, i.e., writhing down the formulae necessary to the problem and then solving the obtained system of equations. As the consequence of this approach, teachers have difficulties sometimes with helping students to understand reasons for using the formulae, which have been used. When working with teachers, we used to construct the following learning aids: - The dictionary connecting the everyday lexicon and Physics terminology. - The classification table of typical physical models matching to the situation described in the problem. - The table of the correspondents between the models and the physical quantities needed for the quantitative description of the models. - The table of the correspondence between the models and the formulae needed for the quantitative description of the models. - The schemata of logical connections between categories involved in the analysis of the physical situation described in the problem.

column5: An Incremental Approach to Computational Physics Education
column15: Kelly R Roos, Bradley University
column18: I have over the last ten years developed an ?incremental? mode of computational physics instruction wherein I interweave modern computational techniques with the more traditional aspects of my upper level classical mechanics and thermodynamics courses. My guiding philosophy in implementing this program is anchored on the belief that computational principles are best grasped when students directly program and control all aspects of their computer applications, and do not rely on the deceptive utility of the modern black box of commercial software. Thus, required learning of the fundamentals of a programming language, in addition to numerical and computational principles, is an integral part of my approach. In this talk I will describe the details of my incremental program, and discuss some of the difficulties as well as advantages inherent in this mode of working computational physics into an undergraduate physics curriculum.

column5: Evaluating Alternatives to Newton
column15: David L Morgan, Eugene Lang College
column18: In teaching introductory physics, we often treat the laws of mechanics as if they emerged fully formed from the mind of Isaac Newton without considering the near misses of his predecessors and contemporaries. In this talk, I will present an activity that asks students to examine the "laws of motion" of Christiaan Huygens and Ren Descartes to see where they agree with Newton's idea of conservation of momentum and where they fall short. This exercise is intended to expose students to some historical science texts as well as provide an interesting alternative to the usual textbook problem solving.

column5: The Fresnel Lens as a Mirror
column15: David Keeports, Mills College
column18: Thin and light, the Fresnel lenses found in overhead projectors possess the refractive properties of much heavier convex glass lenses. While designed as a lens and not as a mirror, a Fresnel lens possesses noteworthy reflective properties. It is capable of forming distinct real and virtual reflective images of objects. Hovering in space and highly convex toward the observer, the former images are especially remarkable. In this presentation, I will discuss a series of experiments I performed with lasers and a Fresnel lens. These experiments demonstrate that the concave and convex reflective focal lengths of the lens depend strongly upon the distance from the center of the lens. Geometric analysis reveals the mechanisms by which the lens forms its reflective images. Further analysis of reflections leads to an indirect determination of the index of refraction of the lens and to the conclusion that the lens I studied is more nearly parabolic than spherical.

column5: Physics of the Galapagos Volcanoes
column15: Karen S Harpp, Colgate University Dept of Geology
column18: Sierra Negra volcano in the Galapagos Islands began erupting on October 22, 2005, and continued to erupt for another 8 days. Because I have been involved in research into the origins and behavior of Galapagos volcanoes for several years, it was important to be able to observe the eruption in progress, a rare opportunity even for a volcanologist. In this presentation, I will describe the eruption, putting our observations in the context of longer term geochemical and deformation studies both of Sierra Negra and of the Galapagos Archipelago in general. In general, I will describe how fundamental physics concepts are used by volcanologists on a regular basis to understand the inner workings of volcanic systems and their eruptive behavior, and, more specifically, how integral physical concepts have been to our on-going research in the Galapagos Islands.

column5: PSSC: Legacy in the Laboratory
column15: Jim Nelson,
column18: As I look back over my career as a physics teacher, I realize that the greatest impact that the PSSC program had on me was the philosophy of the PSSC laboratory component. The laboratory approach was to present many questions, but with no blanks to fill-in, encourage students to develop their own ideas and methods, consider the experimental design, and to coordinated the laboratory activities with the textbook. The laboratory activities stressed the Nature of Physics, Importance of Measurement, and Analysis of Laboratory Data. I came to realize that the leading edge of understanding for me as well as for many of my students is rooted in experience. For students learning physics this experience very often happens in the laboratory. This session will highlight the unique aspects of the PSSC laboratory activities.

column5: Animations for Introductory Physics and Astronomy: What's New and Improved
column15: Michael R Gallis, Penn State Schuylkill
column18: This poster provides an update on the Animations for Introductory Physics and Astronomy project at Penn State Schuylkill. This project has created short animations to help students picture dynamical systems and processes for physics and astronomy topics typically presented in the advanced high school through introductory college level. In this poster a selection of the more recent animations that have been created for this project will be described. Some of the novel uses of animations (such as "What's Wrong with this Picture" video analysis using animations as artificial video) will be presented. Finally a pilot assessment of the impact of the animations on student learning gains will be discussed. The growing collection of (primarily 3-D) animations can be found at http://phys23p.sl.psu.edu/phys_anim/Phys_anim.htm

column5: PSSC: A Student Perspective
column15: Jane Nelson,
column18: Kids today can't image a world without computers, cell phones, and digital everything. So it is for me and physics education without PSSC Physics. I was raised on it. I didn?t realize there had been a time before PSSC until I was a college graduate and teaching physics myself. This session will recall some my experience with PSSC as a studnet.

column5: Getting Involved in the AAPT/PTRA Project
column15: Jim Nelson,
column17: George Amann, Jan Mader, Karen Jo Matsler, Warren Hein
column18: Appropriate for college/university professors and high school teachers. This poster will describe the features of the AAPT/PTRA professional development project for middle school and high school teachers. The poster will highlight the history, achievements, and potential of the AAPT/PTRA project. Learn how you can become involved either as a PTRA participant or as a college/university host institution.

column5: Another Paradox of the Twins
column15: Robert H Balogh-Robinson
