column18: One of the most frequently used examples in Modern Physics is the Twin Paradox, wherein one twin travels to a distant planet at a high speed and the other twin remains at home. The traveling twin returns to find everyone has aged a good deal more, demonstrating the relative nature of time. Calculations are done to show the differing passage of time. A false paradox is then created in order to emphasize the correct use of proper length and proper time. However, many texts, books for lay readers, and websites purporting to describe relativity incorrectly identify the ?resolution? of the ?paradox? by inserting acceleration into the problem. Frequently doing so in a way that is condescending to the lowly reader, while being wildly off the mark and internally inconsistent. This talk will present a quick review of the problem, solution, correct resolution and the incorrect resolutions permeating literature.

column2: New Technologies for Teaching and Learning
column5: From Statistics to Logistics: A Foray into Inquiry in Physics
column15: Elizabeth R Stoddard
column18: Dr. Stoddard will present her own case study of the development, implementation, and impact of an inquiry-based version of a 100-level conceptual physics course. This presentation will address in-coming student attitudes toward new pedagogy, materials management, workload, and other daunting issues professors must take into account when considering implementing inquiry methods in higher education physics courses. The lesson design for this course utilized two primary pedagogical tools, the Learning Cycle and Concept Mapping, which are motivated by research and will be briefly introduced. Sample lessons and materials kits will be presented, and good, bad, and surprising aspects of each will be analyzed with the benefit of hindsight. Student outcome data will be compared to the control, standard lecture and peer instruction format by the same professor.

column5: Pedagogical Models Used in Physics Teacher Preparation at Illinois State
column15: Carl J Wenning, Illinois State University
column18: The value of a model rests in its ability to usefully organize information. The Physics Teacher Education program at Illinois State University (ISU) has developed, deployed, and refined several pedagogical models for overcoming important improvement-of-practice problems associated with high school physics teaching. The presenter will very briefly describe models dealing with levels of inquiry teaching, overcoming teacher and student resistance to inquiry-based instruction, teaching about the nature of science, and achieving student academic success. The presenter will also describe how ISU prepares its physics teacher candidates to deal effectively with the realities of today?s increasingly diverse classroom populations through the use of a pre-student-teaching Social Context Project. All models have been completely described in Journal of Physics Teacher Education Online. Interested individuals are directed to the JPTEO Web site* for details.

column5: Illinois Physics Teacher Pipeline Project
column15: Carl J Wenning, Illinois State University
column18: Within the next decade, a large percentage of Illinois' most capable high school physics teachers will retire or otherwise leave the teaching profession. As a result, the State is facing a long-term and growing shortage of highly qualified secondary-level physics teachers. Starting with a $500 grant from the AAPT in 2004, the Illinois Section began an effort to identify and resolve problems associated with the recruitment and preparation of high school physics teacher candidates. The section now conducts an annual survey of PTE programs, and holds semi-annual discussions to propose, analyze, select, and implement solutions to identified problems. To date, the section has held several focus group discussions, established a physics teacher candidate recruitment Web page, and developed recruitment materials that are geared toward increasing the number of physics teacher candidates in physics teacher preparation programs statewide.

column5: Interaction of a Permanent Magnet and a Moving Non-ferromagnetic Conductor
column15: Xiao Xie, Hunan University
column17: Ping Ping Gu, Zhu Ying Wang, Jian Zhi Jian, Zhong Xie
column18: The interaction between the permanent magnet and the moving conductor is analyzed elaborately, and a novel non-ferromagnetic moving conductor drives the magnet to rotate is invented. From the molecular current viewpoint, an analytic expression exactly describing the magnetic field distributing of a rectangular permanent magnet is derived from the Biot-Savart?s law and compared with measuring values. And the force on the permanent magnet is calculated quantitatively when the conductor is moving five millimeter under the permanent magnet.In all of the text books, the description about the behavior of the non-ferromagnetic metal moving in magnetic field is not completed. Only the magnetic damping effect is depicted. Our result improved the physics picture that the metal not only experience the magnetic damping force, but also a moment around the symmetric axle of the moving metal plate that is vertical to the moving direction. Finally the mistake in the principle explanation on the magnetic levitation experimental apparatus of PASCO Company is pointed out.

column5: Using a Camera to Measure Location and Size of Objects
column15: Robert O Dell, Mohawk Valley Community College
column18: Several methods will be presented for extracting subject distance and/or size information from orthographic and oblique view photographs. The techniques are based upon basic optical principles, careful observation and measurement, and an understanding of perspective. These methods have been used successfully by the author in a variety of physics classes ranging from conceptual level to trigonometry-based general physics level. They provide an interesting enrichment topic for the optics portion of physics courses. Students find the "measuring with your camera" concepts interesting, since they provide insight into the techniques they see being used on the widely popular crime scene investigation based TV shows.

column5: Use of Haikus in Introductory Astronomy
column15: Shannon D Willoughby, Montana State Univ. - Bozeman
column18: In class writing activities can be used to help students learn material by allowing them to put ideas into their own words. To this end, I have employed the use of haiku writing in an Astronomy 101 course in both the fall and spring semesters of the 2005 school year. Writing short poems about the tides, the moon and eclipses gives students the opportunity to synthesize the lecture material. Because this form of poetry is by definition quite succinct, students must be creative in their choice of language in order to fully express their ideas within the constraints of the haiku form. Some haikus beautifully demonstrate their understanding while other examples show difficulties in comprehension. Also misconceptions that have persisted after opposing material has been presented can be gleaned from these haikus as well. Examples of haikus written by students will be presented and discussed.

column5: Three or Four Golden Rules of Lecturing
column15: Michael A Dubson, Univ. of Colorado at Boulder
column18: Over the last 10 years, the way we teach freshmen and sophomore physics at the University of Colorado at Boulder has evolved away from traditional instruction toward a format full of interactive engagment concept tests and peer instruction, online homeowrk, Washington Tutorials, interactive computer simulations, and exams which emphasize qualitative reasoning. Student morale has improved and we have seen dramatic learning gains as measured by standard exams. Our main strategy is the Zeroth Goldn Rule of Lecture: Reinvent Nothing. We let our esteemed colleagues of other institutions do the hard work, and then we import their successful techniques. The key to sustainable course reform is to provide over worked faculty with well-developed tools and then wait. The remaining Golden Rules of Lecture will be revealed. As with any good lecture, there will be lots of audience participation and demonstrations. An electronic "clicker" system will be used to collect audience feedback.

column5: Implementing Socratic Tutorials using Laptops in General Physics Conference Sections*
column15: Steven K Wonnell, Johns Hopkins Univ.
column17: Richard Shingles, Theron Feist, Morris Swartz
column18: We report the results of a pilot study in which students, two to a laptop, worked on problems posed by "Interactive Examples" during the conference sections that accompany a large, calculus-based general physics course. Sections were facilitated by TAs. To measure the effectiveness of this approach, we conducted a series of participant perception surveys each tailored to the specific subject matter topic under study by the undergraduates. We also interviewed the students, teaching assistants, and the course professor. The results include increased student attendance of conference sections, increased engagement with basic physics concepts and problem solving strategies; and a more uniform learning experience among the conference sections, all relative to traditionally-taught sections.
column19: This work has been supported in part by the HP Technology for Teaching Grant Initiative. Interactive Examples is described at http://research.physics.uiuc.edu/PER/ie.html

column5: Temperature Dependence of Breathing and G-Mode Phonons in Carbon Nanotubes
column15: Richard E Bergstrom Jr., Rowan Univ.
column18: We use Raman Spectroscopy to study optical (G-Mode) phonons in isolated suspended single walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs). This experiment is being performed to explain the large increase in resistance at high voltages of SWNTs by determining the temperature of the optical phonon mode. We use Raman Spectroscopy to obtain the temperature of each phonon mode by using the ratio of Anti-Stokes to Stokes lines. Research in this area will assist in understanding conductivity of nanotubes and will also help us to investigate heat transfer between nanotubes.

column5: Alternative Energy Projects for Service Learning in Science
column15: Barbara L Whitten, Physics Dept. Colorado Coll.
column18: Service learning is an effective tool in the social sciences for teaching students to apply knowledge to ?real world? problems. Fewer people have applied these techniques in the sciences. We are implementing service learning projects involving alternative energy and conservation in courses in Physics, Chemistry, and Environmental Science. In the Energy Retrofit Project, students study the physics of convective, radiative, and conductive heat transfer and analyze a home near campus to determine the most cost-efficient way to reduce energy bills. We visit the home and install the changes we have proposed. Students learn to apply their scientific knowledge to practical problems and gain additional analytical and experimental skills. Non profit organizations, poor residents, and the community of Colorado Springs benefits from a more efficient energy system. We will describe how we organize these projects, how we integrate them into a science course, and what we believe students gain from participation.

column5: Physics for Everyone: Designing Inclusive Physics Problems
column15: Barbara L. Whitten, Physics Dept., Colorado Coll.
column17: Sarah K Matthews, Shannon R. Dorato, Suzanne F. Porter, Jessica A Rivas
column18: Recently several innovative alternatives to the standard introductory physics course have been developed, with the goal of making physics more attractive to a broader range of students. Traditional physics problems appeal to traditional physics students, but may reinforce the opinion of women and students of color that physics is not for them. Sue Rosser suggests that science courses should try to incorporate and validate personal experiences that students are likely to have had. Emphasizing the applications of physics to social and environmental problems may broaden the appeal of introductory physics to non-traditional students. In this project we are designing problems that test the concepts of introductory physics, in a variety of contexts that will appeal to less traditional physics students, and illustrate the wide applicability of the principles of physics. We?ll describe our guidelines and give examples of our problems.

column5: Planning for Success in a Middle School Physics Competition
column15: Hui-Yiing Chang, Texas State Univ.
column18: The Society of Physics Students at Texas State University had been assisting a group of 6th graders from a local public school in their preparation for a science competition that included many schools from the Austin area. They tied second place with another group! This is a presentation of the process of preparation that is believed to have contributed to their success. The students were encouraged to make social connections in their model, such as its significance in their lives, and relations to personal experience. The girls were as actively involved as the boys, which generated excitement. The first drafts were evaluated and the reasons for success and failure explained. The physical concepts were taught after they had learned experientially. These concepts were reviewed during subsequent sessions when they were allowed more trials. The students were encouraged to use ?big words?, high-technology equipment and artistry in their final presentation posters.

column5: Does Physics Instruction produce Cognitive Enhancement
column15: John M Clement,
column18: There is evidence that the thinking level as measured by the Lawson Classroom Test of Scientific Reasoning correlates strongly with gain on the FCI. But does physics instruction produce an improvement in reasoning (cognitive enhancement)? So far there are two methods that do this, Thinkin Science by Shayer, Adey, and Yates and Instrumental Enrichment by Reuven Feuerstein. There is tantalyzing evidence that physics instruction may produce enhancement, but the evidence is thin. It may be necessary to specifically target skills and ways of thinking that are not addressed by current curricula.

column5: Revising the Algebra-based Physics Sequence
column15: Robert A Cohen, East Stroudsburg Univ.
column18: For the past decade or so, I have been experimenting with various tweaks to the traditional algebra-based physics sequence with the focus being on introducing new concepts and topics only in response to a perceived need, as opposed to in preparation for some future need. At the same time, traditional boundaries between the first and second semester are maintained in order to preserve transferability between colleges. This poster describes the result of this process. Basically, the theme of the first semester is on Newton?s laws and the power of using a small set of universal laws to predict the motion of a large set of situations. The theme of the second semester is on using theoretical models such as the atomic model. The poster describes how these themes evolve over each course while touching on the traditional concepts. Data supporting how the revised sequence improves conceptual understanding will also be presented.

column5: Visualizing the Black Hole Spacetime
column15: Donald Marolf, Univ. of California
column18: The black hole horizon is a simpler concept than most students expect. It can be fully understood by students who have learned only special relativity, but have no formal training in general relativity. The key point is that gravity is spacetime curvature. Thus, the physics is that of special relativity on a curved surface. In this talk, I will show how black hole horizons can be taught using diagrams which show an important part of the black hole spacetime as a curved surface in a flat spacetime, and students' knowledge of special reltivity in that flat spacetime.

column5: Teacher Learning of Technology-Enhanced Formative Assessment
column15: Ian D Beatty, Univ. of Massachusetts Amherst
column17: William J Leonard, William J Gerace, Allan P Feldman
column18: TEFA-TL* is a five-year, NSF-funded** research project studying how secondary science teachers learn to use an electronic "classroom response system" to implement formative assessment. Formative Assessment (FA) has been demonstrated to be effective in improving student achievement, but is difficult for many teachers to implement. A classroom response system (CRS) helps make FA more efficient and also helps make the classroom more active. The TEFA-TL project began in June 2005, and we have started collecting baseline data from the first cadre of teachers. We will be following these teachers for 3 years. Teachers in the first cadre will begin a professional development course in August 2006, which will continue until May 2007. The baseline year for the second cadre of teachers is AY06-07, and their PD course will start in August 2007.

column5: Student Models of Force and Motion in Activity-Based Physics*
column15: C. Trecia Markes, Univ. of Nebraska-Kearney
column18: With a three-year FIPSE grant, it has been possible at the University of Nebraska at Kearney (UNK) to develop and implement activity-based introductory physics at the algebra level. It has generally been recognized that students enter physics classes with misconceptions about motion and force. Many of these misconceptions persist after instruction. Pretest and posttest responses on the "Force and Motion Conceptual Evaluation" (FMCE) were analyzed to determine the models that students use. Responses were divided into expert model (correct answer), student model (common incorrect answer), and null model (all other answers) categories. Changes in the use of these models were used to identify persistent and non-persistent misconceptions. The effects of traditional and activity-based physics were compared.
column19: *This work was supported by the US DOE's FIPSE Grant No. P116B51449.

column5: Servo-Motor-Driven Laser-Beam Pointer: A Unique Transducer Project for the Basic Electronics Laboratory
column15: Harry E. Bates, Towson Univ.
column18: One element of the Basic Electronics Laboratory at Towson is an experiment to study the application of the 555-timer chip and pulse measuring techniques. This laboratory experiment has been modified to include the control of a servo-motor-controlled laser-beam pointer in a way that generated a lot of interest in a group of students in the Spring Semester 2006. Details of this part of the experiment will be discussed and schematics of the student circuits used will be presented.

column5: An Advanced Exploration in Optics: The Solid Immersion Microscope*
column15: Ernest R. Behringer, Photonics Center/Boston Univ.
column17: Alexander G. Krause, A. N. Vamivakas, Anna K. Swan, Bennett B. Goldberg
column18: The solid immersion microscope (SIM) has been used since 1990 to characterize a wide range of physical systems at high spatial resolution, and consequently we suggest its inclusion in upper level optics courses. In support of this, we describe the SIM within the realm of paraxial ray optics, and a desktop demonstration of the SIM. Although the ray description yields both image location and magnification, it cannot be used to calculate the focal fields produced by the SIM or other high numerical aperture microscopes. We therefore use the angular spectrum representation to numerically calculate the focal fields and their polarization components. A MATLAB graphical user interface enables the user to easily vary parameters and study the resultant focal fields in both a SIM and a fluid immersion microscope when the source is a linearly polarized Gaussian beam. We will demonstrate the software and discuss the resolution achieved by each microscope.
column19: *Supported in part by NSF grant# EEC-0552853 and ECS-0210752
